fields.headline: Caniggia and Milne shoot down Rangers
fields.trailText: Rangers fell 16 points behind Celtic in the one-sided Scottish Premier title race last night after goals from Steve Milne and Claudio Canniggia gave Dundee a rare victory at Ibrox.
fields.body:
Rangers fell 16 points behind Celtic, 2-1 winners at St Johnstone, in the one-sided Scottish Premier title race last night when the substitute Steve Milne's injury-time goal augmented Claudi Caniggia's first-half strike to give Dundee a rare victory at Ibrox.

Dick Advocaat handed two players their full debuts for Rangers but the French winger Fabrice Fernandes was not one of them. International clearance from France was not prompt enough to allow him to begin his loan spell from Rennes via Fulham.

But Marcus Gayle, the £900,000 signing from Wimbledon, began as Tore Andre Flo's latest strike partner and Steven Carson, the young left-winger, added a start to three previous stints as a substitute.

It was the second time the two sides had met in little more than a fortnight, with Juan Sara's two penalty misses contributing to a 1-0 Rangers win on the last occasion.

As Rangers dominated the opening exchanges, Gayle played a one-two with Sergio Porrini inside the box only for the Italian's shot to be blocked by Barry Smith. Carson then forced the goalkeeper Marco Roccati into a block before Chris Coyne headed away the loose ball, and Steven Tweed had to do likewise from Allan Johnston's cross.

Yet it was Dundee who opened the scoring in the 14th minute through Caniggia, appearing at Ibrox for the first time. Rangers repelled a Giorgi Nemsadze free-kick but the Georgian retrieved the ball and when Javier Artero and Barry Smith combined on the right, Smith poked the ball forward to Caniggia in the box. The Argentine slipped his marker and made light of a difficult angle to score at the near post.

Roccati denied Rangers an instant equaliser after Gayle had put Carson cantering clear, with the Italian blocking the eventual shot with his body.

As at Dundee United on Sunday, Rangers toiled away but with little quality emerging from midfield for the front two to work with. In fact Dundee spurned the most promising chance when Javier Artero sent Caniggia away but his cross from the right was sent wastefully wide by Gavin Rae.

Shortly afterwards Scott Wilson was booked for felling Rae but then Rangers were left reeling when Craig Moore was sent off. The Australian was booked for clattering into the back of Sara, and seconds later he was late on the same player and was soon trudging towards the tunnel.

Caniggia was booked soon afterwards for diving as Johnston challenged, and Barry Ferguson soon followed for a foul on Beto Garrido before Flo blazed a chance over to the fury of the Ibrox fans. Artero then joined the trend with a booking for a foul on Bert Konterman.

webTitle: Axe falls at Milan amid Italian gloom

fields.headline: Axe falls at Milan amid Italian gloom
fields.trailText: Silvio Berlusconi, Milan's owner and Italy's probable next prime minister, yesterday showed his countrymen his hands-on style as he abruptly sacked the coach Alberto Zaccheroni only hours after Milan were eliminated from the Champions League.
fields.body:
Silvio Berlusconi, Milan's owner and Italy's probable next prime minister, yesterday showed his countrymen his hands-on style as he abruptly sacked the coach Alberto Zaccheroni only hours after Milan were eliminated from the Champions League.

Early yesterday morning, Zaccheroni was clearing out his desk. The man who in his first season with Milan won the 1998-9 league title will be replaced by Italy's 1998 World Cup coach Cesare Maldini, assisted by another former captain of the club, Mauro Tassotti, until summer.

Berlusconi on Tuesday night returned to the San Siro, doubtless believing it would do his electoral campaign no harm if his visit coincided with an upturn in Milan's form.

Alas, Deportivo La Coruna spoiled the night for him by holding Milan to a 1-1 draw. With the exit of the five-times European champions, Italy suffered a rare whitewash, with not one club in the last eight of the Champions League or Uefa Cup.

Afterwards, Berlusconi said he had long had reservations about Zaccheroni's tactical approach and promised he would soon "take charge" of the club. "I have suffered in silence. But the results show I was right."

But Milan's campaign has been undermined by speculation that Zaccheroni would leave Milan this summer. As well as Terim, the former Juventus coach Marcello Lippi, sacked by Inter-nazionale earlier this season, has been touted as Zaccheroni's successor.

For the moment Maldini, the 69-year-old father of Milan's current captain Paolo, and Tassotti are in control, charged with the task of achieving a top-four place and another Champions League campaign.

As Italian football licks its wounds after dominating Europe in the last decade Berlusconi feels doubly disappointed. On May 23, a week after he expects to win the general election, the Champions League final, which might have featured his own club, will be played at the San Siro. That is one hell of an inauguration party gone missing.

fields.headline: Preston in play-off place
fields.trailText: Preston moved into the final First Division play-off place with a 2-0 win over Wolves which catapulted them above Watford and Nottingham Forest, who both lost on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Preston moved into the final First Division play-off place with a 2-0 win over Wolves which catapulted them above Watford and Nottingham Forest, who both lost on Tuesday.

Paul McKenna hypnotised the visiting defence to score the first just before half-time. He picked up the ball 30 yards from goal and jinked his way into the box before unleashing a left-foot strike into the top corner. It turned out to be the last goal ever scored in front of Deepdale's Town End, which is due for demolition.

Michael Jackson had to clear off the line to preserve the home side's lead into half-time, but Richard Cresswell came off the bench to score his first goal for the club on his debut after signing on loan from Leicester at the end of last week.

Tranmere could not move off the foot of the division, although they are kept there by Huddersfield only on goal difference. Wayne Allison, the Prenton Park club's captain, put them ahead in the 28th minute against Portsmouth but Kevin Harper equalised half an hour later.

In the Third Division, Brighton returned to second place at the expense of Cardiff with a 4-1 win at home to Barnet, which completed a double over the north London club.

Two goals in two first-half minutes from Andy Crosby and Bobby Zamora put the Seagulls on the road to victory. After Paul Rogers had scored a third in the 54th minute the prolific Zamora added his 24th goal of the season in the 62nd minute.

John Doolan's late penalty was little consolation for the visiting fans. The result, Barnet's 11th consecutive away defeat in the league, will increase the pressure on their manager Tony Cottee, who was appointed in a wave of optimism only in November. The Bees are not yet sure of avoiding relegation; they are only five points ahead of bottom-placed Halifax, who have two games in hand.

fields.headline: Rovers rise above pitch and woeful City
fields.trailText: Blackburn Rovers gave irresistible evidence last night that they are the likeliest lads to accompany Fulham into the Premiership with an emphatic victory over their chief rivals for the second automatic promotion place.
fields.body:
Blackburn Rovers gave irresistible evidence last night that they are the likeliest lads to accompany Fulham into the Premiership with an emphatic victory over their chief rivals for the second automatic promotion place.

The win makes Rovers the first team to register a double over City this season and also ends a run of five successive wins for Trevor Francis's men. More importantly for Rovers the victory puts them level on points with both City and Bolton Wanderers and, with games in hand on both, their destiny is in their own hands.

All of which suggests City, run ragged in midfield and posing little threat to the Rovers goal, will have to take their chances in the play-offs for a third successive season.

A pitch pock-marked with divots, produced leaden-footed fare and although City had had more chance to grow accustomed to its vagaries, it was the visiting team who adapted better.

The former Manchester United winger Keith Gillespie found himself one on one with the City keeper Ian Bennett but failed to capitalise, shooting high and even wider.

Bennett had to get involved a minute later following another hefty clearance out of the Rovers defence aimed for Marcus Bent. Remarkably Bennett, despite conceding several inches in height to the Blackburn striker, won the duel of heads. But Bent was able to recover in time to retrieve the loose ball but responded with a shot that turned into a sideways pass to Matt Jansen.

City, already suffering from an extensive injury list, experienced another blow when their centre-back Michael Johnson limped off midway through the half.

Rover's keeper Brad Freidel was finally brought into the game in the 36th minute when he had to dive full length to his left to palm away a shot from distance from Curtis Woodhouse.

The goal Rovers had long threatened finally arrived four minutes before the interval and, inevitably Bent was in volved. The lanky striker had caused the City defence all sorts of problems with his height and speed but neither were needed when he was left unmarked to hook home Gillespie's right-wing cross from close range.

Then, just eight minutes into the second the midfielder Damien Duff set off on a mazy run that took him clear of the City back four before he slid a left-foot shot passed the advancing but woefully exposed Bennett. In an ill-tempered ending to the game, Darren Purse was sent off in last minute for violent conduct.

fields.headline: Liverpool 2 - 0 Porto (agg: 2-0)
fields.standfirst: Preview
fields.trailText:
Liverpool: Westerveld, Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher, Hamann, Gerrard, Murphy, Smicer, Owen, Fowler. Subs: Ziege, Heskey, Arphexad, McAllister, Diomede, Wright, Litmanen.
FC Porto: Espinha, Alves, Paredes, Secretario, Andrade, Alenitchev, Santos, Candido Costa, Clayton, Pena, Silva. Subs: Ovchinnikov, Aloisio, Deco, Drulovic, Chainho, Nuno, Maric.
Referee: Kim Nielsen
fields.body:
Liverpool: Westerveld, Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher, Hamann, Gerrard, Murphy, Smicer, Owen, Fowler. Subs: Ziege, Heskey, Arphexad, McAllister, Diomede, Wright, Litmanen.
FC Porto: Espinha, Alves, Paredes, Secretario, Andrade, Alenitchev, Santos, Candido Costa, Clayton, Pena, Silva. Subs: Ovchinnikov, Aloisio, Deco, Drulovic, Chainho, Nuno, Maric.
Referee: Kim Nielsen

1 Liverpool kick off. A big test for the Reds, who must really look to win this tie tonight. With this in mind, it seems that Vladimir Smicer is playing further forward, and more centrally, than usual.
2 Pena, the touted Brazilian striker, is already looking more lively in this second leg than he did in the first. On this occasion he breaks free from two Liverpool defenders in the box, but is pulled back by an offside flag.
4 Brave running and jostling by Michael Owen wins Liverpool the first corner of the match. But a poor delivery from Smicer only results in a throw-in.
5 Sami Hyypia clatters into Pena just outside of the centre circle. An unnecessary challenge and one that perhaps should have earned Hyypia a yellow card.
9 Liverpool are temporarily down to 10 men whil Steven Gerrard goes off to change his boots.
10 Liverpool enjoy prolonged possession around the Porto box, without acheiving much penetration. A deflected cross from Smicer finally results in a corner for the Reds, but it comes to nothing.
11 Owen gets the ball out wide and jinks his way past two defenders on the left-hand side. But his final effort, neither shot nor cross, is rather disappointing.
13 Again Owen is on the ball, this time just inside the Porto half, but is scythed down by Claudio Santos. Yellow card
14 Porto's first attack on the counter, is well-crafted by Dmitri Alenitchev. With Clayton and Pena in front of him, the Russian picks out the latter, who can only scuff the ball.
15 The first real save of the game is forced by Steven Gerrard with one of his increasingly characteristic 30-yard drives. Espinha does well to tip over the shot, which was dipping just under the bar.
18 Liverpool continue to maintain good possession without unduly troubling the Porto defence. With Smicer pushed forward, there is little width to the Liverpool attacks, something their fullbacks may have to remedy.
20 Either that, or get Owen to do it. The England man skins Secretario for the second time this evening, and this time Santos does well to cut out the cross.
21 Again Pena receives the ball in the Liverpool area, and again his contribution leaves something to be desired. Porto do eventually get a corner out of it however, which Alenitchev duly hits straight against Robbie Fowler.
24 Babbel wins Liverpool another corner. Taken this time by Danny Murphy the ball flies much deeper and ends with a scrabble in the Porto box, which Santos duly clears.
25 Owen beats Secretario once more and this time is hacked down by the veteran full-back. Secretario then chooses to roll around on the ground. But not only does he not avoid the inevitable yellow card referee Neilsen also initially refuses to stop play for him to receive treatment. The result is a stand-off lasting nigh-on five minutes.
29 Finally the free-kick is taken and headed out for a corner by Andrade. Secretario hobbles his way back onto the pitch seconds later.
30 Another scramble in the Porto box. This time, Murphy hooks the ball over the head of a defender and onto Owen, whose well-intended hook shot ends up flying straight into the arms of Espinha.
31 GOAL! Liverpool 1- 0 Porto Markus Babbel, who has been getting further forward in the past 10 minutes, wins the ball from Fernando Nelson. He loops it back to Gerrard, who hits a phenomenal first time cross to Murphy on the left hand side of the box. Murphy controls the ball with both knee and hand but, without the referee blowing. then volleys the ball just inside the far post.
34 Now Porto will be forced to come out and play. And play they do, with Clayton almost equalising straight away. But his low shot from 18 yards is scrambled away by Sander Westerveld.
36 GOAL! Liverpool 2 - 0 Porto Michael Owen gets his reward for an impressive first half, and puts Liverpool in a comfortable position. Another corner is fed back to Steven Gerrard, who hits another great cross which Owen meets with a downward header that flummoxes the less-than impressive Espinha and loops under the post.
41 A half-chance for the visitors is wasted by Santos, whose volley spoons over the bar after Pena chested the ball into his path.
45 With the Porto defence looking increasingly uncertain both Smicer and Gerrard look to take on the entire back line. But while Smicer's run ends in a pull-back which just only evades Owen, Gerrard's ends in a wild two-footed challenge and a yellow card.
47 Nearly another goal for Liverpool and Owen, as the Porto defence continues to unravel. This time Murphy finds Owen in undue amounts of space on the left-hand side of the box. He works his way past two men and then digs out a right-footed shot that Espinha claws away - just.
48 Half-time.

45 Porto substitution: Nuno Capucho for Candido Costa; Deco for Secretario.
46 A half-chance within seconds for Liverpool as Smicer's knock-down almost falls into the path of Fowler. Hastily cleared by Andrade.
47 A wonderful cameo from Hyypia who, standing just outside the six yard box and with a man on his back, juggles the ball and flicks a right-footed cross over his head and across the face of the goal, just beyond his teammates.
47 Another chance for Liverpool and Danny Murphy, who feints his way past three defenders in the box but, instead of cutting the ball back to Owen, opts to shoot and cannons the ball off Espinha.
49 More openings for Liverpool, with Smicer, Gerrard and Murphy impudently playing one-touch football inside the Porto area. Again the shooting chance falls to Murphy but his strike deflects of the head of Paredes.
54 With practically continuous Liverpool possession there looks like being only one winner in this tie tonight (extremities crossed). Another opening is wasted by Smicer, who finding the customary 10 square yards of space in the box, cuts the ball across the goal to noone in particular.
57 Lo and behold, Porto go and craft only their third opening of the game. Fernando Nelson, the former Aston Villa player, is the creator, bursting in-between Hyypia and Stephane Henchoz on the edge of the Liverpool box. But his low shot is smothered by Westerveld.
58 Back at the other end and Robbie Fowler gets the ball 20 yards out and, after what seems like a good five minutes, opts to slip in Owen who fires just over the bar.
61 Another right-wing cross from Steven Gerrard, this time from a free-kick, picks out Robbie Fowler who should have done better than hit a stooping header five yards over the bar.
63 A great sweeping move from Liverpool ends with Michael Owen swivelling neatly on the edge of the box and chipping a shot that dips under the bar, but not past Espinha. Surely a third goal must be in the offing.
67 Perhaps not. A well-struck shot from Clayton forces a decent stop from Westerveld. A reminder to the home side that they cannot afford to be complacent.
72 Porto continue to increase their share of possession, without ever really threatening.
74 Liverpool substitution: Heskey for Fowler and Litmanen for Smicer.
75 Heskey immediately makes an impact, chesting a pass from Murphy down while holding off a defender, and then releasing Babbel down the right. Babbel is fouled by Nelson, and from the subsequent Gerrad free-kick only fails by inches to connect with a header.
78 Jari Litmanen, after giving away possession outside his own area, wins it back and clears the ball 60 yards into the path of Heskey. Heskey stops, turns his man and shoots low from 15 yards, straight into the arms of Espinha.
79 Porto substitution: Silvio Maric for Paulinho Santos.
82 With Litmanen now dictating play in the middle of the park, Liverpool are in the ascendant again.
85 Great control and lay-off from Murphy reaches Owen who, for all his skills this evening, hits yet another shot high and wide.
88 Liverpool substitution: Christian Ziege for Danny Murphy.

92 Full-time. A comfortable and highly professional win for Gerard Houllier's Liverpool. Will it be Barcelona next?

Hastily cleared by Andrade. 47 A wonderful cameo from Hyypia who, standing just outside the six yard box and with a man on his back, juggles the ball and flicks a right-footed cross over his head and across the face of the goal, just beyond his teammates. 47 Another chance for Liverpool and Danny Murphy, who feints his way past three defenders in the box but, instead of cutting the ball back to Owen, opts to shoot and cannons the ball off Espinha. 49 More openings for Liverpool, with Smicer, Gerrard and Murphy impudently playing one-touch football inside the Porto area. Again the shooting chance falls to Murphy but his strike deflects of the head of Paredes. 54 With practically continuous Liverpool possession there looks like being only one winner in this tie tonight (extremities crossed). Another opening is wasted by Smicer, who finding the customary 10 square yards of space in the box, cuts the ball across the goal to noone in particular. 57 Lo and behold, Porto go and craft only their third opening of the game. Fernando Nelson, the former Aston Villa player, is the creator, bursting in-between Hyypia and Stephane Henchoz on the edge of the Liverpool box. But his low shot is smothered by Westerveld. 58 Back at the other end and Robbie Fowler gets the ball 20 yards out and, after what seems like a good five minutes, opts to slip in Owen who fires just over the bar. 61 Another right-wing cross from Steven Gerrard, this time from a free-kick, picks out Robbie Fowler who should have done better than hit a stooping header five yards over the bar. 63 A great sweeping move from Liverpool ends with Michael Owen swivelling neatly on the edge of the box and chipping a shot that dips under the bar, but not past Espinha. Surely a third goal must be in the offing. 67 Perhaps not. A well-struck shot from Clayton forces a decent stop from Westerveld. A reminder to the home side that they cannot afford to be complacent. 72 Porto continue to increase their share of possession, without ever really threatening. 74 Liverpool substitution: Heskey for Fowler and Litmanen for Smicer. 75 Heskey immediately makes an impact, chesting a pass from Murphy down while holding off a defender, and then releasing Babbel down the right. Babbel is fouled by Nelson, and from the subsequent Gerrad free-kick only fails by inches to connect with a header. 78 Jari Litmanen, after giving away possession outside his own area, wins it back and clears the ball 60 yards into the path of Heskey. Heskey stops, turns his man and shoots low from 15 yards, straight into the arms of Espinha. 79 Porto substitution: Silvio Maric for Paulinho Santos. 82 With Litmanen now dictating play in the middle of the park, Liverpool are in the ascendant again. 85 Great control and lay-off from Murphy reaches Owen who, for all his skills this evening, hits yet another shot high and wide. 88 Liverpool substitution: Christian Ziege for Danny Murphy. 92 Full-time. A comfortable and highly professional win for Gerard Houllier's Liverpool. Will it be Barcelona next?

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Cathy
fields.trailText: Cape Town is one of the most beautiful cities I have been to (and amazingly cheap due to the exchange rate). Also, if it's your thing, you can visit Stellenbosch and stock up on some excellent, very cheap wines for the trip home!
fields.body:
Hi Sam

Just caught up with all your travel experiences. I did a similar route to you last year and reading about you is making me decidedly itchy-footed again.

Just read that you were unsure of which route to take in Africa. I did an overland tour from Cape Town to Victoria Falls and would certainly recommend it. I never went further north than Zimbabwe so can't comment on that bit, but Botswana in particular was one of the most amazing experiences I have had. As part of the tour we did a three-day bush camp in the Okavango Delta, traveling by makoro (canoe) with local guides to a remote area where we went on sunrise and sunset game walks through the bush with a tracker. It certainly beat any of the game-park experiences I had. Also, Cape Town is one of the most beautiful cities I have been to (and amazingly cheap due to the exchange rate). Admittedly it is very touristy, but much more cosmopolitan than east coast Australia. Also, if it's your thing, you can visit Stellenbosch and stock up on some excellent, very cheap wines for the trip home!

Whatever you decide, have an amazing time (I have no doubt you will!)

fields.headline: Top Express sports writers under threat
fields.trailText: Fears are rising that Richard Desmond intends to wipe out the biggest names in the sports department, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Fears are rising at the Daily Express that new owner Richard Desmond intends to wipe out the biggest and most experienced names in the sports department.

Cricket correspondent Colin Bateman, who has been with the paper 20 years, is said to be under the spotlight simply because of the expensive nature of his job.

Barry Flatman, the long-standing tennis correspondent who doubles up as Tim Henman's ghost writer, and Martin Hardy, an Express man for 22 years, are also being targeted, according to insiders.

"What Desmond fails to understand is you can only cover sport by being there," said a source.

"Colin has been away from his family for two months, following the cricket team around the far east. And he was away before Christmas. These guys and Bob McKenzie are hugely experienced.

"What is particularly appalling is Desmond just wants kids to come in and take everyone's jobs and then pay them pittance," the source added.

Mr Hardy is considered one of the leading writers in his field.

He ghost-wrote, Into the Bear Pit, the controversial book by European Ryder Cup captain Mark James.

Insiders at the Express say today's announcement of 145 redundancies has yet to sink in.

"It is gallows-humour here but it will soon turn to depression once those redundancy letters appear," said one journalist.

Another said: "It's like an end of term feeling. It appears Desmond is willing to turn the paper into a magazine.

"He will lose circulation and the paper will just wither on the vine. This is the end of the Daily Express as a newspaper," the journalist lamented.

fields.headline: Cabinet fury at gay exposure
fields.trailText: 08/11/1998: Brown's outing sparks backlash
fields.body:
DOWNING Street went on the offensive last night against intrusive prying into the personal lives of politicians as the Cabinet rallied to Agriculture Minister Nick Brown , who was forced to reveal his homosexuality.

The Prime Minister fears that Mr Brown's disclosure that he is gay could set off a further media feeding frenzy of inquiries into the private lives of ministers and seriously distract attention from the Government's legislative programme.

Tony Blair's official spokesman, battling to turn the tide on a fortnight of personal revelations about cabinet members, insisted the climate was changing and the public was 'becoming sick of the media in the way they are prying into people's public lives'.

The Government had been braced for hostile stories about ministers after enjoying almost 18 months free from the kind of scandals that routinely disrupted John Major's premiership.

Last month Mr Blair fired a prescient warning shot in his Blackpool conference speech, when he said of his commitment to strengthening the family: 'I challenge the media: don't use it as an excuse to dredge through the private lives of every public figure.'

Mr Brown, aged 48, MP for Newcastle upon Tyne East, who admitted to having had a two-year affair with a young man, echoed the sentiments yesterday, saying: 'I had rather hoped I could have a private life like other people do, that was private.

'What's happened is enormously embarrassing for me, certainly, and I'm sad that my family, my friends, my constituents, have all had to read today's press. I've got a very important job to do and I'm going to get on with it.'

But in a pooled interview, conducted by the BBC, he refused to be drawn on whether resignation had been mentioned during his weekend discussions with the Prime Minister.

Friends said part of the reason for his embarrassment and anger was that he had not told his mother, who is seriously ill, about his sexuality.

The disclosure follows the resignation of the Welsh Secretary, Ron Davies, after his nocturnal visit to Clapham Common, and the 'outing' of the Trade and Industry Secretary, Peter Mandelson, on BBC TV's Newsnight.

Downing Street, heavily criticised for its handling of the Davies affair, reacted quickly, when it became apparent the News of the World was preparing to run its story about Mr Brown.

It issued statements from Mr Blair and Mr Brown at 9.40pm on Saturday after Mr Brown's former partner allegedly tried to sell a story about their relationship to the News of the World . Mr Brown, a former Chief Whip, denied he had paid for sex, only helping him out with taxi fares of around pounds 20 and a handout of pounds 80.

The News Of The World editor, Phil Hall, said the paper had approached Downing Street 'after a young man gave us an unsubstantiated account of a relationship' with Nick Brown . 'Mr Brown then volunteered a statement which we have published in full. We have not published the young man's account in any form.'

But Downing Street described the News of the World as disingenuous and said it had been tracking Mr Brown for two years. 'They put specific and unpleasant allegations to Nick and he felt the best thing to do was to confirm some and deny others,' a spokesman said.

He added that attempts had been made at entrapment. The young man had been phoning Mr Brown 'to try to get stuff on tape. Nick had sensed something was up.'

Downing Street and Mr Brown hope they can bring the issue to a close quickly. Mr Brown may be helped by his popularity among fellow MPs at Westminster. The Conservatives decided not to make capital out of his embarrassment.

Mr Brown, crucially, also has the backing of his local constituency party.

The Defence Secretary, George Robertson, echoing an increasing view among ministers, said: 'What people do in their private lives, as long as it doesn't affect others, is a matter for them, and I think that's the view of the vast majority of the British people.'

Mr Brown cancelled his attendance along with other cabinet colleagues at the Remembrance Day service at the Cenotaph yesterday morning, citing his fear that the solemn occasion could have turned into a media scrum.

fields.headline: Laying the foundations for trouble
fields.standfirst: Conflicts of interest are all in a day's work for the planning minister
fields.trailText: Conflicts of interest are all in a day's work for the planning minister.
fields.body:
Nick Raynsford's alibi is unchallengeable. The minister was not trying to cover up his decision to allow a unique listed building in Oxford to be moved, to make way for a business school funded by the arms broker Wafic Said. He had failed to inform the local MP simply because he was away in Egypt, leading a trade mission.

It's still not clear why the government refused to examine an application to dismantle one of the country's most important industrial monuments, or why the prime minister's office felt compelled to intervene in such a trivial matter as the timing of a planning decision. But the most interesting question has yet to be asked: what was the British planning minister doing on a trade delegation to Egypt? The answer suggests that Mr Raynsford's alibi is rather more heinous than the alleged crime.

Mr Raynsford was leading a delegation of 27 corporations. Among them were some of the most controversial multinationals stationed in this country: Balfour Beatty, Enron, Laing, Mott MacDonald, Thames Water and WS Atkins. The projects they visited included Egypt's most contested development scheme: the $90bn Toshka programme to divert the Nile. Environmentalists warn that it will devastate the river's ecology, financial consultants warn that it will have a similar impact on the country's economy. It's the sort of scheme, in other words, which, were it to have been proposed in Britain, should have been subject to the fiercest scrutiny by planning officials at the Department of the Environment, overseen by Mr Raynsford.

Interestingly, the major beneficiary of the trade mission appears to have been not a British company, but a Norwegian one. Soon after the tour, Kvaerner revealed that it had landed a £266m contract to build a pumping system at Toshka. Kvaerner's otherwise inexplicable presence on a British trade tour might have had something to do with the fact that it had seconded more of its employees into the DoE than any other company.

So why was Mr Raynsford, rather than a minister from the Department of Trade and Industry, helping these companies to sell their wares in Egypt? Well, Nick Raynsford has a curious double role. He is minister for planning, which means he is the regulator of development in Britain. But he is also minister for construction, which means he is the promoter of development in Britain. He routinely resolves this conflict of interests in favour of the industry he's supposed be regulating.

Nick Raynsford has gone to some lengths to show construction companies whose side he is on. "I see my job," he told Building magazine, as "creating a climate in which the industry can do well." To this end, his division has sought repeatedly to undermine government policy. It has sponsored, for example, a public relations offensive for the quarrying industry called Minerals 98. One of its purposes was to help companies lobby against the tax on roadstone which another division of the environment department had proposed.

At Labour's 1998 local government conference, Mr Raynsford argued against the environment department's plans for a tax on out-of-town parking places and in support of the superstores' objections to them. He has promised the British Council of Shopping Centres that he will seek to speed up major new retail schemes. Last week, he undermined the government's commitments on climate change by watering down the rules on energy efficiency in new homes, arguing that the standards were "an undue burden on builders".

But perhaps most alarming is his alleged role in the debate about the Ilisu dam in Turkey: the devastating ethnic cleansing project which will drive 78,000 Kurds out of their cultural heartland. It was Mr Raynsford, according to Whitehall sources, who persuaded Tony Blair to back the project. Why should he have done so? Well, in September 1999 he led a trade mission to Turkey. The consortium he accompanied was seeking to land £4bn-worth of contracts for rebuilding after the earthquake. The consortium was fronted by Balfour Beatty, which also happens to be the firm hoping to build the Ilisu dam. Three months later, the British government announced that it was "minded to grant" export credit for the Ilisu scheme. Is it possible that Raynsford was told by the Turkish government that British rebuilding contracts were conditional on support for the dam?

The real scandal surrounding the Oxford business school is that everything Mr Raynsford says about it is probably true. There were no peculiar measures taken to approve the development; there was nothing unusual about the government's decision not to review the case. Decisions to turn a blind eye to the destruction of our heritage and environment are taken on behalf of the construction industry every week, by the man who is supposed to be policing it.

fields.headline: Desmond to slash back Express sports staff
fields.trailText:
11.15am: The Express sports department is expected to suffer casualties amid fears Richard Desmond has decided it is too expensive to cover international events. By Lisa O'Carroll.
Mar 14: Northern & Hell for high earners

Mar 14: Axe falls at Express

Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
The Express sports department is expected to suffer severe casualties today amid fears that Richard Desmond has decided it is too expensive to cover international events.

Sources say motoring correspondent Bob McKenzie is facing the axe as part of the brutal cuts that could see a third of the Express group's editorial staff made redundant.

Mr McKenzie, who is in Malaysia to cover this weekend's Grand Prix, is said to be astounded with the attitude of Mr Desmond.

He has been with the paper for 10 years and is considered one of the paper's big sports names.

It is believed coverage of other sports including international golf, tennis, cricket, athletics and rugby could also be affected.

"They are not being cut because of any lack of interest but because Desmond's men have decided that they cannot afford to run those jobs and several others, mainly those which involved travel outside London, and have decided to buy in the reports from agency or internet," said one source.

The NUJ is meeting with management at 11am today to discuss the cuts planned by Mr Desmond.

It is expected that at least 130 jobs out of 440 will be cut from the Daily and Sunday Express.

fields.headline: Liverpool accentuate the positive
fields.standfirst: Live minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: As diversions go, the Uefa Cup has proved to be attractive, lucrative and educational for Liverpool this season.
fields.body:
As diversions go, the Uefa Cup has proved to be attractive, lucrative and educational for Liverpool this season.

If the tournament also proves to favour the brave, the Merseysiders may well sweep into the last four at Anfield this evening - a highly meritorious achievement, but one unlikely to send shudders of apprehension through those clubs currently pre-eminent in the European pecking order.

Liverpool's manager Gerard Houllier would happily swap victory over Portugal's Porto tonight for a Champions League berth but he is unlikely to pass up an opportunity to gorge himself again at the well stocked table of football's moveable feast.

Seven days ago, after his side had chiselled out a goalless draw on a filthy Porto night in the first leg of the quarter-final, the Frenchman wore the smile of a largely contented man; if he was disappointed that his players had not managed an away goal, he hid it well.

Unable to deny that Porto are unlikely to display such a slack demeanour a second time, Houllier believes it may be tight tonight, very tight.

"It will be a different sort of game, I think," he said. "Although the onus will be upon us, as the home team, to be positive, Porto too will have to consider how best to win the tie.

"We coped well in the first game but with neither team able to score a goal it all comes down to the second leg."

Porto have not won in seven away games but need only a score-draw tonight and they remain confident of shelving Liverpool's hopes of achieving success in three different cup competitions.

"Liverpool have proved themselves to be most adept in knockout football so far this season," said their manager Santos Fernando. "But, while we did not manage a goal in the first meeting, we did not concede and in the final count that may well prove to be decisive."

Houllier is expected to practise some rotation, in Liverpool's 20th cup tie of the season, with possibly five of the team that overcame Tranmere in Sunday's FA Cup quarter- final either ruled out or left out.

Nick Barmby will definitely not be risked after damaging an ankle at Prenton Park and Gary McAllister may stand down to accommodate the return from suspension of Dietmar Hamann.

The centre-back Stephane Henchoz is expected to be fit to resume alongside Sami Hyypia, allowing Markus Babbel to return to right-back.

Liverpool (possible, 4-4-2 ): Westerveld; Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher; Murphy, Hamann, Gerrard, Smicer; Litmanen, Heskey.

Porto (possible, 4-3-1-2 ): Ovchinnikov; Secretario, J Costa, Andrade, Nelson; Paredes, Deco, Chainho; Capucho; Pena, Drulovic.

Nick Barmby will definitely not be risked after damaging an ankle at Prenton Park and Gary McAllister may stand down to accommodate the return from suspension of Dietmar Hamann. The centre-back Stephane Henchoz is expected to be fit to resume alongside Sami Hyypia, allowing Markus Babbel to return to right-back. Liverpool (possible, 4-4-2 ): Westerveld; Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher; Murphy, Hamann, Gerrard, Smicer; Litmanen, Heskey. Porto (possible, 4-3-1-2 ): Ovchinnikov; Secretario, J Costa, Andrade, Nelson; Paredes, Deco, Chainho; Capucho; Pena, Drulovic.

webTitle: Epidemic blamed for death of farmer

fields.headline: Epidemic blamed for death of farmer
fields.standfirst:
Big rise takes toll to 230 as ministers face pressures for more radical cull and easing of restrictions in disease-free areas

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth crisis claimed its first human victim as a huge rise of 25 new cases - equal to the highest daily total on Monday - was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis claimed its first human victim as a huge rise of 25 new cases - equal to the highest daily total on Monday - was confirmed yesterday.

The worsening crisis was blamed for the death of a Welsh farmer found hanging at his farm in Llanfechainn, Powys, near the Shropshire border. Brian Oakley was discovered by his wife Gillian.

Although father-of-two Mr Oakley, 54, had suffered from depression for several years, friends said the foot and mouth outbreak, which had made him a prisoner at his 26-acre Bryn Coch holding, had tipped him over the edge.

Clifford Evans, a fellow farmer and founder of the Shropshire Rural Stress Network, said: "Brian had not been well and he needed to get out and see the family and meet farmers at the market. He felt trapped at home.

"His sheep were lambing, were short of grass, and he was worried he could not move them. This was the last straw for him and after struggling for ages, when foot and mouth arrived, with all the restrictions it just got on top of him."

Samaritans in north east Wales have seen calls from farmers increase by 50% over the past few weeks at their centre in Rhyl.

Yesterday saw the virus spread to a new county, Cheshire, as well as fresh outbreaks in Cumbria, Berkshire and Essex.

The total of 230 cases brings the number of animals to be destroyed close to 200,000 but many more may be culled if the government decides to press ahead with even more radical attempts to eradicate the disease. A programme to kill all animals that may have had any contact with markets where the disease existed or were carried in infected vehicles is being considered.

With the losses to tourism and countryside activities suspended there is pressure in Whitehall to reduce restrictions in areas currently free from infection. The northern two thirds of Scotland, most of East Anglia and west Wales, all key holiday areas, could be designated for this purpose.

Jim Scudamore, the chief vet, is known to be reluctant to do this unless he can be sure that there are no potentially infected animals in these areas. The government is considering a scheme of sending suspect animals to designated abattoirs for slaughter, and then putting their carcasses in cold store, so they can be destroyed in rendering plants once the outbreak is over and the pressure to dispose of infected animals has eased.

Mr Scudamore said he was concerned that thousands of animals from the Welshpool and Northampton markets which may have been infected had still not been traced.

Tony Blair in the Commons said that it would be right to intensify the slaughter of animals not suffering from the disease but which had come into contact with those that had. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, will make a statement to MPs today.

The rural task force, chaired by the environment minister, Michael Meacher, met yesterday to try to restore confidence in the tourist industry. The group wants to identify areas of the country that can be safely visited and to look for short-term practical help for rural business.

fields.body:
Good day

The Wombles. The Tories were so impressed by the classic 70s Wombles theme tune that they have turned to its composer for their official election campaign ditty. Mike Batt has crafted an inspirational piece of music for William Hague. It is however unlikely to trouble the scorers at Top of the Pops.

Bad day

Tony Blair. Apparently the prime minister has only one more term in office to look forward to. William Hill has opened a book on how long he will keep the top job. And so far 2006 is the 9/4 favourite date for him to leave office. But if you were feeling rash you could get 16/1 on a further 11 years of Blair at No 10.

Today

Commons: Questions to the education and employment secretary David Blunkett. Debate on foreign affairs committee report on weapons of mass destruction. Short debate on future of the footwear industry in Norwich.

Lords: Private security industry bill (Lords), third reading. Health and social care bill, committee. Short debate on student poverty.

webTitle: Work for all within reach, says Blair

fields.headline: Work for all within reach, says Blair
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair held out the prospect of a return to full employment yesterday after official figures showed unemployment dropped below 1m last month for the first time in more than 25 years.
fields.body:
Tony Blair held out the prospect of a return to full employment yesterday after official figures showed unemployment dropped below 1m last month for the first time in more than 25 years.

The prime minister hailed the fall as an historic milestone which meant that jobs for all was no longer an idle dream. "Full employment is within our grasp for the first time in a generation," Mr Blair said.

He was speaking at a London press conference after government figures showed the number out of work and claiming benefit declined by 10,600 in February to 996,200. The last time the claimant count was below 1m was in December 1975.

The government's preferred measure of unemployment, the International Labour Organisation definition which includes everyone available and searching for work but not necessarily on benefit, also fell. It was down 81,000 over the three months to January, taking the jobless total to 1.535m.

While higher than the claimant count measure, it still shows Britain in a favourable light internationally, with a jobless rate of 5.2% compared with 8.7% in France and 7.8% in Germany. But the US has a rate of just 4.2%.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, said that whichever measure was chosen the news was good. Since the election, the claimant count was down 667,000, a 40% cut, the ILO definition was down 556,000, a fall of 27%, and employment was up by more than 1m. He added, however, that there would be no relaxation in the government's effort to get more people into work.

Wages, meanwhile, showed little sign of upward pressure, raising hopes that the Bank of England will cut interest rates again soon to offset the impact of the global slowdown.

According to the office for national statistics, average earnings rose by 4.4% per annum in the latest three months, the same as in the figure in the previous three. The figures helped to allay fears in the City that a tightening labour market was threatening the government's 2.5% inflation target.

"With average earnings remaining stable and inflation heading down there can be no more excuses to delay a cut in interest rates," said John Monks, general secretary of the Trades Union Congress.

After cutting the cost of borrowing by a quarter point to 5.75% in February, the Bank put it back on hold this month. Some economists blamed Mr Brown's expansionary budget for the decision not to cut.

Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist of Deutsche Bank, said: "Today's report clearly illustrates the improved trade-off between unemployment and earnings in the labour market, tied into such factors as rising female participation, and lower long term unemployment. With inflation pressures muted, the monetary policy committee still has scope to lower rates further, and we continue to expect 0.25% off in the second quarter of the year."

Business greeted the fall as testimony to reform of the labour market and sensible economic management. But Ian Fletcher at the British Chambers of Commerce said the challenge for the government now was to cut the red tape that was preventing further job creation.

After climbing above 1m in 1975, unemployment hit a peak of almost 3m in the early 90s .

Theresa May, the Tory education and employment spokeswoman, said: "If the rate of fall under the last Conservative government had continued under Labour, then the claimant count would have fallen below 1m in July 2000."

webTitle: Poll decision on knife edge, says Brown

fields.headline: Poll decision on knife edge, says Brown
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, Labour's chief general election strategist, has told colleagues that the decision on whether to go ahead with the poll on May 3 is now on a knife edge.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Michael White  and Paul Brown
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, Labour's chief general election strategist, has told colleagues that the decision on whether to go ahead with the poll on May 3 is now on a knife edge.

His remarks to close ministerial allies on Tuesday counter the public reassurances from Downing Street yesterday that the foot and mouth outbreak will not affect Tony Blair's thinking on the poll date or cause a deferral of the county council elections.

Mr Brown is said to be concerned that the electorate would not understand why Labour was pressing ahead with an election a year before it had to, if the crisis worsened. Ministers close to him fear the public mood could swing against the government if it was thought they were arrogantly overriding the sombre mood in the countryside.

The spread of the foot and mouth outbreaks continued yesterday, reaching Cheshire for the first time, and leading the government to consider a larger cull of animals.

With 230 confirmed cases - including 25 new ones yesterday, equal to the highest daily total so far - the number of animals being destroyed reached almost 200,000.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, is to make a Commons statement today on new moves for destroying animals which may have come into contact with the disease.

The worsening crisis was also blamed for the death of a Welsh farmer found hanging at his home near the Shropshire border. Brian Oakley was discovered at his farm in Llanfechainn, Powys, by his wife..

A Guardian survey yesterday of the 28 Labour MPs with more than a thousand farmers and farmworkers in their constituency revealed divisions about the timing of an election.

A majority warned that Tony Blair may have to drop the poll within a fortnight if the number of cases grows. Most claimed that the poll could go ahead, but only if the outbreak did not worsen between now and the end of this month.

Russell Brown, Labour MP for Dumfries,who has 28 cases in his constituency, said: "If we are not on top of this in the next fortnight, I would be pressing for a delay in the election. I believe in free and fair and open elections and that includes MPs being able to get to every part of their constituency this week".

Peter Bradley, chairman of the rural group of Labour MPs, called on the government to conduct "an immediate review of the numbers of people who would be disadvantaged were there to be a general election on May 3".

Diana Organ, whose Forest of Dean constituency has four outbreaks of the disease and is facing a severe fall in tourism, said: "It is a bit like saying, do you have granny's funeral and then hold daughter's wedding the day after."

The prime minister's spokesman tried to kill off mounting speculation by saying that postponement of the county council elections would damage rural tourism and feed a worldwide impression that the British countryside was a no-go area.

But the pressure to delay grew yesterday when the Countryside Alliance and the National Farmers' Union insisted that an election in the current crisis would be an insult to the countryside and democracy.

The Conservatives refused to call openly for delay, but are privately praying for postponement. The Liberal Democrats are internally divided on the issue.

fields.headline: Former watchdog calls for reforms
fields.standfirst:
Ministers and MPs compelled to give evidence in investigations against other cabinet members


Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Parliament's first commissioner for standards, Sir Gordon Downey, today calls for his successor to be given new powers to compel ministers and MPs to give evidence in investigations in the wake of the Keith Vaz affair.
fields.body:
Parliament's first commissioner for standards, Sir Gordon Downey, today calls for his successor to be given new powers to compel ministers and MPs to give evidence in investigations in the wake of the Keith Vaz affair.

Writing in the Guardian, Sir Gordon warns ministers and MPs that they have a duty to co-operate with inquiries and expresses barely disguised dismay at the way Mr Vaz, the Foreign Office minister, and John Reid, the Northern Ireland secretary, behaved during recent investigations.

Sir Gordon says: "The procedures will only work well if there is a positive commitment by parliament to uphold high standards and an acceptance by individual MPs that it is their personal responsibility to abide by the code of conduct and to cooperate fully with any inquiries resulting from it."

In a thinly veiled attack on Mr Vaz, he goes on: " I think it is important for the committee and the house to remember that, in their capacity as MPs, ministers and shadow ministers have exactly the same obligations under the code of conduct as backbenchers. It cannot be wholly coincident that disagreements between the committee and the commissioner have almost invariably arisen on cases involving ministers or former ministers."

Sir Gordon makes a strong case for new powers for the standards commissioner, warning that failure to strengthen the position could compromise future investigations.

"At present the commissioner does not have the power enjoyed by select committees of sending for 'persons and papers'. In my view, if the evidence is needed for the completion of the inquiry it should have been called for by the committee on the commissioner's behalf, when any refusal would then be a contempt of the house.

"If this is not the accepted practice, the commissioner's authority is permanently damaged and the independence of the particular investigation is compromised."

He also says that MPs on the Commons standards and privileges committee must not be overawed in dealing with cabinet ministers or former ministers. He urges committee members to consciously put aside all feelings of "deference or ambition" when dealing with people who may carry influence.

"This may be an argument for a larger representation on the standards and privileges committee of senior respected members such as the present chairman, Robert Sheldon, who may be less concerned with future preferment."

He also criticises the growing use of lawyers by MPs and witnesses when facing allegations of breaking the MPs' code of conduct or House of Commons rules - a reference to Mr Vaz's use of the solicitor, Geoffrey Bindman. "In my view they should be discouraged from taking a prominent role and should certainly not be permitted to 'represent' an MP or a witness or to refuse cooperation on behalf of his client."

webTitle: Euro group calls on MEPs to reform

fields.headline: Euro group calls on MEPs to reform
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European parliament
fields.trailText: Reform of the European parliament must be speeded up if it is to win legitimacy and the respect of its electors across the continent, a group of Euro-MPs warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Reform of the European parliament must be speeded up if it is to win legitimacy and the respect of its electors across the continent, a group of Euro-MPs warned yesterday.

Launching a campaign to clean up the 626 seat parliament - two years after it helped bring down Jacques Santer's European commission - they called for efforts to drive through change and kill off the impression of sleaze over pay and perks.

Simon Murphy, Labour leader in the parliament, said: "Two years after the fall of the Santer commission, Euro-MPs have failed to put their own house in order. Nothing has changed and the reform process has ground to a halt."

MEPs were "dragged into disrepute" by a salaries and expenses system which was "out of date, untransparent, and in urgent need of an overhaul".

He accused "powerful vested interests" of burying attempts at reform - a priority for the Blair government, which is worried about the low turnout in the last European elections, Labour's poor performance, and general apathy towards EU institutions.

Last year it was recommended that MEPs should be paid a uniform salary in return for agreeing to justify their notoriously inflated expenses. In addition to being paid a flat rate of around £57,000, all were to adhere to a system permitting the reimbursement only of costs actually incurred.

Under current practice some MEPs have claimed huge amounts without having to prove they incurred the expenses.

Other have employed their spouses and pocketed generous secretarial allowances.

MEPs can claim the equivalent of a first class air fare while on official business, no matter how they travel.

Last year the president of the parliament, Nicole Fontaine of France, announced that Friday sessions in Strasbourg were being abolished. But it transpired that MEPs could nevertheless claim the full daily rate for Fridays, even though all they now have to do is travel home.

fields.headline: Brown's next step on 'jobs crusade'
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government took the next step towards achieving its goal of full employment yesterday by announcing an extension of the New Deal, involving spending an extra £120m on creating seven teams of troubleshooters to target unemployment blackspots.
fields.body:
The government took the next step towards achieving its goal of full employment yesterday by announcing an extension of the New Deal, involving spending an extra £120m on creating seven teams of troubleshooters to target unemployment blackspots.

As ministers celebrated un employment falling below 1m for the first time in more than 25 years, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, pledged there would be no relaxation of the government's efforts to get people off welfare and into work.

Having helped to get 270,000 young people into jobs since its launch 1998, the second stage of the New Deal would focus on coaching the hard to employ, and sector by sector initiatives to meet Britain's long-term skills needs, Mr Brown said.

He was speaking at a press conference at the Industrial Society in London which was also attended by the prime minister, the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, and the social security secretary, Alistair Darling.

Mr Brown said: "Full employment is not just an economic cause that will make the economy more efficient. For all of us who have seen the devastating social effects of unemployment it is a crusade.

"As someone put it, I want every child in every part of Britain as they get up for school every morning to see a whole community around them getting up and going to work."

Ministers have been impressed by the results achieved by some of the existing 38 action teams for jobs, including one in Hartlepool where more than 50% of the people seen have been helped into employment. The teams give counselling to a wide range of benefits recipients, not just those on jobseekers' allowance.

A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment said seven teams were being created in Islington, north London, Hull, Newcastle upon Tyne, Salford, Dundee, North Lanarkshire and Halton. Mr Brown said these would bolster his plans, announced in the Budget, to offer new tax incentives to business to invest in the poorest areas.

The government also announced £40m of new funding to help the disabled to find work, another £35m to target those who are not yet equipped to enter the labour market, such as people with behavioural difficulties, and it took the first steps towards a merger of the employment service and benefits agency by saying it would set up 50 experimental one-stop shops for benefit claimants.

Theresa May, shadow education and employment secretary, dismissed the New Deal as "the most expensive job creation scheme in history". She said the Conservatives would replace it and offer private sector companies a "bounty" of around £1,500 for placing a jobless person in work, to be doubled to £3,000 if they remained in the post long-term. This compared favourably with the £20,000 cost of each job found by the New Deal for Young People.

fields.headline: New Deal is just the job
fields.standfirst:
An old wound is healing 25 years on

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The one real danger with falling unemployment is that it may make ministers complacent. Happily, neither complacency nor smugness was on show yesterday when unemployment dropped below the symbolic 1m mark for the first time for 25 years.
fields.body:
The one real danger with falling unemployment is that it may make ministers complacent. Happily, neither complacency nor smugness was on show yesterday when unemployment dropped below the symbolic 1m mark for the first time for 25 years. True, the old counting method of 1975 would have lifted the present figure to considerably more than 1m. But no one can dispute the rise in employment (up by 1.2m since the 1997 election to the highest level since records began), nor the fall in claimants (down by more than 600,000). The proportion of working-age people in the UK now in employment has reached 75%, exceeded only by Denmark (78%) in the league table of 19 developed states.

But rather than relax, both Gordon Brown and Tony Blair yesterday rightly insisted that their existing New Deal welfare-to-work programmes should be extended. They will now cover not just the over-25s but groups previously considered unable to work: partners of the unemployed, people who are disabled and lone parents. Labour's new crusade is for genuine full employment. Job action teams will be extended to more deprived areas with pockets of high unemployment. New literacy and numeracy programmes will be aimed at 750,000 adults lacking even these basic skills and new efforts made to identify local skills gaps.

What will trouble some people on the left is the proposal to extend the New Deal's "stick" of withholding benefits from older people if they refuse to accept one of the programme's four options: work, training, a place on an environment project or in a voluntary organisation. Yet the arguments justifying this approach to younger people apply with equal force to older workers: people out of work have a one-third higher risk of premature death at all ages; unemployed middle-aged men are twice as likely to die in the next five years as employed men. At all ages, the long-term unemployed suffer more cancer, heart disease and accidents. Other social costs can be equally devastating: separation, divorce, depression and suicide.

What is missing from yesterday's green paper is adequate recognition of the need to improve the New Deal programmes. It would be worth reviewing again whether it would be better for a specific agency to organise environment and voluntary sector placements rather than contract them out to various private organisations. Certainly the quality of the placements - particularly on environment projects - needs to be improved. Even more fundamental improvement is needed with skills training courses. This is still a bleak area for too many new dealers. Yesterday's press conference included several successful "graduates" who had improved their qualifications and found new jobs. But many programmes are still not sufficiently work-based. Too many courses are too lax - or teach inappropriate skills. New incentives must be devised to involve more employers in the schemes.

There is one other reform which ministers should examine after the election: the Dutch scheme under which anyone who has been unemployed for two years is guaranteed a job in the community. This helps not just individuals, but the community too, making the programme more publicly popular by providing additional neighbourhood wardens, park attendants, gardeners and adventure playground supervisors. Labour played with this idea but rejected it for fear of being accused of creating phoney "make work" schemes. The Dutch have shown just how successful this approach can be.

webTitle: Comment: Politicians leap on to crime-and-punishment bandwagons

fields.headline: Bad laws, little order
fields.standfirst:
Politicians leap on to crime-and-punishment bandwagons at elections and end up restricting our rights

Special report: policing crime
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The "tough on crime" agenda seems to have run out of control - and is getting worse as we get closer to the election. The Tories and Labour, neck-and-neck in the polls on law and order, each seek a chink in the other's armour - some policy to justify a claim that they are soft on criminals. With the exception of the Liberal Democrats, who are more committed to the principle of civil liberties, few are willing to challenge the "hardline" consensus. But this is a key battleground: a failure to preserve our rights now will make it difficult, perhaps impossible, to reassert them in the future.
fields.body:
The "tough on crime" agenda seems to have run out of control - and is getting worse as we get closer to the election. The Tories and Labour, neck-and-neck in the polls on law and order, each seek a chink in the other's armour - some policy to justify a claim that they are soft on criminals. With the exception of the Liberal Democrats, who are more committed to the principle of civil liberties, few are willing to challenge the "hardline" consensus. But this is a key battleground: a failure to preserve our rights now will make it difficult, perhaps impossible, to reassert them in the future.

These pre-election statements cannot be ignored as mere puffs: they can all too easily turn into parliamentary bills after the election. Criminal justice and policing issues now become intensely political very quickly. An example of this was the important but relatively technical issue of "double jeopardy", seized on by William Hague last year despite the fact that the issue had been passed to the law commission. Sadly, Labour themselves now seem less than committed to retaining this protection. They also show an alarming tendency to blow in the wind of public opinion: think of last year's change of heart by Jack Straw over the passports of football supporters, or Labour's initial silence on the News of the World "name and shame" sex offender lists.

It is very difficult to challenge this consensus of crude populism on law and order - those fighting for rights are less likely to be answered with rational debate than to find themselves caricatured either as bleeding-heart liberals or (in the case of lawyers) as self-interested "forces of conservatism" - with their concerns thus belittled and ignored. Now, those whose job it is to fight for the rights of defendants (defence lawyers) are criticised by the home secretary merely for doing that job.

Part of the difficulty in fighting each proposed change in the rules is that politicians seize on one - often horrifying - example of a problem as a justification for the law being changed: but they don't restrict the "solution" to those circumstances. Concern at animal rights protesters demonstrating outside the homes of those who run laboratories did not lead to a clear-eyed assessment of whether or not the police have sufficient powers to deal with intimidation or violence (in fact, they have ample powers to do so). Instead the nearly automatic reaction was to get out the statute book, pencil in a few more powers for the police and create a few more criminal offences. The powers are rarely carefully crafted to deal only with the current "problem": they virtually always have much more wide-ranging effects.

For example, the criminal justice and police bill will make it a criminal offence not to obey a police officer who has told you to leave a demonstration. This power will not be restricted to use outside the homes of those involved in animal research but will be available to stop demonstrations outside residential property generally. Will this new law be used outside the home of the prime minister? Would it have been used to stop demonstrations outside the residence of General Pinochet or of the apartheid-era South African ambassador?

The police and others have been vacuuming up new powers, many of them unnecessary, since the beginning of the 80s (about 85 acts of parliament dealing with crime and criminal justice since 1981). Some changes, such as the draconian terrorism powers which were rushed through parliament in the wake of the Omagh bombing, are hardly ever used. Unfortunately, all too often the extra powers tilt the balance against protesters, suspects and defendants just a bit more.

Perhaps you feel that all this is worthwhile, if crime is being reduced. But in fact there's no evidence that taking away our rights has any effect whatsoever on levels of crime. Michael Howard told the Tory party conference in 1993 about his 26 changes to the criminal justice system which would make the difference to crime. The resulting Criminal Justice & Public Order Act 1994 locked up children, restricted bail, gave police extra powers to stop and search, restricted the rights of travellers, the homeless and protesters and eroded the right to silence -to no obvious benefit.

Last week Labour announced new proposals to use the civil courts to confiscate the assets of those the police suspect of being criminals. These proposals undermine the presumption of innocence, create a system in which accusations by the police will be enough to force people to disclose all their private financial affairs first to the authorities and then in public at the trial. Even if they are not found guilty, they will have been humiliated, had to pay for lawyers and have their private life dragged through the newspapers. There will be no jury and the judge will base decisions on the "balance of probabilities" - a person will be "convicted" on the basis they are "probably" guilty.

The danger is that if no action is taken now to stop this it will be too late to recover the rights that have been cut away, slice by slice.

John Wadham is director of Liberty.

webTitle: Analysis: Railtrack calls for more cash

fields.headline: Running out of steam
fields.standfirst:
The Strategic Rail Authority's record is one of delays, lack of leadership and poor decisions. It's no wonder the railways are in such trouble
Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Another day in the life of a senior Railtrack executive, another cry for help. Steve Marshall, its chief executive, yesterday put it even more strongly: the company needs extra cash and "inescapably" most of it will have to come from the government.
fields.body:
Another day in the life of a senior Railtrack executive, another cry for help. Steve Marshall, its chief executive, yesterday put it even more strongly: the company needs extra cash and "inescapably" most of it will have to come from the government.

As the election approaches, Mr Marshall is putting out a begging bowl and his message (to a meeting of the rail passengers' council) was simple. Railtrack has not got the cash it needs to maintain and enhance the rail network. A wit in the audience helpfully suggested that in today's climate, if anybody in the industry needs money, an appointment to see Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority, would be the best solution. But, of course, it would not.

Sir Alastair's new strategic agenda for the railway was published this week. It may look impressive - a £60bn investment over the next 10 years - but it is a grand deception which has to be set against hard reality.

Sir Alastair is prevented from offering help to Railtrack on maintenance although he might be able to oblige on improving the system. As a private company, Railtrack is supposed to be big enough to look after itself, but clearly cannot. Worsening financial problems beckon unless the Treasury doctor applies a bandage to its gaping wounds.

Sir Alastair's £60bn is a recapitulation of the government's promise made last summer to spend this amount of money on rail over the next decade. But only half, probably less, is due to come from the taxpayer. The rest will come from the private sector, inspired by the entrepreneurial spirit of the industry, and possibly overhopeful assurances from the SRA that passenger numbers are expected to soar by 50% over the same period.

Around £15bn of the total has already been sanctioned by the rail regulator for Railtrack to spend over the next five years as part of its development programme. But no sooner has the ink dried on the agreement than along comes Mr Marshall asking for an extra £1bn - or is it £1.5bn? The official numbers keep on changing.

This week's presentation by the SRA has been disappointing, considering it has been the government's only big idea for rail since privatisation. It is supposed to produce a panacea for the industry, a strategy to lock in the expansion of rail and to encourage the train companies to provide better services for the public. Yet the strategy has so far not got off the starting blocks.

In effect, the strategy has been delayed for almost 12 months. Sir Alastair has produced several excuses, among them the Hatfield rail crash and Railtrack's negotiations with the regulator. We will now have wait until the autumn for the strategy, a move which cannot come too soon for the train companies who want to invest for a further 20 years with new contracts.

The SRA's lack of leadership has been a serious disappointment to ministers. Sir Alastair had been recruited by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, as a person who could get things done. His critics say that his lofty aspirations are one thing, but that he has failed to become involved in issues which directly affect passengers, like fares and overcrowding, where he could have made an immediate impact.

Ministers have begun a whispering campaign against Sir Alastair and his chief lieutenant, Mike Grant. Both men have another year of their contract to run, and once the election is over could be conveniently removed from their jobs having finally produced their strategy and departed with the grateful thanks of the government ringing in their ears.

Sir Alastair denies that he has any problems with the government and that the only reason for his departure would be because of "hard work". But it is a dirty business, made more so by the fact that government sources are already circulating the names of possible candidates.

The SRA's glossy booklet is full of aspirations. It carries a long list of potential schemes including a new railway under London. But these are mere ideas, dependent on somebody, almost certainly from the private sector, coming forward in support.

Almost two years into its life the SRA cannot even claim to have negotiated new rail franchises. Admittedly, it has booted out Connex, the French-owned group, which operates one of the largest London suburban franchises, but has not been able to sign a deal with the new company. In the meantime, passengers continue to grumble about the poor quality of the Connex product.

By now, Sir Alastair should have been able to announce the successful bidder for the south-west trains franchise, but like all decisions at the SRA these days, it is still delayed.

His worst moment was a decision to overrule a recommendation that a bid by Stagecoach-Virgin to operate the east coast main line with a new franchise gave "value for money". Part of the Virgin bid was a new dedicated 120 mile track from Yorkshire to the outskirts of London. Yet another decision that will have to wait till after the election.

Above all, Sir Alastair has had to contend with the Treasury. Its control over his domain is almost as tight as it was in the old days of British Rail. Much of the £3bn a year coming direct from Gordon Brown until 2009 is going straight to Railtrack. Some will have to go on subsidies to rail companies, leaving very little for grand plans.

Keith Harper is the Guardian's transport editor.

His critics say that his lofty aspirations are one thing, but that he has failed to become involved in issues which directly affect passengers, like fares and overcrowding, where he could have made an immediate impact. Ministers have begun a whispering campaign against Sir Alastair and his chief lieutenant, Mike Grant. Both men have another year of their contract to run, and once the election is over could be conveniently removed from their jobs having finally produced their strategy and departed with the grateful thanks of the government ringing in their ears. Sir Alastair denies that he has any problems with the government and that the only reason for his departure would be because of "hard work". But it is a dirty business, made more so by the fact that government sources are already circulating the names of possible candidates. The SRA's glossy booklet is full of aspirations. It carries a long list of potential schemes including a new railway under London. But these are mere ideas, dependent on somebody, almost certainly from the private sector, coming forward in support. Almost two years into its life the SRA cannot even claim to have negotiated new rail franchises. Admittedly, it has booted out Connex, the French-owned group, which operates one of the largest London suburban franchises, but has not been able to sign a deal with the new company. In the meantime, passengers continue to grumble about the poor quality of the Connex product. By now, Sir Alastair should have been able to announce the successful bidder for the south-west trains franchise, but like all decisions at the SRA these days, it is still delayed. His worst moment was a decision to overrule a recommendation that a bid by Stagecoach-Virgin to operate the east coast main line with a new franchise gave "value for money". Part of the Virgin bid was a new dedicated 120 mile track from Yorkshire to the outskirts of London. Yet another decision that will have to wait till after the election. Above all, Sir Alastair has had to contend with the Treasury. Its control over his domain is almost as tight as it was in the old days of British Rail. Much of the £3bn a year coming direct from Gordon Brown until 2009 is going straight to Railtrack. Some will have to go on subsidies to rail companies, leaving very little for grand plans.
