fields.headline: Uganda's long road to democracy
fields.standfirst: After his re-election for a final presidential term, Yoweri Museveni must build a pluralist democracy if he wishes to be remembered as the man who put Uganda back on its feet, writes Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: After his re-election for a final presidential term, Yoweri Museveni must build a pluralist democracy if he wishes to be remembered as the man who put Uganda back on its feet, writes Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
The victory of Yoweri Museveni in this week's Ugandan presidential election was hardly unexpected.

Although facing a serious challenger for the first time since he took power in 1986, Museveni won 69% of the vote, only three points down on his 1996 total.

But claims by Museveni's principal opponent, Kizza Besigye, that the election was rigged, were not unexpected either.

"I vehemently reject the election results and demand fresh elections," Besigye, who gained 28% of the vote, told Uganda's election commission.

He said he was the victim of "massive fraud". Independent observers said that while malpractice and voter intimidation had been recorded at about 10% of polling stations, it was unlikely that fraud had affected the overall outcome. "This election reflects the will of Ugandans," said the head of the non-governmental organisation, Election Monitoring Group.

There are two problems with this comfortable assertion. One concerns the conduct of the election campaign prior to Monday's vote. The other concerns the ability of Ugandans to express their "will" in future elections, especially in 2006 when Museveni is due to stand down.

The independent Human Rights Watch group was in no doubt about the way this year's campaign was run. In a report issued earlier this month, its Africa division counsel, Binaifer Nowrojee, reported serious problems.

"The Museveni government is trying to win this election by bullying the opposition. The electoral playing field is definitely not level. Since the start of the campaign in January, the opposition have been threatened by violence, arrests and intimidation from soldiers and police," Nowrojee wrote.

Amnesty International also expressed worries about respect for democratic freedoms in the run-up to the poll. Launching a human rights manifesto for Uganda at the end of January, backed by 12 Ugandan NGOs, Amnesty urged all Ugandans "to understand that they have rights and to demand that all presidential candidates make a public commitment to improve their human rights". Numerous incidents of intimidation and the production of fake ballot cards, were reported in the weeks preceding election day.

"In a number of cases, police dispersed rallies held by supporters of opposition candidates," Amnesty said, adding that in one incident in January, two of Besigye's supporters were killed by unidentified gunmen.

The US state department's annual human rights report also painted an unflattering picture of Museveni's rule when it was published last month.

It highlighted the government's "severe restriction of political activities", "serious human rights abuses" by the internal security organisation (which answers direct to Museveni), the directorate of military intelligence, and the police, and the frequent arrest of individuals without charge and their detention without trial.

The opposition's contention, therefore, is that much of the electorate was thoroughly intimidated long before polling day arrived.

Museveni is rightly given much credit in the west and elsewhere for pulling his country out of the chaos he inherited from Milton Obote and Idi Amin.

His record in reducing poverty, combating Aids, extending primary education and encouraging private business led former US president Bill Clinton to praise him as a role model for African leadership.

But for these reasons, and because of Museveni's careful nurturing of relations with foreign aid donors, the election campaign irregularities and abuses are unlikely to become a big issue outside Uganda.

Compared with recent events in Congo and Zimbabwe, for example, Uganda's problems of political leadership do indeed look like small beer.

But as Museveni embarks upon his final term as president, bigger questions will loom over Uganda's political future. In particular, Museveni's refusal to allow opposition groups to form independent political parties may increasingly become untenable.

Under a unifying system devised by the president, all Ugandans currently belong, in theory, to the "Movement". Opponents may stand in elections as individuals but they are not allowed to develop separate power-bases.

Dissatisfaction with this system is likely to grow as Ugandans begin to wonder who and what will follow Museveni, and seek to articulate differing visions of their country's future.

Criticising current arrangements, Human Rights Watch's Nowrojee wrote: "It is more clear than ever that Museveni's Movement system is in fact a means to perpetuate his power through a system that does not allow free and fair democratic elections."

A failure over the next five years to establish an alternative to this system, which depends on and principally serves one man, could spell future disaster for Uganda.

If he really wants to go down in history as the man who put Uganda back on his feet, Museveni should concentrate in his final term on building a democratic, pluralist democracy that can withstand the passing of a president.

webTitle: Up to 1m animals may face slaughter

fields.headline: Up to 1m animals may face slaughter
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government hugely expanded the foot and mouth slaughter programme today to include hundreds of thousands more animals than expected as the toll of the disease continued to rise.
fields.body:
The government hugely expanded the foot and mouth slaughter programme today to include hundreds of thousands more animals than expected as the toll of the disease continued to rise.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, told the Commons that he was implementing a policy of "safety first" with the backing of farming groups.

The new measures entail slaughtering healthy animals where a strong risk of infection exists and, in the worst case scenario, could push the animal death sentence towards a million.

The policy was welcomed as "grim but necessary" by the National Farmers' Union, which warned that the slaughter would leave large swathes of farmland effectively "dead".

Mr Brown said: "We are intensifying the slaughter of animals at risk in the areas of the country - thankfully still limited - where the disease has spread."

However, he said the government also hoped over the next 7-10 days to relax restrictions in areas that still "remained clean".

The new slaughter programme includes culling all animals within 3km exclusion zones in Cumbria, which is an area of high infection.

It was not yet clear whether the cull would include wild animals, or whether the cull zones would apply to other high infection areas such as Devon and Dumfries and Galloway.

Up to 100,000 sheep which may have come into contact with diseased animals through markets in Welshpool and Northampton but have not yet developed the disease will also be traced and killed.

In Devon, where foot and mouth had been spreading from farm to farm, vets and trained lay staff will carry out "intensive patrols" within the 3km zones of infected farms.

The NFU said the culls would mean the slaughter of a "significant" number of healthy animals.

The NFU president, Ben Gill, said: "There will be many tears around the British countryside today. Our farms should be starting to jump to life with newborn lambs and calves.

"Instead, many will feel that spring has been cancelled and their farms are simply dead."

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, revealed yesterday that 132,000 animals had already been killed.

The Prince of Wales yesterday announced a £500,000 aid package for farmers, to ease the plight of those under severe strain from the "dreaded outbreak" and spoke of his fears of the crisis causing suicides.

Father-of-two Brian Oakley, 54, was found hanged at his 26-acre Bryn Coch farm, in Llanfechain, on the Powys-Shropshire border on March 2, it emerged yesterday.

fields.headline: NY agency swoops for JWT's Donkin
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: One of New York's biggest advertising agencies has poached JWT's Chris Donkin to head up its new European office, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
One of New York's biggest advertising agencies has poached Chris Donkin, head of J Walter Thompson's Jaguar Global Communications Group, to head up its new European office.

Messner Vetere Berger McNammee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG has hired him to oversee Volvo's European advertising business.

The new agency will be called MVBMS Fuel Europe.

Last year Volvo awarded lead global agency status to its US advertising agency, the Havas-owned Messner Vetere Berger McNammee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG, which means the agency is now overseeing all European campaigns.

"This is one of those opportunities that comes along very rarely," said Mr Donkin.

"Running a dynamic start-up office as part of a well-respected US agency with one of the strongest motor brands in the world - if you're interested in car advertising it doesn't get much better than that," he added.

The news will add to the rumours that Jaguar is planning to withdraw its advertising business from JWT and hand it to fellow WPP agency Young & Rubicam.

Mr Donkin will be managing director of the new agency, which will be located in Amsterdam and employ around 40 people.

The creative director will be Keith Klein, who joins from the agency's New York office.

In the past, Volvo has used a number of creative agencies across Europe including Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO in the UK.

AMV retains its place on Volvo's agency roster, but will concentrate on local tactical adverts rather than big branding campaigns.

Mr Donkin joined JWT as a graduate trainee 12 years ago. He later spent four years in the agency's Asia office before returning to London to head up the Jaguar business.

webTitle: Modernising local government: the issue explained

fields.headline: Modernising local government: the issue explained
fields.trailText: It's make or break time for the town hall modernisers. With the Local Government Act rapidly coming into force, ministers and campaigners face the first test of the new political structures they have created to make town halls more open, efficient and accountable.
fields.body:
It's make or break time for the town hall modernisers. With the Local Government Act rapidly coming into force, ministers and campaigners face the first test of the new political structures they have created to make town halls more open, efficient and accountable.

Failure to make cabinet-style council leadership and directly elected city mayors work will dent the credibility of the government as a whole and seriously damage the reputations of Tony Blair and local government minister Hilary Armstrong.

Fortunately for them, the voters seem to like the idea of change. An ICM poll last year showed that more than half of respondents thought mayors would improve council accountability, and there has been an explosion in the number of campaign groups working to collect the 5% of local voter signatures needed to force a referendum for a mayor. Berwick-upon-Tweed borough council showed just how easy this could be when independent councillor Brian Douglas launched a one-man referendum campaign and quickly collected the 1,100 signatures he needed.

Many in local government speak of a domino effect, arguing that once one city puts a mayor in place, others will be persuaded to follow. And this is already happening. Ministers are working to organise a democracy day of mayoral referendums across the country, which could take place late next year. The key to persuading campaigners and councillors from as far afield as Liverpool and Lewisham to come on board was Birmingham city council's decision to ballot on a mayor.

This is despite widespread resistance to the idea of mayors from local politicians. Research from the Local Government Association last year showed that just 1% of councils wanted a mayor, and that the vast majority favoured cabinet-style local government. But while this may be the less radical option, it could prove just as difficult to implement.

The media has given the new structures associated with the modernisers a rough ride because of plans for cabinet councillors to take decisions in private. The regional press, opposition politicians and freedom of information campaigners have persuaded the government to make concessions on openness. Ministers now insist councils take key decisions in public, although concerns remain about how well the government has defined which decisions those should be.

More worryingly, research on the new structures has not all been positive. A government report on six councils that were piloting the new arrangements expressed concern that the scrutiny of cabinet decisions was poorly developed. This scrutiny function is crucial to the government's new structures, and is designed to give backbench councillors a chance to hold their executive colleagues to account. The findings point to a long period of upheaval and confusion in local government before the new structures bed down.

The lack of enthusiasm for modernisation among many councillors could prolong and complicate that process. More than a third of those who stood down at last year's local elections gave political modernisation as a reason. Conservatives in particular feel cabinets and mayors are an unwanted Whitehall imposition, and politicians of all parties fear their role will decline as day-to-day executive power is concentrated in the hands of a small number of local councillors.

The changes will also affect local government officials, who will have to reassess their position in relation to these more powerful politicians. Senior officers who are used to having an important policy-making role could find themselves becoming simple administrators under a city mayor, and Birmingham's chief executive Sir Michael Lyons last year announced his resignation for just this reason.

The concerns are understandable. Officers, councillors, ministers and campaigners are now exposed to the electorate in a way they never have been before. Local voters have the power to directly effect a revolution in their town and city halls, and to make or break political careers in the process. If they topple one domino, the chances are that more will follow.

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: Whirring away on the treadmill, I contemplate my new indoor life. I'm living in an artificial light zone. All frosted glass, mirrors, polished wooden floors, TV screens and 16 channels on the gym's in-house entertainment system. I'm confined here in this world of sweat and Lycra for the foreseeable future, with my tibialis posterior - that ankle muscle - acting up again and making it a bit painful to jog on the hard, unforgiving road. But I am worried. Will training just in the gym get me fit enough for the marathon? Is pounding the treadmill as good as road running? I consult the web.

And happily the Americans have sorted it all out. Their medics have tested the cardio-vascular effectiveness of treadmills and found them to be tip-top. They have even produced a treadmill champion. Last year, Dr Christine Clark, a 37-year-old pathologist, was the shock winner of the US Olympic marathon trials in a time of 2.33.31. She came from Alaska and, because of the icy roads and rather chilly winds, did her entire training schedule on a treadmill - 70 miles a week. It's simple then: do it indoors, with warmth, drinks on tap, TV and a sweat towel.

But there are a few basic rules. The treadmill is a moving road. In order to go forward, you simply need to lift your legs from the conveyor belt. Road running knackers you out because you need to use your muscles to push off the ground and propel yourself forward.

So you need to reproduce the effort of the road - along with the potential wind resistance - which means running at a slight incline: between 1.5 and 2 degrees, they say. There is the added advantage of being able to alter the incline to suit the course you are about to complete. If you could be bothered, you could probably programme in the exact course of the London marathon into the treadmill - hills and inclines.

The Americans, though, do add one warning. Avoid watching TV or reading a magazine because this reduces your work-out intensity. I never really understood what this meant until I watched an action replay of the Liverpool vs Tranmere Rovers match on the gym TV last Monday. As Steven Gerrard lunged forward to head the ball into the back of Tranmere's net, I unconsciously replicated the action and ended up on the floor, the rubber conveyor whistling by my ear and a hundred mocking eyes witnessing my embarrassment.

fields.headline: Dear Doctor
fields.standfirst: On whether humans can get foot and mouth, reducing the risk of heart attacks and irregular periods
fields.trailText: On whether humans can get foot and mouth, reducing the risk of heart attacks and irregular periods.
fields.body:
Disease on the farm

I live in a village in Herefordshire. We don't live on a farm but are surrounded by farmland. Is there any danger to my family from foot and mouth disease?

Foot and mouth is caused by a virus that affects all cloven-hoofed animals and spreads like wildfire between them. Humans can catch it but usually only after very close contact with affected animals. There hasn't been a human case reported since the last outbreak in 1967. You can't catch it from the milk or meat of diseased animals. Even in the unlikely event of infection, it causes a mild illness in humans with tingly blisters on hands, fever, sore throat and occasionally blisters on the feet and tongue. There is an unrelated viral illness that often affects young children and also causes blisters on the hands, feet and mouth. It's called hand, foot and mouth disease but it has nothing to do with cloven-hoofed animals and everything to do with other kids who infect one another.

Taking vitamin E

Should I take vitamin E supplements to prevent the ravages of ageing and reduce my risk of heart attacks?

Would that life were so simple. Vitamin E is an antioxidant which is, in general, a good thing. It's found naturally in fruit and veg. It's hard to be deficient in vitamin E unless you have cystic fibrosis, long-standing jaundice or severe bowel problems. Two recent studies have shown conflicting evidence about the role of vitamin E in reducing heart disease. On the other hand, it's unlikely that a supplement will do you harm.

Breakthrough bleeding

I have always had irregular periods but last year I had breakthrough bleeding between periods. I was put on the pill, which I hated, but it seemed to clear it up. Now I am bleeding again between periods. Is there anything that I can do apart from go back on the pill?

If all potentially dangerous/treatable conditions have been ruled out (ie blood test for thyroid, scan of ovaries and womb and cervical smear, etc), you can put your bleeding down to hormonal fluctuations - usually not enough progesterone to keep the womb lining in place except during periods. The combined pill is the best way of stabilising things. Alternatively, you can have a coil fitted which releases a tiny amount of progesterone into the womb. If you decide just to live with it, have a blood test now and again to check you are not becoming anaemic.

Anaemic after birth

I had a baby by caesarean section three months ago and following the procedure was told I was anaemic. I declined a transfusion and a follow up blood test showed that my iron/haemoglobin count was a respectable 12. However, six weeks ago at the gym I experienced a sensation of losing my balance. I thought this was a one off as it was my first gym visit in almost a year. However, this feeling of imbalance has not gone away since. My GP took my blood pressure which he said was low and attributed my loss of balance to low iron and low blood pressure so he has prescribed me more iron tablets. I am also experiencing a tingling feeling in my lower legs. What advice can you give me on this matter as it is disconcerting?

You can tell whether you are low in iron by asking whether the full blood count showed small and pale cells or normal looking ones. If there is any doubt, a further blood test specifically to measure your iron stores may be a good idea. I agree that both rushing into a transfusion and taking iron tablets orally are to be avoided unless necessary - and with a haemoglobin of 12, as you say, it seems unlikely that you are anaemic enough to make you dizzy.

Having low blood pressure is a good thing from a long-term health point of view but makes you prone to dizzy spells, especially if you are on your feet a long time or get very hot. There is no specific treatment in the UK and most people learn to avoid the dizzy spells by not overheating and sitting or even lying down if they feel dizzy.

You may also have a mild inner ear virus making you dizzy. This virus passes on its own within a few weeks. If it persists ask for further tests.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: Health: Patching up addicts. Nicotine replacement therapies are to be made available on the NHS.

fields.headline: Patching up addicts
fields.standfirst: Nicotine replacement therapies are to be made available on the NHS. But, asks  Sarah Ebner, will they really help to wean smokers off cigarettes?
fields.trailText: Nicotine replacement therapies are to be made available on the NHS. But, asks Sarah Ebner , will they really help to wean smokers off cigarettes?
fields.body:
On Saturday, it will be a fortnight since Emma Strangwayes-Booth last had a cigarette. "I was really ill a few weeks ago," she says. "I had a viral infection of my airways and couldn't breathe. It was really horrible and I'm sure I was iller because I'd been smoking for so long."

Strangwayes-Booth, 26, has been smoking for 13 years and has often thought of giving up. "I always found it really hard," she says, "and all the things you can buy to help seem so expensive." But yesterday she decided to hang the expense and buy her first nicotine replacement patches. They cost her £14.73 for seven.

Strangwayes-Booth is exactly the kind of person the Department of Health hopes will give up smoking for good. Yesterday - No Smoking Day - the public health minister, Yvette Cooper, announced that nicotine replacement therapies (NRT) would soon be available via NHS prescriptions.

The new policy, starting at the end of April, will cost the government between £10m and £40m a year - pennies compared with the £1.7bn that the NHS spends on smokers annually. It means that GPs will be able to prescribe NRT products such as nicotine patches, gum and inhalers to smokers who want to quit. It will be up to individual GPs to decide who gets what, but those recipients will be benefiting financially. One £6 prescription will be enough for two weeks' supply. At the same time, some NRT products will be made available at supermarkets.

Strangwayes-Booth, a receptionist at Goldcrest Films in London, is impressed by the plan. "I think it's a really good idea for the NHS to try to help people stop smoking, and I would definitely go to my doctor to get a prescription," she says. "It's also sensible to be able to buy patches or gum at the same places you can buy cigarettes, rather than have to go to a chemist."

The plans are part of New Labour's heavy emphasis on public health. Its 1998 white paper introduced a multitude of targets, from healthy eating to cutting heart disease, including three aimed at cutting down smoking. A fourth anti-smoking target, aimed particularly at the poorly paid, was added as part of the NHS cancer plan. Its target is a reduction in the number of smokers among manually skilled workers from 32% to 26% by 2010.

"NRT will be available on prescription, because research shows that it doubles the chance of people giving up smoking," says an NHS spokesman. "But it's also because we particularly need to help people in lower-income groups. They tend to smoke more and may find the cost of NRT prohibitive."

But this doubled success rate only applies if you are ready to stop. Taking NRT cannot make you more committed to giving up smoking or transform you into a non-smoker, although it can help end the psychological habit of reaching for a cigarette.

Professor John Britton, a consultant in respiratory medicine at Nottingham city hospital, admits that many smokers simply cannot quit. Over the course of a year, he says, only around a fifth of those who try to give up manage to do so permanently. And that includes those who go by his favoured method - using nicotine replacement therapy and getting behavioural support.

"NRT is not enough on its own. When you're trying to stop smoking, you need to be taught ways of dealing with times when having a cigarette seems like a good idea."

Mary Ostle would second that. A heavy smoker for 35 years, she was getting through 25 to 30 cigarettes a day before deciding to quit last November. But Ostle, a nurse from Middleton St George, near Darlington, says it was preparation that helped her.

"So much more needs to be done for smokers. I managed to give up through determination, by knowing that having a cup of coffee made me want a cigarette, so not drinking coffee any more. But more support is needed. There aren't nearly enough smoking cessation clinics."

She tried a Nicorette Inhalator, but says she only used it around four or five times. "I didn't find it a lot of help," she says. "It was kind of a prop, something to carry around, and it was very expensive. I'm sure many people wonder why they should spend money on that when they can buy a packet of fags for less money and enjoy themselves."

Because of this, she is convinced that the government's plans are exactly what are needed. "I'm sure this will be a success," she says. "But it's about time it happened."

"I've been calling for this for years," says Britton. "NRT is an extremely efficient clinical treatment which saves lives and doesn't cost much money. It hasn't made sense to deny it to those who are addicted. Other addicts get help. Why shouldn't those addicted to nicotine?"

In addition, he says, nicotine replacement therapy is a safe way to try to give up. The treatments work by giving people the nicotine they are addicted to, but in a way that is safe and controlled.

"There's a misconception about the dangers of smoking," he says. "People think that it's nicotine that causes cancer, but that's not true. Cigarettes are dangerous because of the other things in them. It's the tar and other products of the cigarette which cause the harm." In other words, people smoke for the addictive nicotine, but it is not the most damaging substance.

"A cigarette delivers nicotine into your blood and that goes into your brain directly," says Britton. "It's all very quick. The nicotine replacements don't work like that. You take them in through your skin, your mouth or your nose and they have to go right round your body to get to your brain. It's diluted and that's safer."

Strangwayes-Booth is keen to try out her new patch. "I really want to give up smoking this time," she says. "But I haven't been to the pub yet. The patch will be coming with me, when I do, and I really hope it works."

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman worries about fatal insomnia and Vanessa Feltz
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman worries about fatal insomnia and Vanessa Feltz.
fields.body:
Friday: For some strange reason, I have been sent two copies of a new Health Encyclopaedia by a certain Dr Robert Youngson. According to the back cover, Dr Thomas Stuttaford of the Times thinks it "should prove invaluable in the home" - a compliment with the scrawled, automatic ring of " 'A tour de force,' Anthony Burgess" on the back of a novel, but even so it would be rude not to dip in for five minutes and get a flavour of Dr Youngson's work.

Saturday: I awake tetchy and prickly-eyed, having passed a brief night (I didn't drop off until after 4am) to find my wife sitting on the edge of the bed in a menacingly straight-backed manner. She is holding my encyclopaedia. "What is this?" she asks, pointing at the annotation on page 292. "That? A note on a disease called fatal familial insomnia," I tell her, glancing down, "a terminal, genetically determined disease . . ." I look up to find myself alone.

Sunday: Last night I hardly slept again, and now a familiar jittery sensation ripples along the area beneath my ribs. It's panic, of course, and so intense is the need to gainsay the terror by articulating it that I wait until Rebecca is a captive audience in her bath before striking. "This fatal familial insomnia . . ." I tell her, and she slides irritably beneath the water. When she surfaces, I go on. ". . . occurs between 40 and 60, and I think it killed my grandmother Suds."

"Why?"

"She claimed not to have slept for more than 20 minutes since 1936." From the thinning of her lips, Rebecca is preparing one of her Socratic dialogues.

"How long does it take to kill?" she asks.

"It is fatal," (I have memorised the entry) "within seven to 33 months of its onset."

"And when did Suds die?"

"In 1990, a week before the FA Cup final," I reply.

"At what age?"

"Eighty-four."

"So she was 24 years too old and suffered it for 50-odd years too long. And you really think this illness killed her?"

"Well," I reply, "she might have had a new variant strain."

When a family-size bar of Imperial Leather clips me on the left temple, I leave Rebecca to her bath.

Sunday: The river of marital tension, which has been rising for 24 hours, bursts its banks when Rebecca angrily accuses me of ruining Celebrity Big Brother by muttering ceaselessly throughout. The truth is, I'm worried about Vanessa. "She's becoming paranoid," I explain. "It says here on page 557 that factors include lowered self-esteem, distrust and suspicion of others, and social isolation. That's Vanessa all over." I am shouting now because the volume has been turned up to maximum, and when the neighbours begin banging on the wall I take the book and a bottle of Glenlivet and retire morosely to bed.

Monday: Say what you will, this encyclopaedia is wide-ranging. There is even an entry on frottage, the practice of "rubbing the body against another person for the purposes of sexual gratification . . . without exposing himself the active male rubs his genitals against a woman's buttock or thigh."

Fascinating, but what's it doing here?

Tuesday: I awake jumpy and neuralgic after passing a troubled night, in which, during the one very brief period of sleep, I dreamed of Andrew Neil. We are fellow housemates in a journalists' Big Brother (it's for charity: we're raising money for the Barclay brothers' internet division) when I spontaneously develop fatal familial insomnia. Andrew picks up a guitar and tries to soothe me to sleep by singing Simon and Garfunkel songs. "When you're weary," he croons, "when you're a poisonous little prick/ When tears are in your eyes . . ." But it's hopeless, and when I begin to scream, Dr Thomas Stuttaford leaps naked from the hot tub, where he has been sporting with Janet Street-Porter and Libby Purves. When he charges in, with syringe drawn to sedate me, I awake.

Wednesday: The illness appears to have gone into remission, and I awake after 11 hours' sleep refreshed but annoyed to find the encyclopaedia still missing. I first noticed its absence late last night, and this morning a copious search of this Bermuda Triangle of a house (the book joins 23 other medical textbooks, 11 thermometers, three stethoscopes, an enema kit, two blood-pressure-testing devices and a range of Chinese herbs to have vanished in four years) reveals nothing. Still, how prescient of Bloomsbury to have sent two copies. For now I think the other is best left in the office.

fields.headline: Trial and error
fields.standfirst: Medical research needs human guinea pigs. But the news this week of patients irreversibly damaged by a new treatment for Parkinson's disease has highlighted the risks. When is it worth it?  Sophie Petit-Zeman  reports
fields.trailText: Medical research needs human guinea pigs. But the news this week of patients irreversibly damaged by a new treatment for Parkinson's disease has highlighted the risks. When is it worth it? Sophie Petit-Zeman reports.
fields.body:
Just how ill would you need to be before agreeing to take an experimental treatment, the risks of which were unknown? You might consider, if you were suffering from a terminal illness, that the possibility of a miracle cure - however slim - would make the chance one worth taking. But what if you had a disease that was painful or debilitating, but unlikely to kill you? How do you assess potential risks when the whole point of the treatment is that you are the guinea pig?

Earlier this week it was announced that a trial of a new treatment for Parkinson's disease had, for some patients, gone horribly wrong. A group of volunteers in the US had foetal cells transplanted directly into their brains, in the hope that they would survive and produce dopamine, the "chemical messenger" missing in patients suffering from Parkinson's.

But the researchers were horrified to discover that instead of being helped by the experiment, a small number of the patients got much worse. The cells appear to have gone into overdrive, producing too much dopamine and causing the patients to writhe and jerk their heads uncontrollably. Unlike many experimental procedures, scientists have no way of reversing this particular treatment. The experiment has been stopped completely, prompting despair in many sufferers who hoped it offered a possibility for a cure.

It is a sobering moment for those involved in trials at the cutting edge of medical research. But the results should not affect the will of the medical profession to continue experimenting on new procedures, says Sir Iain Chalmers, director of the UK Cochrane Centre, an international organisation that collects evidence on experimental treatments, and a leading expert on clinical trials.

Chalmers agrees that all trials are risky but stresses that the public need to know they are important. He sees the climate of fear which surrounds them as extremely unhelpful. "Trials have to go through enormous scrutiny procedures before they're launched. But the whole enterprise is tarnished because people so often don't understand how they work," he said. "There's a perceived need to protect people who are inside trials, yet it's the 99 out of a 100 who aren't in them who are at risk."

So convinced is Chalmers of the potential benefits of experimental treatments, he carries a card asking to be entered into any clinical trial for which he may be suitable. "I'm afraid it's all a case of hedging my bets. There's overwhelming evidence that people in trials do better than those outside them, whether they're receiving the test treatment or the placebo, probably simply because they get better care."

His faith is borne out by Mary Combe, 80, who has been involved in Progres, a trial for a new treatment for stroke victims, for the last 5 years. After suffering a mini-stroke in 1996, her GP encouraged her to join the trial to find out whether conventional blood pressure-reducing drugs decreased the danger of further problems in high-risk patients, even if their blood pressure was not problematically high. While not testing a new drug, the application of this treatment in this area was untested. Its results will be released in June.

Combe's experience has been a positive one. "I had no doubts about doing the trial," she says, "and went to the hospital every few months. I enjoyed my outings and had superb care. I was called back just yesterday to see how I was getting on."

And it was that routine visit that may prove so important for Combe. "I'd had a lump in my breast for ages, which I'd ignored. But as I was going, I thought I'd mention it, and the doctor gave me a good going over. He'll help get me seen quickly now."

Her doctor and trial co-ordinator, Richard Lindley of Edinburgh's Western General Hospital, says it is just this kind of discovery that can make being involved in trials so beneficial. "You're seen regularly by people with more time than usual, you chat, and get the chance to pick things up and deal with them early."

But clinical trials remain highly risky, and public concern is understandable. In May, the US government produced a report which revealed that a number of research institutes were not taking risk and ethical considerations fully into account, and research was suspended in some of the country's top centres including Duke University and the University of California, Los Angeles.

An example of the kind of thing that can go wrong is illustrated by the recent suspension of gene therapy trials run by Dr Jeffrey Isner, a top researcher at Tufts University in Massachusetts. He received a warning letter from the US food and drug administration last year because he had enrolled a patient into a study to see whether a gene for vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) could help grow new blood vessels in patients with heart disease or other circulatory problems.

The administration found that Dr Isner had included in his trial one patient with lung cancer and that the VEGF gene may have fed this man's tumour. With gene therapy trials likely to become big business, clearer standards to control them are urgently needed.

Facts on the number of people involved in trials have been incredibly difficult to come by, says Chalmers, because there is no mandatory requirement to register experiments. All trials carried out within the NHS must now be registered, but many still escape the lists, such as some of the experiments that advertise for volunteers in newspapers, and those arranged between drug companies and doctors outside the NHS.

In some cases, in fact, trials have been double-counted, leading to absurd situations where there have been more apparent trials than there were patients, because the same trial was being differently reported.

New regulations should enable experimental treatments to be better monitored, provide accurate figures of the number of volunteers taking part, and reduce publication bias in favour of positive trial results, which are currently more likely to be published than those which are negative or equivocal.

Alongside clinical trials which participants join knowingly, there are also those to which patients may be unwittingly entered at critical times. These include the current third interna tional stroke trial, also being co-ordinated in Edinburgh by Lindley. Aimed at ascertaining whether a "clot busting" drug, recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA), increases the number of people who survive without disability after a stroke, the risk is that such drugs can increase bleeding within the brain, and could cause death if used in people where this was a problem.

As Lindley explains, people are carefully screened before they are admitted to the trial to ensure, as far as possible, that this risk is not relevant to them. Strict criteria of this sort have enabled the trial to go ahead with an unusual "waiver of consent" rule. This means that doctors can enter patients for the trial without their consent or that of relatives, if it cannot be obtained quickly enough to allow them to receive the drug during the relatively short "window" after the stroke when it is thought to work.

While this trial sounds scary - patients being given drugs which might hasten their death, and without being asked first - the need for it is clear. Every year thousands of people in the UK survive, severely disabled, after a stroke. The value of rt-PA is unproven, but some doctors are so convinced of its benefits that they use it despite a lack of trial-based evidence. Lindley says that trials are vital to stop the "postcode lottery" of stroke care. As he explains: "We must do the proper trial, find out if the treatment really works, and then make the drug available, or not, on this basis. If you have a stroke in, say, Glasgow or Newcastle, you may be given these drugs because some doctors there are confident that they work."

While the failure of the Parkinson's trial is devastating for those affected and their families, Chalmers says that he would have participated in the trial himself. In the sense that any results, even negative ones, are invaluable, he persists in viewing this experiment as "a tremendous success". "This trial is important because it urges humility on those who make claims without careful studies," he says. "The public need to understand that we can't simply rely on what works in the lab working in the clinic."

fields.headline: Dot gone from Express
fields.trailText:
3.15pm:Another correspondent is leaving the Express as a further bout of redundancies is announced writes Jessica Hodgson.

Mar 15: NUJ fears for future of Express
Mar 15: Union warns of cuts
Mar 15: Sports staff face axe
Mar 14: Northern & Hell for high earners
Mar 14: More jobs to go at Express
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Another correspondent is leaving the Express as a further bout of redundancies is announced.

Dorothy Lepkowska, the paper's education correspondent, is leaving the paper after two-and-a-half years to be the Mirror's education correspondent.

Ms Lepkowska is replacing Richard Garner, who is going to the Independent to replace its education editor Judith Judd, who is joining the Times Educational Supplement.

She denied the move had been prompted by the announcement of 145 redundancies at the paper.

"I've been here two-and-a-half years," she said. "There's always a time to move on and this is it.

"The Mirror made me an offer I couldn't refuse. It's a great paper and I'm looking forward to joining the team there."

But the opportunity is bound to come as a relief after news that a third of the paper's staff are to be cut.

Before joining the Express, Ms Lepkowska worked for the Times Educational Supplement and the Evening Standard where she was a respected education correspondent.

Related stories

fields.headline: The day Shell turned hostile
fields.standfirst: This is the governor of California announcing rebates for electricity users who save power. The US is running low on gas, threatening more blackouts in the sunshine state. And it's why a $100bn oil company is stalking tiny exploration firms
fields.trailText: This is the governor of California announcing rebates for electricity users who save power. The US is running low on gas, threatening more blackouts in the sunshine state. And it's why a $100bn oil company is stalking tiny exploration firms.
fields.body:
City analysts were in no hurry to arrive at Plaisters Hall in London on that cold morning - December 14 - back in 1998. They anticipated another dull briefing from Royal Dutch Shell, regarded by many as an arm of the Foreign Office with an arrogance and opaqueness to match.

But the atmosphere soon turned electric as chairman Mark Moody-Stuart came clean and admitted the world's second largest oil group had lost its way and would need to write down $4.5bn (£3.1bn) worth of assets.

Many have been shocked by the recent transformation of Shell from aloof but genial giant to aggressive predator simultaneously chasing hostile bids on opposite sides of the world.

But the change can be tracked back to those fourth-quarter results just over two years ago when Shell was forced to admit it had made some painful mistakes.

These included spending too much on the relatively recent purchase of Tejas gas operations and an involvement in the Montell chemical joint venture.

Analysts were stunned at the detail in the figures and the sudden openness of the chairman. "I am absolutely clear that our group's reputation with investors is on the line," Mr Moody-Stuart said, promising to "clear out the cupboard" with 4,000 job cuts and 40% of its chemical business sold.

The scale of the group's financial ills had forced a fundamental rethink at a time when oil prices appeared to be in free fall and rivals Exxon and BP were embarking on a huge round of consolidation through takeovers.

While Exxon pounced on Mobil and BP snapped up Amoco and Arco, Shell stood apart from the frenzy and argued it would first put its own house in order.

The investment community was initially sceptical, but the tarnished colossus gradually began to earn praise as it tackled an unwieldy operational structure some still attributed to the alliance, agreed in 1907, of Royal Dutch Petroleum with Shell Transport & Trading.

Sacred cows such as the politically sensitive Shellhaven refinery in Essex - where jobs for life had been the order of the day - were unceremoniously closed. Shell's beautiful Art-Deco offices on the Strand in London were sold as part of plans to achieve savings of $2.5bn a year.

The financial performance of the group steadily improved quarter by quarter, and as the share price climbed from 350p towards its close last night of 564p, the company began to look outside as well as within for future growth.

Last May the Anglo-Dutch group threw overboard a long held commitment to consensual mergers by launching a hostile bid for gas-rich Woodside Petroleum in Australia.

It then opened talks to win control of the energy interests of Fletcher Challenge in New Zealand, and made it clear that it planned to follow ExxonMobil and BP into gas as the fuel of the future.

Then last week with the Woodside deal still undecided Shell opened a second hostile front - this time targeting Barrett in the US, thereby reversing an earlier policy to withdraw from gas there.

Yesterday Shell again underlined a new hardline stance by filing a second set of papers in a US district court to stop Barrett trying to rebuff its approaches.

Analysts shaken by the rapid changes in style and direction have focused on the emerging power of Phil Watts, the head of exploration who takes over from Mr Moody-Stuart as group chairman on July 1.

Rough and tough Mr Watts is quite different from the idealistic Mr Moody-Stuart, who once invited a Buddhist priest to address a Shell management meeting.

The new hardball tactics have horrified traditionalists who see Shell losing its cool. "It does not do Shell's image much good to be charging round like an enraged elephant trampling on companies such as Barrett, one hundredth its size," was how one industry watcher put it.

Shell is also criticised for offering $55 per share for Barrett, amounting to a lowly $1.8bn total. That made the immediate rejection by the US company's board almost automatic.

But if it really does want to increase gas reserves in the US, why not buy a company with significant reserves - such as Burlington Resources, ask the doubters. And why did Shell sell its US gas interests in Altura recently if wanted to build its fu ture round the more ecologically acceptable gas? Industry experts believe that Shell has belatedly woken up to the importance of gas after BP secured its position in this sector through its takeovers of Amoco, Arco and Vastar Resources.

Short-term interest in gas has been increased by US prices doubling from $2.4 per million British thermal units to $5.3 btu, fuelled by growing demand from electricity producers.

Shell shrugs off the criticism, admitting it is indeed in a hurry to bulk up its gas interests because they produce less harmful emissions when burned and are likely to avoid tightening legislation.

But the group argues that it is carefully cherry-picking the best gas assets in the world and is offering a "full and fair price" for each of them.

Further, it points out that the offer price for Barrett represents a 24% premium over its market price of $44.25 per share on February 28, the last trading day prior to Shell's initial proposal.

Since then the share price has soared to over $62.

But analysts on both side of the Atlantic question whether Shell can possibly succeed with what it has claimed to be a final offer.

Fadel Gheit, energy analyst with New York-based brokerage firm Fahnestock & Co, said: "Barrett over the last three sessions has traded 8m shares and they are now in the hands of arbitrageurs, who are betting the stock will go higher.

"I think Shell will have to offer $65 or Goldman Sachs [the financial adviser acting for Barrett] will go off and find an alternative. Independents such as Apache or Anadarko could come in, and so could one of the other majors."

Another London-based analyst who asked not to be named felt equally pessimistic about Shell's chances, pointing out that there were "poison pills" in place at Barrett which would require legal action to remove.

He said: "Would you accept $55 per share when the share price is way above this and when there is a very good chance of other companies coming in with bids?"

They also question whether it is wise of Shell to be involved in a hostile bid for Barrett before it has won over Woodside.

The Anglo-Dutch group may have to wait until the end of April before it hears whether its move against the operator of the massive north-west shelf gas project is successful.

Few takeovers are rejected in that country. But political sensitivity over the deal has soared as the Canberra government's electoral appeal has slumped.

Shell Australia's chairman, Peter Duncan, was left issuing veiled threats yesterday in order to exert his own pressure on politicians.

He said rejection "would not be a good sign for Australia in terms of foreign investment and open economy. All those things which it's done so well".

Meanwhile back in London it is clear that Mr Watts has a growing influence, although it is too early to suggest a tradition of consensual management has been thrown overboard, too.

But now the gloves have come off in London and the Hague.

As one Shell insider put it: "Remember what Mark Twain said - 'when its steamboat time, you steam'."

fields.headline: Keith Vaz must go
fields.standfirst: Did Tony Blair sack the wrong minister in the Hinduja passports affair, and how long can he continue defending the embattled minister for Europe, asks Westminster correspondent David Hencke
fields.trailText: Did Tony Blair sack the wrong minister in the Hinduja passports affair, and how long can he continue defending the embattled minister for Europe, asks Westminster correspondent David Hencke.
fields.body:
The latest revelations in today's Guardian about Keith Vaz's behaviour do not paint a pretty picture.

Disgraceful, contemptuous, intimidatory were terms used about Mr Vaz's behaviour during a Labour party inquiry seven years ago, while this week's investigation revealed an image of a minister obstructing and refusing to answer questions from the parliamentary commissioner.

Yet Mr Vaz stays. Today, for the third day running, Downing Street dug in hard in defence of the embattled minister for Europe. ''Mr Vaz has the prime minister's full support. End of story,'' the No 10 spokesman, Godric Smith told reporters.

As a civil servant, Mr Smith was unable to say whether Mr Blair had received Watford MP Claire Ward's letter of complaint about the way she and other members of the inquiry were treated by him back in 1994.

It was a party matter, relating to before 1997, he suggested. The previous day his boss, Alastair Campbell, was even more robust. So was Mr Blair at Commons question time, and Robin Cook in his statement of support.

Yet now Mr Vaz's reputation is looking a tad dodgy. His lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman insists that Mr Vaz has been cleared of everything except for a minor point.

But each and every case looks a little bit dodgy. It just depends on your view of the standard of proof required.

A £250 gift to his office here, an £8 a month payment to his office there, a company set up by his wife and mother and run from his home address. Not really the image you want if you are a minister of the crown, even if you say it is all squeaky clean and above board.

It seems extraordinary the lengths to which Mr Blair and Mr Cook have gone to defend the man, and it can't be just because he is the first Asian minister appointed by New Labour.

Mr Cook waxes lyrical about Mr Vaz's ability and his knowledge of everything, particularly his responsibility for passports and visas at the FO. Mr Blair seems to think the whole affair is being cooked up by the media.

Over the last two days Godric Smith and Alastair Campbell have been quizzed about this. Mr Campbell was asked: "Has Mr Blair actually read the standards and privilege's committee's report?" ''He's looked at it,'' he said. Had Mr Campbell read it? ''I've looked at it pretty carefully.''

Still the questions remained unanswered. Is Mr Blair simply protecting his minister until after the election? MPs ask. Or did he sack the wrong minister in the Hinduja passports affair, Peter Mandelson, not Mr Vaz?

The answer is increasingly looking like yes to both questions, and Mr Vaz himself might soon see the need to go himself.

So far he is carrying on as if nothing has happened. That could be fatal. It may not be a sleaze tale of the proportion of the Neil Hamilton and Tim Smith "cash for questions" variety, but it sure stinks and he shouldn't be in government at the moment.

fields.headline: Modernising local government: the basics
fields.trailText: • Councils are undergoing a revolutionary shake-up in their political structures. The century-old committee system is on its way out, to be replaced by new town hall mayors, powerful council managers and Westminster-style cabinets.
fields.body:
 Councils are undergoing a revolutionary shake-up in their political structures. The century-old committee system is on its way out, to be replaced by new town hall mayors, powerful council managers and Westminster-style cabinets.

 These new "executives" will mean the day-to-day running of councils is handed to a small number of councillors - up to 10 in the case of a cabinet, and just one in the case of a mayor. The rest will be involved in setting their authority's policy framework, and scrutinising the executive's work.

 Councillors overwhelmingly prefer the cabinet option, but they do not have the final say. Voters can force their authority to hold a referendum for a mayor if they produce a petition signed by 5% of the local electorate.

 The government argues that the new structures will make local government more open, accountable and efficient.

 Opponents say the changes will put too much power in the hands of too few people, particularly where voters choose a mayor. They worry that the scrutinising councillors will be excluded from decision making, creating two tiers of local politician.

fields.headline: Diamond loses her sparkle
fields.trailText: 3pm: Anne Diamond has been axed from ITV show Live Talk after just one series, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Anne Diamond has been axed from her ITV show after just one series.

Insiders at daytime chat show Live Talk say she was dumped because she was considered too old-fashioned and didn't appeal to younger, more upmarket viewers.

She is being replaced by Paul McCartney's girlfriend Heather Mills, who is joining anchorwoman Kaye Adams and ex-EastEnders star Nadia Sawalha for the second series.

The decision by Granada TV bosses not to renew their contract with Ms Diamond will come as a blow to the former breakfast TV presenter.

Just weeks ago she was signed up as a star columnist on the Daily Express and described how she was looking forward to returning to the show.

A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a new producer and a new controller in the department and they wanted to give Live Talk a much sparkier and edgier feel to the show."

The show started life as Loose Talk and starred Ms Kaye, Ms Sawalha and Sun columnist Jane Moore.

It was then revamped and renamed with Ms Diamond taking over from Ms Moore.

Ms Diamond hoped the series would lead to a revival of her TV career. This now looks seriously in doubt.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Sony desktop
fields.body:
Sony desktop
Sony is to make its long-promised move into the UK desktop PC market in early summer. At a press conference last week in Munich, Germany, it unveiled the PCV-LX1, a PC similar to models recently launched in Japan and the US.

In typically bullish Sony style, the company promised to "add excitement and originality to the PC market". And while the PCV-LX1 doesn't exactly turn PC design on its head, it does sport an innovative dual hinge LCD screen that can be used either upright or virtually flat on a desk.

Sony is keeping the model's full specification under wraps, although it did confirm that the PC will run Microsoft's Windows Me (Millennium) operating system, feature an integrated CD-RW/DVD drive and arrive with a selection of Sony and Adobe digital imaging software installed. It also has a generous array of sockets, including five USB ports, an Ethernet port, two iLink connectors, and slots for memory sticks and PC cards. The PC is expected to retail for between £1,800 and £2,000. Other desktops are to follow later in the year.

The company has also announced upgrades to its Vaio notebook PC range. Due shortly are five new models in the desktop replacement FX series, two new ones in the high-end portable Z600 range, and a new lightweight SR model. Also new is the PCG-QR10, a take- anywhere budget notebook PC that sports black casing and an aluminium handle designed for easy carrying. The model's fairly basic specification includes an Intel Celeron 650MHz processor, 64MB of memory, a 10GB hard drive, a 13.3-inch TFT LCD screen and an integrated CD-rom drive and modem.

The major downside is the inclusion of the large Vaio logo on the casing, which not only gives free advertising to Sony, but also alerts would-be thieves that the user is carrying a laptop PC.

Due to arrive in UK shops in the next couple of weeks is Sony's long-awaited take on the PDA - the Clie. The slim purple-and-silver handheld PC marries traditional Sony Vaio features, such as a memory stick slot, digital-imaging software and a jog-dial control, with the Palm PDA operating system. Sony has also promised users that a selection of Clie gadgets, which fit into the unit's Memory Stick slot, will become available over the following months. These include a digital camera, a GPS system and a fingerprint detector. A connector for hooking the unit to a mobile phone, allowing the Clie to browse the web using its integrated AvantGo software, is also on the cards. However, potential buyers should note that the lead is only compatible with Sony mobile phones.

Also due in the stores shortly is a 128MB version of Sony's Memory Stick storage card, which is to retail for around £200.

Finally, in among a host of DVD players, surround sound systems and hi-fi components, Sony announced it would feature two potential replacements for the VHS VCR in 2002. Video fans will be offered both a DVD recorder, compatible with the rival DVD+RW and DVD- RW recording formats, and a hard disk-based recorder, almost certainly developed in conjunction with the TiVo group in the US.

Digital take
Olympus has unveiled a digital take on its best-selling Mju range of film cameras. The new model, the Camedia C1, shares its siblings' sleek minimalist styling, although as it has to accommodate extra digital features and a SmartMedia card slot, it is slightly larger.

Targeted at non-technical users, the C1 has a budget price tag of around £275, which is reflected in its modest selection of features. Image resolution is rated at 1.34 megapixels - significantly less than most Olympus digital cameras. Still shots (there is no moving image facility) are stored on the 8MB SmartMedia card that accompanies the camera.

Other facilities include a 3.8cm TFT LCD screen, a 2x digital zoom, a selection of pre-programmed auto-exposure modes, and a self-timer.

The Camedia C1 goes on sale next month.

fields.headline: TV bosses fear defeat in World Cup battle
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: BBC and ITV bosses have privately conceded that they may lose the battle for World Cup rights, reports Dan Milmo.
Mar 7: Kirch heads for World Cup talks
Mar 6: Mogul who rules the World Cup
Mar 5: BBC sports chief slams Kirch
Feb 16: MPs warn Kirch over World Cup rights
fields.body:
Senior executives at the BBC and ITV have privately conceded they may lose the battle to broadcast the next World Cup.

The broadcasters have been told by legal advisers that German media group Kirch, which owns the rights to the 2002 tournament, could get around UK laws designed to keep the event off pay-TV.

"There are fears within the industry that the legislation only protects the rights to bid for the coverage, not to show it," said one TV executive.

However, today the heads of BBC and ITV sport came out fighting against Kirch's demands that the next World Cup should be on pay-TV.

"We have been asked far far too much for these rights. We have an ambition at ITV to transmit this World Cup but we will not do it at any price as I think the public and the government are fully behind us," said Brian Barwick, controller of sport at ITV.

BBC head of sport Peter Salmon added that the corporation was "disappointed" Kirch had not responded to its original bid for the football championship.

"We want to sit down with Kirch and talk about it. We are amazed that one month after making our offer that they still have not agreed to sit down and talk to us.

"We have put a full value on these rights and we are disappointed they have not sat down and talked to us."

webTitle: Going for a song: Peter Blake's artwork on an Ian Dury tribute album.

fields.headline: Going for a song
fields.standfirst: Why did Peter Blake, creator of the world's most famous record cover, take on a tribute album to Ian Dury?  Robin Denselow  finds out - and explains how you can help Comic Relief by bidding for the new artwork
fields.trailText: Why did Peter Blake, creator of the world's most famous record cover, take on a tribute album to Ian Dury? Robin Denselow finds out - and explains how you can help Comic Relief by bidding for the new artwork.
fields.body:
Back in the early 1970s, when Peter Blake was teaching at Waltham Forest College in east London, the grand old man of British pop art used to "booze quite a lot". He would never leave home before 9am - which meant he was often late for work. Arriving late at the start of one term, he found his new class had already been sent out to do some sketching. Among them was Ian Dury, who later became the lead singer of the Blockheads.

"I thought I'd pop into a pub - only to find that Dury and other students were already there. Instead of saying, 'Let's get working,' I suggested we all had a drink, and after that Ian did a very nice painting. I think he was a bit shocked by a teacher being all right, and from then on we were friends, right through."

Dury died last March, and now he is remembered in a tribute album called Brand New Boots and Panties. Blake designed the album cover and the original artwork is being auctioned through the Guardian in aid of Comic Relief.

"I think," says Blake, "that Ian would have liked this. It's a unique piece, and these are rather valuable photographs." It is late evening, and the artist is in his London studio, finishing off a gloriously cheerful portrait of his old friend.

Around the edges of the portrait - based on a 1970s picture by the rock photographer Penny Smith - are bright borders in green, red, yellow and blue. "Those are the sort of borders that Ian used in his paintings," says Blake. "He liked bright colours. He probably borrowed the idea from me, so I'm borrowing it back from him." Outside those borders, neatly stuck down, are a number of signed Polaroids, which Blake feared he had lost earlier in the day. They would have been hard to replace.

All the artists on the album contributed these snapshots, and they are something of a Who's Who of British pop. There's Paul McCartney, whom he still sees, since Blake created the iconic album cover, for Sgt Pepper. Then there's Robbie Williams, Sinead O'Connor, Billy Bragg, Madness, Shane MacGowan, and members of the Blockheads, who provide the backing on most of the tracks. In the central painting, Dury is wearing a T-shirt with a picture of Joe Strummer of the Clash. Strummer, in his Polaroid, is wearing a T-shirt with a picture of Elvis. "A nice kind of link," says Blake. The whole is a remarkable piece of art, and deserves to raise a hefty sum.

Blake rated Dury as a painter ("He was good - very graphic"), and taught him again when he took a job at the Royal College of Art, soon after Dury "and a whole group of other Walthamstow ruffians" were accepted there. Later, Blake helped find him a flat near where he was living in Chiswick, and he even got him work. "I was doing a lot of graphics, but when my painting became successful, I passed a lot of jobs on to Ian from the Sunday Times or the Observer. They were very brightly coloured, second generation pop art. He was very talented."

But Dury moved on to music, despite the disabilities caused by childhood polio. When Blake first met him he even had problems walking: "He was always losing his balance and falling over." But he built up his strength to become a compelling stage performer, first with Kilburn and the Highroads, then with the Blockheads, and to create his unique mix of punk, funk and English music hall. He stopped painting, though Blake remembers - "he kept taking photographs, and with the Kilburns, he painted his amps with orange and green diagonal bands similar to imagery I used - and which I have now used again on that portrait."

The pop star and the painter still kept in touch - Blake even toured with Dury and the Blockheads. When Blake held an exhibition at the Tate in 1983, he decided to include a list of all the bad reviews he had received - and then match them with good reviews from his pop star friends such as McCartney, Pete Townshend and Dury. Dury also composed a theme song for the exhibition, "so as you went in, you heard Ian singing Peter The Painter. Last year, Paul McCartney followed that tradition by providing Blake with a "sound collage" for an exhibition that recently ended at Tate Liverpool.

fields.bodyText: Back in the early 1970s, when Peter Blake was teaching at Waltham Forest College in east London, the grand old man of British pop art used to "booze quite a lot". He would never leave home before 9am - which meant he was often late for work. Arriving late at the start of one term, he found his new class had already been sent out to do some sketching. Among them was Ian Dury, who later became the lead singer of the Blockheads. "I thought I'd pop into a pub - only to find that Dury and other students were already there. Instead of saying, 'Let's get working,' I suggested we all had a drink, and after that Ian did a very nice painting. I think he was a bit shocked by a teacher being all right, and from then on we were friends, right through." Dury died last March, and now he is remembered in a tribute album called Brand New Boots and Panties. Blake designed the album cover and the original artwork is being auctioned through the Guardian in aid of Comic Relief. "I think," says Blake, "that Ian would have liked this. It's a unique piece, and these are rather valuable photographs." It is late evening, and the artist is in his London studio, finishing off a gloriously cheerful portrait of his old friend. Around the edges of the portrait - based on a 1970s picture by the rock photographer Penny Smith - are bright borders in green, red, yellow and blue. "Those are the sort of borders that Ian used in his paintings," says Blake. "He liked bright colours. He probably borrowed the idea from me, so I'm borrowing it back from him." Outside those borders, neatly stuck down, are a number of signed Polaroids, which Blake feared he had lost earlier in the day. They would have been hard to replace. All the artists on the album contributed these snapshots, and they are something of a Who's Who of British pop. fields.headline: At a glance: media select committee recommendations
fields.standfirst: The main recommendations of the Commons media select committee report on the communications white paper
fields.trailText: The main recommendations of the Commons media select committee report on the communications white paper.
fields.body:
Ofcom
 The new regulator should be required to report annually to Parliament on progress towards the government's aim of making Britain the most dynamic and competitive media and communications market in the world.

 It should have distinct objectives for consumer protection and promoting open and competitive markets.

 It must take a key role in driving analogue TV switch-off and broadband take-up and report annually to Parliament on progress towards both goals.

 It should prioritise commercial provision of unmetered internet access.

Department of Communications
 A separate department of communications should be set up with its own secretary of state. The new department would take over responsibility for broadcasting and media from the Department of Culture, Media and Sport; telecoms and internet from the Department of Trade and Industry; electronic delivery of government services from the cabinet office; and video regulation from the Home Office.

Cross-media ownership
 Existing cross media ownership rules should be removed, leaving general competition law, sector specific regulatory powers and content regulation by licensing.

BBC
 The House of Commons should be allowed to consider the future regulation and governance of the BBC as part of the upcoming communications bill.

 Ofcom should take over the culture secretary's current responsibility for approving new BBC services.

Public service broadcasting
 In future the government should focus on providing public service content from the most appropriate source, rather than protecting the privileges of certain broadcasters for their own sake.

Switchover from analogue to digital TV
 The government should establish a kite-marking scheme for integrated digital TV sets by October 2001.

 A public information campaign on digital TV, including the leafleting of every UK home and advertisements on all free-to-air channels, should be launched by the government and TV industry by October 2001.

Radio
 The communications white paper should remove all ownership restrictions specific to radio.

 The Radio Authority should identify pilot schemes for expanded community radio projects to launch before the communications white paper becomes legislation.

 A fund, financed mainly from general taxation, should be established to provide money to launch and run non-commercial community radio services.

Internet
 The promotion of internet access via digital TV should become a higher government priority.

 Ofcom should be explicitly prevented in law from regulating internet content.

webTitle: NUJ fears for future of Express

fields.headline: NUJ fears for future of Express
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: The NUJ has condemned the Express for its "demoralising" treatment of editorial staff, after letters were sent out today warning that one third of the editorial staff are to be axed.
Mar 15: Union warns of cuts
Mar 15: Sports staff face axe
Mar 14: Northern & Hell for high earners
Mar 14: More jobs to go at Express
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
The NUJ has condemned the Express for its "demoralising" treatment of staff, after letters were sent out today warning that one third of the editorial jobs are to be axed.

And the union warned that "there is a real fear for the future of these papers if the cuts go ahead".

Jeremy Dear, the NUJ's national newspaper organiser, warned the union was "extremely determined to avoid damaging cuts, both in terms of the number of staff and the conditions of the remaining staff".

Letters are going out to 540 editorial staff today, informing them Express Newspapers wants to cut 145 editorial and support posts over the next three months. The company confirmed that 130 of these are editorial jobs.

Mr Dear hinted that strike action was a possibility as details of the redundancy programme unfold.

"I'm sure that resolution will come up at some point over the next few months," he said. "Whether that time is now or further down the line, it's too early to say."

A spokesman for Express Newspapers said the redundancies would be subject to a three-month consultative period, with the first consultation expected to start by April 10.

The spokesman said: "The management of Express Newspapers wants radically to change the culture of the way newspapers work, and they believe it will be possible to maximise capabilities significantly."

He refused to comment on speculation that job cuts would be largely from the Express and Sunday Express, or that areas such as showbusiness and sport would bear severe cuts.

Journalists at the paper say Express owner Richard Desmond has already singled out foreign travel for sports journalists as excess to requirements. This would make several posts redundant.

Asked to comment on speculation that the Express plans to scrap its newsdesk in favour of subbed agency-generated copy, the spokesman said: "All newspapers use agency copy extensively and the Express will continue vigorously to use agency copy."

The letters will ask journalists whether they want to be consulted on an individual basis or through the unions.

Completed forms must be returned by March 20.

Mr Dear said the company had not yet asked staff to volunteer for redundancy, although it claims it wants the redundancies to be achieved voluntarily.

"I'm sure, given what's gone on there over the past few months, that there are people who will be tempted by redundancy," he said.

"But we are asking people to think about the remaining staff who will be left there after the redundancies - if they go ahead - are completed."

Senior journalists who have worked with the paper in the past are astounded by Mr Desmond's action.

One said: "We all know that the good journalists disappear - they take the redundancy money in the knowledge that they can get employment elsewhere. I really think this is a step too far."

webTitle: Man cleared of Veronica Guerin's murder

fields.headline: Man cleared of Veronica Guerin's murder
fields.trailText: John Gilligan was today cleared at Dublin's special criminal court of ordering the murder of the prominent Irish investigative journalist.
fields.body:
John Gilligan was today cleared at Dublin's special criminal court of ordering the murder of Irish investigative journalist Veronica Guerin.

Gilligan, 48, was also cleared of four charges of possessing firearms and ammunition but was found guilty of 11 charges of importing cannabis resin into Ireland.

Judge Diarmuid O'Donovan told the packed non-jury court that he had "grave suspicions" about Gilligan's involvement in the 1996 shooting of Guerin, 37, who had received death threats after exposing Dublin's drugs gangs.

But the judge said the uncorroborated evidence of Gilligan's former criminal associates was not enough to convict him. Gilligan was extradited from England to face trial.

Ms Guerin, a crime reporter with the Sunday Independent newspaper, was shot six times as she sat in her car on the outskirts of Dublin on June 26, 1996. Her death sparked public outrage and one of the biggest murder investigations in the history of the state.

Two men, Paul Ward and Brian Meehan, are currently serving life sentences following their convictions for her murder in 1998 and 1999 respectively. The prosecution alleged that the pair acted under the "control and command" of Gilligan.

Three former criminal associates of Gilligan, all now serving time in jail while under the state's witness protection programme, gave evidence against him during the course of his 43-day trial.

Judge O'Donovan said while there was independent evidence to corroborate the allegation that Gilligan was the "prime mover" in a massive drug importation racket, he must be acquitted on the separate weapons-related charge and the most serious offence of murder.

The judge told the court that despite his suspicions of Gilligan's role in the murder: "The court is not persuaded beyond reasonable doubt that this is so. And therefore the court is required by law to acquit the accused on that charge."

Terence McDonald, defending, described Russell Warren's account of witnessing the murder of the journalist as "a complete fabrication". Mr McDonald said that Warren, currently serving five years for money laundering and for stealing the motorbike used in Ms Guerin's shooting, must be treated "potentially as an accomplice in the murder of Veronica Guerin".

Judge O'Donovan said in delivering the court's verdict: "It is the view of the court that the only evidence which was heard that could possibly implicate (Gilligan) in the murder of Veronica Guerin was that of Russell Warren.

"His evidence is so suspect that the interests of justice demand that it not be relied upon except when corroborated by independent evidence." There was, however, "no corroboration whatsoever".
