fields.headline: Big business at your service
fields.standfirst: WTO rules could force governments to privatise their basic functions
fields.trailText: The United States does not grow many bananas. Yet under a virtually unknown trade agreement it won a case challenging the European Union's support for small Caribbean banana producers. The dispute was initiated under the General Agreement on Trade in Services (Gats), after pressure from banana-growing multinationals and a large donation from Chiquita to the Democratic party in the US.
fields.body:
The United States does not grow many bananas. Yet under a virtually unknown trade agreement it won a case challenging the European Union's support for small Caribbean banana producers. The dispute was initiated under the General Agreement on Trade in Services (Gats), after pressure from banana-growing multinationals and a large donation from Chiquita to the Democratic party in the US.

Bananas need to be distributed, and distribution is a service under Gats. Such is the scope of what has been termed the most important trade agreement since 1948.

Negotiations begin this month on the extension of Gats. If powerful industry lobbies have their way, Gats would undermine the ability of governments to act in the interests of the poor, workers, consumers and vulnerable groups in society. These powers are being replaced by new rights for multinational companies.

Government rules on the provision of services are at the heart of the way societies treat their citizens. In 1994 Gats was signed as part of the agreements that set up the World Trade Organisation (WTO). It includes basic services such as health care, education, water supply; infrastructure such as communications, post and public transport; cultural services, including films, broadcasting, museums and libraries; as well as finance, retail, professional services and tourism. The commonly used definition of services is "anything you can't drop on your foot". The 160 sectors included under Gats account for most of the world's economy.

The multinationals that stand to benefit were deeply involved in the negotiations to establish Gats. Lobbying by groups such as the US Coalition of Service Industries and the European Services Forum has kept up the pressure.

Trade agreements on products have focused mainly on external barriers, such as tariffs. Gats is different. Most of the rules that are regarded as "barriers to trade" are local and national government rules and policies. Gats includes commercial presence in services, and has been described by the WTO as "the world's first international investment agreement". It includes many of the provisions of the failed Multilateral Agreement on Investment, which was abandoned after a strong civil society campaign.

There are two types of provisions under Gats. The first types are the commitments that governments make to open up their service industries. These are supposed to be voluntary offers, but in the real world they are not. Developing countries face unfair negotiations, complex agreements, tiny budgets and few government staff, and no assessment on the likely impacts of Gats. Their negotiators are coming under pressure to open up services in return for concessions on other unfair WTO agreements, such as in agriculture. There should be no trade-off. Developing countries should not be required to pay for the failure of agriculture policies in the rich world.

The second types of provisions cover all service sectors. Included is the requirement that regulations should not be more burdensome than necessary (interpreted as burdensome on the corporations selling services). The WTO could have applied criteria to insist that regulations are "as equitable as possible" or "as environmentally sound as possible". But Gats elevates the interests of corporations above other aims.

Governments claim that public services are safe because Gats excludes services provided "under the exercise of government authority". But Gats does apply if services are supplied commercially or in competition with the private sector. There are few service sectors in most countries that do not include some element of service provision by companies, such as in broadcasting, private medicine and education.

The cornerstone of the agreement is a commitment to continuous liberalisation. Gats has a ratchet mechanism - governments can liberalise more, but not less. And Gats commitments are in effect irreversible. This removes the rights of democracies to vote for stronger regulation or more public sector involvement in the economy.

Yet there is increasing evidence of the social costs of gung-ho privatisation and liberalisation. Many developing countries have had these policies imposed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as a price for receiving debt write-off or new loans. In many cases private monopolies have replaced the public sector, resulting in higher prices and poorer service.

One example was a botched privatisation of the water system in Cochabamba, Bolivia. The US multinational that bought the system doubled prices to many users, so poor families were paying more for water than for food. They were even charged for collecting rainwater on rooftops. After huge demonstrations the privatisation was replaced by local water supply. This reversal would have been practically impossible under Gats.

Privatisations gone wrong in rich countries have included the rail system in Britain, electricity in California and water in New Zealand. The deregulatory approach under Gats also threatens universal access to public services, workers' rights, environmental regulations and public health.

Campaigners round the world are waking up to the threat of Gats. An international statement is calling for a halt to negotiations, and for reform of the core of the agreement. The debate is not between those who want more rules and those who want none, but over whose rules will be applied, and for whose benefit. Corporate rights must not be allowed to take precedence over all other aims.

Barry Coates is director of the World Development Movement. For further information see its website: www.wdm.org.uk
fields.bodyText: The United States does not grow many bananas. Yet under a virtually unknown trade agreement it won a case challenging the European Union's support for small Caribbean banana producers. The dispute was initiated under the General Agreement on Trade in Services (Gats), after pressure from banana-growing multinationals and a large donation from Chiquita to the Democratic party in the US. Bananas need to be distributed, and distribution is a service under Gats. Such is the scope of what has been termed the most important trade agreement since 1948. Negotiations begin this month on the extension of Gats. If powerful industry lobbies have their way, Gats would undermine the ability of governments to act in the interests of the poor, workers, consumers and vulnerable groups in society. These powers are being replaced by new rights for multinational companies. Government rules on the provision of services are at the heart of the way societies treat their citizens. In 1994 Gats was signed as part of the agreements that set up the World Trade Organisation (WTO). It includes basic services such as health care, education, water supply; infrastructure such as communications, post and public transport; cultural services, including films, broadcasting, museums and libraries; as well as finance, retail, professional services and tourism. The commonly used definition of services is "anything you can't drop on your foot". The 160 sectors included under Gats account for most of the world's economy. The multinationals that stand to benefit were deeply involved in the negotiations to establish Gats. Lobbying by groups such as the US Coalition of Service Industries and the European Services Forum has kept up the pressure. Trade agreements on products have focused mainly on external barriers, such as tariffs. Gats is different. Most of the rules that are regarded as "barriers to trade" are local and national government rules and policies. Gats includes commercial presence in services, and has been described by the WTO as "the world's first international investment agreement". It includes many of the provisions of the failed Multilateral Agreement on Investment, which was abandoned after a strong civil society campaign. There are two types of provisions under Gats. The first types are the commitments that governments make to open up their service industries. These are supposed to be voluntary offers, but in the real world they are not. Developing countries face unfair negotiations, complex agreements, tiny budgets and few government staff, and no assessment on the likely impacts of Gats. Their negotiators are coming under pressure to open up services in return for concessions on other unfair WTO agreements, such as in agriculture. There should be no trade-off. Developing countries should not be required to pay for the failure of agriculture policies in the rich world. The second types of provisions cover all service sectors. Included is the requirement that regulations should not be more burdensome than necessary (interpreted as burdensome on the corporations selling services). The WTO could have applied criteria to insist that regulations are "as equitable as possible" or "as environmentally sound as possible". But Gats elevates the interests of corporations above other aims. Governments claim that public services are safe because Gats excludes services provided "under the exercise of government authority". But Gats does apply if services are supplied commercially or in competition with the private sector. There are few service sectors in most countries that do not include some element of service provision by companies, such as in broadcasting, private medicine and education. The cornerstone of the agreement is a commitment to continuous liberalisation. Gats has a ratchet mechanism - governments can liberalise more, but not less. And Gats commitments are in effect irreversible. This removes the rights of democracies to vote for stronger regulation or more public sector involvement in the economy. Yet there is increasing evidence of the social costs of gung-ho privatisation and liberalisation. Many developing countries have had these policies imposed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as a price for receiving debt write-off or new loans. In many cases private monopolies have replaced the public sector, resulting in higher prices and poorer service. One example was a botched privatisation of the water system in Cochabamba, Bolivia. The US multinational that bought the system doubled prices to many users, so poor families were paying more for water than for food. They were even charged for collecting rainwater on rooftops. After huge demonstrations the privatisation was replaced by local water supply. This reversal would have been practically impossible under Gats. Privatisations gone wrong in rich countries have included the rail system in Britain, electricity in California and water in New Zealand. The deregulatory approach under Gats also threatens universal access to public services, workers' rights, environmental regulations and public health. Campaigners round the world are waking up to the threat of Gats. An international statement is calling for a halt to negotiations, and for reform of the core of the agreement. The debate is not between those who want more rules and those who want none, but over whose rules will be applied, and for whose benefit. Corporate rights must not be allowed to take precedence over all other aims. Barry Coates is director of the World Development Movement. For further information see its website: www.wdm.org.uk

webTitle: In brief: maverick director talks up Javier Bardem's Oscar chances

fields.headline: Maverick director talks up Javier Bardem's Oscar chances
fields.standfirst: Plus: legendary cinematographer dies; Goodfella Ray Liotta turned down Sopranos; Jason Priestley takes on presenting gig on TV
fields.trailText: Plus: legendary cinematographer dies; Goodfella Ray Liotta turned down Sopranos; Jason Priestley takes on presenting gig on TV
fields.body:
 Who would back rank outsider Javier Bardem to win the Oscar for Best Actor for his role in Before Night Falls? The film's director, for one. Abstract artist turned angry movie-maker Julian Schnabel has already been pouring scorn on Bardem's rivals for the award, dismissing the Tom Hanks showcase Cast Away as "idiotic" and deeming Geoffrey Rush's performance in Quills to be "no big deal". Having tackled his rivals, Schnabel then turned on his own side, lambasting Before Night Falls's backers Fine Line for not spending enough money promoting it. They probably reasoned that with Schnabel trumpeting the film at every opportunity, they had little need to.

 The legendary cinematographer John A Alonzo died at his California home on Tuesday at the age of 66. The son of Mexican migrants, Alonzo became one of his profession's most respected artists and his style of soft focus-saturated colour became synonymous with a certain strain of classic 70s American cinema. Alonzo worked on the road-movie Vanishing Point, the acclaimed Norma Rae and the cult favourite Harold and Maude, but remains best known for the startling visual style he brought to Roman Polanski's Chinatown.

 GoodFellas star Ray Liotta yesterday told NBC's Today program that he has turned down a role in the TV show The Sopranos in favour of concentrating on feature films. "It was a two-year commitment and I didn't really want to give up that time now," said Liotta, who can currently be witnessed eating unusual foodstuffs in Ridley Scott's Hannibal. But the 45-year-old actor did say he would consider a smaller role in the acclaimed Mafia drama. "I would love to do a guest spot on there. Having done GoodFellas, it's definitely a genre I'm familiar with."

 Former Beverly Hills 90210 mainstay Jason Priestley has been signed on as a co-presenter on ABC sports coverage of Indy Racing League events in the US. The chirpy star of Love and Death on Long Island certainly has some first-hand knowledge of dangerous driving. In 1999 he was convicted of being drunk behind the wheel of his Porsche.

fields.headline: A life inside
fields.standfirst: A friendship comes under strain after Rinty visits the prison pychologist, and the truth about Feckles is uncovered
fields.trailText: A friendship comes under strain after Rinty visits the prison pychologist, and the truth about Feckles is uncovered.
fields.body:
'All I'm saying . . ." I was in Big Rinty's cell, sitting on the end of his bed. Rinty was perched on the edge of his soft-backed chair, in the corner opposite the head of his bed. "You're saying nothin', 'cos ah don't want te know," he interjected, poking his half-rolled cigarette at me for emphasis.

"I decided to try one last time. "But Feckles . . ."

"Fuck Feckles!" Rinty exclaimed. "He's a nonce. He's a grass. You're as bad as him. I'm telling you - I'm not interested."

His outburst silenced me. I knew he was under stress because of his psychology call-ups. But I still felt hurt by this accusation. It was undeserved and he knew it. He sat back in his chair and finished rolling his cigarette. "Fair enough," I said. He flipped his lighter and lit the roll-up. Soon he was engulfed in clouds of blue smoke.

We didn't speak over the next few days. Since Rinty and I live just a few cells apart, it made life a little more uncomfortable than usual. But I refused to blank him. Nothing raises attention more on a spur than a couple of long-termers falling out, actively ignoring each other and allowing the imagined wounds to fester.

Whenever we passed on the spur or met in the meal queue or recess I would nod politely and force a half smile. I was loath to attempt a conversation. Another angry retort from my pal would only have increased the distance between us. Neither did Rinty blank me. He always acknowledged my nods with the same, and a slight raise of the eyebrows.

All I had been trying to do was to share a little information I'd picked up about John Feckles. He was nobody especially important, certainly not to me. My only knowledge of him came from having encountered him twice before in different prisons.

From what I had seen I knew Feckles was into prison politics and that he was adept at agitating the easily led into food strikes or sit-downs. My view, for what it was worth, was that being around someone like that was likely to make doing time even more unpleasant. So his company was to be avoided when possible.

That was the main reason I'd never exchanged more than a few words with him. Another reason was that I'd had it on good authority some years earlier that Feckles's best friend in prison was a man who secretly acted as an informant for the authorities. I had no idea if Feckles was an informant, too. But the fact that he always secured moves to open prisons long before his EDR (earliest date of release), in spite of being the antithesis of a model prisoner, led me to surmise that he probably was.

Not that I have anything against informants. Good intelligence is essential to the safety of those who live and work in prison. But prisoners who inform on others rarely do so in order to benefit the community. On the contrary, with rewards ranging from pay bonuses to positive parole recommendations on offer, informants enter a moral fog where falsehood and fabrication thrive and where principles are often sacrificed at the altar of self- interest.

Feckles had only been here a couple of days and already he had a small gang of acolytes. When I first mentioned his presence - only to Rinty and Felix the Gambler - all I said was: "A wise man would keep him at arm's length." It was all they needed to know.

Within a week of his arrival I learned from a good source that in his last jail Feckles had had his locker broken into. "Deps" (depositions) in which it was stated that he had ceased to be a police informant in 1988 had been stolen and circulated. This was salient information. It was what I was trying to relate to the big Dundonian when he almost bit my head off.

Even though I'd taken slight umbrage at Rinty's attitude I understood that he wasn't really angry at me. He was angry because for the past few months he has been duelling with the prison psychologist - whom he calls "the astrologist". "According to him, I've done nothing positive in 22-years of jail," he said to Felix and me after his last interview. "All he wants to know is which boxes have I ticked on the forms he keeps giving me to fill in. It's a joke."

Only it's not a joke. Risk assessment does seem to depend more and more these days on box ticking and mathematical formulas. Personally, I don't think you can beat keeping your ears to the ground, and discreet observation. Subjective maybe, but I was right about Feckles.

 The writer is serving a life sentence. He will not be paid for this article.

webTitle: International: Macedonia brink of civil war

fields.headline: Macedonia 'on the brink of an explosion'
fields.standfirst: Fighting between police and rebels could mean civil war in Macedonia
fields.trailText: Macedonia appeared to be on the brink of civil war last night as fighting between police and ethnic Albanian rebels erupted close to Tetovo, the country's second largest city, and threatened to ignite another Balkan conflagration.
fields.byline: Nick Wood near Tetovo, Macedonia and Rory Carroll  in Ostrovica, Kosovo
fields.body:
Macedonia appeared to be on the brink of civil war last night as fighting between police and ethnic Albanian rebels erupted close to Tetovo, the country's second largest city, and threatened to ignite another Balkan conflagration.

At least seven policemen were injured in the violence, which marks the spread of the ethnic Albanian insurgency into north-western Macedonia.

Meanwhile, Yugoslav security forces, with Nato's consent, rolled into the buffer zone between Kosovo and Serbia yesterday to push back rebels who had occupied the Presevo valley.

The artillery and machine gun fire which could be heard coming from hills a mile from Tetovo seemed to be getting closer to the city. The latest clashes began on Wednesday and took place 35 miles from previous incursions.

"The situation is horrible. They're shooting at our positions with various types of weapons. There is a major attack under way," said Stevo Pemdarovski, a spokesman for the Macedonian interior ministry.

Around 200 ethnic Albanian rebels were reported to be involved in the fighting, which is taking place in and around the village of Larce. Mr Pemdarovski blamed the attacks on the National Liberation Army, an ethnic Albanian rebel group that emerged in Macedonia two months ago.

"We are at the brink of an explosion. I don't know what they have in mind, there may be attacks on other towns in Macedonia. We are there with all our forces _ but they have hand weapons, mortars and heavy weapons. They've built these up over a long period of time. These are not new ones."

The spreading conflict casts doubt on Macedonian claims that the guerrilla groups did not have a solid base inside the country but were coming in from Kosovo.

Last night fires began to burn in the wooded hills surrounding Tetovo and flares lit up the sky. Young men watched from the city's main square. "We've been waiting for this moment for 40 years," said one man who refused to be named. "We have nothing here, no work or any rights."

Opposition to the ethnic Macedonian government has been strong among Tetovo's majority Albanians for a long time. Albanians make up over a quarter of the Macedonian population, but their language has yet to be given official recognition in the constitution.

Further north, on Kosovo's eastern border, convoys of Serb military trucks and armoured personnel carriers churned into the Presevo valley at dawn yesterday, disgorging paratroopers and paramilitary police into wooded hills controlled by ethnic Albanian guerrillas.

Nato peacekeepers watched from helicopters and observation posts as the Serbs plodded through fog and mud to reclaim the southern tip of the three-mile buffer zone created in June 1999 to separate the two armies.

Since January last year ethnic Albanian extremists have exploited the vacuum to arm and train a guerrilla force - the Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac, known by its Albanian initials UCPMB - to bomb and shoot the lightly armed Serb police officers who patrolled the area, which is inside Serbia.

From Ostrovica ridge, just inside Kosovo, Yugoslav army units could be seen waving flags and making three-fingered victory signs as they fanned into the countryside. Under terms agreed with Nato they cannot use tanks, enter villages nor fire first if confronted by rebels.

Their task will be to cut rebel supply lines without repeating the atrocities committed two years ago against ethnic Albanian civilians. To demonstrate good faith, Slobodan Milosevic's successors named the mission Operation Peace.

Belgrade and the guerrillas signed a 20-day ceasefire on Monday but few expect it to last that long. Several detonations, thought to be mortars, rocked the area two hours after the Serbs arrived but it was not known who fired.

webTitle: Nato refuses to intervene in Macedonian conflict

fields.headline: Nato refuses to intervene in Macedonian conflict
fields.trailText: Police and ethnic Albanian guerrillas clashed outside Macedonia's second-largest city for the second day running as news came that Nato has refused to intervene in the conflict.
fields.body:
Police and ethnic Albanian guerrillas clashed outside Macedonia's second-largest city for the second day running as news came that Nato has refused to intervene in the conflict.

The Macedonian government today tried to curtail an insurgency that has spread from the countryside towards the city of Tetovo. Police reported sporadic clashes with the Albanian rebels on the slopes of Mount Sar Planina, just north of the city. Machine gun and mortar fire could be heard from three villages throughout the morning. There were no reports of casualties.

There were long lines at petrol stations in Tetovo - with a population of around 80,000 - as the mostly Slavic residents began to flee the predominantly ethnic Albanian town. Shops remained closed today and most residents stayed indoors.

Southern Serbia remained edgy but calm early today, a day after Yugoslav troops moved into an area held by ethnic Albanian insurgents. The Nato-brokered ceasefire between the rebels and Belgrade appeared to be holding.

Nato declared today that it stands "shoulder-to-shoulder" with Macedonia's government but made clear that it will not send combat troops to help fight ethnic Albanian rebels.

A Nato official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said fighting in the southern Balkan country was a domestic issue and that the alliance does not consider this a foreign invasion, despite claims the insurgents are operating out of Kosovo.

Kosovo has been under Nato and UN control since June 1999, when the alliance forced Yugoslav police and troops out of the province following a 78-day bombing campaign. Nato maintains logistical troops in Macedonia to support the peacekeeping mission in Kosovo.

"Nato believes the government of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has the situation in hand," the official added.

Nato allowed the Yugoslav troops to deploy forces in the 25-square-kilometre (10-square-mile) area near the boundaries with Kosovo and Macedonia. This was done to stem the guerrillas' uprising and to prevent the movement of weapons and fighters into Macedonia. Nevertheless, this successful deployment was overshadowed by the fighting in Macedonia.

Police spokesman Stevo Pendarovski said that yesterday's clashes began when around 15 rebels opened fire on police in Kale, a suburb of Tetovo a mile north of the town's centre, and in the nearby village of Selce.

"The situation is exceptionally serious," Mr Pendarovski said. One person was killed yesterday according to prime minister Ljubco Georgievski. Raim Thaci, director of the Tetovo hospital, said at least 14 people were wounded, including 11 policemen.

Mr Georgievski said that today the authorities would discuss the introduction of a nationwide state of emergency, due to the deteriorating security situation. This measure would mean sealing off Macedonia's borders, beginning a general army and police mobilisation, implementing a partial curfew and introducing a ban on public gatherings and movements of larger groups of people.

Ethnic Albanians account for at least a quarter of Macedonia's 2m people, dominating western regions of the country and a large section of the capital, Skopje.

Until yesterday rebel activity had been limited to villages on the northern border with the Serb province of Kosovo. Government troops had hoped to keep the fighting away from urban areas.

webTitle: Stella McCartney's Chloe label grows up

fields.headline: Stella McCartney's Chloe label grows up
fields.trailText: Other British designers in Paris have been busy falling out with their employers so badly as to get their own shows cancelled (McQueen), or creating catwalk drama with boxing gloves, skipping ropes and giant Peruvian hats (Galliano). Stella McCartney has been applying herself to what we might like to wear.
fields.body:
Other British designers in Paris have been busy falling out with their employers so badly as to get their own shows cancelled (McQueen), or creating catwalk drama with boxing gloves, skipping ropes and giant Peruvian hats (Galliano). Stella McCartney has been applying herself to what we might like to wear.

Chloe for autumn/winter 2001 was an elegant, sure-footed show, full of gentle wit and lovingly crafted, detailed clothes. The cheeky Chloe of gold chain vests and pineapple print T-shirts was nowhere to be seen. With a diffusion line aimed at a younger, thriftier customer launched recently, the mainline collection has grown up.

But Kate Moss, Liv Tyler and the other beautiful young things who dotted the front row will find plenty to covet.

Luxurious fabrics and sophisticated colours took on a modern sensibility in the of-the-moment silhouettes and tongue-in-cheek detailing. The show opened with a fur coat - fake, of course, McCartney being an advocate for animal rights, but cut to give a very realistic effect. Worn with a skirt suit, the coat could have looked rather stuffy, but worn Chloe-style over tight jeans, high pointy boots and a wide, low slung belt it looked dead-on hip.

McCartney's trademark sexy hipster trousers looked particularly ravishing in velvet, graded from coffee to cream as if bleached by the sun.

Velvet skirts, gathered into a bustle at the back, were worn with pale gold drape-sleeved blouses in pale gold trailing epaulettes of pearls from the shoulder, or with backless sweaters in the softest ivory cashmere.

Lacquered satin dresses were draped across the shoulders and softly ruched at the hips, in undulating sand dune prints of mushroom or dusty pink.

All around the entrance to the show the word Gucci had been spraypainted on the pavement. This apparently was a coincidence, with no significance regarding unconfirmed rumours that McCartney was considering leaving Chloe to return to designing under her own name, backed this time by the Italian powerhouse Gucci.

The rumours stem from alleged sightings of McCartney in Paris. Her contract with Chloe is believed to expire in June. However, she was linked to Gucci two years ago, when she was tipped to replace Ford at the house - and the rumours proved to be unfounded.

webTitle: Top fashion house turns to another young British star

fields.headline: Top fashion house turns to another young British star
fields.standfirst: Givenchy goes for glamour by giving top job to Welsh designer Julien Macdonald
fields.trailText: In another coup for British fashion, the 28-year-old Welsh designer Julien Macdonald was yesterday appointed to the top job at the Paris label Givenchy.
fields.byline: Jess Cartner-Morley, fashion editor, in Paris
fields.body:
In another coup for British fashion, the 28-year-old Welsh designer Julien Macdonald was yesterday appointed to the top job at the Paris label Givenchy.

The house of Hubert de Givenchy, who famously dressed Audrey Hepburn in Sabrina, will now be headed by the man who dressed Kelly Brook in a sparkly pink dress and matching knickers for the premiere of the Guy Ritchie film Snatch.

Dubbed "the Welsh Donatella Versace" for his sexy, sparkly creations, Macdonald, is one of the stars of London Fashion Week but he is best known as the creator of the revealing dresses that have landed Kelly Brook, Kylie Minogue and Joely Richardson on recent front pages.

Accepting an award for British glamour designer of the Year last month, Macdonald said: "I love glamour, I love beautiful women and I love sparkly frocks."

Macdonald, who is on holiday in Bali, yesterday released a statement saying that the Givenchy job was "a dream come true". He added: "Being given the chance to design for such an amazing house is a fabulous opportunity."

The appointment was feted by Macdonald's celebrity fans. The singer Kylie Minogue, when told of the appointment as she was about to go the stage, said: "His glittering aesthetic is a celebration of the female form - his devotion to glamour is absolute."

The supermodel Jodie Kidd, one of Macdonalds favourite models and a close friend, said it was "absolutely awesome, brilliant amazing news". Speaking from Miami, where she is holidaying with friends, she added: "He's a fantastic designer and he really deserves it. I'm very, very excited for him."

But Macdonald's appointment is likely to attract sneers from some quarters. Not everyone feels that Macdonald, who currently designs a mini-collection for the Marks & Spencer Autograph line and whose designs were called "common" by one prominent fashion critic last week, has the necessary gravitas for the venerable house of Givenchy, which celebrates its 50th anniversary next year.

Undoubtedly, Macdonald's recent collections have sometimes been overshadowed by his showbiz sensibilities - one show featured a Michael Jackson lookalike in the front row, while last autumn's catwalk show featured Anna Nolan, then a media star through Channel 4's Big Brother, and a dress studded with £650,000 of De Beers diamonds.

But Macdonald is a formidable design talent. He was born in Merthyr Tydfil, where his father still works in the town's Hoover factory, and studied at the Royal College of Art. While still a student he caught the eye of Karl Lagerfeld, who appointed him head knitwear designer for Chanel's couture and ready-to-wear collections. Macdonald's innovative cobweb knit techniques won critical acclaim, and in 1997, aged just 24, he designed Chanel's best-selling outfit of the year.

In the same year Macdonald launched his own name label. Later that year, he staged his first runway show. Among those who turned up to show support was a fellow young British designer, Alexander McQueen.

In a strange twist, it is McQueen who Macdonald replaces at Givenchy. Since the retirement of its founder, Givenchy has a history of appointing British designers: before McQueen, the post was held by John Galliano, now at Christian Dior.

Untenable

McQueen's position has been virtually untenable since late last year when he sold a majority stake in his own name label to Gucci Group, the arch-rivals of Givenchy's owners, LVMH. An increasingly visible split between designer and house led to the radical downsizing of January's couture show and of tomorrow's ready-to-wear show, which will be McQueen's last at Givenchy.

"I am really excited about his [Macdonald's] appointment", said the president of Givenchy, Marianne Tesler, yesterday. "His design sensibility is very representative of the Givenchy woman - classy, modern, elegant, sexy and feminine."

Myron Ullman, managing director of LVMH, added: "The talent and taste of this young designer correspond ideally to the Givenchy clientele."

The house of Givenchy, proud of its links with Audrey Hepburn, is no doubt hoping that Julien Macdonald's "sparkly dresses" will bring a new generation of glamorous Hollywood stars into the Givenchy fold.

The timing of yesterday's announcement could not have been more Machiavellian. Not only did it succeed in further undermining McQueen's final show for Givenchy - heralding his successor before his last collection has even been unveiled - it was leaked just as the audience was assembling for the Yves Saint Laurent show, the centrepiece of the Paris fashion week calender for Gucci Group.

It has not yet been confirmed when the Welsh designer will take up his new post. However, a Givenchy spokeswoman, Katie Weisman, said that "the logical thing" would be for Macdonald to make his Givenchy debut at the July couture shows. A spokeswoman for Marks & Spencer said Macdonald's contract to design another collection for the store chain still held "as far as we know", although Givenchy may be less than keen on their head designer moonlighting on the high street.

It is likely that Macdonald's new post will also mean forfeiting his own name label for the time being - a blow for London Fashion Week.

Alexander McQueen, the departing Givenchy designer, speaking from the front row of the show by Yves Saint Laurent, a stablemate of his label at the Gucci Group, said only: "Good luck to him."

Designers abroad

 John Galliano - First appointed to LVMH-owned Givenchy in 1995, promoted to designer at Christian Dior in 1996, succeeding Gianfranco Ferre. He has since turned the label into one of the most controversial but successful brands of its type. Galliano also designs his own label, which is shown in Paris.

 Alexander McQueen - The outgoing talent behind Givenchy, the British Designer of the Year is rumoured to be showing from next season in Milan. This follows the acquisition of his own label company by the Gucci Group.

 Stella McCartney - The powerhouse behind Parisian label Chloe, Stella has confounded critics since her appointment in 1997. In her time at the label, she has more than tripled sales. Rumours suggest McCartney will soon leave Chloe to set up her own label in Paris.

 Hussein Chalayan - Chalayan has just designed his last collection for US label TSE New York. His own label currently in voluntary liquidation, it is rumoured that Chalayan will show abroad when he returns to the fashion schedule next season.

Antonio Berardi - A contemporary of McQueen, Berardi designs for the Italian label Exte. Although his shows used to be one of the highlights of London Fashion Week, he now presents his collections in Milan.

 Clements Ribeiro - The husband and wife design duo Suzanne Clements and Inacio Ribeiro have been behind the revival of French label Cacherel for the past two seasons. They also show their own line collection in London.

 Giles Deacon - The little-known young London designer has been transforming Italian label Bottega Veneta into one of the must-see shows of the Milan calendar. The make-over has been such a success, a majority stake in the company has been bought by Gucci Group.

 Luella Bartley - The 27-year-old London-based designer, this season decamped to Milan to show her hit eponymous collection at the Bottega Veneta headquarters. By showing abroad, Bartley found the costs were much lower than they would be for putting on a catwalk presentation in London.

fields.headline: Guilt by association
fields.standfirst: A correlation is not the same as a cause
fields.trailText: The report on parents' employment and children's school results paid for by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and carried out by John Ermisch and colleagues at Essex University is a rum affair.
fields.body:
The report on parents' employment and children's school results paid for by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and carried out by John Ermisch and colleagues at Essex University is a rum affair. The JRF is a valuable source of knowledge about society; Professor Ermisch has always been a rigorous researcher. Yet here correlations are turned into causes and unfounded statements made about women as workers and mothers - the most trumpeted of which is the claim that children of mothers who work full-time during most of their pre-school years do less well at A-level and are more at risk of unemployment and stress. The authors are not responsible for the way some newspapers interpreted the findings. But they are to blame for a tendentious presentation of what turn out to be puzzles rather than finished analysis.

Essex specialises in "longitudinal" studies that follow the same people over a span of time. Thus A-level results can be linked back to experience pre-school. Linked to, not shown to be caused by. Fathers who worked a lot when their children were under five (this finding was not highlighted in the ostensibly family-friendly press) are linked, later, with less unemployment among their kids and at the same time worse 18-plus results.

What this kind of study cannot tell us is much about the quality of childhood. Childcare differs markedly, within and outside the home. The brute fact of a mother's going out to work predicts nothing about a child's life chances in and of themselves. Professor Ermisch found an association in time between the full-time employment of a mother with a pre-school daughter and the likelihood that, 15 to 20 years on, she would not become pregnant before the age of 21. In other words the same mothers "causing" poor A-level results were also prophylactic. The research report admits that it "does not clarify the mechanisms through which such an effect might work". Indeed.

webTitle: Five different endings for Planet of the Apes

fields.headline: Five different endings for Planet of the Apes
fields.trailText: Tim Burton is keeping audiences guessing about the climax of his remake of the science fiction classic by filming five different endings
fields.body:
Those who trip along to Tim Burton's new version of Planet of the Apes confident in their apparent knowledge of the film's ending - the revelatory sight of a decayed Statue of Liberty rising from the sand - may have a surprise in store. The maverick director has apparently filmed no fewer than five separate finales for his film in order to keep the public guessing.

Then again, the film's backers have always made it clear that the Fox production will be no mere retread of the 1968 original. The studio has dubbed it "a re-imagining, not a remake" and Burton and screenwriter William Broyles are thought to have thrown in numerous ideas of their own.

The picture stars Mark Wahlberg as the embattled human, Estella Warren as his love-interest, Kris Kristofferson as a rebel leader and Helena Bonham Carter as a liberal-minded chimp. Charlton Heston (the star of the 1968 movie) and George Clooney (a friend of Wahlberg's) are thought to have taken brief cameos as apes in the film.

Fellow cast-member Michael Clarke Duncan has seen all five separate endings, but isn't saying which one Burton has gone with. All he will reveal is that the new, improved finale is "fantastic" and "will blow your mind". But then he would say that, wouldn't he?

fields.headline: NUJ slams Reed sale
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Reed Business Information is planning to sell some 60 staff to a company based in Swanley, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Journalists at Reed Business Information in Sutton are up in arms after discovering that Reed is planning to sell some 60 staff to a company based in Swanley, Kent.

Reed Business Information is close to selling 10 business magazines to Highbury House Communications subsidiary Cumulus Business Media.

A Reed spokesman confirmed that 10 magazines were up for sale, mostly covering the retail industry

Titles include Independent Retail News, Checkout and Electronics World.

But NUJ members at Reed are unhappy about the move, partly because of the change to travel arrangements and also because they claim Highbury House offers journalists poorer contracts.

NUJ Father of Chapel at Reed Patric Cunnane said "Swanley is not somewhere people will find it easy to travel to. It's no secret that people are unhappy about it.

"We believe that the terms and conditions at Highbury House are inferior. We want to ensure that they transfer union recognition over to what is at present a non-union house," he added.

A spokesman for Highbury House would only say the company was in "advanced talks".

On the issue of moving staff to Swanley, he said: "The cost of the location is an important one. But the location, as with all the other parts of the deal, is subject to ongoing negotiations."

fields.headline: Thursday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are up the duff and back on the toot
fields.trailText: Mark Viduka has denied rumours linking him with a £16m move to Roma. "I don't want to talk about leaving Elland Road because it is just not an option at the moment," he said. "My words at the press conference the day before the game were taken out of context and twisted."
fields.body:
Mark Viduka has denied rumours linking him with a £16m move to Roma. "I don't want to talk about leaving Elland Road because it is just not an option at the moment," he said. "My words at the press conference the day before the game were taken out of context and twisted."

Sunderland are on the verge of completing a £3m deal for Inter Bratislava striker Szilard Nemeth, according to the Express. Although the player could sign on a Bosman free in the summer, Peter Reid will try to land the 22-year-old before next week's transfer deadline in order to ward off interest from Manchester United.

Chelsea are willing to swap Sam Della Bona for Internazionale's Clarence Seedorf, according to the latest whispers. But the Stamford Bridge club are playing it down. "We admire Seedorf, he is a great player and of course if he became available no doubt we would be an interested party," a spokesperson told Teamtalk. "But to think that we would want to lose Sam Della Bona is crazy."

Stan Collymore has been offered a cut of gate receipts to play for his first club Stafford Rangers. But according to Southend manager David Webb, who has also tried to sign the now-retired player, Stan is off to Hollywood to make his name in Tinseltown. "I spoke to his agent but Stan is off to New York to try to make his name in films," said Webb.

Bradford defender Andy O'Brien is now the official subject of a £1.5m bid from Newcastle. However, the move is in danger of collapse as Bradford are insisting on a sell-on clause in the contract.

Middlesbrough are confident Dean Windass will be officially registered as their player before the derby at Newcastle this Saturday.

David Hopkin is set for a £600,000 return to Crystal Palace. The Bradford midfielder is the latest player on his way out of Valley Parade as part of Jim Jefferies' wage-cutting purge.

An unnamed Premiership club is showing an interest in Utrecht defender Patrick Zwaanswijk, according to the player's agent. Planet Football reports how the 26-year-old, one of the best uncapped defenders in Holland, desires a move to England, quoting agent Piet Buter: "We hope it is true, we don't have official contact, but there are rumours and a host of clubs from England are watching. He might move next, next year or not until five years, but people have spoken and a Premiership club does have his name."

fields.headline: Patching up addicts
fields.standfirst: Nicotine replacement therapies are to be made available on the NHS. But, asks  Sarah Ebner, will they really help to wean smokers off cigarettes?
fields.trailText: Nicotine replacement therapies are to be made available on the NHS. But, asks Sarah Ebner, will they really help to wean smokers off cigarettes?
fields.body:
On Saturday, it will be a fortnight since Emma Strangwayes-Booth last had a cigarette. "I was really ill a few weeks ago," she says. "I had a viral infection of my airways and couldn't breathe. It was really horrible and I'm sure I was iller because I'd been smoking for so long."

Strangwayes-Booth, 26, has been smoking for 13 years and has often thought of giving up. "I always found it really hard," she says, "and all the things you can buy to help seem so expensive." But yesterday she decided to hang the expense and buy her first nicotine replacement patches. They cost her £14.73 for seven.

Strangwayes-Booth is exactly the kind of person the Department of Health hopes will give up smoking for good. Yesterday - No Smoking Day - the public health minister, Yvette Cooper, announced that nicotine replacement therapies (NRT) would soon be available via NHS prescriptions.

The new policy, starting at the end of April, will cost the government between £10m and £40m a year - pennies compared with the £1.7bn that the NHS spends on smokers annually. It means that GPs will be able to prescribe NRT products such as nicotine patches, gum and inhalers to smokers who want to quit. It will be up to individual GPs to decide who gets what, but those recipients will be benefiting financially. One £6 prescription will be enough for two weeks' supply. At the same time, some NRT products will be made available at supermarkets.

Strangwayes-Booth, a receptionist at Goldcrest Films in London, is impressed by the plan. "I think it's a really good idea for the NHS to try to help people stop smoking, and I would definitely go to my doctor to get a prescription," she says. "It's also sensible to be able to buy patches or gum at the same places you can buy cigarettes, rather than have to go to a chemist."

The plans are part of New Labour's heavy emphasis on public health. Its 1998 white paper introduced a multitude of targets, from healthy eating to cutting heart disease, including three aimed at cutting down smoking. A fourth anti-smoking target, aimed particularly at the poorly paid, was added as part of the NHS cancer plan. Its target is a reduction in the number of smokers among manually skilled workers from 32% to 26% by 2010.

"NRT will be available on prescription, because research shows that it doubles the chance of people giving up smoking," says an NHS spokesman. "But it's also because we particularly need to help people in lower-income groups. They tend to smoke more and may find the cost of NRT prohibitive."

But this doubled success rate only applies if you are ready to stop. Taking NRT cannot make you more committed to giving up smoking or transform you into a non-smoker, although it can help end the psychological habit of reaching for a cigarette.

Professor John Britton, a consultant in respiratory medicine at Nottingham city hospital, admits that many smokers simply cannot quit. Over the course of a year, he says, only around a fifth of those who try to give up manage to do so permanently. And that includes those who go by his favoured method - using nicotine replacement therapy and getting behavioural support.

"NRT is not enough on its own. When you're trying to stop smoking, you need to be taught ways of dealing with times when having a cigarette seems like a good idea."

Mary Ostle would second that. A heavy smoker for 35 years, she was getting through 25 to 30 cigarettes a day before deciding to quit last November. But Ostle, a nurse from Middleton St George, near Darlington, says it was preparation that helped her.

"So much more needs to be done for smokers. I managed to give up through determination, by knowing that having a cup of coffee made me want a cigarette, so not drinking coffee any more. But more support is needed. There aren't nearly enough smoking cessation clinics."

She tried a Nicorette Inhalator, but says she only used it around four or five times. "I didn't find it a lot of help," she says. "It was kind of a prop, something to carry around, and it was very expensive. I'm sure many people wonder why they should spend money on that when they can buy a packet of fags for less money and enjoy themselves."

Because of this, she is convinced that the government's plans are exactly what are needed. "I'm sure this will be a success," she says. "But it's about time it happened."

"I've been calling for this for years," says Britton. "NRT is an extremely efficient clinical treatment which saves lives and doesn't cost much money. It hasn't made sense to deny it to those who are addicted. Other addicts get help. Why shouldn't those addicted to nicotine?"

In addition, he says, nicotine replacement therapy is a safe way to try to give up. The treatments work by giving people the nicotine they are addicted to, but in a way that is safe and controlled.

"There's a misconception about the dangers of smoking," he says. "People think that it's nicotine that causes cancer, but that's not true. Cigarettes are dangerous because of the other things in them. It's the tar and other products of the cigarette which cause the harm." In other words, people smoke for the addictive nicotine, but it is not the most damaging substance.

"A cigarette delivers nicotine into your blood and that goes into your brain directly," says Britton. "It's all very quick. The nicotine replacements don't work like that. You take them in through your skin, your mouth or your nose and they have to go right round your body to get to your brain. It's diluted and that's safer."

Strangwayes-Booth is keen to try out her new patch. "I really want to give up smoking this time," she says. "But I haven't been to the pub yet. The patch will be coming with me, when I do, and I really hope it works."

fields.headline: A need for more powers
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Downey calls for stronger control over MPs in the wake of the Vaz affair

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: As the former parliamentary commissioner for standards, I view allegations of misconduct against politicians with suspicion until they are proved. Yet I cannot help thinking, in the light of some recent events, that MPs need to watch their system of self-regulation rather carefully if public trust is not to be forfeited.
fields.body:
As the former parliamentary commissioner for standards, I view allegations of misconduct against politicians with suspicion until they are proved. Yet I cannot help thinking, in the light of some recent events, that MPs need to watch their system of self-regulation rather carefully if public trust is not to be forfeited.

The case for a parliamentary commissioner was made by the Nolan committee in 1995. It found that politicians were held in dangerously low esteem and that, although self-regulation could be supported in principle, it should be reinforced by the introduction of a code of conduct and an independent commissioner.

One of the commissioner's functions is to review and, if he or she thinks appropriate, to investigate complaints about the conduct of individual MPs. Previously, these had been handled by a select committee of the House which, all too often, had allowed itself to be influenced by party political considerations.

The procedure went some way towards addressing this problem. The commissioner undertakes the investigation and, in doing so, has discretion to range as widely as necessary to reach conclusions. The findings are then reported to the committee of standards and privileges who, in turn, report to the House. Although final decisions therefore rest with MPs, their response will be judged against the reports of the independent commissioner, which have, without exception, been published, albeit at the discretion of the committee.

The procedures will only work well if there is a positive commitment by parliament to uphold high standards and an acceptance by individual MPs that it is their personal responsibility to abide by the code of conduct and to cooperate fully with any inquiries resulting from it.

It is the collective and individual commitment which needs to be watched carefully because the House will ignore it at its peril. Clearly it is not for me to comment on individual cases because I am not in possession of the facts but there have been a number of incidents recently which are a cause for some concern.

I think it is important for the committee and the House to remember that, in their capacity as MPs, ministers and shadow ministers have exactly the same obligations under the code of conduct as backbenchers. It cannot be wholly coincidence that disagreements between the committee and the commissioner have almost invariably arisen on cases involving ministers or former ministers. Particularly for members of the committee, it needs a conscious effort to put aside considerations of deference or ambition in reaching decisions on the actions of those who may carry influence in the party hierarchies.

This may be an argument for a larger representation on the standards and privileges committee of senior respected members such as the present chairman, Robert Sheldon, who may be less concerned with future preferment.

In addition, the commissioner needs the wholehearted support of the committee if the process is not to be undermined. In a recent investigation I was dismayed to hear that the commissioner had sought evidence from an MP and witnesses and that this had been denied.

At present the commissioner does not have the power enjoyed by select committees of sending for "persons and papers". In my view, if the evidence is needed for the completion of the inquiry it should have been called for by the committee on the commissioner's behalf, when any refusal would then be a contempt of the House. If this is not the accepted practice, the commissioner's authority is permanently damaged and the independence of the particular investigation is compromised.

A further aspect which struck me as unhelpful to the investigative process was what appeared to be a dominant position taken by lawyers acting for MPs and witnesses. The code of conduct is not a legal document and, having helped to draft it, I know it was never intended to be interpreted as such. These were not criminal proceedings but allegations of misdemeanour under the code.

If, as I have suggested, members should be expected to cooperate with proper inquiries, the interposition of lawyers will often merely confuse the issues. This is not to say that lawyers can be excluded altogether if those concerned want to seek advice from them. But in my view they should be discouraged from taking a prominent role and should certainly not be permitted to "represent" an MP or a witness or to refuse cooperation on behalf of their client.

I am not suggesting that the present procedures do not work perfectly well in a majority of cases: nor do I believe that standards in parliament are falling.

Nevertheless it is essential to see that the system we have is not compromised and my belief is that it could be improved by a few modest, but important steps. The House should commit itself periodically to maintaining high standards and remind individual members (including those on the frontbenches) that they have a personal obligation to cooperate with the standards and privileges committee and with the commissioner. When the committee is reconstituted, it would benefit from a higher representation of senior members. The commissioner should be given the powers to publish his or her reports and to send for "persons and papers", instead of relying on the committee at second hand.

Within parliament, the integrity of the system depends on a mutual confidence between the committee and the commissioner. The House can always choose a new commissioner but whoever holds the position should be given wholehearted support.

But it is not sufficient that parliament and its officials should be at ease with themselves. It is vital that the public, too, should have confidence in the process and this is something many MPs too often forget.

 Sir Gordon Downey was parliamentary commissioner for standards from 1995-98.

webTitle: Danny Boyle decision may mark end of Trainspotting team

fields.headline: Danny Boyle decision may mark end of Trainspotting team
fields.trailText: Danny Boyle, John Hodge and Andrew Macdonald could be about to go their separate ways after Boyle signs to direct Tick-Tock, a big budget Hollywood thriller
fields.body:
British director Danny Boyle has signed to direct the high-concept thriller Tick-Tock for Columbia studios. The Los Angeles-based production takes the Trainspotting director out of his native UK and possibly signals a split with regular collaborators Andrew Macdonald and John Hodge.

Tick-Tock, which plays out in real time during one afternoon in the run-up to Christmas, tells the tale of an amnesiac who is forced to assist an FBI agent in tracking down a series of bombs that are planted in shopping malls around LA. Meanwhile, the amnesiac struggles to regain his memory and work out whether he actually planted the devices. The script was written by Charles Mondry and Anthony Bagarozzi, who thrashed out the idea while working at Tower Video in LA's Orange County.

Last year Boyle served as the director on two TV plays - Strumpet and Vacuuming Completely Nude in Paradise - that were written by Jim Cartwright. But Tick-Tock will be his first feature film without producer Macdonald and writer Hodge.

Boyle, Macdonald and Hodge first came to fame with the Scottish noir Shallow Grave in 1995, then followed that up with the mammoth critical and commercial hit Trainspotting the following year.

But in recent years the trio have shown signs of strain. They suffered their first flop with 1997's A Life Less Ordinary and were reportedly stung by the controversy and negative critical response to their ambitious, American-funded backpacker saga The Beach, starring Leonardo DiCaprio. In the event, The Beach performed fairly well at the box office, but the experience is thought to have soured their partnership and hastened their split.

Hodge recently wrote the media satire The Final Curtain for director Patrick Harkins, with Macdonald on board as executive producer. Boyle, meanwhile, appears to have gone his own way. As yet un-cast, Tick-Tock shoots in the autumn.

fields.headline: Rooke takes top job at iVillage
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Former Carlton Online operations director Phil Rooke has resurfaced at women's portal iVillage, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Former Carlton Online operations director Phil Rooke has resurfaced at women's portal iVillage.

Mr Rooke takes the role of chief executive officer.

He is joined by Alastair Pinkney, former head of strategic planning at the now-defunct Express Digital Media, who will look after client sales.

iVillage has been seeking a chief executive for some time and, according to insiders, held talks with Ellis Watson, international chief of Celador, about the position earlier this year.

Mr Rooke left Carlton Online, now Carlton Interactive, three months ago after more than two-and-a-half years with the company.

He is not fazed by being a man in charge of a women's website.

"This role combines my enthusiasm for the women's market - gained from my years at NatMags - with my passion for the internet and the online advertising industry," he said.

Before Carlton, Mr Rooke worked at the National Magazine Company, the Daily Telegraph, the Press Association and Scoot.

iVillage UK launched in December as part of a £46m joint venture between US women's network iVillage.com, which recently merged with Women.com, and Tesco.

webTitle: 3i gains BA's clearance to land Go deal

fields.headline: 3i gains BA's clearance to land Go deal
fields.trailText: Go, British Airways' low-cost airline, is expected to be sold to 3i, the venture capital group, later this month after BA announced yesterday it had awarded the private equity firm exclusive negotiating rights.
fields.body:
Go, British Airways' low-cost airline, is expected to be sold to 3i, the venture capital group, later this month after BA announced yesterday it had awarded the private equity firm exclusive negotiating rights.

The sale will fetch around £100m, the figure mentioned for some months, yet well below the £300m forecast by analysts when BA announced its intention to sell.

The deal will almost certainly lead to Barbara Cassani remaining as Go's chief executive. She is popular among staff at the company's Stansted headquarters and this week announced the establishment of a second base at Bristol.

Until this week, KLM and 3i were vying for the company, but the Dutch carrier confirmed yesterday it would not be putting in a final bid. The company said: "This is due to the valuation as well as to the complexity of the deal in terms of regulatory approval. We have a non-binding proposal based on our assessment of a fair valuation. It is not in the interests of its shareholders for KLM to pay more."

BA said it expected to complete the sale by the end of the month or shortly afterwards.

It cost £25m to set up Go in May 1998 but the airline only recently began to make a profit. BA's original plan was to back Go for three years. But the arrival of Rod Eddington as BA's chief executive last March has hastened the sale.

Mr Eddington has been culling BA's peripheral activities, including loss-making European routes from Gatwick. Go has been sold because it competes on some routes with BA flights.

BA's reorganisation has also led to a reduction in staff by natural wastage from 63,000 to 59,000 in little over a year.

In the next few weeks, BA and 3i will negotiate the complicated transfer. The move will be welcomed by shareholders, who have been waiting for a decision for several months.

The deal will be a coup for 3i, enhancing its European status. Rival venture capitalist Electra Partners pulled out of the auction this month.

The impending sale details came after news from Rome that Alitalia and Air France are discussing closer links. Alitalia's new chief executive, Francesco Mengozzi, said both companies were looking "in all directions" and hoped to sign a global alliance soon.

It cost £25m to set up Go in May 1998 but the airline only recently began to make a profit. BA's original plan was to back Go for three years. But the arrival of Rod Eddington as BA's chief executive last March has hastened the sale. Mr Eddington has been culling BA's peripheral activities, including loss-making European routes from Gatwick. Go has been sold because it competes on some routes with BA flights. BA's reorganisation has also led to a reduction in staff by natural wastage from 63,000 to 59,000 in little over a year. In the next few weeks, BA and 3i will negotiate the complicated transfer. The move will be welcomed by shareholders, who have been waiting for a decision for several months. The deal will be a coup for 3i, enhancing its European status. Rival venture capitalist Electra Partners pulled out of the auction this month. The impending sale details came after news from Rome that Alitalia and Air France are discussing closer links. Alitalia's new chief executive, Francesco Mengozzi, said both companies were looking "in all directions" and hoped to sign a global alliance soon.

fields.headline: Prison terms for illegal adoptions
fields.standfirst: Internet babies case prompts tough new sanctions and illegal adoptions could lead to prison sentences
fields.trailText: Internet babies case prompts tough new sanctions and illegal adoptions could lead to prison sentences
fields.body:
Jail sentences for people avoiding child protection procedures by adopting children from overseas will be introduced by the government next month in the wake of public concern over the "internet babies" case.

It will become a criminal offence to bring a child into the UK from another country for the purposes of adoption without first gaining approval from a recognised adoption agency. Prospective adoptive parents bringing children to Britain without first passing these tests will be subject to a prison term of up to three months, a £5,000 fine or both.

The tough approach will be announced today by John Hutton, the health minister responsible for adoption and social care, as he publishes legislation introducing the first comprehensive overhaul of British adoption law for 25 years.

The bill is expected to get a quick second reading debate in the Commons, but is not likely to complete its passage through parliament before the election.

The speed of its introduction was dictated by a slip of Tony Blair's tongue during exchanges in the Commons about the twins brought into Britain in January by Alan and Judith Kilshaw. The north Wales couple bought the babies through a child broker advertising on a Californian website.

Health ministers wanted to legislate this year, but the prime minister said the bill would come in the present session. It is expected to have more than 100 clauses, including a right of appeal for prospective adopters who believe they have been unreasonably turned down by the adoption agencies.

Criminal sanctions against people bringing in children from abroad without prior vetting will be introduced by regulation next month under legislation on inter-country adoptions passed two years ago. These powers will only work against those intending to complete the adoption under UK law.

Ministers are considering using the new bill to target those - such as Mr and Mrs Kilshaw - who complete adoption formalities abroad before bringing the children back into Britain. The bill will include powers to prosecute internet service providers relaying advertisements for adoption agencies that would be illegal under British law. Service providers would be told if they were providing links to websites selling children for adoption and expected to block the material.

Other measures in the bill include financial allowances for adoptive parents and a streamlined system to reduce the time children spend in council care. A national adoption register will be given statutory backing.

Mr Hutton will say the legislation should increase the number of adoptions from 3,000 to 4,000 a year - and more than that in the longer term.

The government will claim that hundreds of children a year can be given a better start in life if they can be moved more quickly from council care into adoptive families.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said: "I welcome the bill, but we get adoption legislation only once every quarter century. We have got to get it right. This must not go through on a groundswell of public reaction to a particular case. Children are too important for that."

Social workers are perceived by the public as interfering, ineffective and excessively bureaucratic, according to a survey published yesterday as the Local Government Association launched a campaign to restore public confidence. More than one in six jobs in social care work is now vacant and two-thirds of social services departments have reported difficulties in obtaining staff.

fields.headline: Newspaper giant puts website up for sale
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Trinity Mirror is putting its ic24 internet service provider up for sale and slashing online spending, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Newspaper giant Trinity Mirror is putting its ic24 internet service provider up for sale and is slashing its online spending in a bid to turn around its sluggish performance.

The publisher of the Mirror and the Birmingham Post, which spent £42.3m on internet ventures last year, will cut its planned three-year internet spending from £150m to £90m after admitting revenues were "significantly below expectations".

Trinity's stock has underperformed the media sector by 30% since it merged with the Mirror group 18 months ago, and investors have been clamouring for a shift in strategy.

The ic24 operation will be put up for sale in a market that is extremely wary of internet companies, but analysts expect Trinity to recoup the £25m it has invested in the service.

European internet firms T-Online and Tiscali are both looking for a way into the lucrative UK market and are early favourites to bid for ic24, which had 250,000 subscribers.

However, the news came as Trinity Mirror announced strong growth in its core newspaper business and said the fragile advertising market was holding up well.

The UK's largest newspaper publisher said pre-tax profit before digital investment was £196.4m last year, compared with £175.1m for 1999.

Turnover rose from £995m to £1.05bn.

Newspaper publishers have been fighting the twin demons of escalating newspaper print prices and falling advertising revenues, but Trinity said it remained confident about the company's prospects over the next 12 months.

"The sharp rise in newspaper print prices was an unhelpful start to the year. However, advertising in the national titles has improved significantly and recruitment advertising in the regional newspapers has remained strong since the beginning of the year," the group said.

Trinity has been best by management clashes, the City Slickers scandal which threatened to engulf Mirror editor Piers Morgan, and the task of integrating the Mirror titles.

On top of this, there have been wider concerns about the health of the advertising market and rising newspaper print prices.

Investors gave Trinity's announcement the thumbs up in early trading, marking its shares up nearly 3% to 473p.

fields.headline: Disgraceful and contemptuous - the secret verdict on Keith Vaz
fields.standfirst:
Row over resignation of Keith Vaz picks up momentum


Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The row over government minister Keith Vaz will be reignited today with the emergence of claims from a fellow Labour MP that he acted in a disgraceful, intimidatory and contemptuous manner towards a previous inquiry into his Leicester East constituency.
fields.body:
The row over government minister Keith Vaz will be reignited today with the emergence of claims from a fellow Labour MP that he acted in a disgraceful, intimidatory and contemptuous manner towards a previous inquiry into his Leicester East constituency.

Two letters sent by the Watford MP, Claire Ward, to senior officials within the party make serious claims about the way Mr Vaz obstructed an internal Labour inquiry. It is believed Tony Blair was made aware of worries over Mr Vaz's behaviour.

The letters, seen by the Guardian and obtained from outside Westminster, allege that the party has failed for years to deal with allegations of irregularities and "improper interference" by the minister in the running of his local council in Leicester. They were passed to the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin.

Ms Filkin interviewed the author of the letters on three occasions as part of her inquiries, culminating in last week's report which cleared Mr Vaz of most charges, but highlighted his unwillingness to cooperate and outright obstruction.

It is known the evidence from Ms Ward, revealing the way the minister for Europe treated Labour party members during the earlier inquiry, did not form part of the allegations against the minister for breaking the MPs' code of conduct, but did influence the way the commissioner viewed the whole affair. Further details of the report, expected to contain more of Ms Ward's criticism of the minister, will be published tomorrow.

In her report Ms Filkin commented: "I am bound to record the anxiety which Ms Ward expressed to me that if matters raised with the inquiry team by members of the Labour Party were not dealt with, they were likely to resurface." One Whitehall source who has seen the entire report said last night the letters show exactly what the inquiry has been up against.

The internal Labour party investigation, set up by the NEC, took place in 1994 over claims of irregularities in the membership of Mr Vaz's Leicester East Labour party and allegations that he had tried to interfere in city council business and bullied party members.

The investigation lasted three days, including one day of hearing evidence.

After the inquiry was wound up without conclusion, Ms Ward, a member of the NEC and the inquiry team, wrote to Tom Sawyer, then chairman of the Labour party, in 1995, saying: "I have now reached the point where I believe that Keith Vaz has been allowed to escape any investigation into the complaints made to the inquiry team by Leicester party members and that he is treating both those members and myself with contempt.

"I am not prepared to accept that a Labour member of parliament should be allowed to act in such a disgraceful manner. It would appear that others in the party feel intimidated by Mr Vaz and therefore may be cautious of taking any action. I can assure you that I do not take that view.

"I therefore propose to write to the leader, Tony Blair, advising him of this matter and specifically requesting that he become involved."

In a second letter, seen by the Guardian, to the Labour party's regional secretary in Nottingham, which was written three months after the one to Mr Sawyer, Ms Ward again accuses Mr Vaz of contempt, intimidation and claims that certain allegations were covered up. Ms Filkin says in her report: "These documents were supplied to me in confidence and I have not therefore thought it appropriate to attach them as annexes to this memorandum.

"They do however provide some background information about disagreements and disquiet in Leicester East constituency Labour party, in which at least some of those giving evidence to the inquiry team believed Mr Vaz to have had some part."

Ms Filkin rejected nine complaints that Mr Vaz failed to disclose cash donations of thousands of pounds to his office and charities which he supported. Eight other complaints could not be properly investigated by the commissioner after witnesses and Mr Vaz refused to cooperate or anwer any further questions about them.

Ms Ward last night did not want to comment about the disclosures.

Geoffrey Bindman, the lawyer representing Mr Vaz, described the documents as "irrelevant".

Mr Bindman said: "This information is completely irrelevant to any of the inquiries being made by the commissioner into Mr Vaz's behaviour over the MPs' code. Mr Vaz was anyway cleared of all but one of the allegations by the committee."

Mr Vaz was in Cyprus yesterday for talks with the island's Greek and Turkish communities. At a news conference in Nicosia, he declined to answer questions about whether he intended to resign, appealing in vain for questions about Cyprus instead.

Last night despite widespread unease among MPs about Mr Vaz's conduct - William Hague called it "obstruction and a lack of candour" - both Tony Blair and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, stood firmly behind the minister.

Mr Blair, who is said to have merely "looked at" the Filkin report, has been persuaded that Mr Vaz is a victim of unfair smears and media attacks.

During prime minister's question time Mr Blair told the Tory leader: "The committee of standards and privileges cleared my honourable friend of all the charges except one upon which they recommended no penalty."

But Mr Hague countered: "The minister has no need to hire an evasive lawyer (Geoffrey Bindman) when he's got the prime minister to defend him!" He said that Mr Blair could "keep his government 's integrity or his minister. He cannot keep both".
