webTitle: Royal stock portfolio takes a hit

fields.headline: Royal stock portfolio takes a hit
fields.standfirst:
Queen's stake in Getmapping.com drops 94% from record high

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Queen's 'annus horribilis' as a dot.com investor took a turn for the worse yesterday after shares in a firm she has backed slumped 42%. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
The Queen's "annus horribilis" as a dot.com investor took a turn for the worse yesterday after shares in the fledgling internet firm she has backed slumped a further 42%.

Shares in aerial photography specialist Getmapping.com fell 11.5p to an all-time low of 15.5p. They have dropped 94% from the high of 237.5p they touched shortly after floating last year.

The Queen has a 1.5% stake in the firm. At one stage her investment was worth more than £900,000 but last night it was valued at just £67,000. However, she is still making a paper profit. She paid £50,000 for the shares when Getmapping was a private company.

Dealers blamed yesterday's fall on a shareholder offloading a large line of stock.

Getmapping is compiling an aerial photography map of Britain which it aims to sell over the internet to estate agents, civil engineers and local authorities, as well as private individuals.

Its share price has fallen in line with those of many other dot.coms and it has said it that sales have been disappointing.

The company's stockbroker, Peel Hunt, predicts that loss-making Getmapping has enough cash to get it through 2001 but after that it will be relying on an overdraft to take it through to profitability. "This is quite a long-term story," said analyst Peter Joseph. "It's only selling a tiny number of maps over the web to private individuals but it shouldn't have to raise more money before it hits breakeven."

He estimated that Getmapping had about £2.7m cash in the bank at the end of December and would report a loss of about £2.5m when it publishes results for 2000.

Sales of a Doomsday millennium map dedicated to the Queen - the product that attracted her to the firm - have been particularly poor.

fields.headline: Straw castigated over 'appalling' jail
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has been strongly criticised by the chief inspector of prisons for failing over two years to prevent conditions getting worse inside Winson Green, Birmingham - by common consent the worst jail in Britain.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has been strongly criticised by the chief inspector of prisons for failing over two years to prevent conditions getting worse inside Winson Green, Birmingham - by common consent the worst jail in Britain.

Sir David Ramsbotham said in a report published today that the appalling conditions which he revealed in a 1998 report have got worse.

He made clear his frustration that Home Office ministers, including Mr Straw, reacted to his earlier findings by demanding £860,000 of budget cuts in Birmingham instead of sending in a taskforce and extra funds as they had done with other failing prisons.

"Having already appealed to ministers without success, what is the chief inspector of prisons meant to do or say, and to whom, when he and his team return to a prison, only to find that, despite some peripheral improvements, conditions for and treatment of prisoners are if anything worse than before?" he said.

The report is the most scathing the chief inspector has published in his five years in the job. He leaves the post this summer without his contract being renewed.

The prison service responded to his report by arguing that the newly appointed governor must be given time to turn the prison around.

Sir David said: "This appalling report describes treatment of and conditions for prisoners that are far worse than other failing prisons, such as Brixton, which very recently have been so roundly and rightly condemned by both the minister and me. It describes some of the worst conditions we have ever seen in a prison in England and Wales."

Birmingham was named as "one of the six hellholes of the prison service" by the director general, Martin Narey, when he threatened to resign if governors and staff did not fully support his modernisation programme. Mr Narey agreed little had changed at the jail since an inmate, Barry Prosser, was "kicked to death by staff".

Sir David said Birmingham was the country's second most overcrowded prison with a population of 1,060 inmates held in cells built for 734. Each inmate had only five hours' "association" out of cell each week. A shortage of 500 workplaces, and only 120 education places, meant half the population was bound to be idle every day.

The report also revealed an even darker side to the prison in which beatings of inmates were common and mentally ill prisoners were left to rot.

Mr Narey said the £860,000 efficiency cuts had now been reduced to £160,000. He said the prison would receive a new healthcare centre, significant support from NHS mental health in-reach services and a further investment of about £500,000.

The Ramsbotham report reveals:

 In the healthcare centre one prisoner, an epileptic, lay on a mattress on the floor. Conditions in the single rooms were appalling. Many were unfurnished apart from a concrete plinth as a bed.

 "We were very concerned to see a framed cartoon on the wall of the principal officer's office with very offensive remarks on it including Join the National Front".

 Prisoner survey showed 62% felt unsafe and 11% claimed they had been assaulted by staff.

 Hygiene on some wings was appalling. Many prisoners were short of clean clothes, some did not even get weekly showers, toilet paper was rationed to six sheets each.

fields.headline: Chechens hijack Russian passenger jet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Chechnya
fields.trailText: A hijacked Russian passenger plane carrying 174 passengers and crew has landed in Saudi Arabia, hours after being taken over by two men armed with knives.
fields.body:
A hijacked Russian passenger plane carrying 174 passengers and crew has landed in Saudi Arabia, hours after being taken over by two men armed with knives.

The hijackers - believed to be Chechen - took control of the Vnukovo Airlines flight shortly after its take off from the Turkish capital, Istanbul. The flight was bound for Moscow.

Qatar-based al-Jazeera television said the plane had landed in the Muslim holy city of Medina in Saudi Arabia. An airport official told the television station by telephone: "The plane has landed at Prince Mohammed bin Abdel Aziz airport."

Saudi authorities have begun negotiations with the hijackers.

Of the 12 crew members on board, one was injured in the takeover, according to the Turkish transport minister, Enis Oksuz. One of the pilots is reported to have struggled with the hijackers.

The pilot of the hijacked aircraft, which entered Egyptian airspace at 3.45 (13.45 GMT), told civil aviation authorities at Cairo airport that the plane was heading to Medina, Saudi Arabia.

Anxiety gripped relatives and friends waiting at Vnukovo airport for loved ones to arrive from Turkey, as confusing information about the incident blared from TV sets and official announcements.

Two planes from Istanbul were due in at Vnukovo at about the same time, and many people did not know whether their friends and family members had taken the one that was seized.

"I'm shaking all over," said Alexander, a 26-year-old man who did not give his surname as he sat in an airport cafeteria holding a red rose for his wife.

Turkey is a favourite destination for Russian tourists and for so-called shuttle traders who take advantage of cheap flights to travel to Istanbul and load up on inexpensive goods, especially clothes and leather coats. fields.headline: Interactive TV proves a safe bet
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The betting shop's days could be numbered as consumers take to gambling via interactive TV, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The days of the macho betting shop could be numbered as a growing number of consumers take to betting via interactive TV.

New research shows two out of three people believe the main method of betting on sporting events in the future will be through interactive TV.

The popularity of sitting in the living room and having a spontaneous flutter on sporting events is gaining momentum.

Since launching its interactive TV betting service in December, Open has already registered more than 20,000 customers.

The service is more appealing to women who have traditionally disliked going into bookmakers' shops.

However, it is not just women who are intimidated by betting shops.

According to the survey, 40% of people surveyed said they did not feel confident about walking into a high street bookmaker to place a bet.

Surprisingly, one in three men also admitted to lacking confidence when in the local bookie.

The purchase of lottery tickets though interactive services is also set to become big business.

A significant 40% of people surveyed said they would buy lottery tickets over the internet or interactive TV if the option was available.

Orbis, the company that provides online betting software to the likes of Ladbrokes, Littlewoods and Blue Square, conducted the survey.

"Imagine sitting down to watch the FA Cup Final with your mates, and being able to bet from your TV remote control on whether David Beckham will get the next penalty goal," said Charles Malir, marketing director at Orbis.

"The appeal for this kind of fun betting will be huge," he said.

fields.headline: Salmon leaps to the top again
fields.trailText:
Leo Burnett's quirky advert for John West Salmon has picked up its second industry prize in a week at the BTAA Awards. By Claire Cozens.
List of winners: BTAA website
fields.body:
Leo Burnett's quirky advert for John West Salmon has picked up its second industry prize in a week, winning the ITV best commercial award at the British Television Advertising Awards yesterday.

The news comes only days after the advert won the top prize at the Creative Circle Awards. The BTA Award is one of the most prestigious in the advertising calendar.

The prize for most successful agency of the year went to Lowe Lintas for its long-running Stella Artois campaign and the new Reebok "Belly" commercial.

The agency also won awards for its "Withabix" campaign for Weetabix and its sponsorship idents for Quality Street.

Production company of the year was Harry Nash, which was responsible for gold award-winning campaigns for Skoda, Monster.co.uk and Adidas as well as a bronze award-winning film for the Guardian.

The chairman's prize went to Frank Budgen, one of advertising's most sought-after directors whose credits include the Sony PlayStation "Double Life" commercial and the latest Levi's campaign.

Fallon's campaign for Skoda won two gold awards, one for best car commercial and one for best series of adverts. Mother also won a best series gold for its campaign for QTV.

Gold awards also went to TBWA for its campaign to launch the PlayStation 2, to Leagas Delaney for its Barclays Bank advert starring Anthony Hopkins and to WCRS for its Orange advert.

In the public services category, the BTAA awarded golds to Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO for an anti-smoking advert in which a young girl is shown talking about her smoker father.

The other went to an anti-drink driving commercial by McCann-Erickson Belfast.

In the clothing category, advertising agency 180 won the gold for its Jonah Lomu advert. And in the overseas category, the gold went to Cliff Freeman & Partners for its campaign for Fox Sports.

The gold award for programme sponsorship went to Lowe Lintas for its Quality Street sponsorship idents for ITV's movie strand.

fields.headline: Freeserve boss Keeling is casualty of Wanadoo merger
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Freeserve's chief operating officer has fallen victim to the company's merger with France Telecom's Wanadoo, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Freeserve's chief operating officer Frank Keeling has become the unlikely casualty of the internet company's merger with France Telecom's Wanadoo.

Mr Keeling's resignation comes as a direct result of Freeserve introducing a new organisational structure now its operations have been integrated with those of Wanadoo.

His role will now be taken on by chief executive John Pluthero, who will take a more hands-on approach to business strategy now he has been freed up from corporate discussions.

"Since joining the company last June, Frank has had a remit over revenue, access, customer management and portals. With John now 'back in the business' after the corporate discussions that have been taking place since last June, he can assume the chief operating focus that he didn't have time to spend on for most of last year," said Paul Barker, communications and investor relations manager.

"Having discussed the new structure with Frank Keeling and in the absence of any alternative role commensurate with his significant skills and experience, it has been agreed that he will leave the company with immediate effect."

Two new departmental managing directors will be appointed to look after access/customer management and sales, and Jon Gisby has been confirmed as managing director of portals.

A new marketing director is being sought to report to Sarah Carpenter, managing director of marketing and strategy.

"The aim is to give more clarity to departments and roles within the organisation, and ensure the business focuses on a number of key areas," added Mr Barker.

Mr Keeling, former senior vice-president and board director of AOL Europe, has left with immediate effect and it is not clear what his next role will be.

Observers have already said he would be the perfect candidate for the soon-to-be vacant position of managing director of Yahoo! Europe.

Freeserve shares were yesterday de-listed from the London Stock Exchange and listed as part of the enlarged group Wanadoo in Paris.

fields.headline: Hague 'pandering to race prejudice'
fields.standfirst: Liberal Democrat leader attacks rival over 'foreign land' speech as parties vow not to exploit issue in election campaign
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, last night came close to accusing William Hague of playing the race card in pre-election campaigning, charging the Conservative leader with being "soft on racism and soft on the causes of racism".
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, last night came close to accusing William Hague of playing the race card in pre-election campaigning, charging the Conservative leader with being "soft on racism and soft on the causes of racism".

In his fiercest assault to date on the Tories over race, Mr Kennedy claimed that his Conservative counterpart's warnings that Britain was becoming a "foreign land" were "playing on some people's fears and pandering to some people's prejudices".

The accusation, made in a speech in London to party strategists, came on the day that leaders of Britain's five parliamentary parties signed a joint declaration promising not to exploit race issues or stir up prejudice at the general election.

The declaration, drawn up by the commission for racial equality, commits the party leaders to disciplining anyone found to be playing the race card in future campaigns.

During a wide-ranging speech Mr Kennedy used strong language to attack Mr Hague, although he also took pains to avoid accusing the Tory leader personally of racism. He said: "I do not believe that William Hague is a racist. But by his use of emotive language over the issue of asylum and immigration, and now by his claim that Britain is becoming a 'foreign land', William is playing on some people's fears and pandering to some people's prejudices.

"William Hague is not racist - but by choosing his language so carelessly he shows himself to be soft on racism and soft on the causes of racism."

The Conservative leader should "stop using the easy language of fear and start behaving like a responsible leader of a political party".

The charge of pandering to racism was last night dismissed as "ludicrous" by the Tories.

Mr Hague's spokesman said: "Charles Kennedy was with William Hague and the prime minister this afternoon when they signed a document against racism and I don't think he said any of this to him then."

The Liberal Democrat leader was "wilfully misinterpreting" the meaning of Mr Hague's reference to a foreign land, made during his party's spring conference in Harrogate 10 days ago, the aide suggested.

"It is quite clear that the context of William's remarks was the threat from the European superstate and the loss of the currency."

Mr Hague infuriated one nation Tories as well as opposition critics when he warned that a second term of Labour government would create a "foreign land" in a speech which also contained promises to lock up all asylum seekers and immediately deport those losing their claims. Painting a picture of "the royal mint melting down pound coins ... the chancellor returning from Brussels to raise taxes still further", he added: "That is not bigotry, it's plain common sense."

Mr Kennedy, who will launch further attacks on Mr Hague for jumping on a bandwagon of prejudice at his own party's spring conference this weekend in Torquay, plans to make a defence of social justice and civil rights a key theme of election campaigning.

While the Liberal Democrats will be critical of Tony Blair, particularly if Labour fails to include a promise of a referendum on proportional representation, their message will be "Labour a disappointment, Tories a disaster", according to one aide.

By portraying Mr Hague as an extremist willing to pander to the most hardline members of his party, they hope to win over more moderate Tories to their own side.

The CRE last night declined to comment on the latest race row, arguing that its new compact was intended to encourage the public to respond if it felt parties were playing to race prejudices.

Elsewhere in his speech, Mr Kennedy insisted his party could win "more votes and more seats" in the forthcoming general election than it had in 1997. He attacked the government's record on public services, saying his party was prepared to tax more and spend more on health, education and crime to secure improvements.

fields.headline: Two surgeons under scrutiny
fields.trailText: Two gynaecologists at the same hospital are under investigation following complaints from up to 60 women alleging botched operations or insensitive and arrogant treatment.
fields.body:
Two gynaecologists at the same hospital are under investigation following complaints from up to 60 women alleging botched operations or insensitive and arrogant treatment.

One, Lennox Kane, is on sick leave with Parkinson's disease and the other, David Rosenberg, was suspended last Friday after months on special leave from Hemel Hempstead hospital, Hertfordshire.

The private Bupa hospital at Harpenden, where Mr Kane had treated patients since 1986, is also checking its records.

Allegations have been made about the treatment women received from the surgeons following local media coverage of complaints against Mr Kane, some dating back to long before he alerted hospital managers to his developing illness in late 1999. He was still carrying out major surgery last year.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is taking a keen interest and local Tories are demanding an independent inquiry into management at the hospitals.

The NHS has been sensitive about the behaviour of gynaecologists since the case of Rodney Ledward, struck off the medical register in 1998.

The West Herts NHS trust yesterday insisted the investigations into the records of the two doctors were separate issues. Complaints against Mr Kane, which go back eight years, include allegations of problem hysterectomy operations, scarring and rudeness.

One patient, Anastasia Insley, from St Albans, who had a private hysterectomy in September 1997, is taking legal action against Mr Kane and said she was about to have her third repair operation. "My life has been totally ruined."

The Medical Protection Society, which is representing Mr Kane, last night insisted he was "a caring and conscientious obstetrician and gynaecologist" who, on discovering he was suffering from Parkinson's, had informed the authorities and submitted himself to independent assessment. When his condition worsened "he voluntarily ceased all NHS work and has cooperated fully in inquiries".

The trust said that Mr Kane was on light duties by October. "At the beginning of this year, it was decided his condition had deteriorated so much, that he should go on sick leave."

A patient who wished to remain anonymous said she had been treated arrogantly and insensitively by Mr Rosenberg over the termination of her pregnancy three years ago. She alleged "a deap-seated old boys' club and complacent attitude" at Hemel Hempstead hospital.

fields.headline: Bannister slides back to Beeb
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Former BBC boss Matthew Bannister is returning to the corporation just four months after leaving - as a Radio 5 Live presenter, writes Jason Deans.
Feb 14:Bannister returns with DJ talent agency
Oct 13 Bannister quits BBC
fields.body:
Former BBC boss Matthew Bannister is returning to the corporation just four months after leaving - as a Radio 5 Live presenter.

The former director of marketing, who quit his post in December, will do a three-day stint as a stand-in presenter for 5 Live current affairs show Late Night Live over Easter weekend in mid-April.

He began his BBC career as a radio journalist more than 20 years ago and went on to be Radio 1 controller and director of radio.

"Matthew is going back to his roots in radio broadcasting," said a 5 Live spokeswoman. "He's a strong character with his own opinions and a good chairman of a discussion."

The spokeswoman added that 5 Live controller Bob Shennan had approached Mr Bannister about coming to work for the station on a more regular basis.

But Mr Bannister has initially only agreed to do the brief Late Night Live stint because of other commitments with music talent agency Trust the DJ, which he joined last month as chairman and chief executive.

"Bob very much thinks Matthew could add a certain something to 5 Live," the spokeswoman said. "He sees him fitting into the Brian Alexander and Nicky Campbell mould."

She added that further opportunities could arise for Mr Bannister at 5 Live after the initial Easter booking.

fields.headline: EM.TV moves to woo Henson buyers
fields.trailText: 8.30am: German media group EM.TV is rushing out the financial figures for the Jim Henson Company to tempt wary investors, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
German media group EM.TV is rushing out the financial figures for the Jim Henson Company in a bid to tempt wary investors into buying the firm.

EM.TV is looking to sell the company behind the Muppet Show in a bid to reduce its crippling debts, but potential buyers have not been able to access the Jim Henson accounts.

However, an EM.TV spokeswoman said it will release the results for its subsidiary ahead of the parent company's main financial figures.

"The Jim Henson Company statement will be ready before the EM.TV group statement, and will be released before the end of the month," said the spokeswoman.

She added that EM.TV was only "considering" the sale of the Jim Henson Company, which it bought for £430m in February last year.

"It is true that we are considering a sale, but no final decision has been made," she said.

EM.TV is battling to pay off a £680m debt that has been amassed through a series of expensive and ill-advised acquisitions, including the move for Henson.

Analysts remain sceptical about EM.TV's chances of selling its subsidiary, as it has already delayed posting the company's results.

"I think no one would want to make the mistake that EM.TV made, which was to buy a company which they knew very little about," said one analyst, who asked not to be named.

EM.TV is expected to recoup just £170m from selling Henson, underlining the risk it took in buying the firm.

EM.TV is also trying to finalise a £380m rescue deal with Kirch Group, which involves selling half its stake in Formula One holding company SLEC.

fields.headline: Teenage magazines criticised by coroner
fields.trailText: Teenage magazines were accused by a coroner of contributing to a 17-year-old's eating disorder that led to her death, reports Mary O'Hara.
fields.body:
Teenage magazines were accused yesterday by a coroner of contributing to a 17-year-old's eating disorder, which led to her death.

Melissa Booth, from Walton, Liverpool, died on January 14 this year after suffering a heart attack in her sleep.

The Liverpool coroner, Andre Rebello, said at the inquest that Miss Booth's heart attack was brought on by complications associated with bulimia nervosa.

After recording a verdict of death by natural causes, contributed to by self-neglect, Mr Rebello said: "The availability of diuretics and laxatives and teenage magazines pushed her further into having an eating disorder, even caused it. Melissa's father told me she read magazines aimed at teenage girls quite a lot. It would be unfair to name names, but it is true to say they all have a preoccupation with body image."

Miss Booth's father Gary, 41, told the inquest that he wanted to see tighter controls on the selling of laxatives and diuretics.

He said his daughter had suffered from bulimia nervosa for a number of months.

Miss Booth had been assessed at the Rathbone eating disorder unit in Liverpool last September and soon afterwards told her parents she had stopped using laxatives and diuretics to keep her weight down.
fields.bodyText: Teenage magazines were accused yesterday by a coroner of contributing to a 17-year-old's eating disorder, which led to her death. Melissa Booth, from Walton, Liverpool, died on January 14 this year after suffering a heart attack in her sleep. The Liverpool coroner, Andre Rebello, said at the inquest that Miss Booth's heart attack was brought on by complications associated with bulimia nervosa. After recording a verdict of death by natural causes, contributed to by self-neglect, Mr Rebello said: "The availability of diuretics and laxatives and teenage magazines pushed her further into having an eating disorder, even caused it. Melissa's father told me she read magazines aimed at teenage girls quite a lot. It would be unfair to name names, but it is true to say they all have a preoccupation with body image." Miss Booth's father Gary, 41, told the inquest that he wanted to see tighter controls on the selling of laxatives and diuretics. He said his daughter had suffered from bulimia nervosa for a number of months. Miss Booth had been assessed at the Rathbone eating disorder unit in Liverpool last September and soon afterwards told her parents she had stopped using laxatives and diuretics to keep her weight down.

webTitle: Britain hindered by euro, says BASF

fields.headline: Britain hindered by euro, says BASF
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: BASF, the world's largest chemicals group, yesterday became the latest to warn that its UK operations were handicapped by Britain remaining outside the eurozone.
fields.body:
BASF, the world's largest chemicals group, yesterday became the latest to warn that its UK operations were handicapped by Britain remaining outside the eurozone.

Deputy chairman Max Dietrich Kley said that investment at the company's plant at Seal Sands near Middlesbrough had been held back "by the currency problem".

BASF is planning to streamline cross-border processes in areas such as information technology, accounting, hu man resources and logistics to respond to what it sees as an increasingly "tightly knit" European market following the launch of the single currency.

Mr Kley said that BASF's UK operations were already well integrated with those in Ireland and Scandinavia, and Britain's non-membership of the single currency was not a serious concern in this area.

"The structures are fully integrated. Naturally there are limitations - currency limitations - in law but even in euroland we still have national restrictions. For the UK the currency problem is the most important."

The Seal Sands plant, which employs 450 people - down from 650 in 1999 - manufactures chemicals used in the production of high quality plastics, mainly for export.

"When you look at Seal Sands I think it's a great place for chemicals. If you look at the skills in the cluster of chemicals [manufacturing] it must be one of the most appropriate places for investment," said Mr Kley.

But he added that when it came to big investment decisions alternative BASF sites in Antwerp and Tarragona tended to get the nod because investing "within euroland is more attractive".

Mr Kley was speaking after BASF had announced record results with sales in the year 2000 up by 22% to €36bn (£22bn) and operating income up by more than 15% at €3.4bn. Looking ahead, the group is expecting a "somewhat subdued" first half this year as the US economy slows, although that will be balanced by the performance of operations in Asia and Europe.

fields.headline: Whitehall warriors
fields.standfirst:
Yesterday the government showed how seriously it is taking the foot and mouth crisis - by assembling a taskforce to tackle it. John Mullan considers Labour's soft spot for military lingo

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Yesterday the government showed how seriously it is taking the foot and mouth crisis - by assembling a taskforce to tackle it. John Mullan considers Labour's soft spot for military lingo.
fields.body:
Often, the presence of military metaphors in the language of politicians seems almost subliminal. With their all their defences and responses, they are subconsciously thinking of themselves as steely commanders. Just listen to a speech by the Nato secretary-general, Lord Robertson of Port Ellen, who has indeed passed from the world of politics to that of the military, to hear him mount a "robust defence" of Nato's "robust response" to the Serbs or the Iraqis.

Military metaphor lends purpose and apparent determination to political gestures. Politicians confronting perennial social problems like to talk of the war on drugs, poverty, crime and so on. As if there might be some final victory to be earned. Similarly, they fight battles not against people, but against malign forces (racism, deprivation, BSE).

Journalists confirm politicians in this linguistic self-importance and come the election campaign, we will be hearing endlessly about the electoral battlefield and the party war rooms . But then campaign itself was a military term before the politicians borrowed it, so it is natural to call lowly party members or backbench MPs troops or foot-soldiers.

In fact, perhaps the politicians reach for these metaphors because they spend so much time reading journalism that dramatises politics in military terms. Politicians fire broadsides and pick fights. They mount raids on each other's territory and have to deal with Exocets from ministers of other EU governments.

It is not surprising that they imagine themselves embattled. They are bombarded and heroically dodge the flak. (The American equivalent of a spin-doctor is a flak-catcher - distracting the anti-aircraft fire so that his boss is not shot down.) If you are prime minister you are in the Downing Street bunker. Damage limitation has to be carried out by your aides - the latter a buried military metaphor, from aide-de-camp: a junior officer who assists the general.

For the British, the second world war has lent special enchantment to military terms. Taskforce is itself a term from that war, American in origin but made even more persuasive by the Falklands war. Here the taskforce was a miscellaneous collection of whatever the country could scrape together, but became a kind of embodiment of the nation. Political taskforces, of course, are spearheaded by someone important - a metaphor that sounds old but entered the vocabulary of military tactics in the 1930s.

Labour politicians are probably more prone to this language than those of other parties because of the folk memory of socialism's endless fighting talk. Some once thought that they were in a class war, that their opponents were their enemies , groups of union militants (which originally meant "engaged in warfare") were shock troops, and (as Tony Benn still repeats) anything ever gained had to be fought for.

In those days, enthusiasts for Soviet communism were mocked as tankies (how they loved the Red Army!). For military words in political talk can be simply comical. Equally mock-military was Kenneth Clarke disdainfully telling young party ideologues to get their tanks off his lawn. You don't want to make yourself as ridiculous as Michael Portillo chanting S - A - S at a hall full of geriatric Tories. After all, for those - politicians and journalists alike - who love military talk, but at a distance from any action, there is a deadly oxymoron: " armchair warriors".

webTitle: War on thought: Suzanne Goldenberg on the Israeli attack on Bir Zeit University.

fields.headline: War on thought
fields.standfirst:
More than 400 people have died in the latest intifada, and each day's toll barely warrants a headline. But when the Israelis laid siege to Bir Zeit University, the world united in outrage. Why is the Palestinian's oldest academic institution such a potent symbol, asks Suzanne Goldenberg

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: More than 400 people have died in the latest intifada, and each day's toll barely warrants a headline. But when the Israelis laid siege to Bir Zeit University, the world united in outrage. Why is the Palestinian's oldest academic institution such a potent symbol, asks  Suzanne Goldenberg.
fields.body:
This is the journey of Ibrahim Sabah yesterday, on the day the science student was to have started spring term at Bir Zeit University. He left his village near the West Bank city of Hebron at 6am by shared taxi, and rode as far as Bethlehem, changing cars at the first of six Israeli army roadblocks along his route. From Bethlehem, he drove north through Azariya, on the edges of Jerusalem, and then passed through Ramallah, and Surda, before the final yellow taxi deposited him at the gates of Bir Zeit.

At each station along his route, he got out of the car and made his way past heaps of earth piled on the road, concrete barricades, Israeli soldiers and the occasional tank, to fight for a place in the next taxi. At the last stop he trudged over a road torn up by Israeli army bulldozers, all within range of an Israeli army machine-gun nest. Sabah's total travel time yesterday: 4.5 hours. Total distance travelled: 40km.

When the Israeli army laid siege to Bir Zeit this week, breaking up a 400 metre strip of pavement and digging two trenches three metres deep on the road connecting the university to Ramallah, they were simply replicating a policy of containment that has unfolded gradually over the past six months of penning the Palestinians into ever smaller enclosures. The trenches outside Bir Zeit also cut off more than 30 villages and 65,000 civilians from the commercial and political hub of West Bank life in Ramallah. They also damaged phone lines and water pipes.

But that has gone largely unnoticed because in extending the siege to the cam pus of Bir Zeit, Israel's hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, committed a monumental blunder: he underestimated the enormous influence the foremost Palestinian academic institution exercises on the local population, and the outside world. International opinon - which has been relatively muted on Israel's siege of West Bank towns and Gaza - was immediately mobilised on Bir Zeit's behalf, and a campus that has stayed on the sidelines of this intifada burst on to centrestage.

For the Palestinians, the siege of Bir Zeit went far beyond Israel's flimsy pretext of a security alert against potential car bombers; it represented an attempt to snuff out an institution that was a potent symbol of aspiration long before the intifada erupted six months ago. "According to them, the blockade is for security reasons, but I think they want to paralyse academic life and put pressure on the university," says Sabah.

The Palestinians are the most educated people in the Arab world and Bir Zeit, the oldest - and reputedly the best university in the West Bank and Gaza - epitomises their ambitions, on both personal and national levels. "It is one of the very strong bastions of democratic institutions, with a fairly good academic standard," says Dr Hanna Nasir, the university president. "It spearheaded the whole issue of higher education under the occupation."

It did so through turbulent times, marked by strikes, sit-ins, leaflet campaigns, protests and enforced shutdowns during the 70s and 80s which were led by the mainstream nationalist Fatah movement of Yasser Arafat. Until the arrival of limited self-rule six years ago, there were frequent clashes with the Israeli soldiers posted at the gates of the hilltop campus. During the last intifada, in the late 80s, Israel closed down the university for more than four years.

Along the way, Bir Zeit produced a generation of leaders who occupy key positions in the Palestinian political and academic establishment. Prominent alumni include Marwan Barghouti, a leader of the Fatah militias in the West Bank, who has emerged as a leading field commander of this intifada. Barghouti was a student leader at Bir Zeit in the 70s and 80s before he was deported by Israel. But he earned an MA in history.

"Bir Zeit always used to be in the lead in confrontations and fights," says Ghassan Khatib, a Palestinian analyst who was a student leader at Bir Zeit in the late 70s. That has not been the case during this uprising, which has been fought largely by the armed cells of Fatah, shooting at Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers.

The stone-throwing demonstrations of the first few weeks of the uprising faded away, partly because of Israel's brutal response, which saw as many as 19 demonstrators killed in a day. More than 420 people have been killed to date, mostly Palestinians.

But the Palestinians' resort to firearms - the most marked change from the last uprising - also stopped the uprising from developing into a genuine mass movement. "The whole intifada has changed. The involvement of the people was much more in the first intifada," says Vera Tamari, who teaches Islamic art and architecture. "Now the confrontation is localised in specific locations, and not all sectors are involved."

With the withdrawal of Israeli troops from its gates several years ago, the campus ceased to be a flashpoint. Meanwhile, a new generation of students came of age, too young to remember the first intifada, who championed a peace process which failed to deliver any discernible benefits. Now the next generation of activists has emerged. During the past few years, Hamas and other Islamist organisations have won the student council elections, dislodging Fatah. But although Bir Zeit has been sidelined of late, several of the students who battled their way to the hilltop 5kms north of Ramallah which houses Bir Zeit's new campus yesterday, said they were drawn to the university as much for its tradition of activism, as for its academic reputation.

"It has a reputation for being a place of activists," says Awali Samara, who moved here from Brooklyn in August to begin an MA in democracy and human rights. A Jerusalemite, it was her first time back since emigrating to the US in 1985. "I felt that when I registered here, I would not just be studying human rights, but I would be living it, too," she said. "You could see the fact of the occupation, but at night we would go out and it was not that much different from New York. Now it has become all too real."

Early yesterday morning, after the Israeli forces left the trench and retreated to an overlooking slope, it was the turn of Palestinian bulldozers to move huge mounds of rubble around the sole road linking Bir Zeit to Ramallah. They rumbled over a pavement scored and broken by Israeli earth-moving equipment at the weekend. By mid-morning the road was open to traffic again, and cars scraped their undercarriages over the dirt mounds that filled in two Israeli trenches. By afternoon, a few hundred protesters had planted Palestinian flags in the earth, and some were throwing stones. The Israeli army jeeps retreated to a slope behind a concrete barrier, firing rubber-tipped steel bullets in their wake. Bir Zeit, the erstwhile centre of Palestinian political life, had been activated once more.

"What happened this week is not over," Nasir says. "It's going to linger like a bad cold." Although classes will restart on Saturday, several teachers at Bir Zeit fear the loss of further students because of the newly installed Israeli military checkpoint. They see the checkpoint as a provocation, luring the students of Bir Zeit into clashes with the Israeli soldiers stationed there.

Other students will stay away for fear of having to pass the Israeli troops. About 800 of Bir Zeit's students have dropped out since the start of the intifada, exhausted by an Israeli siege that has turned travel between Palestinian cities into a nightmare. Some 300 other students are stranded, unable to return to their homes in the Gaza Strip because Israel's blockade means they might never be able to return to finish their degrees. Others face arrest for leaving Gaza without Israel's permission.

When the Israeli checkpoint went up this week, their world, already constrained by the blockades in the West Bank, drastically shrank. "Now I can't even go to Ramallah 5km away," says Fahdi Omar. A final year engineering student, he smuggled himself out of Gaza to Egypt and then to Jordan before enrolling at Bir Zeit five years ago, and has not returned to visit his family since because that would involve crossing Israel, and possible arrest. "Personally, I don't mind if I get caught, but my being here means everything for my family," he says.

Research trips to Jerusalem and other cities are impossible because of the blockade, and several of the staff have been blocked from going to conferences abroad because Israel will not let them use its airport. But, until this week, it appeared that the Bir Zeit would concentrate on its real business of education.

"There was a false sense of normality for a while. The occupation was not as militaristic as it has been over the past 34 years - at least in Bir Zeit," Tamari says. "Now the situation is in limbo - neither occupation nor liberation, neither autonomy nor living under Israel. It is very difficult for us to cope."

webTitle: Boom time for few signals misery and death for many

fields.headline: Boom time for few signals misery and death for many
fields.standfirst: Oil firms stoke up Sudan war
fields.trailText: Oil is more a curse than a blessing to the people of Sudan. It has become both the justification and means for the military to pursue a campaign to depopulate vast areas of the country to make way for international oil companies.
fields.body:
Oil is more a curse than a blessing to the people of Sudan. It has become both the justification and means for the military to pursue a campaign to depopulate vast areas of the country to make way for international oil companies.

Thousands of villages have been destroyed and tens of thousands of defenceless people killed or displaced. Why is it that, in a country in which half the children do not go to school, oil wealth is deepening the misery?

The simple answer is an explosive combination of poor domestic governance and unregulated foreign business.

Christian Aid's partner organisations in Sudan have reported that the atrocities have increased since oil came on-stream in 1999. The 18-year civil war between central government and armed opposition groups based in the south has already caused more than 2m deaths and 4m internally displaced.

Since 1998, the government has doubled its military budget, spending virtually what it receives in oil revenues - around $1m a day. In December, the minister for roads and transport in Southern province resigned in frustration at the lack of resources for development, saying oil revenues were intensifying the war in the south.

Before oil, Sudan produced few weapons, now it has two manufacturing sites which, by the government's own admission, were set up for dual civilian-military use.

One general has boasted that Sudan is increasing its domestic arms production thanks largely to the "unprecedented economic boom" that oil revenues have caused.

Unfortunately, there are no benefits to be enjoyed by the poor in either the north or south of the country.

The civil war is being fought over complex issues of identity and culture among diverse African and Arab peoples and over control of natural resources such as land and livestock.

But now it is increasingly being fought over oil and any lasting peace agreement will need to ensure a fair distribution of resources and development for all.

But as long as the oil revenues promote the burnings of homes and mass displacement and are not invested in Sudan's children and social services, they will contribute to the "de-development" of the country.

The foreign oil companies in Sudan are choosing to wall themselves off from these realities. Many, such as Talisman (Canada), Lundin (Sweden) and CNPC (China), are complicit in the atrocities through their inaction.

Roads and airstrips which are part of the oil infrastructure are used by the military in the campaign of destruction. The same troops providing security to the companies have committed human rights atrocities.

The companies' presence provides not only the resources but lends international legitimacy to a government at war with its own people.

Christian Aid and our partners in Sudan are calling on the oil companies to cease operations immediately, sending a strong signal to the government.

Companies can use their influence to help stop human rights violations. It is about time they did.

Mark Curtis is head of advocacy at Christian Aid

The civil war is being fought over complex issues of identity and culture among diverse African and Arab peoples and over control of natural resources such as land and livestock. But now it is increasingly being fought over oil and any lasting peace agreement will need to ensure a fair distribution of resources and development for all. But as long as the oil revenues promote the burnings of homes and mass displacement and are not invested in Sudan's children and social services, they will contribute to the "de-development" of the country. The foreign oil companies in Sudan are choosing to wall themselves off from these realities. Many, such as Talisman (Canada), Lundin (Sweden) and CNPC (China), are complicit in the atrocities through their inaction. Roads and airstrips which are part of the oil infrastructure are used by the military in the campaign of destruction. The same troops providing security to the companies have committed human rights atrocities. The companies' presence provides not only the resources but lends international legitimacy to a government at war with its own people. Christian Aid and our partners in Sudan are calling on the oil companies to cease operations immediately, sending a strong signal to the government. Companies can use their influence to help stop human rights violations. It is about time they did. Mark Curtis is head of advocacy at Christian Aid

webTitle: Oil firms stoke up Sudan war

fields.headline: Oil firms stoke up Sudan war
fields.standfirst:
Christian Aid report accuses foreign companies of complicity in mass displacement and killing of thousands

Boom time for few signals misery and death for many
fields.trailText: Oil companies operating in Sudan are complicit in the systematic depopulating of large areas of the country and atrocities against civilians, tens of thousands of whom have been killed and displaced from the areas around the oil fields, according to a report to be published today.
fields.body:
Oil companies operating in Sudan are complicit in the systematic depopulating of large areas of the country and atrocities against civilians, tens of thousands of whom have been killed and displaced from the areas around the oil fields, according to a report to be published today.

Christian Aid, in a searing report on the consequences of Sudan's new oil bonanza, accuses the oil companies of deep involvement in the government's war machine against southern civilians.

The companies are protected by government forces and allow their airstrips and roads to be used by the military, while the revenues from oil are funding expansion of the war, the report says.

The report includes dozens of eyewitness accounts from villages where people have been driven out by bombing and ground attacks.

"Oil has brought death," said one Nuer chief, Malony Kolang. "When the pumping began, the war began. Antonovs and helicopter gunships began attacking the villages. All the farms have been destroyed, everything around the oil fields has been destroyed."

Christian Aid's report calls on foreign oil companies - from Canada, Sweden, China, France and Austria - to suspend their operations in Sudan. It also calls for BP and Shell to divest their shares in firms whose parent company is involved.

The report accuses the oil companies of trying to distance themselves from the catastrophe of southern Sudan by claiming they are not responsible for the behaviour of companies in which they are shareholders.

BP said last night it had no intention of disposing of its interests in PetroChina "because there is no reason why we should". The Chinese company, in which BP bought a $578m stake 12 months ago, is not active in Sudan, although its parent group, China National Petroleum Corporation, (CNPC) is.

Toby Odone, a spokesman for BP, insisted there was no operational connection between PetroChina and CNPC. "When PetroChina did its IPO [listing on the US stock market] it assured the Securities & Exchange Commission that it had no interests in Sudan because of the sanctions issue," he explained.

A Shell spokesman said it had no exploration or production interests in Sudan either directly or through its Chinese partner Sinopec. Dave Stuart said: "Although Sinopec did at one stage control interests in Sudan as a result of the restructuring of the Chinese state oil industry, that stake was moved back to CNPC during 1999."

He said Shell would not agree to Christian Aid demands that it withdraw from its shareholding in Sinopec because there was no connection between Sinopec and CNPC.

Rolls Royce admits it provided 34 diesel engines to help pump oil along a 1,000-mile pipeline from Sudan's oil fields to an export terminal on the Red Sea.

Martin Brody, a Rolls Royce spokesman, said the company always took advice from the British government on where it could do business but also had its own criteria. He added: "As a supplier of equipment we always take a responsible view of our actions. We gave a lot of information to Christian Aid and will need to look at its report in more detail."

Glasgow-based Weir Group is also being criticised for a £20m contract to provide equipment for pumping stations on the same pipeline. Emrys Inker, a spokesman for Weir, confirmed its involvement in Sudan but said all the work had been done with the approval of the Department of Trade and Industry and the British government.

Weir had no comment on accusations that it is complicit in human rights abuses, or on speculation that it is involved in a second contract to supply pumps.

The report gives harrowing details of the lives of refugees from the oil areas who have walked hundreds of miles to very precarious areas of southern Sudan, already wracked by decades of civil war.

"All the villages along the road have been burned," said John Wicjial Bayak, a local official driven from a village close to the main road built for access to the oil fields. "You cannot see a single hut. The government doesn't want people anywhere near the oil."

One man described fleeing the bombing with six of his grandchildren to hide in a forest. "We dug a hole for the children and put a blanket on top," he said. "We stayed 20 days in the forest eating wild fruit."

Systematic attacks on the villages began in March 2000, according to village chiefs. One was bombed 10 times before government troops finally burned out the residents.

Across southern Sudan life is on a knife-edge and the government's strategy of banning aid flights to Upper Nile is fanning fears of a new famine tragedy similar to that of 1998, in which tens of thousands died.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Double up | Top marks
fields.body:
Double up
Last year, I read in Online that there would be new motherboards that would use two chips instead of one, and that it would be cheaper to buy a 1,000 megahertz machine with two 500MHz chips than one 1,000MHz chip. Now I see PCs coming out with 1.3GHz processors, and presumably by the end of this year they will have gone up past 2GHz. Does this mean I should wait and buy a machine with the new architecture? Of course, next month is always the best time to buy a computer, but what's your advice on this? Jason Pennells
jason_pennells@hotmail.com

Jack Schofield replies: Two-processor motherboards have been available for years, but Microsoft Windows 95/98/Me is a single-processor operating system. For two you need Windows NT/2000 or similar alternative, and they are not widely used by consumers. Maybe things will change when Windows XP appears, but it will take years. Also, overproduction of memory chips, competition between Intel and AMD, and the threat of a market recession has brought down PC prices faster than expected. You can now get a 1GHz PC for about £700 and a great machine from a direct supplier for about £1,000.

The next two months should be a good time to buy a new system - or pack the one you own with more memory, before memory prices recover. I am shopping for two new PCs myself. Faster, cheaper machines will be available next year, as always. However, this year's systems will have no problems running Windows XP, Office XP and any other software on the horizon.

Top marks
I have bookmarks in three different places: two on networks, one on a standalone PC. How do I create a common list that I can use in all three places? Dave Sheppard
dsheppard@charter.southwark.sch.uk

JS: One idea is to make a text file of all the addresses (including the http:// bit) and post it to a Yahoo or similar mailbox. (Don't use Hotmail, which opens links inside Hotmail frames.) Netscape keeps its bookmarks in one file, but you can create one very easily in Internet Explorer by selecting File|Import and Export, and using the wizard to export your "Favorites" to a file called Bookmark.htm However, I suggest you use one of the many websites that will store your bookmarks online so you can get at them from different computers. Examples include: www.favoritesanywhere.com, www.bookmarksplus.com, www.blink.com,, and www.mybookmarks.com.

How the cookie crumbles
I used to be able to use the Postcode Finder at www.royalmail.com/trackandtrace. Now I get a message: "This site requires your browser to support and accept cookies. Please enable and accept cookies." Can you help, please?
Bob Hutton
hutton@ukonline.co.uk

JS: Cookies are small bits of text that record your visit to a site. They are kept in the Cookies folder in the Windows directory. To enable your PC to accept cookies, run Internet Explorer, select Tools|Internet Options and click on the Security tab. Click the button marked Custom, scroll down to the section headed Cookies, and click on the two radio buttons marked Enable.

Sticking point
In Windows Explorer, folders can be viewed in four different ways: large icons, small icons, list or details. Mine persist in opening as large icons, but I want the default view to be details. George Katritzky
gkatritzky@lineone.net

JS: This happens a lot. The cure is to open Windows Explorer and select View|Details. Next select View|Folder Options (right at the bottom), click the View tab, and click the button Like Current Folder. Click Yes to confirm your choice, then OK to exit. This should make it stick - until it doesn't, of course.

Thumbnail views
I have Windows 98 and need the use of thumbnails in My Documents. Recently, after I installed a virus scan program, my thumbnail facility disappeared. Please can you help me retrieve it? Yvonne Kedge
y.Kedge@lineone.net

JS: Go to your directory in Windows Explorer and select View|Folder Options. Click the radio button for Web Style folders. Next, right-click on the folder name, in the left-hand pane, and select Properties. Put a tick in the lowest box on the Properties sheet, which says Enable Thumbnail View, and click OK. Select View again, and this time you should see a new entry for Thumbnails, just above Large Icons. If you select that, your thumbnail views should magically reappear. This works on my PC but Microsoft says it only applies to Internet Explorer 5 (which I use) if the Windows Desktop Update is installed.

This comes with Windows 98 and Internet Explorer 4: see http://support.microsoft.com/ support/kb/articles/Q176/8/ 82.ASP If you just want to handle thumbnail directories of images, then Irfan View, Thumbs Plus (www.cerious.com and ACDSee do the job competently. Irfan View is good and free for non-commercial use.

Excellent
I want to scan/copy documents such as bank statements into Excel worksheets. Do you know if this is possible? Tom Clyde
tclyde@moneymanagersltd.co.uk

JS: It is easy if the type is legible and the columns are regular. Scan your statements and save them as plain text files, then clean them up in a word processor if necessary. Start Microsoft Excel and use File|Open to find the directory containing the file you want to load. In the Files of type box, click Text Files, then double-click the file you want to import. Excel's Text Import Wizard will then let you choose how to divide the text into columns. However, the value of the result will depend on all numbers being recognised correctly. And you can't find errors with a spell-checker.

Seek and you shall find
After complaining about Adobe Portable Document Files that were hard to read, I praised Google for a new feature: it indexes PDF files and holds a plain text version. "However, there does not seem to be a way to limit a Google search to PDF files," I complained. John King
john@kingshome.co.uk has provided a helpful answer from the Search Engine Report: the undocumented inurl command. For example, try searching Google for this: "Jack Straw" inurl:pdf I also complained about the difficulty of saving streaming RealMedia files. Gavin Brelstaff points out that you can use Total Recorder to capture RealAudio streams. However, unlike Streambox VCR, it cannot capture streaming video. Finally, John Nicholson j.nicholson@cableinet.co.uk points out that there is a much simpler keyboard shortcut to close down Windows, bypassing the Start menu: just press Alt-F4. This is, of course, a standard way of closing down Windows applications. Why didn't I think of that?

fields.headline: Game over for Ericsson sports sponsorship
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Ericsson is ending its sports sponsorship in the UK in favour of music and youth-based initiatives, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Ericsson is pulling its investment in sports sponsorship in the UK in order to concentrate on music and youth-based initiatives.

The Swedish mobile phone giant's sponsorship of QPR football club and the Wasps rugby club will not be renewed when the contracts run out at the end of this season.

Ericsson has sponsored QPR for five years and Wasps for three years.

It will maintain a relationship with the rugby club by becoming and associate sponsor - its logo will appear on the players' shirtsleeves.

"Our relationships with Wasps and QPR has been very successful - they have given us a profile and continuity with the public - but we are focusing more on music this year," said Alex Rodrigues, marketing director of Ericsson UK.

Mr Rodrigues was unable to say whether Ericsson was to stop investing in sport on a global basis.

This year, Ericsson will sponsor the Homelands dance music festival for the third time.

It has sponsored the Muzik magazine awards and later this year will sponsor the MTV Europe awards.

A raft of marketing activity is being planned around the June release of the Tomb Raider film, in which Erissson products feature.

Vijay Anand, the UK marketer responsible for putting together Ericsson's partnership with dance music brands, has recently been appointed to the newly created role of global youth marketing chief.

webTitle: Mail style editor joins H Bauer

fields.headline: Mail style editor joins H Bauer
fields.trailText: 8.30am: H Bauer has poached the style editor of the Daily Mail for its top-secret women's launch, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
H Bauer has lured the style editor of the Daily Mail to its top-secret women's magazine launch, Project Helena.

Trudi Wallace is joining Project Helena as fashion director.

Meanwhile, Sian Rees has been appointed lifestyle director.

She previously worked as deputy editor of Project Florence, the G+J women's lifestyle title that was shelved after the publisher was bought by the National Magazine Company.

Project Helena's deputy editor will be Karen Pasquali-Jones, a former Sunday People and Today journalist.

Lindsay Maggs, who has worked at the Times and the Daily Mail, comes on board as picture editor.

They join former That's Life editor Janice Turner, who is launch-editing the magazine.

"The existing women's glossies are beautiful to look at but they only take about five minutes to flick through and have absolutely no relevance to women's lives," said Ms Turner.

"Throughout our extensive research, all the women we spoke to said the same thing - 'we want a glossy women's magazine that gives us something to READ'."

The magazine has been shrouded in secrecy.

Staff at H Bauer's headquarters said the Project Helena office had been sealed off from the rest of the building.

The magazine's name has been kept strictly under wraps. However, industry sources claim the working title is Real.

A spokesman for the magazine said this was one of many working titles.

The magazine, which will be the first fortnightly glossy to hit the market, is backed by serious investment from H Bauer, the German publishing firm.

It is the latest in a long line of magazine launches to enter the lucrative "middle youth" sector.

In the past two years, Emap Elan's Red, the BBC's first women's glossy Eve, Dennis Publishing's PS and IPC's Nova have all appeared in the market.

More recently, Time Inc and Conde Nast have introduced UK versions of the high-profile US magazines InStyle and Glamour.

fields.headline: ITV and BSkyB talk peace
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ITV and BSkyB are settling their differences over the network's absence from the Sky Digital platform.
fields.body:
ITV and BSkyB are settling their differences over the network's absence from the Sky Digital platform.

ITV announced yesterday a deal to secure capacity on the Astra satellite network which is likely to presage its appearance on Sky Digital by the end of the year. One ITV insider said there was a "willingness on both sides" to agree a conditional access deal with Sky.

ITV is taking enough capacity on the satellite - launched on the Ariane rocket last December - to allow it to broadcast 16 regional services as well as its planned "family of channels".

Sky Digital subscribers should also be able to receive ITV2 by the end of the year, followed by other themed channels, the first two specialising in sport and children's entertainment.

Until now ITV has argued that BSkyB charged too much for access to the Sky platform. It recently disclosed that the satellite broadcaster would charge the network £20m a year to appear on Sky Digital.

Both sides privately admit that it would be in their mutual interests to agree a deal. Advertisers have pressed the network to appear on the platform, which is in 4.7m homes. At present Sky Digital viewers need to switch out of their digital platform and on to analogue to watch ITV. The network is also not listed on the Sky electronic programme guide.

webTitle: News: Job cuts at the Express

fields.headline: Express axes 130 journalists
fields.trailText: The blood letting at Express Newspapers is about to begin in earnest as Richard Desmond, who bought the newspapers last November, prepares to announce around 130 editorial job losses.
fields.body:
The blood letting at Express Newspapers is about to begin in earnest as Richard Desmond, who bought the newspapers last November, prepares to announce around 130 editorial job losses.

The reduction in staff has been widely anticipated since Mr Desmond took over the group which includes the Daily and Sunday Express and Daily Star. The company says that the three titles employ around 520 editorial staff between them, including 106 on the Star.

Mr Desmond, who built his business on the back of consumer magazines such as OK! and publishing soft porn, was said to have been shocked by the staffing and salary levels at the newspapers.

The Express titles will bear the brunt of the job losses and there was some suggestion that another 30 may come from other parts of the business, including the newspapers' library, taking the tally to 160.

Letters from Paul Ashford, the editorial director of Northern & Shell, informing the entire staff of the company's plans are being sent in the post today. The company declined to comment.

Mr Desmond has invited representatives from the National Union of Journalists for a meeting this morning to discuss the plans.

Jeremy Dear of the NUJ said industrial action had not been ruled out. At a chapel meeting with Express staff held in the newspapers' canteen yesterday he said emotions had been running high. "I haven't ever genuinely felt so much anger at a situation like this," he said.

The job losses proved to be the breaking point for the previous editor of the Daily Express, Rosie Boycott, who quit in January.

Mr Dear said the union would be watching closely to see if the terms on offer were within the bounds of the NUJ's agreement with Express Newspapers which runs until December. The agreement is notice period plus three weeks for every year with a minimum 20-week payoff. The union also fears that remaining staff will be forced to accept Northern & Shell contracts, reducing holiday from six weeks to four weeks a year and that staff will be made to work across the titles, including OK!

Northern & Shell borrowed £97.5m to buy Express Newspapers. A month after acquiring the titles, Mr Desmond made 60 back office staff redundant.

webTitle: Social workers' image falls to an all-time low

fields.headline: Social workers' image falls to an all-time low
fields.trailText: Recent scandals have left the image of social workers at an all-time low, with many members of the public seeing carers as interfering, ineffective and excessively bureaucratic, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
Recent scandals have left the image of social workers at an all-time low, with many members of the public seeing carers as interfering, ineffective and excessively bureaucratic, according to a survey published today.

The results coincide with the launch of a poster campaign by the Local Government Assocation (LGA) and Community Care magazine, aimed at restoring the public's confidence in the profession and turning round the spiralling crisis in social services recruitment.

More than one in six jobs in social care work is now vacant, while two-thirds of social services departments have reported difficulties recruiting staff to fill them.

Kevin Wilson, who heads the LGA's task force on workforce planning, said: "There is a clear and desperate need to address the manpower shortage in social services. This campaign demonstrates that social work is rewarding and satisfying."

The survey found that 46% of people in the UK believe social workers are "politically correct". Four out of 10 say they are bureaucratic and use jargon that ordinary people do not understand.

More than a third of the 1,000 people questioned for the survey believed social workers were ineffective and interfering.

But despite their concerns about social workers, two-thirds of those surveyed recognised that carers are overworked, and three-quarters believe they do help vulnerable people.

The survey, which was carried out for the magazine, which, was conducted in the wake of reports of highly publicised failures of social workers to act in child abuse cases.

They include the case of two-year-old Chelsea Brown, whose father Robert was last week convicted of murdering her after months of physical abuse. The trial heard that Chelsea had been on a child protection register since she was born and at the time of her death had more than 40 injuries over her body. Social workers had visited her more than 20 times but despite seeing bruises on her body and knowing her father had a history of violence, no action was taken. Earlier this year Marie-Therese Kouao and her boyfriend Carl Manning were convicted of murdering Kouao's eight-year-old great-niece Anna Climbie.

The little girl had been beaten, tied up, placed in a bin liner and left in a bath.

At the time of her death she had 128 separate injuries and a Home Office pathologist described it as the worst case of child abuse he had ever seen.

An independent investigation has now been launched into the failures surrounding the case.

webTitle: Time is right for change in adoption legislation

fields.headline: Time is right for change in adoption legislation
fields.standfirst: The long-awaited adoption bill has been published today - and now we must seize the opportunity to ensure that adoption legislation will really meet the needs of children, writes Felicity Collier
fields.trailText: The long-awaited adoption bill has been published today - and now we must seize the opportunity to ensure that adoption legislation will really meet the needs of children, writes Felicity Collier.
fields.body:
The government has today published the long-awaited adoption bill - it has been suggested that this will be a substantial piece of new legislation with more than 100 clauses.

I have to admit that it is quite a surprise, given the proximity of the general election and the likelihood of the bill becoming law this session being unlikely to say the least.

Nevertheless, this is a welcome and important move and will allow the prime minister's promise, made at question time in the heat of the internet adoption saga, to be realised.

Perhaps less charitable commentators may reflect on the fact that it has taken a high profile case causing public outrage to get the government into gear to deliver at last the key plank of the adoption agenda.

But it does not matter what the trigger was - the government has already demonstrated its commitment to reforming adoption services through the prime minister's report and the white paper published just before Christmas.

What is important now is that we have a "once in a generation" opportunity to ensure that we have the adoption legislation on the statute book which we hope will really meet the needs of children (the last major amendment to 1958 adoption legislation was in the 1975 Children Act).

Much has been written about the government's wish to rehabilitate adoption in the eyes of the public, in order to encourage more confidence in the system. Fears have been expressed that the simplistic drive to adoption, backed up by quantitative targets, can only reduce the opportunity for disadvantaged and struggling parents to care successfully for their own children, with appropriate support. I doubt however whether this will be the case with the impact of the Human Rights Act and a stated government commitment to family support.

We know from our own evidence that there are many many children for whom adoption is the plan - children living in temporary foster care, for whom there are simply no families available. The evidence of this is clear in British Agencies for Adopting and Fostering's monthly publication, in which more than 400 children are featured each month.

I hope the proposed adoption register will be included in this legislation, and will enable families approved to be adopters to be available for children wherever they may live where they can meet the children's needs. This is surely a sensible move and much welcomed. However it is clear to many of us that even this measure will not easily produce the numbers of families needed.

New adoption legislation, which we hope will provide proper financial and practical support to adoptive families and place the child's needs at the centre of the process, could really make a difference to this recruitment crisis.

The white paper provided little additional detail of the proposed legislation and we await in interest the opportunity to consider the proposals in the bill in detail. Our concern is that this bill is not rushed in on the back of populist comment surrounding the internet twins case - proper time for consultation and discussion is essential. I do believe the government will understand this.

 Felicity Collier is chief executive of the British Agencies for Adopting and Fostering.

webTitle: Britain backs war on stolen antiquities

fields.headline: Britain backs war on stolen antiquities
fields.trailText: The government is to sign the 1970 Unesco convention banning the international trade in stolen art and antiquities, a worldwide trade estimated to be worth billions and in which the British art market is believed to be a major player.
fields.body:
The government is to sign the 1970 Unesco convention banning the international trade in stolen art and antiquities, a worldwide trade estimated to be worth billions and in which the British art market is believed to be a major player.

The trade ranges from stolen 19th and 20th-century European paintings to fragments of Roman pottery and coins and entire sculptures hacked off temples in Asia to order.

East Anglian churches, now kept locked almost permanently, have lost silver, furnishings and pictures to the same ruthless trade. In Britain insured losses alone, believed to be the tip of the iceberg, are running at over £150m a year.

The advisory committee set up by the government last year to study the extent of the trade and recommend action found that police in London working with Interpol dealt with 132 cases in 1999 alone, while customs was making around 30 seizures of cultural goods being smuggled into the country every year.

Yesterday the arts minister, Alan Howarth, said signing the convention - stonewalled for 30 years by successive governments citing "legal problems" - was an important step in concerted international action against a scandalous trade. "This news will send out a powerful signal to those who do so much damage to the world's cultural heritage."

webTitle: Key measures in the adoption and children bill

fields.headline: Key measures in the adoption and children bill
fields.trailText: Key measures in the adoption and children bill
fields.body:
Key measures in the adoption and children bill:

 Changing the law to make the welfare of the child the paramount consideration in all decisions relating to adoption.
 Allowing courts to set timetables to cut delays in adoption court cases.
 Re-affirming existing safeguards that make it an offence to "make arrangements" for adoption or advertise children for adoption, other than through adoption agencies.
 Giving all adoptive families a new right to an assessment for post-adoption support.
 Placing a clear duty on local authorities to provide an adoption support service.
 Establishing a new national adoption register to enable faster matches between children waiting to be adopted and approved adoptive families.
 Establishing a new independent review mechanism for prospective adopters who feel they have been turned down unfairly.
 Introducing a new special guardianship order to provide security and permanence for children where adoption is not suitable.
 Making improvements to the legal process of placing a child.
 Providing adopted people with consistent access to information about the background to their adoption.
 Only allowing approved adoption agencies and councils may advertise children for adoption, whether using traditional media or the internet.
