webTitle: Adoption bill to give parents more support

fields.headline: Adoption bill to give parents more support
fields.trailText: The government has unveiled its long-awaited overhaul of adoption procedures, announcing a bill that will speed up the process and offer support to parents. Linda Steele reports.
fields.body:
The government has unveiled its long-awaited overhaul of adoption procedures, announcing a bill that will speed up the process and offer support to parents.

Adopting parents will for the first time have the right to post-adoption support, including an assessment of their needs. Local authorities will have a statutory duty to provide adoption support services.

The adoption and children bill - the biggest change to adoption law in 25 years - aims to create "permanent, secure and strong" new families for children who cannot live with their natural families.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, said that the 28,000 children in care for more than two years needed a "better deal".

A computerised national adoption register will be set up to enable children to be matched more quickly with prospective parents throughout England and Wales. Courts will be able to set timetables to cut delays in adoption court cases.

"Adoption must become a first-choice option for looked-after children who can't return home," said Mr Milburn.

The government said that the bill would "put the needs of children at the heart of the adoption process". But would-be adopters, who feel unfairly treated when refused by social workers, will be able to turn to a new independent review mechanism.

The bill follows prime minister Tony Blair's review of adoption and a white paper last year, as well as concerns over the recent case of a British couple who adopted American twins over the internet.

Rob Hutchinson, Association of Directors of Social Services spokesman on children, welcomed the bill but called for adequate funding. "It will provide a better service to children who need permanent homes," he said.

"In particular, we welcome, the emphasis on post-adoption services - including the right to an assessment of needs and provision of support. It could be anything from social services helping to sort out a problem to an extension to a house for a disabled child.

"However, to make a real difference requires a determination by social work staff to make it a reality and adequate funding by the government."

When launching the adoption white paper last December, the government had promised an extra £66.5m to improve adoption services. Privately, some adoption experts feel the money will not be enough.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said the bill was the right move but should not be rushed through parliament in a pre-election period.

"We only get one opportunity in a generation for reforming adoption law and it is vital that the government gets it right," she said.

"Reducing delay for children is vitally important but we are pleased that the announcement today also recognises the importance of safeguarding children via new powers to regulate internet adoption.

"The prohibition of advertising children on the internet, except by approved adoption agencies will give a clear message to the rest of the world that we are determined to protect the interests of children."

Conservative shadow health secretary Liam Fox said his party would "support any measures which put the child at the centre of the [adoption] process, rather than giving undue weight to social or political factors." He would be looking to "plug any gaps we think may exist especially with regard to older children and children with special needs".

He qualified a controversial earlier demand for all children in care for over a year to have an adoption plan. Experts have argued that such children should have a "permanency" plan, rather than automatically being put up for adoption, which does not suit all children.

"When I talk about an 'adoption plan', it's about deciding what's the most appropriate plan - with an assumption that adoption should be one of the options - a plan that says: 'This child should be adopted where it's possible to adopt them'," said Dr Fox.

fields.headline: Q&A: adoption and children bill
fields.trailText: Q&A: adoption and children bill
fields.body:
Why an adoption bill now?
Right this minute? Well, the hooha over the case of the American "internet twins" bought over the internet by Welsh couple Alan and Judith Kilshaw made adoption a watercooler issue and made ministers determined to be seen to act.

So the bill's about internet adoptions?
Not really. This bill is basically about adoptions happening in England and Wales. But the government has said it will act quickly to implement section 14 of the Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act 1999, which will make it a criminal offence to adopt a child's overseas if the adoptive parents haven't got clearance from approved agencies in the child's home country. There may be a couple of minor amendments during the bill's passage through parliament to tighten up some loopholes.

This intercountry law does what exactly?
When fully ratified by all four parliaments, in England, Northern Ireland, Wales and Scotland, it will enable the UK to ratify the 1993 Hague convention on protection of children and co-operation in respect of intercountry adoption. This is essentially a framework of minimum standards to make sure adoption is in the best interests of the child and that no profit is made from the process. But today's adoption bill is really about domestic adoption.

So why the need for change on the home front?
The last Adoption Act was in 1976 - although The Children Act 1989 included passages on adoption. Times have changed for children and families.

Estuary-accented TV Tweenies have replaced Daphne Oxenford's received pronunciation on Radio 4's Listen with Mother?
There's rather more to it than that. Changing family structures and a social acceptance of lone parenthood have radically altered adoption. Until the late 1970s, social services departments would encourage single mothers to give up their children for adoption. Now, single women tend to keep their babies. Different social mores and the advent of the contraceptive Pill mean that there are far fewer healthy newborns up for adoption.

Who is up for adoption?
The majority of the children available have been in care, which means they come from troubled or traumatic backgrounds. Many have special needs - such as learning difficulties, behavioural problems or disabilities - and some wait a long time to find the right adoptive parents. They tend to be older and may have siblings who need to be adopted with them. In short, they are much more difficult children to place successfully.

What difference can a new law make?
Recruitment of suitable families is key. At present, there is no national register of children available for adoption, so if social services can't find suitable parents for a child in their own catchment area, it's hard to hunt elsewhere. The bill will outline plans for a computerised database of children waiting for adoption throughout England and Wales (Scotland may join the database at a later date.)

What else?
Tony Blair made adoption his crusade last summer, when he headed a review. "When children cannot live with their birth parents, for whatever reason, we all share a responsibility to make sure that they have a chance of a fresh start, and an opportunity to enjoy the kind of loving family life which most of us take for granted."

Did he praise motherhood and apple pie, too?
Actually, he started to put the boot in just after that. Social workers weren't providing those happy families. "In far too many parts of the system, there is a lack of clarity, of consistency and of fairness. Most pressingly, children in an already vulnerable position are being badly let down," he said. The prime minister said he was fed up with children languishing in care and was determined to speed up adoption. The bill underpins this approach, setting targets for each stage in the adoption process.

Are things bad and getting worse, then?
Adoption experts certainly agree on the need for change - and social services directors would acknowledge that more needs to be done. However, the trend appears to be moving in the right direction. Rob Hutchinson, children's spokesman for the Association of Directors of Social Services, says: "Social services departments have been making progress, not least because they have been given new resources by the government under the Quality Protects scheme. You can't just simply work on the basis of statistical figures - we can't push children into adoption to make up our figures - but generally more children are being adopted in local authorities." Last year, 2,700 children who were looked after by local authorities were adopted - representing half of all adoptions in England. This compares with 2,200 in 1999 and 1,900 in 1996. Of those 2,700, 420 were given up voluntarily and 1,100 were "freed for adoption".

Freed for adoption - what does that mean?
It's a phrase used when parents and social workers come to a supposedly "voluntary agreement" and means that, when a case comes to court, an adoption order will be granted without contest. But some parents, faced with losing their children, feel they're put under pressure to make it easier for the children by "freeing" them. And they resent the way it's phrased on the social services form, which they feel suggests that they're willingly giving up their children.

What else is the bill promising?
One of the significant elements will be the statutory post-adoption services on offer to adopting parents. At present, it's good practice, but rarely happens. Now, for the first time, adoptive parents will have a right to an assessment of their needs and to services meant to meet those needs.

Anything else I should know?
Isn't that enough? Well, one last thing to remember - this new piece of legislation pretty much brings together domestic adoption law in one act.

Many have special needs - such as learning difficulties, behavioural problems or disabilities - and some wait a long time to find the right adoptive parents. They tend to be older and may have siblings who need to be adopted with them. In short, they are much more difficult children to place successfully. What difference can a new law make? Recruitment of suitable families is key. At present, there is no national register of children available for adoption, so if social services can't find suitable parents for a child in their own catchment area, it's hard to hunt elsewhere. The bill will outline plans for a computerised database of children waiting for adoption throughout England and Wales (Scotland may join the database at a later date.) What else? Tony Blair made adoption his crusade last summer, when he headed a review. "When children cannot live with their birth parents, for whatever reason, we all share a responsibility to make sure that they have a chance of a fresh start, and an opportunity to enjoy the kind of loving family life which most of us take for granted." Did he praise motherhood and apple pie, too? Actually, he started to put the boot in just after that. Social workers weren't providing those happy families. "In far too many parts of the system, there is a lack of clarity, of consistency and of fairness. Most pressingly, children in an already vulnerable position are being badly let down," he said. The prime minister said he was fed up with children languishing in care and was determined to speed up adoption. The bill underpins this approach, setting targets for each stage in the adoption process. Are things bad and getting worse, then? Adoption experts certainly agree on the need for change - and social services directors would acknowledge that more needs to be done. However, the trend appears to be moving in the right direction. Rob Hutchinson, children's spokesman for the Association of Directors of Social Services, says: "Social services departments have been making progress, not least because they have been given new resources by the government under the Quality Protects scheme. You can't just simply work on the basis of statistical figures - we can't push children into adoption to make up our figures - but generally more children are being adopted in local authorities." Last year, 2,700 children who were looked after by local authorities were adopted - representing half of all adoptions in England. This compares with 2,200 in 1999 and 1,900 in 1996. Of those 2,700, 420 were given up voluntarily and 1,100 were "freed for adoption". Freed for adoption - what does that mean? It's a phrase used when parents and social workers come to a supposedly "voluntary agreement" and means that, when a case comes to court, an adoption order will be granted without contest. But some parents, faced with losing their children, feel they're put under pressure to make it easier for the children by "freeing" them. And they resent the way it's phrased on the social services form, which they feel suggests that they're willingly giving up their children. What else is the bill promising? One of the significant elements will be the statutory post-adoption services on offer to adopting parents. At present, it's good practice, but rarely happens. Now, for the first time, adoptive parents will have a right to an assessment of their needs and to services meant to meet those needs. Anything else I should know? Isn't that enough? Well, one last thing to remember - this new piece of legislation pretty much brings together domestic adoption law in one act.

webTitle: Comment: Opportunism seems set to conquer democratic virtue

fields.headline: Opportunism seems set to conquer democratic virtue
fields.standfirst:
If the election goes ahead on May 3, Labour's foot will be in its mouth

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: If the election goes ahead on May 3, Labour's foot will be in its mouth.
fields.body:
Does it matter when we have an election? The spirit of the age says no. We're living at a time of matchless apathy. Cynical about all politicians, we surely couldn't care less about the timing of their little games. Why would people trouble themselves with the finer points of a mechanistic question, requiring engagement with a class of person whose performance in the game makes no difference to them anyway? Isn't the choice Tony Blair soon has to make a very minor matter?

Call me a romantic, but I have to resist this, even though, when I did so a fortnight ago and proposed a postponement from May 3, I was dumped on by important people for credulous naivety. The hideous influx of foot and mouth disease has exposed a divide which is not between north and south, or rich and poor, or old and young, or numerate and illiterate, or friends of Blair and friends of Brown, or even between the city and the country. The divide is between two Britains, and two moods, and it becomes clearer day by day.

The first mood infiltrates the entire administration, the entire Labour party, and almost the entire band of Labour's hangers-on. It is stern and purposeful. The election is a piece of machinery, an essential cog in the apparatus of government, calibrated and primed for active duty on May 3 2001 ever since the date, four years ago, when democracy last did the business for Mr Blair.

This mood is much influenced by the diligence with which the given date has been prepared for. It is lost in wonder at the fineness of the budget, grovels before the timing of pension rises and other handouts, all of them made possible by the strategic foresight that led to an economic miracle reaching the apogee of its perceived brilliance at precisely the moment required. The hoardings are bought, the broadcasts planned, the party war-rooms readied for action down to the last on-line work-station allocated and mapped exclusively in the Guardian.

The mood regards itself as doing a job of work. All this diligence is for the good of the country. For the country needs another Labour government to continue the start that's been made, and if stealing a year off the five-year mandate is the way to maximise the outcome, the duty of the prime minister is clear. Plainly he must do it quickly. His recent visits to marginal constituencies north, south, east and west cannot be allowed to go to waste. How cretinous to imagine otherwise! For this is the plan, and the plan must be kept to, in the national interest.

Moreover, the public are apparently insisting that it should be. Asked if they want to vote now, more than 60% register the opinion that they wouldn't say no. An election by public demand! Besides, only 5% of voters live in areas affected by foot and mouth. Does anyone suggest the other 95% should be denied their rights to suit the convenience of this suffering, but ultimately insignificant, minority? Why should the majority be disappointed? The very fact that the election has been timetabled for the last four years becomes a reason for abruptly concluding it, come what may.

Such is the mood of the professionals. It's not untouched by a secret cynicism. The parties duly out-cynic each other. Labour privately reckons the 5% in question are mostly in Tory areas any way. For their part the Tories pretend that the last thing they want is any delaying of the moment when they have the Blair cabinet gagging on the ground, the electorate's boot across its windpipe. But the key to the mood is its stony-eyed indifference to the broader view, its denial that any kind of crisis might exceed in importance the crisis of seeing the computerised coordinates of an electoral plan disturbed.

There is a second Britain, and an alternative mood. In normal times it might accept some of the arguments of the professionals. The four-year term, after all, has become commonplace. Voters are used to the self- interested calculations of prime ministers. Each day now, though, the gulf gets wider between the thinking of the government and the feeling, the temper, the unarticulated sensibility of a public which, I believe, stretches well beyond the quietly disposable 5%.

It's a question of propriety and priorities. Even voters a hundred miles from the nearest bovine funeral pyre become aware that something is wrong. To insist on conducting an unnecessary election while the fires are raging and unburied cadavers stink, far from asserting the timeless importance of democracy, will show the frivolity with which the present incumbents regard it. A country alerted by television to the sombre mood this calamity deserves to summon up will find itself forced into a procedure which, just now, does not seem overwhelmingly important.

It's airily said that electoral procedure has changed. Nobody needs to move around any more, either to canvass or to vote. The mobile phone and the postal ballot are the disinfectants of virtual democracy. All true, for those who can arrange it. But all an apologia that comes from the professional's playbook, not from the experience that an election is supposed to be.

My guess is that the first mood is going to win this contest. Its exponents are extraordinarily unyielding. They're the more focused, the more organised, and one man's imperial thumb, up or down, is enough to give the signal. Unless the next 10 days produce an upsurge of foot and mouth that even he cannot claim is under control, the four-year critical path will reach its predestined end.

But two consequences can already be predicted with certainty. First, it will be a sour election. It was never likely to repeat the exultancy of 1997. It will now descend further into joylessness. In their guts, voters far beyond the county farmlands will feel it ought not to be happening. For all their preparations, the government will find the campaign hard to conduct. Unless foot and mouth is declared to be old news, or television is bludgeoned into adopting a new agenda, the paralysis of the countryside is likely to be displayed nightly alongside the affectations of imminent triumph over every problem, which is the message election campaigns are exclusively designed to convey. The contradiction will be jarring.

It seems unlikely, second, to do Labour any favours. An election called as the culmination of an exercise in well-managed opportunism will have the opposite effect. Labour won't lose, whatever the date. But Labour will seem ruthless, and an agent of the very cynicism Mr Blair once looked as though he seriously intended to dispel. A foot and mouth election will lose votes, not win them, for the people who inflict it on us in their larger plan to take over the 21st century. Or else we will forgive them even this, and plod, untroubled, on our downward path to the incinerator of democratic virtue.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Say what you will about MI5, it is deadly serious about opening itself up, and such is its craving for transparency that today at the Royal United Services Institute, a Whitehall-based think-tank, a big conference is being held on overseeing the security and intelligence services. For the first time, the MI5 chief, Sir Stephen Lander, will make a speech in public, and rightly much has been made of the fact that anyone can attend: all those interested, including the comedian Mark Thomas, were invited to apply until the hall was full. It is true that a couple of people were refused tickets. A certain David Shayler and his girlfriend Annie Machon, another ex-MI5 officer, were told they were blacklisted by the RUSI which perplexingly said only members and guests could attend, but that must have been a cock up. After all, the only other explanation - the deliberate exclusion of the only two people apart from Sir Stephen with inside knowledge of MI5 and serious points to make - would render the conference a time-wasting sham.



 Don't be bamboozled, however, into thinking that military intelligence is the preserve of the security services. The government shows plenty of brains as well in this field, not least when considering using army snipers to take out possibly infected livestock. It's a brilliant idea, albeit not quite as original as it might appear. In what must be regarded as a classic case of life initiating art, the inspiration for the brainwave was, as many of you will have guessed, Carry On Up The Khyber. The connoisseur's choice as the finest of its genre, this 1968 masterpiece features Her Majesty's Third Foot and Mouth regiment under the command of Sir Sidney Ruff-Diamond (Sid James).



 Thinking ahead to the army's involvement, meanwhile, my colleague Marina Hyde is minded to call the Ministry of Defence with an enquiry. Could we know which medals will be up for grabs, she asks Paul Sykes in the press office, should army snipers be called upon to enter the foot and mouth fray? "I don't think we'd be in that position," he replies. "I don't think we'd be talking about military decorations in such an event. Goodbye." Poor show.



 Everything I said yesterday would appear today will now appear tomorrow. If there's room.



 I was sad to miss my old friend Jonathan Aitken at the opening of a very stylish production of The Servant at the Lyric in Hammersmith on Tuesday night, and guess that religious studies in Oxford kept him from seeing his nephew Jack Davenport reprise the part of "Mr Tony" played by Dirk Bogarde in the film. Then again, since in his book he credits an item here, about a sermon he gave in a church close to the theatre, with persuading him to resign, perhaps the area holds painful memories. Whatever, he missed a bit of a treat - although whether members of the butlers' school which has taken a large block booking will see it that way is unclear. Still, if they choose to view Robin Maugham's play as a teaching aid, and not an unusually dark study of homosexual power plays, that's their business.



 Good to see Nasty Nick writing in G2 yesterday, and how acute he was in pinpointing all the privileges given to Big Brother's celebrity housemates that were denied him and his colleagues. "There were," he says of the mollycoddled incumbents, "radiators all over the house" - but none when he was involved. In the summer. Such a bright boy.



 "Matthew," begins an email from Paul Desmond of Tavistock Communications, "would you be interested in a picture-story on Ballykissangel actress Marion O'Dwyer and top Irish chef Richard Corrigan joining forces at his restaurant [name deleted] to prepare a traditional Irish dish for the Bank of Ireland's St Patrick's Day Business Challenge?" No, Paul, I would not. Nor would anyone else.

fields.headline: Now for democracy
fields.standfirst: What Mr Museveni needs to do next
fields.trailText: In Africa, another election, another fiddle. But in Uganda, it is not quite so simple. Yoweri Museveni, the country's ruler since 1986, was duly re-elected this week to serve what the constitution suggests will be a final five-year term.
fields.body:
In Africa, another election, another fiddle. But in Uganda, it is not quite so simple. Yoweri Museveni, the country's ruler since 1986, was duly re-elected this week to serve what the constitution suggests will be a final five-year term. His principal opponent, Kizza Besigye, who took 28% of the vote compared to the president's 69%, just as predictably complained of "massive fraud" and sought legal redress. But Dr Besigye gave assurances that he would respect the Kampala high court's ruling, if indeed the issue goes that far. And in any case, independent election observers declared that while intimidation and malpractice affected perhaps 10% of all polling stations, the overall outcome was not in doubt. "This election reflects the will of Ugandans," the monitors said and Mr Museveni was their clear choice. So a bit of fiddle by the president, then, but nothing really egregious.

Such pragmatical exculpation is both too harsh on Mr Museveni and too generous. Harsh because those who recall how Uganda was trashed and bloodied by Idi Amin and Milton Obote know how considerable is his achievement in creating political stability and a sort of representative governance. Harsh, too, given Mr Museveni's success in extending primary education, reducing poverty, encouraging private sector business and cooperating constructively with foreign aid donors, which still provide 50% of government revenues. Uganda's largely agricultural economy grew at a steady 5% last year and this despite often vicious disruption by the Sudan-based Lord's Resistance Army and western rebels.

But too generous to Mr Museveni for a number of reasons, not least his unpopular, self-serving involvement in Congo's war and his unnecessary falling-out with Rwanda. He has failed to curb chronic corruption within ruling circles, failed to stamp out human rights abuses by the ISO and DMI internal security organisations and by the police, and failed, as in 1996, to create the conditions for a free and fair campaign preceding this week's poll. But Mr Museveni's most dangerous failure is destined to be his continuing refusal to allow opposition groups to organise as independent political parties. His monolithic, supposedly all-inclusive Movement is unlikely to survive him; yet its disintegration may bring new disasters. By way of legacy, Mr Museveni should devote his next, last term to building a responsive, pluralist democracy.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: I hate Flash. And I do not know any regular web users who do not feel the same way about it. For those of you that do not know are not familiar with it by name, Flash provides those animated introductions to websites that may possibly be fun once, but soon become an irritation.
fields.body:
I hate Flash. And I do not know any regular web users who do not feel the same way about it. For those of you that do not know are not familiar with it by name, Flash provides those animated introductions to websites that may possibly be fun once, but soon become an irritation.

My theory is that these Flash intros are the result of a conspiracy between web designers and company bosses who do not know any better.

I can picture the scene. At one end of a room with a big screen behind him stands a man in black with piercings. At the other end sit the suits. They watch as the company logo spins round and some sort of techno music comes out of the speakers. "Great," think the suits. "This is just like our own little TV programme." After all, they never use the web and television is the obvious point of reference. This will probably be the last time they ever look at their company website.

The man in black is happy because he picks up the cheque. His staff get to have fun showing off the tricks they can perform with Flash. Only the poor surfer who is trying to get a bit of information off the site is fed up.

This whole situation is a symptom of the immaturity of the web. The medium is getting in the way of the message.

More than 30 years ago my parents had a friend whose entire record collection con sisted of Herb Alpert and test tones. He did not particularly like Herb Alpert. I do not think he actually liked music. But these recordings showed off the wonders of his hi-fi system.

More recently the birth of desktop publishing (DTP) did terrible things to design. The people with the technical ability to use the software measured success by the number of fonts and special effects they could get onto a single page.

Fortunately DTP has grown up. The programs have become easier to use and have moved out of the hands of the techies and into the hands of the designers. The world is a better-looking place for that.

That is not true of the web. OK, the people creating the sites are called designers, but it is still their technological prowess, the graphical tricks they can do, that is the measure of their ability. It is not the images that are losing out. It is the words.

Look at the top ten websites visited by UK surfers according to online researcher Media Metrix. It is entirely filled with sites that have virtually no graphics on their opening pages. The sites are all household names run by Microsoft, Yahoo! Freeserve and the BBC.

Research involving individual surfers points the same way. At the end of last year Forrester Research said that high-quality content was the number one reason, cited by 75% of respondents, for returning to a website.

"Content" is an admittedly vague word that can cover everything you see on a website including games, graphics, streamed media and all the other wonders of the net. But the principal form of content is text. Another piece of research, this time by the prestigious Stanford Poynter Institute in the United States, tracks users' eyeballs and finds that they go straight to text on a page rather than the more obvious graphics or adverts.

The lessons from this are not being learned by most website owners. Recently, for instance, my television gave up the ghost and I decide to buy a new one. All the major electrical retailers have websites with illustrations of their products. The problem is that a portable looks the same size as a home cinema. Without clear, written descriptions, the graphics are meaningless.

Whoever coined the phrase "A picture is worth a thousand words" is largely to blame. Take a look through this newspaper and see how many photograph would mean anything without a caption to explain who the participants are and what they are doing. Not many pictures are worth a thousand words.

Even sites where the sole reason for their existence is content often fair poorly. Newspapers, magazines and broadcasters, with a few honourable exceptions, tend to shovel what they use elsewhere straight onto the website. There is no concern as to whether it is appropriate for that medium.

The problem throughout is that while companies are willing to spend substantial amounts of money on website design and backend systems for e-commerce, words remain the poor relation. This should not be the case. Creating a good-looking website is nowhere near as difficult as it was even a couple of years ago. That should free-up cash for content.

There is also a commercial logic from another medium. Only one of the 10 largest- circulation magazines in the UK is not branded by a well-known business. The companies are spending their money to attract revenue from their customers.

Often spending it on their websites would make far more sense. Instead of a customer having to visit a shop or at least pick up the phone, they are only a mouse-click away from buying something.

But it is not enough to bung text created for another medium straight onto a website. Surfers first want descriptive headlines, bullet points and short summaries. But behind that bite-size content they want to be able to dig deeper. That is where the internet really comes into its own because there are none of the physical limitations imposed by the printed page or broadcasters' time.

The final argument for the importance of words on the web is simple. You can't put a Flash graphic into a search engine.

 Nick Clayton is managing director of internet content company Penpusher.com

fields.headline: Crossfire
fields.trailText: So the Norwegian Red Cross has taken money from an oil company, but says it won't stop it from being critical (Red Cross signs deal with Statoil, March 10).
fields.body:
So the Norwegian Red Cross has taken money from an oil company, but says it won't stop it from being critical (Red Cross signs deal with Statoil, March 10). The trouble the British Red Cross found itself in after accepting £250,000 from Nestlé in 1999 may be relevant. We were disappointed that when challenged on the ethics of entering into partnership with Nestlé because of the company's baby milk marketing record, the charity defended the company while refusing to meet with Nestlé's critics (we have been attempting to brief the British Red Cross for 18 months). We reluctantly decided to report the matter to the charity commission. The British Red Cross has since moderated its statements and announced that it is commissioning research into Nestlé's activities. Whether Statoil contributes to as much suffering as Nestlé is beyond my knowledge, but I hope the Norwegian Red Cross will be more open.
Mike Brady
Baby Milk Action

fields.headline: Lord Healey reveals all
fields.trailText: It may not be pornographic (Lord Healey took this picture, March 14), but it is, at best, patronising, unnecessary, intrusive and prurient. Did Lord Healey obtain his subject's permission?
fields.body:
It may not be pornographic (Lord Healey took this picture, March 14), but it is, at best, patronising, unnecessary, intrusive and prurient. Did Lord Healey obtain his subject's permission? How can society present a united front against paedophiles when it is considered "natural" to have photographs of naked children enlarged on gallery walls? Perhaps a short-term answer might be to substitute the picture of the Chinese child with "natural" snaps of Lord Healey and Austin Mitchell eating ice cream with their penises hanging out of their trousers?
Martin Davis
Norwich

 Each day while walking my dog in the park I take time to pick up her mess and dispose of it because I think this good etiquette. The most depressing aspect of Tierney Gearon's photographs is the fact that she sees it as perfectly acceptable to encourage, nay celebrate and be amused by, her child dropping his trousers and peeing wherever he deems appropriate.
Ian MacMillan
London

 The only curious message I got from the photos was that the girl is taller than the boy. Sometimes I wonder what people see in simple images.
Kerstin Pramberger
Inzlingen, Germany

 Pornographic? More like someone else's tasteless and boring holiday snaps. Yawn.
Joan Parry
Brading, Isle of Wight

fields.headline: Well done, Mr Brown
fields.trailText: No doubt middle England won't be interested, but I'm sure many readers will be concerned that the adult rate for jobseekers' allowance rises by just 85p this April (Labour imposes tough new rules on jobless, March 14).
fields.body:
No doubt middle England won't be interested, but I'm sure many readers will be concerned that the adult rate for jobseekers' allowance rises by just 85p this April (Labour imposes tough new rules on jobless, March 14). Perhaps Mr Brown will explain how people are to manage on £53.05 a week, when the pensioner's minimum income guarantee is £39 higher.
Tim Mickleburgh
Grimsby, Lincolnshire

 Odd Mr Blair has not reconciled his problems of the indolent jobless and the army's lack of cannon fodder (Head-hunters enlisted, March 13) by reinstating the press-gang.
Conor McCarthy
Newcastle

 If it wasn't for Nick Brown bringing the foot and mouth outbreak under control, we might very well be in the middle of a crisis (Reports, March 14).
Richard George
Stockport

 The prospect of a May election, with a postal vote and no canvassers etc has a certain appeal, does it not?
T Todd
Abingdon, Oxon

 So William Hague is proposing "slaughter on suspicion". I missed the beginning of the story on the news. Is this Tory policy on foot and mouth or asylum seekers?
Tristan Clayton
Cambridge

 Would a Vaz-ectomy help Tony Blair avoid future embarrassment (Letters, March 14)?
Stephen James
Yarm, Cleveland

 Thank goodness we have Salman Rushdie and his ilk to tell us how to enjoy Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon etc (Saturday Review, March 10). Otherwise we would just go ahead enjoying things for the "wrong" reasons. And we wouldn't even know it!
Ellen Olliffe
Beckenham, Kent

fields.headline: Class action
fields.trailText: Graham Lane, chairman of the Local Government Association, says "a strike would be easier to deal with" than the cover-to-contract action. NASUWT has made it clear it accepts totting up, whereby teachers would continue to cover, but be compensated for lost marking and preparation time on, say, Friday afternoon, when pupils would be sent home early.
fields.body:
Graham Lane, chairman of the Local Government Association, says "a strike would be easier to deal with" than the cover-to-contract action. NASUWT has made it clear it accepts totting up, whereby teachers would continue to cover, but be compensated for lost marking and preparation time on, say, Friday afternoon, when pupils would be sent home early. That is a legitimate, but moderate and responsible form of action to deal with totally unreasonable demands being made upon teachers. The action is intended to be protective not disruptive. It seems that Graham Lane would prefer far more disruptive action where no pupil would receive any education whatsoever.
Nigel de Gruchy
General secretary, NASUWT

fields.headline: Taking on the Sun
fields.trailText: I am writing in response to the kind calls, donations and offers of assistance we have received on Esther Thomas's behalf since you wrote of her plight (Sun can be sued for distress, court rules, March 13).
fields.body:
I am writing in response to the kind calls, donations and offers of assistance we have received on Esther Thomas's behalf since you wrote of her plight (Sun can be sued for distress, court rules, March 13).

The costs risk of contesting a court of appeal hearing is in the region of £20-30,000. If the case proceeds to the House of Lords, as envisaged, this sum could be doubled. Costs follow the event in the superior courts, which means that if we lose this test case, Esther may have to foot the bill herself. We also have to raise monies to fund our own legal team and we will require the advocacy skills of a top silk in the court of appeal to ensure that there is equality of arms and hence that Esther can obtain a fair hearing.

The court of appeal will have to balance the Sun's freedom of speech against Esther's rights to privacy and protection from racial harassment. The decision should set the tone of reporting for years to come. Either the tabloid press will be free to harass through unreasonable, biased and inflammatory articles or they will have to report in a responsible and objective manner.

If we win, everyone, not just the rich and famous, will be able to challenge a course of reporting which unreasonably causes them harassment. At present, you have to prove falsehood (and malice) and have substantial reserves to contemplate suing a newspaper for defamation.

Your support means a lot to Esther and to us. It was a joy to know that we were not fighting alone.
Lawrence Davies
North Lambeth Law Centre

webTitle: Letters: MP fights back in battle of Hastings

fields.headline: MP fights back in battle of Hastings
fields.trailText: It is never pleasant to be personally attacked, but it is of particular concern to see the exercise of democracy so thoroughly rubbished (Comment, March 8). George Monbiot's attitude towards the various bodies who are 100% behind the Hastings bypass is condescending in the extreme.
fields.body:
It is never pleasant to be personally attacked, but it is of particular concern to see the exercise of democracy so thoroughly rubbished (Comment, March 8). George Monbiot's attitude towards the various bodies who are 100% behind the Hastings bypass - residents associations, Hastings borough council, Rother district council and East Sussex county council, as well as the 80% of constituents who support these measures - is condescending in the extreme.

He claims that unemployment would rise by 800 if the bypass is built. Those figures are based on an economic model and if the figures are used in the same way for the non-bypass scenario, unemployment would rise by 1,500. He also fails to mention the existing requirement to build new housing in Rother, which will happen with or without the bypass. The demand for jobs will rise in any event, but only the bypass will provide the 8,000 plus extra jobs.

I very much support Labour's policy of preferring rail to roads and public to private transport. However, there is no doubt that the integrated transport solution for Hastings includes the bypass. In Mr Monbiot's skewed vision, that equates to a blueprint for further road building. Residents know this is simply a relief road that should have been built years ago, and which will relieve the urban environment and produce economic growth as part of a larger package of improvements to bus and rail services.
Michael Foster MP

 Peter Hetherington accuses the south-east England development agency, wrongly, of "going for growth al all costs" (Dirty old towns, March 12). Our regional economic strategy, sets out a programme for balanced, sustainable growth, which ensures protection and enhancement of the environment and meets the needs of communities.

Regeneration funding is the largest part of our budget and this is being targeted at communities that have fallen behind the rest of the south-east in living standards and quality of life, indeed the deprivation in areas of Kent and Sussex is comparable with the worst areas in the north.
Anthony Dunnett
Chief executive, South East England Development Agency

fields.headline: Webwatch
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Give water | Sounds good
fields.body:
Watery gave
Thames Water is supporting a click-and-donate site called Give Water, which aims to give £100,000 to provide clean water to the developing world, and encourage visitors to donate as well. Just go to the site and click on the water carrier; once 250,000 clicks are received, Thames Water will make the donation to the charity WaterAid. But you can also sign up to donate cash yourself, or set up a standing order.

Sounds good
The legal UK peer-to-peer music file sharing site Wippit is going to start using copyright protecting software on the MP3 files it makes available to subscribers. Cantametrix makes the software, called MusicDNA, which allows Wippit to track which files from which record companies are downloaded. The software also maintains quality control on the files. You probably know how annoying it is to go through a 15 minute Napster download only to discover you're missing the last two minutes of your chosen tune.

Easy listening
Bored with the old illegal Metallica MP3s? Then why not try compositions based on sequences from the human genome, fractals and earthquakes? Brent Hugh's 'music in math and science' page on MP3.com has to be one of the quirkiest and most delightful musical spaces on the web.

Why not download Hugh's Fractal Variations, Music of the Human Genome, or Earthquake Fugue (for Six Elephants)? Other composers have such offerings as Mathscendence II, Fractal Dream #5: Strange Attractors, and Cosmic Times (based on deep space radio signals).

Net well soon
Help save the net economy by, er, buying something. San Francisco e-marketing firm Iconocast has come up with the idea of Back the Web Day on April 3. They figure that if everyone demonstrates that they are willing to buy or donate online on this day, it will raise a defiant fist in the face of the mockers and "help the net regain its respect". They've even got a manifesto and an official anthem.

Soul trader
Need a "dark gift" but not sure you want to enter a Faustian pact with the devil? Why not visit the Lease Your Soul website, which wisely counsels: "No need to sell your soul with today's flexible financing", just lease it instead. The site provides an easy application form so that your soul can be considered, and there's a simple checklist on which prospective lessors can indicate which dark gifts they would like to receive. Other services include "Cash advances on reality checks."

Door stop
Although the credit card companies themselves recently reported that online fraud is minuscule in comparison with the millions lost annually in "real world" fraud, consumers continue to worry about their card details going AWOL over the net. For wary web shoppers, the venerable security firm Securicor has a new online offering that it hopes will quell such fears. Its SafeDoor service is an online shopping mall with a difference - the merchants never see card details, which are held solely by Securicor and protected by digital certificates and encryption. More than 40 merchants should be on the site by the end of the month.

Brain wave
National Brain Injury Week runs this week, from March 12-18, and a new study for Queen Elizabeth's Foundation on this subject reveals that approximately one million patients in the UK present to hospitals each year with head injuries. But little government or social help is offered for rehabilitation aftercare. The Foundation hopes the report will help raise awareness and spearhead a change in brain injury rehabilitation delivery in the UK. Just go to the site and click on the water carrier; once 250,000 clicks are received, Thames Water will make the donation to the charity WaterAid. But you can also sign up to donate cash yourself, or set up a standing order. Sounds good The legal UK peer-to-peer music file sharing site Wippit is going to start using copyright protecting software on the MP3 files it makes available to subscribers. Cantametrix makes the software, called MusicDNA, which allows Wippit to track which files from which record companies are downloaded. The software also maintains quality control on the files. You probably know how annoying it is to go through a 15 minute Napster download only to discover you're missing the last two minutes of your chosen tune. Easy listening Bored with the old illegal Metallica MP3s? Then why not try compositions based on sequences from the human genome, fractals and earthquakes? Brent Hugh's 'music in math and science' page on MP3.com has to be one of the quirkiest and most delightful musical spaces on the web. Why not download Hugh's Fractal Variations, Music of the Human Genome, or Earthquake Fugue (for Six Elephants)? Other composers have such offerings as Mathscendence II, Fractal Dream #5: Strange Attractors, and Cosmic Times (based on deep space radio signals). Net well soon Help save the net economy by, er, buying something. San Francisco e-marketing firm Iconocast has come up with the idea of Back the Web Day on April 3. They figure that if everyone demonstrates that they are willing to buy or donate online on this day, it will raise a defiant fist in the face of the mockers and "help the net regain its respect". Why not visit the Lease Your Soul website, which wisely counsels: "No need to sell your soul with today's flexible financing", just lease it instead. The site provides an easy application form so that your soul can be considered, and there's a simple checklist on which prospective lessors can indicate which dark gifts they would like to receive. Other services include "Cash advances on reality checks." webTitle: Letters: How to get Mugabe out

fields.headline: How to get Mugabe out
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe must have exulted at Liz McGregor's article on Zimbabwe (Softly, softly, March 13). Sadly, his oppressed people would have despaired.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe must have exulted at Liz McGregor's article on Zimbabwe (Softly, softly, March 13). Sadly, his oppressed people would have despaired. Zimbabweans do not still live in mud huts, hobbled by a forelock-tugging paternalism. Why should we excuse Mugabe's insufferably barbaric conduct on the grounds of "male pride" and "respect for the aged"? Modern Zimbabwe is just not like that.

Take Wilfred, the Chinese-trained Zanla war veteran, who accompanied me round Harare a fortnight ago. "We didn't fight that war," he said, "for things to get as bad as they were under Smith. We fought for freedom - freedom that Mugabe is now destroying."

I agree Mugabe should be able to retire with dignity, but without the golden hand-shake, for a man already replete with stolen millions. That does not mean we should button our lips for fear of offending him. Britain should not be inhibited by residual post-colonial guilt from speaking out. Most Zimbabweans have shed any lingering burden of post-colonial resentment. We should match them.

Suspending Zimbabwe from the Commonwealth would be the clearest way for its neighbours to show their condemnation of a regime whose reputation is infecting all of southern Africa. To maintain that an African dictator should be judged by lower standards than we apply to ourselves is to condemn Zimbabweans to a worse life than they want for themselves, and which they deserve.
Francis Maude MP

 Liz McGregor's approach to the search for a solution in Zimbabwe at last adds a voice of lucidity to the debate. However, her sound conclusions are undermined by misguided conjecture. The solution to this seemingly intractable problem lies in Africa. But not, as Ms McGregor suggests, at the doors of Obasanjo, Nujoma and Masire. Mr Mugabe's disdain is just as applicable to bygone African leaders as it is to western governments. In the face of such contempt, politics and reasoning bear little relevance to the circumstances. It is economics that will provide the solution and the key is South Africa.

President Mbeki is stuck between a rock and a hard place. But ultimately it is incumbent upon the South African government to acknowledge that, on balance, they, along with the rest of the region, will lose more by appeasing Mugabe than they will by switching off the electricity, cutting the fuel lines and denouncing his policies.

The Foreign Office must also play its role. It is time Robin Cook publicly put pressure on South Africa. For it is apparent that both Cook's benign voyeurism and Francis Maude's pedestrian rantings have served little purpose.
Patrick Marks
London

 Liz McGregor is wrong about the Zimbabwe Democracy Trust, which was established to promote democracy, freedom and the rule of law (not principles apparently beloved by Zanu-PF). Our only interest in the MDC is that it was indisputably the will of the people that they win last year's elections. Were it not for the campaign of violence and murder, the party would now have a majority in parliament.

The only hope for the survival of Zimbabwe is for Mugabe to step down as soon as possible. If his departure can be hastened by gentle persuasion and the arrangement of an honourable exit - as was argued by Francis Maude in Harare last month - so much the better. Until now the world has followed Ms McGregor's advice of keeping quiet and hoping President Mugabe would go away - a strategy that has not been blessed with conspicuous success.
John Collins
Zimbabwe Democracy Trust

fields.headline: Carry On Up The Anorak
fields.standfirst: A TV show might have raised few laughs but the internet can be fun, chuckles  Mike Anderiesz
fields.trailText: A TV show might have raised few laughs but the internet can be fun, chuckles Mike Anderiesz
fields.body:
Online comedy has come a long way in the past year. Only last summer C4's abysmal Dotcomedy series could find nothing more amusing than a stream of sexual perversions and a simpering Gail Porter, one of the reasons it was unceremoniously axed at the end of the first series. Now, however, comedy is alive and kicking hard - providing a foothold to many a struggling writer and offering unlikely hope to internet content providers looking for instant stickiness.

Stickiness is already the big buzzword of 2001, as websites struggle to find content which will see users returning again and again, thereby seeing more of their precious banner advertising. Traditionally, the ultimate in sticky content has been porn and competitions, with news trailing in a poor third and comedy almost nowhere to be seen.

"Comedy can be very sticky, if properly executed" says Mike Ragsdale, one of the three founder members of Hecklers.com, the US site launched in 1995 which now boasts 400,000 unique visitors per month and a claimed advertising click through of 3%, when the industry average is 0.5%. Interestingly, Hecklers not only applauds this loyalty but relies upon it. "While some comedians have to hope that their writers can come up with a few good laughs here and there, all we have to do is hope that of the 5,000 emails we receive and review every day, that a handful of them contain an hilarious joke that would have otherwise gone untold, and unrecorded."

In the past, bandwidth restrictions ensured online comedy catered for the lowest common denominator, with the likes of www.jokeindex.com quickly replacing the old Xerox funnies which used to be stuck to company notice-boards, if not gaining a reputation for originality. This too is changing, as improved download times make both animation and video a feasible part of comedy output.

"The problem with internet comedy_" explains Charlie Brooker, co-founder of the UK comedy collective Zeppotron, "is that the user is sitting in an uncomfortable chair with one hand on the mouse and there's a million things they would rather be doing. You have to keep things short. Five minutes is too long, two minutes is about our maximum."

Zeppotron was founded at the end of last year from the writing core of the 11-o'clock show and is best known for the Radio Times spoof TV Go Home and the animated series Office Romance. The TV Go Home page alone boasts 40,000 unique visitors a month with an average visit lasting 14 minutes - highly sticky by anyone's standards. Using this brand-based approach has already worked in mainstream broadcasting for decades. Indeed, the company is 25% owned by Endemol, responsible for TV hits such as Big Brother and Ready Steady Cook - all simple formulae, relentlessly hammered home.

"You do have to be fairly unsubtle," says Brooker. "You have to convince people quickly that's it's a good thing to hang around, which lends itself to sledgehammer tactics. The problem with instant publishing is that writers tend to get carried away and not edit themselves."

However, there is a worry that comedy could go the same way as porn, with users gravitating towards harder material which would be shunned by mainstream broadcasters. Popular spoof-site The Onion may be consistently funny but veers perilously closer to slander. It boasts a steady million visits per week.

"It's really hard to imagine online comedy becoming more radical, if you're talking about the subject matter." concludes Ragsdale. "I mean, at this point online, is there anything we haven't already seen, in terms of sexuality or violence or taboos?

"Advertisers simply aren't comfortable supporting "Rated-X" and even "Rated-R" humour. Believe me, we've tried. And without advertisers or some major corporate backing, it's hard to imagine how a large comedy media company could ever evolve."

All of which puts comedy back where it started, coming to terms with new technology but wrestling with its conscience as to how far to push it. As many a struggling comic has already discovered, being radical is all well and good -but it rarely pays the bills.

The web's idea of funny
www.theonion.com

An accurate pastiche of both Yahoo and CNN, the Onion maintains a hectic stream of very amusing spoofs. While the site is primarily US-oriented, headlines such as "Sociologist Considers Own Behavior Indicative Of Larger Trends" has to be worth further consideration.

www.e4.com

C4's new digital channel has already managed some pioneering comedy such as the excellent Banzai, and its new website delves into original online material too. Unfortunately, the site is unnecessarily Flash-heavy, making it hard to navigate for those using slower PCs.

www.hecklers.com

Inventive American slander, broken into bite sized chunks.

www.disappointment.com
Like most comedy, this quirky, low-budget shrine to tasteless observation divides those who comes across it. The Net recently voted it one of the 5 un-funniest on the web; the author's own girlfriend, described as "crushingly dull and looks like a pig" would be likely to agree. Others, however, think it's hilarious.

www.zeppotron.com

The Zeppotron site focuses on their three best-known comedy brands, TV Go Home, Office Romance and Unnovations. All very funny, for those not easily offended, and much of the content is fast approaching the best standards of TV comedy.

fields.headline: Lost stock & two smoking analysts
fields.standfirst: As the dot.com slump goes on, the finger pointing has started, reports  Edward Helmore
fields.trailText: As the dot.com slump goes on, the finger pointing has started, reports Edward Helmore
fields.body:
How the mighty have fallen. Little more than year ago, Jeff Bezos was flying high. The price of Amazon.com shares was in the stratosphere and the company's beaming 38-year-old chief executive was being lionised as Time magazine's Man of the Year. Supported by the enthusiam of fawning Wall Street analysts, Bezos - like much of the internet world - could walk on water. But no longer: As the internet economy has collapsed, not even the golden calves of IT are immune to the sour mood of the market.

And no one is more out of favour than the Wall Street analysts on whose every pronouncement - "buy", "sell", "hold" - investors once took as gospel. As the Nasdaq dipped below 2,000 this week, more than 3,000 points off its peak of 5,049 just one year ago, the analysts who promoted the tech boom are now being held responsible for the billions lost by investors, many of them individuals seduced into the markets by the lure of easy money.

Call it the blame game: the press blames the analysts, the dot.comers blame the venture capitalists, the venture capitalists blame the markets and almost everyone blames the media. But it is the cheer-leaders of the new economy - analysts - who are taking the heat for the collapse of technology stocks. "The Age of the Analyst is dead," proclaims this week's New Yorker. "In the last five months the clued-in analyst has been exposed as clueless and the equity-analysis game has proved to be something of a sham."

A year ago, Morgan Stanley's Mary Meeker was basking in adulation. She had been dubbed Queen of the Net by supporting Amazon. She had been subject of a glowing profile in the New Yorker in 1999, named the third most powerful woman in business by Fortune (and put on the cover) in the same year and invited to speak at the World Economic Forum in Davos. Meeker became the highest paid woman on Wall Street with a reported base salary of $15 million a year.

Then there was Merrill Lynch's Henry Blodget, Wall Street's loudest cheerleader for internet stocks. Named King Henry by the Wall Street Journal, the red-haired Blodget was an obscure stock picker before he predicted in December 1998 that Amazon, then trading at $240, could hit $400 a share within a year, pushing the stock up 20% in a day. That made him the media's favourite internet talking head.

From the day he burst into the headlines in 1998, Blodget has been mentioned 95 times in the Wall Street Journal, 66 times in the New York Times, 53 times in The Washington Post (which ran a huge profile of him last year) and 27 times in Business Week. Since the beginning of last year, he has been mentioned (or interviewed) on television 816 times.

Then the internet bubble burst. Meeker's stock picks - Ask Jeeves, Drugstore.com, Priceline.com, Women.com - have fallen by as much as 96%. Blodget's top recommendations have plunged 79% - including eToys and Pets.com, both of which have shut down.

The pair are rarely on television now. Meeker hasn't been on CNBC since October. The New York Times says Blodget and others like him need to go "a long way toward explaining why the market for technology stocks has crashed," despite the fact that, like many, they have now changed their tune.

But the story of how Meeker, Blodget and others encouraged investors to bid stocks up to levels they now admit were unjustifiable goes a long way toward explaining why the market for technology stocks has since crashed.

Looking back a year after the peak, it is clear that prices hit astronomical levels in part because of a euphoria infecting not just day traders but giants like Merrill Lynch. "When someone appears to be right, they become larger than life," says Peter Bernstein, a veteran consultant to big money managers.

As the Nasdaq soared, it was considered imprudent to get too particular about business models, let alone poke around at individual valuations. After all, Amazon's stock, like so many internet stocks, relied on the dreams of small investors fed by upbeat TV sound bites from Blodget, Meeker and the rest. And Amazon, perhaps more than any other firm, had a lot to thank the analysts for - and a lot to lose if the sentiment reversed.

Take Amazon: within weeks of its initial public share offering in May 1997, the company was trading below the offering price and Wall Street wags had nicknamed it Amazon.bomb. But by the time Meeker started promoting it three months later, the internet was becoming a mass phenomenon, not just a gathering place for geeks. Amazon, Meeker wrote, "is the leading retailer/ merchandiser on the 'net."

"The great paradox of the analyst's reign was that, as their stature grew, the quality of their analysis plummeted," noted the New Yorker. "With few exceptions, analysts did not see trouble coming and didn't warn their investors to get out of the way."

For her part, Meeker says she was always worried about becoming a posterchild for dot.com mania. "I did not aspire to be a media celebrity in any way, shape or form," she says. "I felt uncomfortable being in the limelight." Blodget, too, has taken a fall. "Things change," he said last week. "The market went from saying, 'We like companies that are growing quickly but are losing a lot of money' to saying, 'We want to see earnings.' It's very hard to predict a 180-degree turn like that."

But some heroes have emerged. Although seen as a heretic when other analysts were still feeding investor euphoria, a 29-year-old Lehman Bros analyst named Ravi Suria issued a scorching report in February saying Amazon would run out of money this year.

Suria had already set himself up as Bezos's nemesis-in-chief. Last June, the then-little-known analyst sounded the first warning, arguing that Amazon was showing the "financial characteristics that have driven innumerable retailers to disaster throughout history". His analysis created a sensation.

The company called it "hogwash", and chief executive Jeff Bezos personally disputed the conclusions. Investors, however, voted with their wallets, sending the shares down nearly 20% in a day. At that time, Amazon stock was trading at around $45, and has fallen ever since.

In theory, the report should have made Suria's career. After all, Meeker and Blodget had become Wall Street and media darlings after writing about Amazon. But they, of course, were on the side of the vast e-commerce company which sells about 11% of all goods sold online and which - along with the auction house eBay - is probably the dot.com most beloved by its customers. But unlike eBay, the strength of Amazon's balance sheet is constantly in dispute.

For Suria, who likes to smoke cigars and skydive, and lists an interest in imported bottled beer, taking on ever-sunny Bezos meant taking on the whole internet economy.

Already irked by Suria's warning last June, the subsequent report on Febuary 5 started a war. "Obviously, you can't take this seriously," Amazon spokesman Bill Curry said. "It's a silly report that's chock full of errors."

According to the New York Observer, Amazon went to considerable lengths to quash Suria's predictions. When Amazon executives learned of the report's harsh nature - that the spectre of bankruptcy was being raised - they leapt to the phones. They held up publication for 10 days, it is claimed.

Whether Suria's predictions prove right or wrong (in the aftermath of his report, half a dozen Wall Street analysts have downgraded Amazon shares, some even saying the company may still be overvalued) he may have changed the nature of the tech analysts' trade.

"Whether or not the Lehman analyst is right to take a bearish stance on Amazon.com, give him credit for taking a much-needed skeptical (sic) stand," said TheStreet.com.

Of course, Bezos strongly denies Amazon is in trouble. But the company has been getting bad press for plans to make severance packages for some 1,300 employees laid off last month, conditional on their continued silence with a "non-disparagement" clause.

And, earlier this month, Bezos completed his third sale of small portions of his Amazon holdings, which total more than $1 billion at current market prices.

In late 1998, Bezos's sales brought him about $23m. Last May it was $20m. This month it was $12m.

And, in the wake of this latest report, even Blodget has downplayed expectations for the firm by saying: "still comfortable, but on alert".

Suria is confident that he will be vindicated after months of having his credibility questioned; Bezos is adamant he will not. "The company has never been in better shape," he said recently.

The same cannot be said of the analysts' trade.

Named King Henry by the Wall Street Journal, the red-haired Blodget was an obscure stock picker before he predicted in December 1998 that Amazon, then trading at $240, could hit $400 a share within a year, pushing the stock up 20% in a day. That made him the media's favourite internet talking head. From the day he burst into the headlines in 1998, Blodget has been mentioned 95 times in the Wall Street Journal, 66 times in the New York Times, 53 times in The Washington Post (which ran a huge profile of him last year) and 27 times in Business Week. Since the beginning of last year, he has been mentioned (or interviewed) on television 816 times. Then the internet bubble burst. Meeker's stock picks - Ask Jeeves, Drugstore.com, Priceline.com, Women.com - have fallen by as much as 96%. Blodget's top recommendations have plunged 79% - including eToys and Pets.com, both of which have shut down. The pair are rarely on television now. Meeker hasn't been on CNBC since October. The New York Times says Blodget and others like him need to go "a long way toward explaining why the market for technology stocks has crashed," despite the fact that, like many, they have now changed their tune. But the story of how Meeker, Blodget and others encouraged investors to bid stocks up to levels they now admit were unjustifiable goes a long way toward explaining why the market for technology stocks has since crashed. Looking back a year after the peak, it is clear that prices hit astronomical levels in part because of a euphoria infecting not just day traders but giants like Merrill Lynch. "When someone appears to be right, they become larger than life," says Peter Bernstein, a veteran consultant to big money managers. As the Nasdaq soared, it was considered imprudent to get too particular about business models, let alone poke around at individual valuations. After all, Amazon's stock, like so many internet stocks, relied on the dreams of small investors fed by upbeat TV sound bites from Blodget, Meeker and the rest. And Amazon, perhaps more than any other firm, had a lot to thank the analysts for - and a lot to lose if the sentiment reversed. Take Amazon: within weeks of its initial public share offering in May 1997, the company was trading below the offering price and Wall Street wags had nicknamed it Amazon.bomb. But by the time Meeker started promoting it three months later, the internet was becoming a mass phenomenon, not just a gathering place for geeks. Amazon, Meeker wrote, "is the leading retailer/ merchandiser on the 'net." "The great paradox of the analyst's reign was that, as their stature grew, the quality of their analysis plummeted," noted the New Yorker. "With few exceptions, analysts did not see trouble coming and didn't warn their investors to get out of the way." For her part, Meeker says she was always worried about becoming a posterchild for dot.com mania. "I did not aspire to be a media celebrity in any way, shape or form," she says. "I felt uncomfortable being in the limelight." Blodget, too, has taken a fall. "Things change," he said last week. "The market went from saying, 'We like companies that are growing quickly but are losing a lot of money' to saying, 'We want to see earnings.' It's very hard to predict a 180-degree turn like that." But some heroes have emerged. Although seen as a heretic when other analysts were still feeding investor euphoria, a 29-year-old Lehman Bros analyst named Ravi Suria issued a scorching report in February saying Amazon would run out of money this year. Suria had already set himself up as Bezos's nemesis-in-chief. Last June, the then-little-known analyst sounded the first warning, arguing that Amazon was showing the "financial characteristics that have driven innumerable retailers to disaster throughout history". His analysis created a sensation. The company called it "hogwash", and chief executive Jeff Bezos personally disputed the conclusions. Investors, however, voted with their wallets, sending the shares down nearly 20% in a day. At that time, Amazon stock was trading at around $45, and has fallen ever since. In theory, the report should have made Suria's career. After all, Meeker and Blodget had become Wall Street and media darlings after writing about Amazon. But they, of course, were on the side of the vast e-commerce company which sells about 11% of all goods sold online and which - along with the auction house eBay - is probably the dot.com most beloved by its customers. But unlike eBay, the strength of Amazon's balance sheet is constantly in dispute. For Suria, who likes to smoke cigars and skydive, and lists an interest in imported bottled beer, taking on ever-sunny Bezos meant taking on the whole internet economy. Already irked by Suria's warning last June, the subsequent report on Febuary 5 started a war. "Obviously, you can't take this seriously," Amazon spokesman Bill Curry said. "It's a silly report that's chock full of errors." According to the New York Observer, Amazon went to considerable lengths to quash Suria's predictions. When Amazon executives learned of the report's harsh nature - that the spectre of bankruptcy was being raised - they leapt to the phones. They held up publication for 10 days, it is claimed. Whether Suria's predictions prove right or wrong (in the aftermath of his report, half a dozen Wall Street analysts have downgraded Amazon shares, some even saying the company may still be overvalued) he may have changed the nature of the tech analysts' trade. "Whether or not the Lehman analyst is right to take a bearish stance on Amazon.com, give him credit for taking a much-needed skeptical (sic) stand," said TheStreet.com. Of course, Bezos strongly denies Amazon is in trouble. But the company has been getting bad press for plans to make severance packages for some 1,300 employees laid off last month, conditional on their continued silence with a "non-disparagement" clause. And, earlier this month, Bezos completed his third sale of small portions of his Amazon holdings, which total more than $1 billion at current market prices. In late 1998, Bezos's sales brought him about $23m. Last May it was $20m. This month it was $12m. And, in the wake of this latest report, even Blodget has downplayed expectations for the firm by saying: "still comfortable, but on alert". Suria is confident that he will be vindicated after months of having his credibility questioned; Bezos is adamant he will not. "The company has never been in better shape," he said recently. The same cannot be said of the analysts' trade.

fields.headline: Is 'big brother' a myth?
fields.standfirst: Diane Sinclair looks at the delicate balance between employers snooping unfairly on their staff and ensuring workers behave themselves
fields.trailText: Diane Sinclair looks at the delicate balance between employers snooping unfairly on their staff and ensuring workers behave themselves
fields.body:
Have you ever had the feeling that someone is looking over your shoulder? That your every move is being scrutinised? You have? If press reports of email and internet monitoring at work are anything to go by you're not alone. But is the coverage of employer monitoring of email and internet use based on fact?

There is scant evidence that employers spend a great deal of effort spying on their staff, and that employees feel that their privacy is violated in this way. If employers are keeping an unnecessarily watchful eye on employees then they are simply poor managers, who will ultimately damage relationships with staff, and consequently their business.

Despite the hype, there are very good business reasons for employers not to engage in large scale surveillance activities. The huge level of resources that would be required to do so for one. Large organisations would need teams of people to read emails and check every website visited in today's technology-driven workplace. Even if wrong-doing was detected, it would be unlikely to warrant such expense.

Employers are, however, concerned to protect employees and themselves from inappropriate emails or internet use by individual workers. Many organisations use software to scan emails and web sites visited for particular words that could indicate abuse of the company's system. And some industry sectors such as finance monitor staff more closely to protect against fraud. As customers, we would not want it any other way.

Indeed most reasonable employees would accept that some monitoring of their performance and behaviour is required. Legally, they are entitled to have their personal information treated in confidence by their employer. Employees should also generally be aware of when and how their work will be monitored. Covert surveillance of employees can only ever be justified in limited circumstances, such as the detection of criminal activity.

For their part, employers have legal obligations to employees, customers and shareholders that require them to conduct some monitoring of staff. Fraud, the downloading of illegal software and time wasting on entertainment sites are just some of the uses of the internet by employees that businesses need to prohibit.

Employers also need to protect their reputation, which may be harmed by inappropriate emails from the organisation's system. At the start of the year, Royal & SunAlliance suspended 80 employees following a complaint by a member of the public about lewd images sent by email. These have been described by the company as offensive and "of a highly graphic nature". Investigations have so far led to 11 dismissals and resignations by seven people.

Employers can also be held liable for employees' actions. Following defamatory emails sent by one of its staff, Norwich Union was obliged to pay Western Provident Association £450,000 in costs and damages. Similarly, inappro priate emails can constitute sexual harassment. If the employer did nothing to prevent the mischief, they could be held responsible.

Despite the existing legal obligations and responsibilities it is clear that there is confusion about what employers should or can do to monitor staff use of email and the internet. The situation needs clarifying. Unfortunately, the position will not be helped by recent proposals from the UK's Information Commissioner, who is responsible for promoting and monitoring good use of personal information.

The Commissioner's public consultation exercise on a draft code of practice on the use of personal data in employer/employee relationships ended earlier this year.

If issued as presently written, the code would place considerable restrictions on the monitoring of employees' emails and their use of the internet. The purpose of the code - to provide guidance to employers on how to protect employees' personal data - is welcome. However, rather than establishing basic principles that are readily understood by employers and employees, the code is overly prescriptive, with 44 'standards' proposed that organisations would have to follow.

Given the restrictions on their operations and bureaucratic burden these would impose, there is a risk that the code will encourage employers to ban workers from using email and the net for personal use, currently allowed by many organisations. As the code covers workers' personal information, employers could regard this as a way of protecting themselves from legal claims by employees. This means that employers would be unable to take as reasonable an approach as they might otherwise like.

The problem with the draft code is that it fails to take account of the array of circumstances in which it would have to be applied. What is important for the relationship between employee and employer is that monitoring of staff is conducted at a level appropriate to the business, in a way that is fair, and seen to be fair.

Good employers achieve this by developing organisational policies, with employees' input, that spell out what is reasonable for their particular organisation. In this way, everyone knows where they stand, and why. The mutual trust that this inspires is the basis for a healthy relationship between employee and employer. This would certainly not be achieved by employers engaging in Orwellian "snooping" tactics.

 Diane Sinclair is a policy adviser to the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development
