fields.headline: Sir Maurice Sutherland
fields.standfirst: Labour local government stalwart with his own vision for Teesside
fields.trailText: Labour local government stalwart with his own vision for Teesside.
fields.body:
In the post-war years, the Labour party threw up a number of strong big-city bosses who ruled their colleagues and their councils with a rod of iron. Maurice Sutherland, who has died aged 85, was not of this kind. He was thoughtful and reflective, with a touch of diffidence - a middle-class solicitor (although the son of a railwayman) in a dominantly working-class environment. But for almost 20 years he was the senior Labour figure, first on the short-lived Teesside county borough and then on Cleveland county council. He was mayor of Teesside from 1972-73 and leader of Cleveland county council for eight years.

I first met him when we both appeared on the shortlist for Labour candidate in the 1962 Stockton-on-Tees byelection. He had grown up in the consituency and I was an outsider. I won the nomination, but he bore me no grudge and campaigned for me. This was the more surprising, because he had flirted with the Communist party in his youth and was on the left of Labour, which I was not. He read widely, walked on the moors, played cricket and enjoyed conversations with me about the wider political world. He seemed cramped, although not resentful, in an unimaginative local Labour party dominated by the trade unions and thinking little about the future. When I left the Labour party in 1981 he did not approve, but he understood and showed no ill-will.

In the 1960s, as the post-war boom came to an end, the north-east once again faced high unemployment and industrial decline. But for the most part the Labour movement was conservative in its instincts and tribal loyalties were intense - never more so than in Hartlepool in those pre-Mandelson days. Maurice Sutherland saw the need for a new Teesside borough offering economies of scale, and which would absorb Middlesborough, Stockton and two smaller units of local government. When further reorganisation pushed a reluctant Teesside into Cleveland county council, he accepted responsibility to try to make it work. When he retired in 1993, he had served approaching 40 years in local government.

His understanding of the need for change and an end to parochialism extended to the competing roles of Teesside, Wearside and Tyneside in the north-east. He recognised that speaking with one voice made Scotland an effective advocate for preferential treatment when it came to investment in infrastructure and the location of new industry. Despite rivalries, the north-east must do the same. He welcomed the setting up of the Northern economic planning council in 1965 and served as its chairman in 1977-79.

I remember Tony Crosland, then secretary of state for the environment, telephoning me late in 1975. He had in mind to recommend Sutherland for a knighthood, what did I think? I said that Sutherland was a man drawn into local government by the idea of service, not by the seductions of political power. Despite that glance towards Westminster in 1962, it was in his own community that he was most persuasive and felt most at home.

Maurice Sutherland leaves his wife, Margaret, and a step-son, together with a son and step-daughter by earlier marriages.

 Maurice Sutherland, politician, born July 12 1915; died March 11 2001

fields.headline: Electronic mail on the web
fields.trailText: Start here...
fields.body:
Electronic mail is one of the main reasons why people go online. Everyone wants to communicate, and email is one of the fastest, cheapest and most efficient ways to do it. And today, you don't even need to own a computer. Web-based mail services let you send email from an office computer or a cybercafe. The main disadvantage is that you usually have to be online to use them.

Web-based email accounts, such as Hotmail, are easy to use, and free. It is therefore worth having one as a back-up when other services are not working properly. You can even set up "junk accounts" to give to websites that require registration, and to people you don't trust.

However, they do not provide anonymity. Even if you sign up under a false name, the service is probably logging your IP (Internet Protocol) address, which can be used to trace you.

All web-based mail services are much the same. Hotmail is the most popular and has the advantage that you can also collect mail using Outlook Express 5. However, I recommend Yahoo's email service (http://mail. yahoo.com) for two reasons. First, it provides six megabytes of storage, which should be enough to hold 500-600 email messages. Second, you can use Yahoo mail even with JavaScript and other advanced browser features blocked - athough you do have to allow "cookies" (small text files stored on your hard drive).

Even if you do not object to scripting, you may sometimes want to collect mail from a handheld computer, network terminal or other device that does not have all the facilities of a personal computer.

In Internet Explorer 5, the settings to control Active Scripting, Java and ActiveX programs, and cookies are in the security section. Go to the Tools menu, and select Internet Options. When the tabbed dialog box appears, click on Security, then on the button at the bottom, marked Custom Level. This will reveal a set of options with radio buttons that let you select Disable, Enable or Prompt.

The Prompt option means the browser will ask whether or not to allow a particular feature to run on a page-by-page basis. Prompt is fine in theory but tedious in practice. Most commercial sites now use scripting and huge numbers use ActiveX.

Whichever web-based mail service you choose, it should at least offer folders and an addressbook. Folders work like directories. You can use them to file away mail that you don't want to delete, but still don't want to see every day.

Hotmail and Yahoo provide folders to store incoming and outgoing mail, draft mail, bulk mail and trash. Draft is used for letters you have started writing but are not ready to send. Bulk mail is used for junk mail or "spam": if the system thinks it sees unwanted commercial email, it will put it in the Bulk Mail folder instead of your Inbox. The Trash folder is used to store deleted email in case you have second thoughts and want it back. Click on the Empty button, however, and it has gone forever.

It is easy to create new folders by typing in a name and clicking the Create Folder button. You can use them to store emails from specific people or about chosen topics. You can even have incoming mail diverted into these folders by setting up "filters" or "rules". To try this in Yahoo, click the Options entry on the left, then click on Filters. Both services also allow you to block mail from specified email addresses.

It is also important to be able to store email addresses: you can't possibly remember them all. To do this in Yahoo, while reading mail, click the Add Addresses button on the right-hand side and fill in the form. Click on Add More Detail to enter phone numbers, nicknames, birthdates and so on. To enter names in Hotmail's much less powerful addressbook, click Save Address, at the end of the From: line.

I have almost 1,000 addresses on Yahoo because I synchronise it with Microsoft Outlook on my desktop PC and with my handheld computer. However, some addressbook features require JavaScript.

Web-based email services are much more sophisticated that they used to be, and most have features that few people know about or use. In Yahoo and Hotmail, for example, you can sort mail by date (ascending or descending), sender, subject, or size, just by clicking the labels at the top of the columns.

Yahoo can also collect standard (POP) mail from three other accounts, and Hotmail from four. Finally, under Options, both let you set a different Reply-To address, such as a home or office mailbox.

But if you use web-based email, you must keep an eye on it. The world is full of extremely inconsiderate people who send out attachments that take up 500K or more space. A couple of those can easily fill up a mailbox. After that, any further mail will be "bounced" - returned to the sender.

Clear out your mailbox at least once a week or you could miss important mail, and upset the people trying to send it to you.

fields.headline: Palm's founders at a crossroad
fields.standfirst: The market Ed Colligan helped create a decade ago is to change forever, writes  Ashley Norris
fields.trailText: The market Ed Colligan helped create a decade ago is to change forever, writes Ashley Norris
fields.body:
In the early 90s, Ed Colligan, along with Donna Dubinksy and Jeff Hawkins, dreamt of a handheld PC that would change the way people lived by offering quick and easy access to their personal information. Almost a decade later, their innovation, the Palm, is the most popular personal digital assistant in the world.

Now Colligan, the senior vice president of sales and marketing at Handspring, stands at another crossroad. Behind him is the phenomenal growth of the Visor range of PDAs (almost 2m units have been sold in the US); ahead is the prospect that the market he helped create is set to change forever. The PDA is about to get connected.

"In five years' time I see a Handspring that is slim, ultra fast, rich in colour, permanently on line and maybe even streaming audio and video content," he predicts.

The difficulty for Colligan is that his dream PDA sounds remarkably similar to the prototypes of other high-end phone devices paraded by companies from Motorola to Psion.

Internet-linked smart phones from Ericsson and Nokia that use the Symbian operating system are already available. Microsoft's Stinger smartphone technology recently featured on a Sendo mobile, and after re-establishing itself in the mobile market last year, Sony has designs on what could prove to be a very lucrative market.

Due to launch in the UK in the next few months is the Visorphone, a GSM add-on that fits into the Springboard expansion slot at the top of Handspring PDAs. Users can then make voice calls, send text messages or surf the net using the new Blazer web-browsing facilities. It will transform the Handspring from a personal information manager to a web-browsing smart phone. But at around £300 will there be many takers?

He is adamant that Handspring won't be intimidated. "The phone manufacturers' expertise is in voice communication. We are experts in data communication and that's the way the market is moving. Software is another area that will become vital and, again, it's an area we excel in."

"The situation is different in the UK. I think you may find that communication products are released here in the UK first and then in the USA."

This model takes Colligan's old company Palm on at its own game, in that it is ultra thin and is finished in an attractive metal casing. fields.headline: Tense, nervous headache?
fields.standfirst:
If you are under stress at work, let off steam with an online therapy session, says Mark Tran
More net news
fields.trailText: If you are under stress at work, let off steam with an online therapy session, says Mark Tran
fields.body:
You've just had a row with your boss or a fellow worker and you want to let off steam, so who do you turn to? There are your colleagues, but suppose discretion is required.

Nyasha Poe would argue that such a situation is tailor-made for her company, friendly-ear.com. Carrying a steaming kettle as its logo, Britain's first online corporate counselling service was launched last month. In an increasingly time-starved society, friendly-ear offers immediate advice from qualified counsellors through email or on the phone.

No prizes for guessing that online therapy was pioneered in America. Last year, there were 200 websites devoted to mental health issues and about 350 individual therapists on the web. The premise is that online therapy can rake in the bucks in a society notoriously in a rush - at least in the world of upwardly mobile professionals. Be that as it may, the proliferation of online therapy in the US has thrown up a host of regulatory and ethical concerns. Virtually all the American sites are unregulated, many are unlicensed, so consumers may be at the mercy of fly-by-night therapists.

Mindful of such concerns, some online therapists under the umbrella organisation of the internet healthcare coalition have crafted voluntary guidelines known as the eHealth code of ethics. The rules ask sites to disclose financial ties or their commercial sponsors to give accurate and well-supported information, while safe guarding privacy and confidentiality.

Anticipating those kinds of issues, Poe insists that her team of therapists, employed on a freelance basis, belong to the British Association of Counselling. Most have been trained at the Tavistock British Association of Psychoanalysis. Poe, who is of Zimbabwean origin, was nominated as business woman of the year in 1998. Before launching a career as an internet entrepreneur, she founded a fostering agency called Banya that placed difficult children for local authorities. She has now left Banya in the hands of her partner to concentrate on friendly-ear, so she has a chance of working directly with people again. Poe tries to spend a couple of hours online a few mornings a week, although her main focus will be to get the business up and running.

Poe's idea for friendly-ear came from her "quite lonely" experience as a businesswoman. "Sometimes family members are not the best people to encourage you, and sometimes it's hard to talk to your partner about such matters," says Poe.

She believes the anonymous nature of email can entice people into greater openness than if they were in face-to-face situations. "It's a bit like confession. I think anonymity is a strength rather than a weakness."

Anonymity is a hotly debated issue in the US, with some psychologists highly critical of the inability of therapists to interact properly with clients in cyberspace. They argue that patients are short-changed if the therapist cannot read the body language that can reveal so much. Poe admits that over the phone or by email, the therapist has to read between the lines. On the plus side, besides the notion that people will tend to be more upfront on the phone or via email, she cites the convenience factor. Workers do not have to leave their desks to receive advice and the service would be available 24 hours a day.

The site already has had positive feedback from customers such as Peter Davids, senior partner in an accountancy firm, who said: "We can't quantify the benefits of using friendly-ear in monetary terms, but we have seen tangible benefits to our performance in the business and have increased profits."

Poe plans to make her pitch to City firms where stress and burnout are high - and of course, where the big money is. The plan is to win contracts with City firms that will offer friendly-ear's services to its employees as part of the overall package. The fees friendly-ear charges will depend on the number of employees the firm has.

She will argue to the human resources department - who will be her ultimate employer - that her company can help boost productivity by reducing stress, sick days, absenteeism or 'duvet days'. Poe believes that a company like hers will find a niche as employees are more likely to turn to an outside agency than risk the stigma of going to human resources, because it is seen as an extension of management.

But it is debatable whether City firms really do care about high turnover and burnout since they seem to be essential features of life in the fast lane. Despite all the government talk of productivity loss from sick days and stress, do City firms really give a fig about employees who cannot hack the macho culture?

In offering a 24-hour ser vice, friendly-ear may also be biting off more than it can chew. Although Poe can call on some 60 freelance counsellors, some of the big firms may prove too taxing for a fledgling company like friendly-ear.

Still, Poe is confident of the soundness of her concept. She argues that employees will want to talk about issues that are bothering them, such as bullying - apparently an extremely common workplace problem.

She in adamant that firms will want to offers the services friendly-com provides as one of the perks offered to potential employees.

"With low unemployment, firms need to finds ways to retain people beyond just offering the gym. They have to include staff support such as coaching and therapy," Poe says.

"Companies have to take a holistic view of their employees. You turn up at the office as a person, not just a worker, with home and personal problems."

fields.headline: E-marketplace
fields.standfirst: Daniel Wilson is chief operating officer for Europe of FreeMarkets, the world's largest e-marketplace
fields.trailText: Daniel Wilson is chief operating officer for Europe of FreeMarkets, the world's largest e-marketplace
fields.body:
How did you first use computers? I started my career working for Siemens as a budget analyst, which was my introduction to using PCs and very early spreadsheets like VisiCalc (developed by Dan Brinkman for early Apple II machines) and SuperCalc. I encountered the net quite early on through content management and setting up websites as an advertising vehicle. Now, with e-mail and so on, I would consider myself to be a fairly heavy user.

Has there been a reappraisal of e-commerce after the dot.com slump? I think there's been a return to "is there really a business here?" We started in 1995 about six months after Netscape went public. So we started this because there was a real business need, not because the internet was there. The net has opened up the world and allowed us to use new technologies to proliferate and build our business, but I think the markets are saying "let's get back to basics. What's your business model and what is the value that you're trying to deliver to your customer base?"

Is the UK's net infrastructure in need of an overhaul?

Not for what we do. All companies, buyers and suppliers need to use our technology is access to the web. I think the net is well entrenched in the UK, and throughout Europe, and most people have good access to it.

So how does the UK compare in terms of e-commerce? I think there's a little bit of scepticism but in general the UK's a bit more adventurous and open to new things than what we see on the continent. On the Continent companies are more risk averse, so I think the UK is more closely aligned with the US in that regard.

Your website talks a lot of e-sourcing - what is it? E-Sourcing culminates in an online auction but we se it as a combination of market-making services, global supplier information and the technology for the online auctions. It's a process of identifying what is appropriate to put on an online auction, providing services to help prepare request for quotations that differ from those put together for a manual negotiation. Also, providing services around training and working with the company's existing suppliers, and introducing new suppliers.

How does your Quick Source technology work? It's a technology that allows a company to set up its own branded marketplace. It means that more of the sourcing process is left up to the customer.

Any favourite websites? So much of our business is done over the net that I tend to gravitate towards the content aggregators such as Yahoo! and AOL. They're logical portals to a whole variety of other services. Probably two or three times a year I purchase books at Amazon. I don't keep a tremendous number of bookmarks.

Visit: www.freemarkets.com

fields.headline: Working the web Crime
fields.standfirst:
Fans of the Krays and their sidekick Mad Frankie Fraser can sink their teeth into cyber gangland, writes Heather Welford
More net news
fields.trailText: Fans of the Krays and their sidekick Mad Frankie Fraser can sink their teeth into cyber gangland, writes Heather Welford
fields.body:
What is going to happen when UK hard man Charles Bronson finally gets out of jail? Readers of his website can be reassured. He has a lot of "straight work" to keep him occupied: "I will be doing talks, book signing, parties, TV interviews, radio interviews", he tells Kevin M, who has emailed Charlie to ask if he will ever "go back to blagging".

Charlie's webmaster is helping him while away those long hours in solitary by passing on the responses to his site. You can, if you are female, send in a picture of yourself (preferably in something lacy and not very large) to enter Charlie's cellmate of the month competition. Or bid in a cyberauction for one of Charlie's possessions, such as his knuckle duster, or even his brain (a deal to be honoured post-mortem, to prevent the Home Office nabbing it) - all proceeds to "Bronson's Children" charity, which aims to raise a million for a further prosecution of Myra Hindley and Ian Brady.

That life on the outside can be one long Rent-a-Memory played out for an uncritical audience is exemplified by Mad Frankie Fraser, the former Kray associate who is currently selling his own interactive CD-rom ("chilling, unrepentant and at times funny and heart-warming", according to the sales pitch). Frank is also available to act as your guide for a Gangland Tour through London's East End.

These sites form part of the UK Hardman and Gangster Web Ring. You can link up to the entire list at www.davecourtney.org.uk. Dave Courtney, whose career inspired the Vinnie Jones character in Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, has two websites, the flashier of which is at www.davecourtney.com. Here you will find sound, streaming video, and a collection of articles about the man they call "the original fun-loving criminal".

Criminals' sites are often managed by fans, whose own lives appear to be a million miles away from anything approaching the underworld. Mike Grey, who styles himself as "the owner of the largest collection of Biggs memorabilia", helps run www.ronniebiggs.com for the Great British Train Robber, still holed up in Rio, aged 71. Grey's fascination with the robber began when he had to do an A level English project on any news story in 1974 - and he chose Biggs.

On the whole, the fans seem internet-literate and dedicated enough to put in the hard work that maintaining a site demands.

The introductory page of The Krays, however, has yet to acknowledge Reggie Kray's death in October last year - a conspicuous oversight, especially as the rest of the site appears to be up to date.

The Krays has a long and apparently sincere bulletin board-style condolence book. Anyone suggesting that, actually, the streets weren't safer when the Krays were about, or that, truth be told, not everyone adored them, is quickly frowned on. Rather optimistically, contributors are confident that all three Kray brothers "are now in heaven", and they are "loved by millions". Spelling is, however, erratic. At one point, Charlie Kray is described as "a lovable rouge".

Of course, they tend to do things bigger in the US. Organised crime UK-style is a vicarage tea party compared to the viciousness of La Cosa Nostra. For a detailed overview of the whole scene, visit Jerry Capeci's Gang Land. It was on to this site that young Meadow Soprano (of the hit HBO series The Sopranos) logged to convince her kid brother that when dad Tony said his job was in waste management, he wasn't exactly telling the whole story.

The Sopranos naturally has its own site. And while we are talking drama, the highly recommended Godfather Trilogy - the Website You Can't Refuse at www.exit109.com/~jgeoff/ godfather/godfathr.shtml has whole scripts, and a set of frequently asked questions to satisfy the most trivia-obsessed. However, to find out whether the horse's head in the bed was actually a different horse from the one seen earlier in the stables, you will need to visit Nitpickers www.nitpickers.com/movies/ nitpicks/titles/88174.html.

If you want to understand underworld lingo, either real or fictional, check out the difference between a BG (someone who has not yet shot anyone) and an OG (someone who has) and other US gang argot at http://linz.orf.at/gast/shocky/gang-slang.htm.

For UK prison slang, HM Prisons issues a primly sanitised glossary of terms see www.hmprisonservice.gov.uk.

To read lively and not always politically-correct discussion of crime and punishment, fromliberal left through to authoritarian right, see the newsgroup uk.politics.crime.

Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Interest wane
I couldn't help feeling slightly envious of David Birch's experience with NTL (Rebel with a cable, March 8).

I don't think he knows how lucky he's been. I'm sorry if I sound a bit jaded, but my opinion of NTL as a company has been prejudiced by my experiences with it in the past (also with its predecessors Videotron and Cable & Wireless). Recent contact with NTL has really underlined what a feeble position the lone residential client occupies in the company's scheme of things. I was hoping to upgrade my TV/phone package to digital. Its glossy brochures urge you to "Jump into a world of choice". The details of my new contract were completed over the phone and I was given an appointment. It was on the day of the appointment that the field engineer rang to say that it would be impossible for me to convert to digital.

The street box is filled to capacity and would need upgrading to provide the digital service/broadband internet access the company is so cheerfully promoting. NTL will not say when this might happen. I can see its strategy is to attract new customers, but I could not work out why it is so poor with existing customers. Then, in Friday's Guardian, I read an article about NTL and the penny dropped.

It has made 11 acquisitions in the past 18 months and is $10bn in debt. It is simply not interested in upgrading any existing customers where it may incur some cost to them. Far better to concentrate on take-up.

So my chances of being a rebel with a cable will have to wait for the interest payments on NTL's debts fall to a more manageable level.
Barry Campbell
barray@dircon.co.uk

Half right
Please stop plugging cable internet access every week. My student house has several PCs networked and accessing the net through NTL and we have no wish to see the speed of our connection drop.

Seriously though, NTL's promotion has been non- existant, despite halving the cost to £20 (just after we signed up). In addition, customer service is horrendously difficult to reach over the phone. So, a great product, but a shame about the service.
Dan Windwood
dan_windwood@hotmail.com

Stealth bomb
When I read last Thursday's article about cable modems I was sceptical of the £20 a month figure quoted, but NTL's website confirmed this (though it is £25 if you also rent the modem) plus £25 installation. Unfortunately, I live in a Telewest cabled area, and its offering is much less attractive: £33 a month with compulsory modem, plus £50 installation.

I also wonder just how reliable the service will be. Using Telewest's dial-up unlimited service, I have experienced its stealth rationing of access. Instead of an engaged tone or a failure to log on, I can often connect, only to find that any attempt to access mail, Usenet or Web servers times out (this morning it took six attempts to connect to my mail server).

After several frustrating calls to technical support, one engineer eventually admitted that this happened because there was too little capacity. Is the same thing going to happen if I sign up for their cable modem service?
Richard Williams
rwilliams79@compuserve.com

No putdown
Why do you repeatedly denigrate BT Highway-ISDN (Online, March 8)? If one has only a BT phone line then all the other possibilities are simply out of reach.

ISDN has at least two advantages for me. Firstly speed, as connection to my ISP is much faster and data download is overall more than twice as fast. Secondly, thanks to the second line, no longer do I hear the cry: "Are you still on the phone?" Yes, the ISDN adaptor costs more than a 56k modem and there are BT's additional charges, but set against these are the reduction of the time dialling and being online. As far as I am concerned it is well worthwhile.
G M Brewin
gmbrewin@waitrose.com

Still growing
I was fascinated to read your article last Thursday detailing the history of Acorn computers. You suggest these machines are no longer used and are not being developed.

I am writing this on a RiscOS RiscPC - the most recent Acorn reincarnation - still developed and sold by several manufacturers. We eagerly await a new machine, the Omega and a new version of the operating system Risc OS 4.5 this summer. There are many advantages - intuitive drag and drop, virus resistance and reinstall in a couple of minutes.
Dennis Mews
dennismews@lineone.net

Nut case
Nice to see your Acorn article pay a deserved tribute to a British success story - congratulations! However, it failed to mention that the operating system, Risc OS, has survived and is prospering, both in desktop form and in set-top boxes/home entertainment systems with Pace. There is a chance that, by the end of this year, more people in the UK will be using Risc OS (even if they don't know or care) than use the Mac OS. George Greenfield
free080.isp@ukgateway.net

Steam age
It is a shame that no mention of the excellent work that has (and is) being done by Pace and Risc OS and all the companies making new machines and developing the OS (as well as new software) were not mentioned last week. Risc OS has a future, not only in education but in all spheres of ICT - it's just that the weight of American imperialism steamrollers any signs of British innovation. Very sad. Neil Turner
philip.turner1@ntlworld.com

Fare enough
Re ordering a taxi via SMS - What a brilliant idea! From a woman's point of view, nothing could provide greater piece of mind. How refreshing to be able to order a cab and feel safe and secure in the knowledge that there is a clear audit trail of who picked you up, from what company, at what time and in what car. No more hanging around street corners looking for cabs, thanks to Obvious Solutions. Fran Jacobson
fran.jacobson@gs.com

fields.headline: RLNISEWMMAFATTVC*
fields.standfirst: * The Review of the List of Nationally Important Sporting Events Which Must be Made Available on Free-to-Air Terrestrial TV Channels.
fields.trailText: * The Review of the List of Nationally Important Sporting Events Which Must be Made Available on Free-to-Air Terrestrial TV Channels.
fields.body:
Charged with reviewing the list of sporting events for which live TV coverage must be made available in a year during which Sky acquired the rights to a several major sports events previously shown on terrestrial TV.

Chaired by Lord Gordon of Strathblane; plus eight people from sport and broadcasting, including Michael Parkinson, Jack Charlton, Steve Cram and Kate Hoey.

Chris Smith said: "Sporting events which are truly part of our national culture should be freely available on national terrestrial television for everyone who wishes to watch."

Unanimous that the list should be revised to reflect changes in the public profiles of major sports events since the last review in 1991. Proposed a revised regulatory framework to be operated by the ITC.

In June 1998, Chris Smith announced a revised list of sporting "crown jewels" for all to view free, including the European football championship finals, the rugby league challenge cup final and rugby world cup.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: IRA has met Chastelain
fields.body:
IRA has met Chastelain

The IRA revealed yesterday that it had had a face-to-face meeting with General John de Chastelain's independent commission to discuss disarmament. A statement from the Provisionals said its representative had met the decommissioning body and set out the basis for discussions.

Ban and fine for Speedy Spice

Former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell, 28, was yesterday banned from driving for 42 days and fined £400 by Watford magistrates after she admitted driving at 60mph in a 30mph zone on October 31 last year.

Grim sequel to cliff fall

Kent police officers, seeking to save a man who yesterday fell over the cliffs at Dover, came upon the decaying body of another victim at the foot of the cliffs. The man who fell yesterday was later said to be in a stable condition in hospital at Margate.

Warning on ear piercing

Children as young as three have been treated in hospital with infected wounds after parents had allowed the youngsters to have their ears pierced, according to a report in the Scottish Medical Journal.

One winner for £3.6m jackpot

One ticket holder won the £3.6m national lottery jackpot last night with the numbers 1, 5, 8, 31, 37, 38, bonus 15. No ticket matched the lottery extra numbers, 19, 20, 26, 32, 45 and 46.

fields.headline: Tickets disaster at opera house
fields.standfirst: Poor ticket sales cause the Royal Opera House to launch a series of special offers in an attempt to entice people to go to performances
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera House yesterday admitted it was resorting to discounting seats, special offers and celebrity first night guests, for the first time since it reopened last year, after disastrous ticket sales for a contemporary opera.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Royal Opera House yesterday admitted it was resorting to discounting seats, special offers and celebrity first night guests, for the first time since it reopened last year, after disastrous ticket sales for a contemporary opera.

Boulevard Solitude, a reworking of Manon Lescaut, first performed in 1952, is being staged as a 75th birthday tribute to the German composer Hans Werner Henze.

As of yesterday morning under a third of the seats had been sold for the six performances. A hectic marketing campaign has been started, including offering free tickets to celebrities such as Esther Rantzen and Joanna Lumley.

An ROH spokesman said yesterday: "There is no panic at all about it. We always knew we would have to work much harder to market this than a more familiar piece.

He added: "The point of inviting people like Esther Rantzen to the first night is to get the chattering classes chattering about something they might not normally contemplate attending. It's not about inviting some minor figure in a sensational frock to get a few pars in the paper - that's not our thing."

The problems raised uncomfortable echoes of Covent Garden's last venture into unknown contemporary opera, when the entire season of Gyorgy Ligeti's Le Grand Macabre was abandoned weeks before the reopening, to gain desperately needed extra rehearsal time for more successful shows.

But observers from other institutions were sympathetic. "You have to hold your nerve, get the marketing right, and build the trust of your audience, and that takes time," said Amelia Freedman, head of classical music at the South Bank complex.

The South Bank is currently mounting a festival of the music of Henze.

At English National Opera, a spokesman said that contemporary work was marketed far more aggressively than the classics. At the Barbican, artistic director Graham Sheffield said he believed the audience for contemporary work was growing. But he added: "We now have a relationship of trust with our audience. But that takes time and we never take it for granted."

One of Covent Garden's fiercest critics, the impresario Raymond Gubbay, who pitched to become the new director last year, was unexpectedly sympathetic.

"Henze is a great composer, and hats off to them in a way for putting him on - it's just what you should be doing with a subsidy," he said. "But you are never going to get people paying £115 for that, for God's sake. You've got to have some sense of how to market it.

"The trouble is the audience they have got at Covent Garden is just too elite, they want to pay a lot of money to go and see a show they know, packed with stars."

Gubbay's production of Aida, which sold 2,000 seats every night of its Albert Hall run, is now packing audiences in on a provincial tour.

He added: "I'd put on Boulevard Solitude myself, Henze is great. But I wouldn't put it on at the Albert Hall, no way."

webTitle: News: Mozart score found in Halifax

fields.headline: To Halifax the glory of a Mozart score
fields.standfirst: Archives in Yorkshire home to Mozart score
fields.trailText: Mozart never made it to West Yorkshire but a score of one of his previously unknown works has turned up in the archives in Halifax, a town whose previous claims to fame have included toffees, carpets and a building society.
fields.body:
Mozart never made it to West Yorkshire but a score of one of his previously unknown works has turned up in the archives in Halifax, a town whose previous claims to fame have included toffees, carpets and a building society.

The score, an arrangement of Handel's oratorio Judas Maccabeus (famed for its chorus See the Conquering Hero Comes, source of the hymn Thine Be the Glory), was discovered by a Leeds University music lecturer, Rachel Cowgill, while researching musical life in the town during the Georgian era.

Mozart made versions of four other Handel works - including Messiah - between 1788 and 1790 and scholars have long speculated that there might be fifth. The find will shed light on the homage one genius paid to another from a previous generation.

Dr Cowgill found the manuscript while investigating the library of William Priestley, a Halifax wool clothier and early member of the town's choral society.

"I asked to see a number of scores in the catalogue, looked at the title page on one volume and there it was," said Dr Cowgill. "I did a bit of a double take because I didn't remember a Mozart arrangement of Judas Maccabeus. I checked with Grove's music dictionary and emailed various friends and found this was certainly worth investigating."

A German inscription on the title page explained that this was Judas Maccabeus, an oratorio in three acts set to music by Handel, "with additional wind parts by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart".

The manuscript, sadly not in Mozart's hand, dates from the end of the 18th century or the beginning of the 19th.

In 1850 Priestley presented it to the society, which still owns it but has placed it on loan with Calderdale council. Priestley had probably acquired the manuscript from a clergyman in Fulneck, near Leeds, who had bought scores from a Leipzig publisher in 1819.

Dr Cowgill suspects that Mozart may have updated Handel to suit tastes in contemporary Vienna. "The orchestra had been reinforced with new instruments such as the clarinet, of which Mozart was a great champion," she said last night. "Viennese audiences were used to a warmer sound, with wind timbres reinforced by sustained wind chords and trombone parts supporting the vocal lines.

"So Mozart thickened and warmed up the texture for an audience which would have found Handel's score in its original state quite primitive because of its sparse textures."

Dr Cowgill is to publish her initial findings in an article in the Musical Times and hopes that the Handel/Mozart version of the oratorio could soon be heard again.

"It would be lovely if the Halifax choral society could have a crack at it," she added.

webTitle: International: EU's boarder with Poland impregnable

fields.headline: Caught on camera on doorstep of Fortress Europe
fields.standfirst:
Hi-tech surveillance and strict enforcement make the EU's border with Poland almost impregnable

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: In the border post on the German side of the frontier with Poland, eerie images glow from a monitor. They show people walking over the bridge across the river Oder that joins the two countries, their faces deprived of features and replaced by bright, blank ovals.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Frankfurt an der Oder
fields.body:
In the border post on the German side of the frontier with Poland, eerie images glow from a monitor. They show people walking over the bridge across the river Oder that joins the two countries, their faces deprived of features and replaced by bright, blank ovals.

At first sight it looks like the negative of a black-and-white video. But it is, in fact, an image shaped, not by light, but by heat, captured by a thermographic camera mounted on the roof outside the Bundes Grenz Schutz (BGS) - frontier police - post.

Here, we are on the very ramparts of Fortress Europe.

With a flick of a joystick, the operator swivels the camera so that it can peer away from the bridge, deep into the forests on the Polish side of the Oder. Depending on weather condi tions, these thermographic devices, originally developed to spot tanks, can "see" up to four and a half miles.

The operator plays a recording from one recent evening. He picks out on the screen a tiny, bright, white speck materialising from the edge of the river. It is a human being.

"A Russian male," says the camera operator. He is probably from Chechnya. The Polish government estimates that 80% of Russian passport holders caught trying to cross the frontier are Chechens.

No luck for this one, though. The operator of the thermographic camera alerted a BGS patrol and within a few hours the illegal entrant had been put back across the border.

Whatever problems the EU may be facing elsewhere around its borders, Fortress Europe can at least be satifsied that the most vulnerable frontier to the east is under rigorous surveillance.

Agnieszka Siarkiewicz of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees in Warsaw, calls it "close to impossible to cross".

Ulla Jelpke, a German MP, believes one reason why asylum seekers are increasingly testing the borders of France, Italy and Britain is because of Germany's success in blocking their route in from Poland.

"As the number of applications in Germany has gone down, the number of applications in the UK has gone up," she says.

But some - including church groups, refugee organisations and Ms Jelpke's party, the Party of Democratic Socialism (PDS), the only one in parliament that stands to the left of the ruling Social Democrats and Greens - believe that such results have been won with unacceptable methods. Ironically, the PDS is the successor to the communist party that governed East Germany in the days of the Berlin Wall.

"We do not seek to minimise the deaths on the Wall, which were also the result of an inhuman policy," says Ms Jelpke. "But what is happening now is no better."

Migrants seeking to enter Germany run the risk of being savaged by unmuzzled police dogs and, if caught, the likelihood that their savings will be taken off them by the border police. In a recent, 33-month period, according to government figures, 47 illegal entrants required medical treatment for bites inflicted by the BGS's dogs.

Chief Superintendent Eckehart Wache, the commander of the sector in which two-thirds of detected illegal crossings take place, said the dogs were used primarily for tracking on a long lead, but on occasions were let off unmuzzled. "They know what they are allowed to do and what not, and they are not allowed to bite anyone unless they are attacked," he said.

But he acknowledgedthat each year some had to be "retrained and rechecked" following incidents which required their withdrawal from service.

Another intensely controversial practice is the levying by the BGS of what are, in effect, fines imposed without trial.

"We do not bring [captured illegal entrants] before a court to have them indicted because the major problem is to bring them out of the country, as the law allows us to do," said Chief Supt Wache. "This is more important and it saves more money, saves more resources ... so we have almost no fines which were fixed by a court."

However, he added: "German law allows the police, or the public prosecutor, to keep the money of an alien when a fine by a court is probable."

Illegal entrants, many of whom are carrying their life's savings with them, have to hand over their possessions when caught and the "fine" is retained when their possessions are returned to them. The standard penalty for illegal entry to Germany is 90 days' earnings. Chief Supt Wache said it was left to the BGS to estimate an illegal entrant's average daily earnings.

A document passed to the Guardian, which he confirmed was a record of possessions taken from a Russian entrant, suggests the fines are, on occasion, reckoned in an altogether more informal fashion.

The detainee had been carrying $450, which was reckoned by the BGS to be the equivalent of DM854 (£285). He was charged about £6 each for the meals he ate while in custody and a further £230 - a sum which is not a multiple of the 90 days claimed to be the basis of calculation. That left the detainee with £40 with which to get back to Russia.

"We never take everything," said Chief Supt Wache.
fields.bodyText: In the border post on the German side of the frontier with Poland, eerie images glow from a monitor. They show people walking over the bridge across the river Oder that joins the two countries, their faces deprived of features and replaced by bright, blank ovals. At first sight it looks like the negative of a black-and-white video. But it is, in fact, an image shaped, not by light, but by heat, captured by a thermographic camera mounted on the roof outside the Bundes Grenz Schutz (BGS) - frontier police - post. Here, we are on the very ramparts of Fortress Europe. With a flick of a joystick, the operator swivels the camera so that it can peer away from the bridge, deep into the forests on the Polish side of the Oder. Depending on weather condi tions, these thermographic devices, originally developed to spot tanks, can "see" up to four and a half miles. The operator plays a recording from one recent evening. He picks out on the screen a tiny, bright, white speck materialising from the edge of the river. It is a human being. "A Russian male," says the camera operator. He is probably from Chechnya. The Polish government estimates that 80% of Russian passport holders caught trying to cross the frontier are Chechens. No luck for this one, though. The operator of the thermographic camera alerted a BGS patrol and within a few hours the illegal entrant had been put back across the border. Whatever problems the EU may be facing elsewhere around its borders, Fortress Europe can at least be satifsied that the most vulnerable frontier to the east is under rigorous surveillance. Agnieszka Siarkiewicz of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees in Warsaw, calls it "close to impossible to cross". Ulla Jelpke, a German MP, believes one reason why asylum seekers are increasingly testing the borders of France, Italy and Britain is because of Germany's success in blocking their route in from Poland. "As the number of applications in Germany has gone down, the number of applications in the UK has gone up," she says. But some - including church groups, refugee organisations and Ms Jelpke's party, the Party of Democratic Socialism (PDS), the only one in parliament that stands to the left of the ruling Social Democrats and Greens - believe that such results have been won with unacceptable methods. Ironically, the PDS is the successor to the communist party that governed East Germany in the days of the Berlin Wall. "We do not seek to minimise the deaths on the Wall, which were also the result of an inhuman policy," says Ms Jelpke. "But what is happening now is no better." Migrants seeking to enter Germany run the risk of being savaged by unmuzzled police dogs and, if caught, the likelihood that their savings will be taken off them by the border police. In a recent, 33-month period, according to government figures, 47 illegal entrants required medical treatment for bites inflicted by the BGS's dogs. Chief Superintendent Eckehart Wache, the commander of the sector in which two-thirds of detected illegal crossings take place, said the dogs were used primarily for tracking on a long lead, but on occasions were let off unmuzzled. "They know what they are allowed to do and what not, and they are not allowed to bite anyone unless they are attacked," he said. But he acknowledgedthat each year some had to be "retrained and rechecked" following incidents which required their withdrawal from service. Another intensely controversial practice is the levying by the BGS of what are, in effect, fines imposed without trial. "We do not bring [captured illegal entrants] before a court to have them indicted because the major problem is to bring them out of the country, as the law allows us to do," said Chief Supt Wache. "This is more important and it saves more money, saves more resources ... so we have almost no fines which were fixed by a court." However, he added: "German law allows the police, or the public prosecutor, to keep the money of an alien when a fine by a court is probable." Illegal entrants, many of whom are carrying their life's savings with them, have to hand over their possessions when caught and the "fine" is retained when their possessions are returned to them. The standard penalty for illegal entry to Germany is 90 days' earnings. Chief Supt Wache said it was left to the BGS to estimate an illegal entrant's average daily earnings. A document passed to the Guardian, which he confirmed was a record of possessions taken from a Russian entrant, suggests the fines are, on occasion, reckoned in an altogether more informal fashion. The detainee had been carrying $450, which was reckoned by the BGS to be the equivalent of DM854 (£285). He was charged about £6 each for the meals he ate while in custody and a further £230 - a sum which is not a multiple of the 90 days claimed to be the basis of calculation. That left the detainee with £40 with which to get back to Russia. "We never take everything," said Chief Supt Wache.

fields.headline: Room each for soldiers
fields.trailText: The army is to demolish or refurbish its barracks, some described by commanders as "slum dwellings", to give all single soldiers a room of their own, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The army is to demolish or refurbish its barracks, some described by commanders as "slum dwellings", to give all single soldiers a room of their own, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, announced yesterday.

As many as 30,000 "bed spaces" - as the Ministry of Defence calls them - are undecorated and without working showers or heating. They include the barracks at Aldershot in Hampshire, described by Mr Hoon yesterday as "frankly appalling".

He said: "Its condition is positively damaging to operational effectiveness, to retaining servicemen and women, and to the day-to-day efficiency of defence. And we know it is getting worse."

Most NCOs have a single room, but privates are normally four to a room. Defence officials conceded that the traditional view of sharing as promoting "team spirit" was inadequate given the "social shift" in expectations.

There are also plans to give personnel ready access to email terminals and websites.

webTitle: Fussing can double risk of heart attack

fields.headline: Fussing can double risk of heart attack
fields.trailText: Are you an obsessive lover of routine, overconscientious, and think cleanliness is next to godliness? Beware. You may be nearly twice as likely to die from a heart attack as more laid back friends and colleagues.
fields.body:
Are you an obsessive lover of routine, overconscientious, and think cleanliness is next to godliness? Beware. You may be nearly twice as likely to die from a heart attack as more laid back friends and colleagues.

A study of more than 1,400 men lasting 20 years also suggests that similar risks face those who display physical signs of anxiety such as palpitations, sweating, sleep disturbance and indigestion.

If that is not enough, men with phobias, such as fear of open spaces, are more prone to a coronary too - but that propensity seems to dwindle with age and was a key factor only in those who died during the first 10 years of the study.

The results of work that can only encourage the need to "chill out", and try to develop an inner calm, are revealed in the medical journal Heart today. The researchers, who monitored workers in local government, a food processing company and the Post Office, suggest that more middle-aged men may benefit from behavioural therapy in an effort to curb Britain's most notorious killer disease.

It might be difficult to identify potential victims. All the men involved - of whom 127 died from a heart attack - displayed no obvious signs of cardiac problems when recruited between the ages of 40 and 64. But as they entered the study, between 1972 and 1978, they were asked to fill in questionnaires designed to outline their psychological profiles.

These helped researchers grade them in a number of areas of mental health, including obsessional thought patterns, and obvious displays of anxiety. Those who died had significantly higher scores after adjustments for factors such as smoking, age and social class.

The authors, while recognising the study, based on white men in London, was relatively small, conclude that psychological factors are likely to increase the risk of fatal heart attack.

Andrew Haines, of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said yesterday: "These were essentially fit working people who had no signs of heart disease at the beginning. Most of us are obsessional to some degree. Most are anxious to some degree. It is normal and it is not a question of labelling one group of people as neurotics."

fields.headline: Ugandan president triumphs
fields.trailText: Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni was re-elected to a final five-year term in office yesterday with 69.3% of the vote, but his principal opponent pledged to contest the results in the courts.
fields.body:
Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni was re-elected to a final five-year term in office yesterday with 69.3% of the vote, but his principal opponent pledged to contest the results in the courts.

Dr Kizza Besigye, who rejected the election even before the final results were released, scored 27.8%, while the other four contenders won 3% in total. Turnout was 70%.

"We shall be petitioning the supreme court and presenting the grounds requiring nullification of the elections," Dr Besigye said.

Monday's presidential election was the second time Mr Museveni had faced a ballot in his 15 years in office, but the first time he had a real challenger. Dr Besigye, a former minister in the government, stood as a reformer of Mr Museveni's National Resistance Movement, which restricts party political activity in the name of national unity.

International observers declared the polling free and fair, but a Ugandan election monitoring body, the NEM-Group, said that in eight of 56 districts it had received reports of intimidation, multiple voting, polling outside gazetted hours and in ungazetted places, harassment of agents and the selling of voters' cards.

 At least one woman died and six people were injured after a home-made bomb exploded at a mini-bus terminal in Kampala yesterday, police said. Five of the six injured were in a serious condition in hospital.

webTitle: Cable, satellite and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Cable, satellite and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Desert Bloom | Young Frankenstein | The Adventures of Baron Munchausen | Meet Joe Black | Dirty Harry | Live Cricket
fields.body:
Films

Desert Bloom (Eugene Corr, 1986) 6am, 12.05pm, Sky Cinema
Set in Nevada, 1950, the time and place for many an A-bomb test. Jon Voight is an embittered, alcoholic second world war veteran at odds with a female household: wife JoBeth Williams and three daughters, of whom Annabeth Gish is the eldest. But when the girls' sexy aunt Ellen Barkin arrives, fission is inevitable.

Young Frankenstein (Mel Brooks, 1974) 8pm, FilmFour
This light-hearted monster movie is one of Brooks's most successful spoofs. The Brooks/Gene Wilder script runs the gamut of screen humour from witty to slapstick, and there's a top-flight, fall-about cast: Wilder as the grandson of the Baron; Madeline Kahn his fiancée; Marty Feldman as Igor and even Gene Hackman hilariously dangerous as the blind hermit. But none is better than Peter Boyle as the eternally bewildered creature.

The Adventures Of Baron Munchausen (Terry Gilliam, 1988) 10pm, FilmFour
Another of Gilliam's extraordinary flights of the imagination: it may lack the coherence of Time Bandits and Brazil, but it's a vibrant, mesmerising visual feast. John Neville is the legendary 18th-century teller of tall tales who travels in a hot air balloon made out of underwear in a quest to save a city besieged by Turks; among a cast of fantastical performances, Robin Williams is the king of the moon, young Uma Thurman is Venus and the late Oliver Reed the lovelorn Vulcan - a role originally intended for Marlon Brando.

Meet Joe Black (Martin Brest, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier
Brest, who directed the interminable Scent Of A Woman, takes a leisurely three hours over his adaptation of a slight 1934 film, Death Takes A Holiday. It's the tale of the Grim Reaper, embodied pleasingly in the form of Brad Pitt, taking a tour of modern life. His guide is Anthony Hopkins's ailing media tycoon, who is buying a little more time; his daughter (Claire Forlani), meanwhile, is attracted to the stranger. A handsome production, but it lasts an eternity.

Dirty Harry (Don Siegel, 1971) 10pm, Sky Cinema
The first appearance of Clint Eastwood's San Francisco cop Harry Callahan set a new yardstick for the detective movie, and few measure up to his .44 Magnum. He gives a performance of steely minimalism, dispatching "punks" effortlessly while munching a hotdog, yet he is a man at the end of his tether. His methods of catching Andy Robinson's revolting Scorpio killer inspired wide debate about the film's supposed fascist stance. Siegel's direction, though, is exemplary.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Cricket 7am, Sky Sports 2 England's first two Tests in Sri Lanka have proved memorable for many different reasons, not least the standard of umpiring, which has bordered on the surreal. But the series is tied going into the third and final Test in Colombo, and the least we can reasonably hope for is a good, clean game of cricket remarkable mainly for the standard of play. Surely England cannot win a fourth successive series?
Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | Omnibus - The Assassin | Leading Edge
fields.body:
The shifting political and diplomatic tides of the Korean peninsula are charted by Julian Pettifer for Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4). After 50 years of grim confrontation, North and South have finally established a wary relationship. A few separated families have been allowed across the borders, but there's still a long way to go. None the less, Pettifer (who did his national service in South Korea) finds evidence that the 37,000 American troops stationed there are not quite as welcome as before.

Demetrio Tsafendas, long-forgotten murderer of prime minister Hendrik Verwoerd during a South African parliamentary session in September 1966, is portrayed in Omnibus - The Assassin (2.30pm, World Service). This powerful two-part drama draws on the researches of Henk van Woerden, the writer who managed to visit Tsafendas just before his death in a psychiatric hospital in 1999. The play, with Antony Sher as narrator, slowly reconstructs the confused life of this illegitimate mixed-race drifter, whose resentment at his treatment eventually brought death to apartheid's principal exponent.

"Overrun on landing", "wire strike", "wheels-up landing" - pilots of light aircraft in New Zealand are reported for such misdeeds twice a week. In Leading Edge (9.0pm, Radio 4) Claudia Hammond reports on new software used to analyse how they arrive at their wrong decisions.

webTitle: Country Diary from the Burren, Ireland.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: The sea at night
fields.trailText: The sea at night.
fields.body:
The Burren, Ireland

On a very quiet and very cold March night, I walked the coast road to Ballyvaughn. The moon shone in silver quietness on a calm sea. I stopped by the Weathercock, that spit of land just before the village, and watched the full tide inching back and forth, hearing its susurration as it advanced, withdrew, a minuet of the great sea. I could not but marvel at the intricate delicacy of the mighty ocean's movement, which just the day before had boomed and blared, flinging bursts of water against rocks.

Now it made little cats' tongues of liquid forever lapping at the land's edging pebbles. Arnold, in his poem Dover Beach, reminds us that "Sophocles long ago/Heard it on the Aegean". So too did Homer, Shakespeare, Milton, Racine, Rimbaud, Yeats and generations of poets, so that for us it becomes like a piece of coral, so delicately wrought, so tough in essence, and we hold it in its multiple accretions in the very depths of our hearts.

I came again in early morning to the same place, the Weathercock, under a "daffodil sky" (Tennyson). Here the village has erected a handsome, timber bird-hide together with a splendid glass-enclosed poster detailing the wildlife to be found along our coast. As I examined it I noticed a slight darkening overhead. I looked up to see one of our herons flying inland and in its great beak a fine fish.

The Weathercock land now belongs to the village, given to it by Mr Paddy Kerins. There are No Entry signs on farm gates now, and our village shop and pubs have disinfected mats outside their doors. Perhaps it is time for agribusiness and it customers to think more of the agriculture and rather less of the business.

webTitle: Hype almost destroyed Gay Dad. They talk to  Caroline Sullivan.

fields.headline: We're back. Don't tell your friends
fields.standfirst: Hype almost destroyed Gay Dad. They talk to  Caroline Sullivan
fields.trailText: Hype almost destroyed Gay Dad. They talk to Caroline Sullivan.
fields.body:
Two years ago, when Gay Dad were at their most hyped, lead singer Cliff Jones predicted that his band's name would be remembered as "either the greatest name in history or the worst you've ever heard". Posterity has yet to decide either way, but "Gay Dad" is still as provocative as it was in early 1999, when many in the music industry believed the newborn group would be the next Oasis.

But names don't sell records, particularly when they're perceived to be part of the biggest campaign of hype this country has seen since Sigue Sigue Sputnik in the 1980s. For a short time, Gay Dad were everywhere, their "walking man" logo reproduced on posters and magazine covers before they had even released a record. Fifteen labels competed for them on the strength of a demo tape and a few messianic soundbites from Jones, a former rock critic, whose self-belief ("Gay Dad are an avatar to aheadness," was a typically modest claim) made him the most talked-about new face of 1999.

"Sadly misunderstood," he sighs now, peering out from under a blue wool cap that covers the upper half of his face. "They thought we were a brand, not a band." He pulls the cap further over his eyes. If it's anonymity he wants this rainy afternoon, he's chosen the right place: the dim upper room of a Soho drinking club, whose only other inmates are drummer Baz Crowe, bassist Nigel Hoyle and, across the room, three City types. He's referring to the treatment meted out to the group once they released their first single, To Earth With Love. It was perfectly engaging but an avatar to nothing much but raucous pop-metal. It reached number 10, the album Leisure Noise a disappointing 14 and their last single a panic-stations 47.

Having built them up, the media industriously set about knocking them down. By the end of 1999, they were (rather un fairly) bracketed with Sputnik as a salutary example of the danger of allowing hype to exceed ability. They left London Records and signed with a new independent label, B Unique, but spent most of 2000 recording, then twice scrapping, an album.

To add to their woes, keyboardist James Riseboro departed, and it was clearly acrimonious. "He was interfering with the creative process, so he had to go" says Hoyle, a cheery fellow with a mullet haircut. So the keyboard player was gone, recording was proceeding dismally, and then Jones had a breakdown. "I got very paranoid and depressed because there were people who didn't get me or Gay Dad, and I'd become a figure of ridicule."

So how did it all go so wrong? He has had plenty of time to think this over, and promptly says: "Don't you dare draw any parallels between us and Sigue Sigue Sputnik." While Sputnik colluded in their myth-making, Gay Dad claim they were innocent victims of a media onslaught.

"We had good ideas, and good ideas attract more attention than bad ideas. But you can't stop a runaway train, and that was how it was. When we found out how excessive the media coverage was, it was too late to stop it. And we fatally got tagged as glam because of one line in a song, 'Put your platforms on.' It was meant to be ironic, but people can't get past the UK's irony curtain. We're the nets in front of the irony curtain," he adds with a sudden smile.

Jones is an entertaining conversationalist, who might better be suited to a Paul Morleyish role, using his journalistic skills as Morley does as "artistic director" of the Art of Noise. Not that this is likely: he's too high on the idea of being a frontman, interviewee rather than interviewer.

"The only thing that's ever been relevant to us is soul and integrity," he's saying passionately. As if to emphasise it, he has gone in for a prudent bit of image-tweaking. The peroxide bouffant do is gone; in its place a sober brown fringe. There is no more rockbabble about avatars; he prefers to talk up the new music. "The single [a breathless rush of 1960s distorto-pop] is about machines having intelligence and wanting to take care of you." He looks gleeful at the thought. "It should pull in a new audience. The rest of the album is hard and stripped-back, completely different from the first record. There was a massive misunderstanding with London Records. They thought they were getting Coldplay because our first album was soaring and epic, while we were listening to the Foo Fighters and At The Drive-In. We'd signed to a pop label, and they wanted us to be a teenybopper group, so we negotiated our way out."

webTitle: Arthur Smith: Chocolat can seriously damage your health.

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.standfirst: Chocolat can seriously damage your health
fields.trailText: Chocolat can seriously damage your health.
fields.body:
Among the various ways of marking the worth of a film, I believe my own to be unique. I eschew stars, ticks and asterisks, preferring the fag index. If I have found the movie so engrossing that I have not left the auditorium at any point, the movie scores a magnificent no-fag rating. If I have nipped out for three fags, then we are in the turkey compound.

Chocolat started pleasantly - lush shots of a groovy French village, sumptuous cinematography, rich music. Then suddenly the music and the reassuring voice-over stopped in mid-flow. Was this an art-house movie? No, it transpired the sound had gone. Embarrassment broke out: this was the cinematic equivalent of an actor drying. Someone said, "I hope they rewind." The sound returned and order was restored.

The film, like the sexual love of chocolate, is primarily a girly thing. The first shot of Juliette Binoche mixing her creamy brew drew high-pitched gasps behind me. Binoche plays that stock character, the itinerant single mum chocolate-maker. Opposing her chocolaterie is the Count, a hard-line Catholic ascetic (Alfred Molina) who would rather leap into boiling oil than be caught eating a Curly Wurly. A series of oppositions are set up: self-discipline versus self-indulgence, order versus sensuality, big black cloaks versus red high-heeled shoes. The audience was encouraged to choose glucose every time.

Then Johnny Depp appeared, sporting a tatty leather jacket and an Irish brogue. Poor old Johnny: it's hard to tell if he's any good at acting because it's almost impossible to see past his lustrous good looks. It was all getting very mythical and symbolic by now, and eventually Alfred Molina fell in some chocolate and realised he liked it. There was a big dance at the end, of course, and before that everyone got married to each other. Well, I presume they did. I don't know because at that point I was in the foyer having my second fag.

webTitle: Strip off your bra and what do you see? Libby Brooks tackles our obsession with breasts.

fields.headline: Strip off your bra and what do you see?
fields.standfirst: As the blow-up bra hits Britain,  Libby Brooks tackles our obsession with breasts. Below, three women talk frankly about what theirs mean to them
fields.trailText: As the blow-up bra hits Britain,  Libby Brooks tackles our obsession with breasts, and three women talk frankly about what theirs mean to them.
fields.body:
Sometimes it feels as though women's bodies exist only to tell lies with. A slick of gloss, a layer of elastic, an injection of collagen - femininity is contructed to the extent that nothing need be natural anymore, least of all the "natural look". Who do you want to be today?

And so it is with breasts. This week, Gossard upped the ante in the quest for the ultimate cleavage, with the launch of the Ultrabra Airotics, which features a cresent-shaped airbag in each cup. The bra comes with a small rubber pump, allowing the wearer to inflate and deflate as circumstance requires.

And for those who prefer a more holistic approach, chemists will soon be stocking a Dutch-manufactured "miracle pill", containing plant-derived hormones that boost breast size by mimicking the action of human oestrogen.

It would seem that women have an insatiable appetite for products and services to shape, firm, support, train or even mutilate their breasts. We spend millions on creating an illusion that will - we are told - increase our sexual and social worth. And a standard has emerged, from a generation of Pamela Andersonalike starlets, of tight, pert hemispheres grafted on to a hip-less boy's body.

Every celebrity snapshot now invites the same litany: are they real? What has she done with her nipples? Are they held up with tape/wire/ a team of specially trained mice?

As Naomi Wolf writes in The Beauty Myth, there now exists an Official Breast that gives no hint of maternal function. "The breast that is high but also large and firm is most likely to belong to a teenager. In a culture which fears the price of women's sexual self-confidence, that breast is the reassuring guarantee of extreme youth - sexual ignorance and infertility."

We know what our breasts mean to other people: babies see food, men see sex, the doctor sees disease, the analyst sees the root of psychosexual disturbance. Lingerie designers see cash, magazine publishers see cash, advertising agencies see cash, global business sees cash. In the breast-obsessed west, you can sell almost anything you want to with a nice pair of tits, including yourself.

We know what our breasts mean to other people, but what do they mean to us? They belong to us, though everywhere they are annexed. But women aren't simply docile victims of commercial and cultural oppression. Sometimes it's a game, this shape we present to an appraising world. Sometimes it's powerful.

What do we really see when we look in the mirror: a symbol and flesh, potency and vulnerability, the maternal and the erotic. We see memories: of being a girl, a lover, a mother. In private, apart from the cult of comparison, unassailed by public sex, we can wonder about the woman we are, the woman we fantasise about being, and why.

My mother tells me that when she was breastfeeding me, I would play with a small mole by her left breast. A couple of years ago, I discovered a similar mole just below my left armpit. It made me smile.

Joanna Taylor, 30 and 36B, is married to Steve and works for Sh! women's sex shop in north London.

I'd always expected to have bigger breasts than I do because my mum's are bigger. When I realised they weren't going to be as large as I'd thought, it was a bit of a letdown. But my husband seems happy with them and I've accepted them as part of me. There are lots of bits of my body I don't much like but I have tried to tell myself that this is my body and I must treat it nicely and not hate it. I have grown to accept my not tiny and not huge breasts - I'm actually quite pleased they're not huge because they'd sag when I got older and might give me backache. But I hear these stories about women whose breasts get smaller after having children and I think, my God, I don't want that to happen.

We are constantly bombarded with images of what the perfect woman is supposed to look like and I think both men and women look at women's breasts. My female friends and I will admire a nice cleavage on another woman and I might get a pang of envy, but I know I'm loved by my husband the way I am.

I think some men always check out a woman's breasts. A friend with large breasts was walking down the street when a man she'd never seen before came up and said: "Nice tits" then just walked off. On the one hand that sort of behaviour is offensive but on the other at least he's being honest and saying straight out what a lot of men would have been thinking.

I don't need a man to validate my breasts but I do sometimes look in the mirror and think, yuk, I'm having a bad boob day today. At times like that, it helps if you know you're loved. I think having nice breasts and showing them off does make you feel womanly, but whether that is a male-imposed value, I don't know.

Vanessa Moon, 35 and 34B, is a painter and has two children.

When I was little, I couldn't wait to develop breasts. Happily they arrived quite early and by the age of 11, I was the proud owner of a 29AA pink gingham bra. I still remember that bra with joy; it was a beautiful moment in my life. I'm not sure why I felt so excited about my new breasts but I felt the same about my first pair of high heels and my first period.

I maintained that happy relationship with my breasts throughout adolescence but I lost touch with them and certainly lost joy in them when I began to have relationships with men. Although I had been very content with them before, I suddenly felt they weren't good enough or enough like so-and-so's in the media. I felt that they became objects for men rather than things for me.

I breastfed my children for quite a long time and as a result my breasts became enormous and like two alien beings attached to me. They were linked to children rather than to me.

I think the public face of breasts has changed a lot in recent years. They are much more in your face, implanted, modified and pumped up, and I worry how these images will rub off on my daughter. I'm not that well-endowed and when I lie down, she points to my breasts and says: "They've disappeared." I tell her that's what they're supposed to do because they're not full of silicone.

When I left my husband and came out as a lesbian four years ago, my attitude to my breasts changed completely - both men and women have generally been quite approving of them but I can accept that praise from a woman better than from a man. At the moment I feel very positive in my own body space. My breasts aren't perfect but I'm very comfortable with them. I'm back to that joyous pink gingham bra stage.

Sharon Moylan, 37 and 34C, lives with her husband Michael and children Rebecca, nine, and Sonny, six. She works for IKEA and five years ago had cosmetic surgery to increase her breast size.

I hadn't noticed there was anything wrong with my breasts until a couple of people commented that they used to be larger. I was fortunate when I was younger that I was a 34B or 34C. I never gave the size or shape of my breasts much thought, but after I breastfed and then lost quite a lot of weight, they seemed to disappear and I started to think how much nicer I'd looked in dresses before.

I'm quite impulsive and I made the decision quickly, after seeing a few surgeons. I know you hear negative things about implants but I haven't had any problems with them. They're as good as the day I had them put in and my breasts are more or less back to what they were before I had the children, only I appreciate them more this time round. I can wear strappy dresses without a bra and they don't bounce around when I move. At a wedding recently, I wore something low-cut and five men came up and told me my breasts looked brilliant.

I think there is undoubtedly more pressure now from the media for women to have perfect breasts but I didn't have implants because of media pressure or pressure from any man. Quite a few men have told me they actually don't like big breasts. As for my husband, he'd always said he was happy if I was happy and that he liked me as I was - but he really likes my breasts now and thinks they're well worth the money.

One thing I would say to women who have their boobs done is go out and buy yourself a decent cardigan. In certain situations if you wear a low-cut top you can get leered at. When I do show my breasts off, it's on my terms, not someone else's.
