webTitle: Annan pleads with west as environment is pushed up UN agenda

fields.headline: Annan pleads with west as environment is pushed up UN agenda
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations, yesterday used a visit to Bangladesh, the country that stands to suffer most from global warming, to urge the worst offenders - the US, Europe and Japan - to cut carbon emissions.
fields.body:
Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations, yesterday used a visit to Bangladesh, the country that stands to suffer most from global warming, to urge the worst offenders - the US, Europe and Japan - to cut carbon emissions.

Mr Annan, who until now has concentrated on the UN's peacekeeping and humanitarian roles, made a rare speech devoted to the environment, throwing the moral authority of the organisation behind the green movement.

After flying over the huge, flood-prone Bangladesh delta, home to millions, Mr Annan urged world leaders to adopt a "new ethic of world stewardship".

He pleaded for promises on the environment made at summits in Rio and Kyoto to be met and for developing countries not to follow the same "wasteful, short-sighted and hazardous" pattern of industrialisation as the developed nations.

Mr Annan's decision to push the environment up the UN's agenda was taken when senior officials at the organisation's headquarters in New York met to discuss future priorities.

Mr Annan said a UN investigation into climate change predicted the monsoons and cyclones that hit Bangladesh will become more frequent and intense.

"In the past, we could afford a long gestation period before undertaking major environmental policy initiatives," he said. "Today, the time for a well- planned transition to a sustainable system is running out. We may be moving in the right direction but we are moving much too slowly. We are failing in our responsibility to future generations and even to the present one.

"Our biggest challenge in this new century is to take an idea that seems abstract - sustainable development - and turn it, too, into a daily reality for all the world's people."

A summit on sustainable development is planned for Johannesburg next year.

"The burden of leadership at this juncture falls on the industrialised countries and, in particular, the United States, the European Union and Japan," Mr Annan said. "To abandon this process now would set back the global climate strategy for many years."

webTitle: International: Jewish slaves to recieve Nazi compensation

fields.headline: Nazi fund topped up but doubt remains
fields.standfirst:
German industy is to pay compensation to Jewish slaves fron the Nazi-era

Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: Jewish representatives and victims' groups welcomed the news yesterday that German industry had made available the remaining DM1.4bn needed to complete a compensation fund for Nazi-era slave labourers.
fields.body:
Jewish representatives and victims' groups welcomed the news yesterday that German industry had made available the remaining DM1.4bn needed to complete a compensation fund for Nazi-era slave labourers.

The groups warned, however, that the funds needed to be distributed quickly as dozens of the 1m victims - the majority of whom are more than 80 years old - are dying every day.

German industry had been under intense pressure from politicians in Berlin and the threat of lawsuits in the US to reach the fund's DM10bn (£3.2bn) target, an amount to be contributed equally by the government and industry.

Industry chiefs and victims' groups have spent months hammering out a deal, with the contributors insisting on assurances from the US that they would not be named in future legal suits regarding their wartime activities. It remained a stumbling block yesterday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Soldiers 'block dying woman'
fields.body:
Soldiers 'block dying woman'

A Palestinian woman died in a car on her way to hospital yesterday after Israeli troops refused to let her through a roadblock at the entrance to the West Bank town of Jenin, a relative and medical sources said.

The Israeli army denied the claims and said soldiers had offered to let the car through and to bring a doctor or military ambulance to help the woman, but the driver refused and took another road. Reuters, Jenin

Police keen to try former PM

Israeli police yesterday recommended that the former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu be indicted on corruption charges.

Mr Netanyahu and his wife, Sara, are alleged to have squirrelled away a fortune in state gifts, and to have connived with a building contractor to defraud the government of hundreds of thousands of shekels. Mr Netanyahu called the allegations "baseless". Suzanne Goldenberg, Jerusalem

Police chief in drugs arrest

A former Albanian police chief has been arrested in Tirana for helping to organise the shipment of 40 tonnes of Colombian cocaine a year into Italy and other western countries, police said yesterday.

Sokol Kociu, who worked in the southern town of Vlore, and one other man were detained on Tuesday. AFP, Tirana

Stalemate in hostage-taking

An Egyptian hostage-taker holding four German tourists captive near Luxor said yesterday that he did not foresee an early end to the stand-off.

Ibrahim Ali el-Sayyed Moussa, a tour guide, abducted the tourists three days ago hoping that he could force the German government to make his estranged wife bring back his sons from Germany. AP, Luxor

Freedom party in Nazi row

Austria's far-right Freedom party was criticised yesterday after one of its local election candidates said he felt happy in a "brown" party.

A prominent member of the party's coalition partner, the People's party, called the remark, referring to a Nazi faction's uniform, "unacceptable", and said it could harm Austria's image abroad. AFP, Vienna

Killer toads take over park

Cane toads have invaded the Kakadu National Park in northern Australia, threatening other species, including crocodiles. Crocodiles have died in other areas after eating the toads, which secrete a powerful toxin when attacked. AP, Sydney

BBC evicted from Kabul

The Taliban expelled the BBC's correspondent in Afghanistan, Kate Clark, yesterday and accused the corporation of "misleading and hostile" reporting last week during the demolition of two giant Buddhas. The Taliban said they were "unhappy" with the BBC, and gave it 24 hours to close its Kabul office. Luke Harding

webTitle: International: Rebels reject talks with Mexican congress

fields.headline: Zapatistas shun congress plan for talks on rights bill
fields.standfirst: Mexican rebels accuse hardline politicians of stalling talk with them on the constitutional recognition of the rights they demand
fields.trailText: The Zapatista rebels have rejected a proposal for opening talks with Mexico's national congress on the constitutional recognition of indigenous rights they demand.
fields.body:
The Zapatista rebels have rejected a proposal for opening talks with Mexico's national congress on the constitutional recognition of indigenous rights they demand.

Subcomandante Marcos said a plan for a 20-strong commission of deputies and senators to meet Zapatista commanders in the upper house of congress was "humiliating, undignified and ridiculous". He insisted that the rebels should be allowed to address both houses from the congressional podium.

"We will not accept a shaming dialogue with the legislative power, limited to a corner and with a reduced number of legislators." Marcos said.

The offer was made by the congressional peace commission after Marcos and 23 other Zapatista leaders made a triumphal entrance into the centre of the capital on Sunday after a two-week march to demand constitutional rights for the 10m indigenous people.

But Marcos accused congressional "hardliners" of pressurising the peace commission in an attempt to sabotage the negotiating of an end to the conflict in Chiapas state that began when the Zapatistas staged an armed uprising on New Year's Day, 1994.

The Zapatistas' disappointment with the commission was such that they would now bypass it and seek direct talks with the leaders of the congressional party blocs, he said.

The commission yesterday called a closed-door meeting to decide how to respond to the rejection of its offer.

Next month, the congress is due to discuss an indigenous rights bill elaborated from partial peace accords signed in February 1996. Those accords were shelved by the previous administration of President Ernesto Zedillo, prompting the Zapatistas to abandon the negotiations and return to their jungle bases in the southern state.

Mexico's new president, Vicente Fox, dusted off the bill and sent it to the legislature as soon as he took office last December, raising hopes for peace and prompting the rebels to organise their unarmed march on the capital.

Marcos has announced that the rebels will not leave the capital until the congress approves the bill. He says approval is a non-negotiable condition for starting peace talks.

The Zapatistas also insist on the release of all their jailed supporters and the withdrawal of three military bases near their strongholds. They reject as inadequate the dismantling of four bases and the partial prisoner release programme Mr Fox has ordered so far.

But the key issue is the bill. Despite the government's support and a groundswell of national sentiment in the measure's favour, the congressional situation is tricky. No single party has a simple majority and several appear split on the bill.

The law would grant indigenous communities significant autonomy in the way they run their communities, and enshrine their right to live by traditions that differ from traditional Mexican forms of authority. Election decisions involving indigenous commu nities, for instance, would be taken collectively and not individually.

Some prominent members of Mr Fox's National Action party have expressed concerns that this could threaten national unity and undermine individual rights, pointing to the secondary position of women in several of Mexico's dozens of indigenous groups.

The rebels have never represented a serious military threat, but their national and international appeal is such that the previous government opted not to attempt a politically costly eradication campaign and instead followed a containment policy aimed at eroding their popular support.

Mr Fox is impatient for a peace accord that would improve Mexico's image abroad in the wake of his defeat of the 71-year-old regime of the Institutional Revolutionary party.

He has welcomed the Zapatista march on the capital as a sign that peace is just around the corner, but the early hitch in the congressional talks will make him think again.

webTitle: US u-turn on emissions fuels anger

fields.headline: US u-turn on emissions fuels anger
fields.standfirst:
Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush has withdrawn a campaign pledge to limit carbon dioxide emissions, causing a split in his cabinet and an angry response from Europe.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington and Ian Black  in Brussels
fields.body:
President George Bush has withdrawn a campaign pledge to limit carbon dioxide emissions, causing a split in his cabinet and an angry response from Europe.

The sudden about turn on carbon dioxide removes the gas from a list of emissions the Bush camp had promised would be subject to controls.

The White House declaration that the pledge was "a mistake" represented a particular humiliation for the head of the environmental protection agency, Christine Todd Whitman, who had restated the pledge only days earlier.

The switch is also a rebuke for the treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, who has said that the threat of global warming was equal to the prospect of a nuclear holocaust.

Moderate Republicans and even some power companies who had urged that environmental measures be taken sooner rather than later were also disappointed.

The decision allies Mr Bush with the big energy corporations which were big contributors to his campaign fund, and with party hardliners such as Senators Jesse Helms and Chuck Hagel, who view constraints on carbon dioxide emissions as covert capitulation to the 1997 Kyoto treaty on global warming, which has not been ratified by Congress.

In a policy speech in Michigan last September, Mr Bush said: "We will require all power plants to meet clean air standards in order to reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, mercury and carbon dioxide within a reasonable period of time."

At the height of the campaign, the promise won plaudits from environmentalists and blunted the challenges from Al Gore and Ralph Nader on green issues.

In fact Mr Bush ridiculed Mr Gore for promising only voluntary reductions.

But Scott McClellan, a White House spokesman, said on Tuesday: "CO2 should not have been included as a pollutant during the campaign. It was a mistake."

In a letter to Senator Hagel, Mr Bush said that controls on carbon dioxide emissions would raise energy prices, adding that "we must be very careful not to take actions that could harm consumers".

"This is especially true given the incomplete state of scientific knowledge of the causes of, and solutions to, global climate change," the letter said, in an apparent retreat from his recognition during the campaign that carbon dioxide exacerbated global warming.

In a sharply worded riposte, the European environment commissioner, Margot Wallstrom, said yesterday: "I am concerned about President Bush's remarks that more research is needed into the causes of climate change before we know what the solutions are."

"The inter-governmental panel on climate change has once again confirmed the evidence on the causes of climate change and the solution," Ms Wallstrom said. "Nobody should ignore these warnings."

A new British study published in today's edition of the journal Nature confirmed the build-up of greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, in the earth's atmosphere, allowing less of the sun's heat to escape into space after being reflected off the earth's surface.

John Harries, who led the Imperial College study, said: "We're absolutely sure, there's no ambiguity. This shows the greenhouse effect is operating and what we are seeing can only be due to the increase in the gases."

This transatlantic clash over carbon dioxide is the latest in a series since Mr Bush took office in January: rows over defence, trade and the withdrawal of US aid to family planning groups have all underlined the potential for trouble between Washington and Brussels.

The withdrawal of Mr Bush's campaign pledge has triggered an uproar among US environmentalists, many of whom had welcomed his apparently friendly posture during the campaign. The main environmental groups held a joint press conference outside the White House yesterday to protest against the decision.

Fred Krupp, head of Environmental Defence, said: "Not only has the administration reneged on a campaign commitment, but in opposing the Kyoto protocol and power plant pollution controls, it has effectively blocked the only two proposed vehicles for fighting global warming - the key environmental threat of this century - while offering no alternative path to protect the planet."

fields.headline: Mbeki rejects Aids state of emergency
fields.standfirst:
South African President, Thabo Mbeki refuses to declare a state of emergency over Aids

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: President Thabo Mbeki yesterday rejected calls by the opposition to declare a state of emergency over Aids, which would allow the South African government to bypass patent laws and obtain cheaper drugs. He said the move was unwarranted and probably unconstitutional.
fields.body:
President Thabo Mbeki yesterday rejected calls by the opposition to declare a state of emergency over Aids, which would allow the South African government to bypass patent laws and obtain cheaper drugs. He said the move was unwarranted and probably unconstitutional.

"No country has declared an emergency on these grounds," he said. "The declaration of a state of emergency in terms of the constitution is a drastic measure which entails the curtailment of the provisions of the bill of rights."

The leader of the opposition, Tony Leon, made the call during the president's twice yearly question time in parliament. Mr Leon said that with more than 4m South Africans infected with HIV, and almost none receiving anti-retroviral drugs, the country was facing a national emergency.

But Mr Mbeki said legislation being challenged in the high court by 39 of the world's largest drug companies should open the way to cheaper Aids drugs through a much wider variety of sources if the government wins the case.

Mr Mbeki said the government would wait for the outcome of the court case and a report from experts - including "dissidents" who question the link between HIV and Aids - before reassessing its policy.

International trade law permits governments to bypass the usual pharmaceutical patent protections if they declare a health emergency. But legal experts have warned that if the government were to do so before the lawsuit was decided it might appear to be trying to bypass the courts.

Mr Mbeki said there were also constitutional obstacles to such a declaration, including fears that it could lead to the curtailment of civil liberties.

Under the constitution, a state of emergency could only be declared "when the life of a nation was threatened" by war or some similar disaster and "the declaration is necessary to restore peace and order". Even then, a state of emergency could only last for 21 days, after which parliament would have to renew it every two months.

"It has complex consequences for the country, which are undesirable, especially where there are other ways to achieve the same objective - that is, obtaining affordable access to all medicines," Mr Mbeki told the parliament.

But Mr Leon accused the president of being reluctant to make anti-retrovirals widely available because he sided with the Aids "dissidents".

"Last year an estimated 250,000 South Africans died of Aids. It is estimated that more than 4m are sick at the moment. If that isn't an emergency, what is?" Mr Leon said.

fields.headline: Cheaper drugs for Africa
fields.standfirst:
Manufacturer to relax its patent on two Aids remedies

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: One of the world's biggest drugs companies yesterday relaxed its patent over two Aids drugs, allowing manufacturers in South Africa to produce cheaper copies for local use, after protests from the scientific community.
fields.byline: Andrew Clark and Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
One of the world's biggest drugs companies yesterday relaxed its patent over two Aids drugs, allowing manufacturers in South Africa to produce cheaper copies for local use, after protests from the scientific community.

Pressure from students at Yale University helped persuade the New York company Bristol-Myers Squibb to make the biggest concession yet by the pharmaceuticals industry to widening the availability of medicines in Africa. It is to relax its patent protection over the Aids drugs Zerit and Videx.

Its decision follows a series of protests about the high price of the treatments from students and scientists at Yale, where d4T, the key chemical compound within Zerit, was invented.

The university earns $40m in royalties a year from sales of the drug, but has little control over pricing under an agreement giving Bristol Myers-Squibb exclusive manufacturing rights.

A spokeswoman for Bristol-Myers Squibb said: "Although we're not actually relinquishing our rights to Zerit, if somebody in South Africa infringes on the method of use in our patent, we're not going to object."

In common with rival drugs manufacturers, Bristol-Myers Squibb is lowering the price of its drugs in Africa from $20 a day to less than $1.

However, its change of heart on patent protection is far more significant - up to now, the industry has vigorously defended its intellectual property rights worldwide. Nearly 40 drugs firms are fighting a court case in Pretoria to prevent local manufacturers from copying their Aids medicines.

We seek no profits on Aids drugs in Africa, and we will not let our patents be an obstacle," Bristol-Myers Squibb's executive vice-president John McGoldrick said. "This is not about profits and patents; it's about poverty and a devastating disease."

The medical aid organisation Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) which has spearheaded the drive to make Aids drugs affordable in the developing world, gave the announcement a cautious welcome yesterday. Toby Kasper, who leads the MSF programme on Aids medicines in South Africa, said: "Having been through a number of seemingly 'unambiguous statements' I'm going to wait until I see the small print."

But Mr Kasper, speaking from the MSF headquarters in Paris, said that if Bristol-Myers Squibb did indeed relax its grip on its patent for Zerit, it would represent a break through in the struggle against Aids in developing countries. "It opens up the possibility for countries like South Africa adopting the model of Brazil, and allowing local generic producers to make Aids drugs at an affordable price for the people of those countries."

An Indian manufacturer, Cipla, has offered to make low-cost versions of Aids drugs for use in Africa. It was unclear whether it would benefit from Bristol-Myers Squibb's announcement - a spokeswoman for the company said only manufacturers in South Africa would be allowed to infringe the firm's patent.

A pressure group at Yale demanding the availability of cheaper drugs has been backed by Professor William Prusoff, the semi-retired scientist who pioneered research on d4T. A Yale spokesman said yesterday the university was still examining Bristol-Myers Squibb's announcement and would make a statement as soon as possible.

A Yale spokesman said yesterday the university was still examining Bristol-Myers Squibb's announcement and would make a statement as soon as possible.

fields.headline: At this price?  Trafficmaster
fields.trailText: Trafficmaster, the traffic information provider, said yesterday it was on the road to success by saying it was on course to triple its revenue over the year.
fields.body:
Trafficmaster, the traffic information provider, said yesterday it was on the road to success by saying it was on course to triple its revenue over the year.

"We are very happy with the achievement over the last 12 months. We have good momentum and we are very excited about the potential for this company," David Martell, Trafficmaster's chief executive, said.

The fact that Trafficmaster lost money in 2000 and saw sales drop over the year did little to put off investors. The share price surged 52.5p, or 23.28% to 278.75p.

The company reported a pre-tax profit of £435,000, compared with £3.8m in 1999. Revenue was also down on the previous period: £13.54m, against £15.1m in 1999.

Analysts said the figures were in line with expectations and the firm looked "remarkably strong". A definite vote of confidence even if Trafficmaster was merely clawing back some of the losses its share price suffered on Tuesday.

Profits and revenues were hit, the group said, because of heavy investment in expansion and a strategic switch from selling hardware to services. The cost of terminating a licensing deal with Mannesmann to operate its own network in Germany also affected the figures.

Trafficmaster announced a deal with Palm, the US hand-held computer maker, to deliver traffic information over new internet enabled hand-helds. Although the deal is non-exclusive and the revenue projections modest - users will pay £4 a month to receive traffic information and the income will be split between Palm and Trafficmaster - it is an additional route to market. The company has been building up presence in America and Europe and, although competition will get stronger, Trafficmaster does have first-mover advantage.

Analysts think the firm is moving in the right direction for the future, and the share price is relatively low, so buy.

webTitle: Campbell family in row over final home for Bluebird

fields.headline: Campbell family in row over final home for Bluebird
fields.standfirst: The story in pictures
fields.trailText: A week after Bluebird was pulled from the sands of Coniston Water, a row has broken out over who owns the speedboat.
fields.body:
A week after Bluebird was pulled from the sands of Coniston Water, a row has broken out over who owns the speedboat.

Paul Foulkes-Halbard, 63, a former racing driver nicknamed "the flying farmer", yesterday claimed he owned the craft which crashed and sank, killing its skipper, Donald Campbell, in 1967.

Mr Foulkes-Halbard said he had papers to prove it and was going to put the craft on a trailer and tow it to his fortified medieval manor house in East Sussex, where he has what is billed as the world's largest collection of Campbell memorabilia.

Residents of Coniston, with the reported support of Campbell's widow, Tonia Bern-Campbell, 64, said that Cumbria was the rightful home of Bluebird and it should be kept there in a purpose-built museum.

Campbell was 45 when he attempted to break his world water speed record on Coniston. The craft left the water, turned over, and crashed down into the 150ft deep lake. His body was never found, Campbell having said beforehand that in death the skipper should stay with the craft.

The wreck of the jet-powered Bluebird also lay lost, until last year when it was found by a team of divers during the filming of a BBC documentary. Last week it was salvaged by divers and taken to a workshop in Newcastle upon Tyne.

Last night Mr Foulkes-Halbard said: "It's simple. I own the boat. At the end of the day, that's the final word."

He has turned Filching Manor into a shrine to the Campbells, father and son. He charges £3.50 to £5 for a guided tour, donating some of the proceeds to charity, and also runs a Campbell memorial go-kart circuit, opened by Campbell's daughter, Gina.

Mr Foulkes-Halbard said he had been a friend of the late Leo Villa, Campbell's race engineer, and came to own the boat in 1991 through the "course of business". He had documents which he would produce in court if needed. He said at least one burglary attempt had been made on the manor this week, which he feared was linked to the documents.

He was with Mr Villa when he died from illness in 1979. "I held his hand and he said to me: 'It wasn't my fault, boy.' He meant the accident that killed Campbell. Long before that he expressed a wish that I get the boat up and examine it to find the cause of the accident. Leo Villa always worried about it at the back of his mind."

Mr Foulkes-Halbard said the divers who salvaged Bluebird had asked his permission beforehand. "People ask why was I not at Coniston when Bluebird was raised, but it would have been far too emotional. I would have been in floods of tears.

"I have not made my mind up yet. But I want to get to the bottom of how the crash happened, and I could do that if I had Bluebird here. I expect I shall come up with a trailer. If people want to discuss it with me then, I'll listen.

"How can they say the boat belongs in Coniston, when it was designed, conceived and built in Sussex, 15 miles from where I am standing?"

Tony Robinson, a friend of the Campbell family, said: "All the Campbells expressed a wish for Bluebird to come to Coniston. There is no reason to believe Mr Foulkes-Halbard's claim until he produces evidence. Just making noises is not enough. If what he says is true, let him produce the evidence and we'll go from there."

webTitle: Misery in the village that awaited a miracle

fields.headline: Misery in the village that awaited a miracle
fields.standfirst: First farm with disease sealed off but talk is of when it will strike next
fields.trailText: On any other day, Lassay-les-Chateaux would be full of charm: a small, well-kept Normandy town; neat stone-built houses clustered round a church; a square, smart flower beds, a butcher, baker, two patisseries, a cafe.
fields.body:
On any other day, Lassay-les-Chateaux would be full of charm: a small, well-kept Normandy town; neat stone-built houses clustered round a church; a square, smart flower beds, a butcher, baker, two patisseries, a cafe.

Yesterday, Lassay-les-Chateaux was grey. Grey with the incessant drizzle that fell from a heavy sky, grey with the grim faces of the few inhabitants venturing on to its streets, grey with the knowledge that two miles up the road was the farm that harboured France's first - and certainly not its last - case of foot and mouth disease.

"So the miracle never happened," said Paul Conneau, a local beef farmer, nursing a glass in the all but empty Le Brazza bar overlooking the square. "The longer the wait went on, the more we all began to think we might have escaped. Now we know: Francis was the unlucky one this time, but tomorrow it could be any or all of us."

A mile up the hill, past St Joseph's chapel, on a bleak plateau, six gendarmes in drab olive capes were manning a roadblock. Only the 200 or so people living within a 1.5 mile radius of Francis and Therese Leroyer's farm may pass; they have to get out of their cars, dip their feet in disinfectant, drive over a treated mat of straw. Only a handful did and none of them much wanted to talk.

"You can just about see the smoke from here," said Jacqueline, the wife of a dairy farmer in the quarantined hamlet of La Baroche-Gondoin. "It's taking two days to burn all Francis's cows. They brought more fuel in at lunchtime, a big trailer load of wood. This region is only farms, you know. I don't know what we'll do."

The authorities in nearby Laval, the capital of the Mayenne department, say there are 47 herds of cattle, pigs and sheep within the first security perimeter surrounding Mr Leroyer's farm, and some 550 within the surveillance zone, policed by 200 gendarmes, extending five miles beyond.

Jean-Francois Rebout is the dealer in La Baroche-Gondoin whose imported Herefordshire sheep infected six of Francis Leroyer's 114-strong herd of Holstein cows. All the sheep were slaughtered two weeks ago but the two men's farms, L'Agneau mayennais and La Haye, are separated only by a narrow road.

Reached by telephone, Mr Rebout said he could not believe the disease would not now spread further: he had sold 4,500 sheep to all parts of France since importing his three British flocks. He said he felt so bad for his neighbour, he didn't really know what to say to him.

"I just buy sheep and sell them on," Mr Rebout said. "It's much worse for him, he raises his cows. He saw them being born. And he really has the model farm, you should see it. It's clean like I don't know what, mown lawn and everything. He had put in all the footbaths and disinfectants. He didn't deserve this, he really didn't."

Mr Leroyer is 57, three years away from retirement. He had spent 30 years building up his herd of Holsteins, his sole source of income. He was calm on the phone, trying hard to see something positive in what had befallen him.

"It took the vets a whole night to put my cows down," he said. "Then the firemen lit the first fire at about 8.30 in the morning. I couldn't watch, of course I couldn't. It's almost unimaginable what's happening to us, a lifetime up in flames. All I hope is that this sacrifice will be worth it and that the whole thing stops here."

Back in town, they weren't so sure it would. "Foxes can carry it," said Philippe, whose agency handles the insurance business of two dozen local farms. "What do you do about them, and birds, even the wind? It moves so fast, this disease. It's everyone's nightmare."

Oddly, maybe, for British sensibilities, no one was out to get the English; there was solidarity among farmers. Instead, the farmers of Lassay-les-Chateaux rounded on French farmers' perennial target: Paris, the ministry of agriculture, the bloody government.

"English farmers didn't want this either, did they?" said Roger Sochon, 54, who has 20 head of cattle inside the first security zone. "Not their fault, is it? But how come those sheep were allowed into France? When I buy a cow, I have to get a certificate for it, get it checked."

His dungaree-clad neighbour, who refused to give his name, joined in. "And why the hell did we ever stop vaccinating against foot and mouth - whose decision was that? The union's taking legal advice on taking them to court, see whether all the precautions were taken. It's just like BSE: Paris does too little, too late. And it's us that suffer. As if we weren't badly enough off already."

fields.headline: What Europe's papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: El Mundo, Spain
fields.body:
El Mundo, Spain

"Foot and mouth disease is, unlike BSE, nothing new. It is something we have lived with in Spain forever. It crops up now and then and is endemic in Morocco, just around the corner. Neither we, nor other Europeans, have reacted with such alarm in the past. That reaction now looks increasingly like collective paranoia."

Die Welt, Germany

"German farmers are trembling with fear following the arrival of foot and mouth on the continent. It's getting nearer and nearer to Germany.

In Germany politicians are right to establish emergency plans of action, and to expect the worst. They reacted too late over BSE and now they're paying the price."

La Stampa, Italy

"When European countries close their frontiers to their animals they are doing something necessary and sensible: the spread of the epidemic has to be blocked. But the adoption of this reasonable measure is often accompanied by accusations and reciprocal recriminations, which are poisoning relations between the countries of United Europe. The continent, until yesterday unified by the dream of community, suddenly seems to be reliving the emotions of the eve of the Thirty Years War."

webTitle: Cost of outbreak soars as crisis goes on

fields.headline: Cost of outbreak soars as crisis goes on
fields.standfirst:
Sports, leisure and tourism feel the pinch

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farmers
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar, Paul Kelso and Sarah Hall
fields.body:
Farmers

The export ban alone will, the NFU claim, cost lamb producers £26m, pigs £17m and dairy farmers £8m this month

The reduction in the value of animals could cost the industry £4m a month, with extra feed and housing costs due to keeping animals on farm of another £4m.

Loss of income from the closure of farmhouse bed and breakfast and farm shops could cost at least £30m a month in a prolonged crisis, the union claims.

NFU economist Peter King said: "In the short term farmers will be able to adjust. The big issue is how long foot and mouth continues to exist. As long as it continues it's going to be extremely difficult."

Gareth Jones, spokesman for the Farm Retail Association, described the economic impact as "potentially huge".

Retail farms employ an average of eight staff, some many times more, and are typically outlets for 200 local suppliers. Farms shops trading for more than 30 years are having to lay off staff for the first time, Mr Jones said.

Hauliers

Drivers of livestock lorries are quitting the business while hauliers must sit it out as their vehicles stand empty.

There are about 500 specialist hauliers, employing round 3,500 drivers. General hauliers are also affected by the ban on exports of meat.

The crisis is estimated to cost the industry £7m a week.

Roger Wrapson, secretary of the Road Haulage Association livestock group, said: "As the whole thing has gone on so the number of people affected has increased. It originally affected the livestock haulier. Now the general hauliers are having difficulty carrying various foodstuffs into Europe."

Tourism

The British Tourism Authority's rough estimate for losses to the industry is between £100m and £150m a week. In March last year, the industry made £840m.

However, the season begins in earnest in April. Last year profits soared to more than a billion in that month.

The worst affected areas have been Cumbria and south-west Devon, with the movement bans badly affecting walking and activity holidays in those regions. American and Canadian visitors' fears have been largely assuaged, the BTA says.The tourist authority's concern is focused in Europe where 250,000 fewer visitors are expected to travel from France this year.

Supermarkets

Some prices have gone up for the consumer. One leading chain said that pork prices had gone up because UK processors were charging more -from £3.29 for a kilo of chops to £3.59, while increased air freight charges had pushed up the price of imported New Zealand lamb.

Sport and leisure

The foot and mouth crisis has dealt the harshest blow to rugby and horse racing, both sports with strong links to rural communities.

Horse racing has been the biggest loser. Racing in the UK was suspended within days of the disease being diagnosed and for seven days the tracks remained quiet at an estimated cost of around £600,000 per cancelled meeting. Yesterday the British Horseracing Board (BHB) estimated that the cost of the week-long shutdown was £15m, a figure that includes betting revenues.

Chairman Peter Savill said a month-long shutdown would cost £60m, and argued that a programme of fixtures be maintained to protect jobs.

The outbreak led to the postponement of the Cheltenham Festival, the climax of the National Hunt season and an event crucial to the economic wellbeing of the town. Around 150,000 people visit annually, pouring around £10m into local coffers. It will now take place on April 17-19.

Key Six Nations rugby union championship fixtures have also been cancelled. The Wales-Scotland match scheduled for Cardiff earlier this month was axed, costing the Welsh Rugby Football Union £5-£6m in lost revenues. The cost to Cardiff's hoteliers, restaurants and bars has been put at £7m.

Next weekend's match between Ireland and England in Dublin has also been cancelled, but this weekend's match in Paris between France and Wales will go ahead. The French agriculture minister ruled that 3,000 visiting Welshmen is a negligible risk compared with the 70,000 Britons who travel to France on a daily basis.

The English Rugby Football Union estimate that ticket sales alone at Twickenham bring in £3m per match, and are hopeful that next month's France game will go ahead.

fields.bodyText: Farmers The export ban alone will, the NFU claim, cost lamb producers £26m, pigs £17m and dairy farmers £8m this month The reduction in the value of animals could cost the industry £4m a month, with extra feed and housing costs due to keeping animals on farm of another £4m. Loss of income from the closure of farmhouse bed and breakfast and farm shops could cost at least £30m a month in a prolonged crisis, the union claims. NFU economist Peter King said: "In the short term farmers will be able to adjust. The big issue is how long foot and mouth continues to exist. As long as it continues it's going to be extremely difficult." Gareth Jones, spokesman for the Farm Retail Association, described the economic impact as "potentially huge". Retail farms employ an average of eight staff, some many times more, and are typically outlets for 200 local suppliers. Farms shops trading for more than 30 years are having to lay off staff for the first time, Mr Jones said. Hauliers Drivers of livestock lorries are quitting the business while hauliers must sit it out as their vehicles stand empty. There are about 500 specialist hauliers, employing round 3,500 drivers. General hauliers are also affected by the ban on exports of meat. The crisis is estimated to cost the industry £7m a week. Roger Wrapson, secretary of the Road Haulage Association livestock group, said: "As the whole thing has gone on so the number of people affected has increased. It originally affected the livestock haulier. Now the general hauliers are having difficulty carrying various foodstuffs into Europe." Tourism The British Tourism Authority's rough estimate for losses to the industry is between £100m and £150m a week. In March last year, the industry made £840m. However, the season begins in earnest in April. Last year profits soared to more than a billion in that month. The worst affected areas have been Cumbria and south-west Devon, with the movement bans badly affecting walking and activity holidays in those regions. American and Canadian visitors' fears have been largely assuaged, the BTA says.The tourist authority's concern is focused in Europe where 250,000 fewer visitors are expected to travel from France this year. Supermarkets Some prices have gone up for the consumer. One leading chain said that pork prices had gone up because UK processors were charging more -from £3.29 for a kilo of chops to £3.59, while increased air freight charges had pushed up the price of imported New Zealand lamb. Sport and leisure The foot and mouth crisis has dealt the harshest blow to rugby and horse racing, both sports with strong links to rural communities. Horse racing has been the biggest loser. Racing in the UK was suspended within days of the disease being diagnosed and for seven days the tracks remained quiet at an estimated cost of around £600,000 per cancelled meeting. Yesterday the British Horseracing Board (BHB) estimated that the cost of the week-long shutdown was £15m, a figure that includes betting revenues. Chairman Peter Savill said a month-long shutdown would cost £60m, and argued that a programme of fixtures be maintained to protect jobs. The outbreak led to the postponement of the Cheltenham Festival, the climax of the National Hunt season and an event crucial to the economic wellbeing of the town. Around 150,000 people visit annually, pouring around £10m into local coffers. It will now take place on April 17-19. Key Six Nations rugby union championship fixtures have also been cancelled. The Wales-Scotland match scheduled for Cardiff earlier this month was axed, costing the Welsh Rugby Football Union £5-£6m in lost revenues. The cost to Cardiff's hoteliers, restaurants and bars has been put at £7m. Next weekend's match between Ireland and England in Dublin has also been cancelled, but this weekend's match in Paris between France and Wales will go ahead. The French agriculture minister ruled that 3,000 visiting Welshmen is a negligible risk compared with the 70,000 Britons who travel to France on a daily basis. The English Rugby Football Union estimate that ticket sales alone at Twickenham bring in £3m per match, and are hopeful that next month's France game will go ahead. What's going on? webTitle: America pays high price for energy appetite

fields.headline: America pays high price for energy appetite
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: American homeowners had a nasty surprise when their heating bills arrived this winter. Soaring demand for natural gas during November and December when temperatures fell to their lowest levels for more than a century sent wholesale gas prices soaring threefold.
fields.body:
American homeowners had a nasty surprise when their heating bills arrived this winter. Soaring demand for natural gas during November and December when temperatures fell to their lowest levels for more than a century sent wholesale gas prices soaring threefold. Some families found that their bills had doubled on a year ago.

Prices have fallen back from December's record of $10 (£6.90) per thousand cubic feet, to $5, but they are still twice as high as this time last year.

Companies such as Shell are bullish about the future of the natural gas, forecasting rising demand and limited supply.

At present only 15% of US electricity comes from gas-burning power plants, but nine out of 10 new plants being built are gas-fired. It is perceived to be cleaner and greener than coal, which provides the bulk of US electricity generation and the high efficiency of modern combined-cycle gas turbines has brought costs down.

Last winter's surge in demand followed a period when output had been cut following the crash in prices of 1998/99. Companies that slashed budgets for developing new reserves are now rushing to invest in the sector in the expectation that prices will stay high. But new developments will take a while to come on stream and in the meantime traditional sources of supply in Texas and the Gulf of Mexico cannot keep pace with demand.

As a result the US is being forced to increase its imports of liquid natural gas - pricier than piped gas because it requires expensive processing and shipping. Mothballed LNG terminals are being reactivated.

Hunger for natural gas will be met in part by plans to build a pipeline that will tap distant gas reserves in Alaska and the Arctic regions of Canada, although President Bush faces opposition from the environmentalist lobby over his attempts to open new fields.

webTitle: World shuts its doors on EU imports

fields.headline: World shuts its doors on EU imports
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: United States
fields.body:
United States

Airline passengers who have visited the British countryside must have their shoes disinfected if they appear soiled. Imports of livestock, fresh meat and unpasteurised dairy products from all 15 countries of the European Union are now outlawed.

The EU expressed surprise that the ban had been extended to all 15 member countries when 13 were disease-free.

But Tom Harkin of the farming state of Iowa, a senior Democrat on the Senate agriculture committee said: "We just don't know how far this disease has spread. It is common sense to take protective measures."

Canada

Even used farm equipment from the EU is now subject to an import ban, as well as all livestock and farm products.

Australia

Imports of all meat, livestock and dairy products from the EU are banned.

New Zealand

New Zealand suspended all imports of livestock and meat products from the EU following confirmation of the outbreak in France.

Czech Republic

About 70 border crossings with Poland and Germany are closed to pedestrians and transit of all products from animals sensitive to the virus is banned. Foreign travellers at international airports are being disinfected.

Poland

All animals and animal products from the EU have been banned, as well as those from Switzerland, Hungary, Liechtenstein, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Norway, Iceland, Croatia, Estonia, Romania, Bulgaria and Slovenia.

Estonia, Latvia

Both Baltic states have banned milk, meat products, and all livestock from France. Visiting motorists must drive through pools of disinfectant.

Japan

France has been added to a list of countries, including Britain, Argentina, South Korea and China, from which all imports of pork and other livestock are suspended. Foot and mouth was first reported in Japan in March last year on three farms in the south of the country. There was another case in Hokkaido in May. No other cases have been reported since.

South Korea

The government yesterday announced a ban on imports of livestock and meat products from the EU.

United Arab Emirates

Eight cases of foot-and-mouth disease confirmed. Imports of animals and birds prohibited without prior permission.

Said Mohammad Raqabani, a minister, said: "The emergence of foot and mouth cases is absolutely normal in the Emirates, a country which imports lots of animals. Most of our imports come from Australia."

Argentina

A case of the disease in Rivadavia, near the capital, was confirmed yesterday. Argentina plans to vaccinate herds against the disease, having voluntarily restricted beef exports. Other cattle have shown symptoms of the disease, suggesting it may have spread further. It is endemic in parts of South America.

Colombia

The Colombian Agricultural Institute (ICA) confirmed that it had diagnosed foot and mouth in a cow and two calves last month. A vaccination campaign is under way and further measures are being taken to ensure that it does not spread to the Caribbean coast.The disease has been present in Colombia for 50 years.

Hong Kong

The import of live pigs, cattle, sheep and goats from France and Britain has been banned to prevent new strains of the virus spreading.

"FMD is an animal disease which is not a public health hazard. It is an endemic disease occurring in pigs in the region, including Hong Kong, during winter seasons," a spokesman said.

webTitle: News: Guide dogs, a thing of the past

fields.headline: Tongue patch to guide blind
fields.standfirst: Guide dogs may be a thing of the past if American scientists develop a device to help blind people see using the tip of their tongues
fields.trailText: The guide dog's days may be numbered. American scientists are developing a device to help blind people "see" obstacles using the tips of their tongues.
fields.body:
The guide dog's days may be numbered. American scientists are developing a device to help blind people "see" obstacles using the tips of their tongues.

Researchers at the University of Wisconsin claim that within five years their "tongue display unit" will be ready for everyday use.

Using a tiny array of 144 electrodes attached to the surface of the tongue, the unit fires mild electronic impulses to relay spatial information from a wireless camera to the brain.

In its simplest form, a tingle on the left side of the tongue means turn left, while tingling from front to back means continue straight ahead.

The research, revealed in New Scientist, may appear the stuff of science fiction, but the developers, Paul Bach-y-Rita, a physician and inventor, and Kurt Kaczmarek, have a reputation for developing devices for blind people.

"You don't see with your eyes, you see with your brain," said Dr Bach-y-Rita, who has applied for a patent. "You can compensate for sensory loss by rehabilitating the brain."

fields.headline: Prison terms for illegal adoptions
fields.standfirst:
Internet babies case prompts tough new sanctions and illegal adoptions could lead to prison sentences


Special report: child protection

Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: Jail sentences for people avoiding child protection procedures by adopting children from overseas will be introduced by the government next month in the wake of public concern over the "internet babies" case.
fields.body:
Jail sentences for people avoiding child protection procedures by adopting children from overseas will be introduced by the government next month in the wake of public concern over the "internet babies" case.

It will become a criminal offence to bring a child into the UK from another country for the purposes of adoption without first gaining approval from a recognised adoption agency. Prospective adoptive parents bringing children to Britain without first passing these tests will be subject to a prison term of up to three months, a £5,000 fine or both.

The tough approach will be announced today by John Hutton, the health minister responsible for adoption and social care, as he publishes legislation introducing the first comprehensive overhaul of British adoption law for 25 years.

The bill is expected to get a quick second reading debate in the Commons, but is not likely to complete its passage through parliament before the election.

The speed of its introduction was dictated by a slip of Tony Blair's tongue during exchanges in the Commons about the twins brought into Britain in January by Alan and Judith Kilshaw. The north Wales couple bought the babies through a child broker advertising on a Californian website.

Health ministers wanted to legislate this year, but the prime minister said the bill would come in the present session. It is expected to have more than 100 clauses, including a right of appeal for prospective adopters who believe they have been unreasonably turned down by the adoption agencies.

Criminal sanctions against people bringing in children from abroad without prior vetting will be introduced by regulation next month under legislation on inter-country adoptions passed two years ago. These powers will only work against those intending to complete the adoption under UK law.

Ministers are considering using the new bill to target those - such as Mr and Mrs Kilshaw - who complete adoption formalities abroad before bringing the children back into Britain. The bill will include powers to prosecute internet service providers relaying advertisements for adoption agencies that would be illegal under British law. Service providers would be told if they were providing links to websites selling children for adoption and expected to block the material.

Other measures in the bill include financial allowances for adoptive parents and a streamlined system to reduce the time children spend in council care. A national adoption register will be given statutory backing.

Mr Hutton will say the legislation should increase the number of adoptions from 3,000 to 4,000 a year - and more than that in the longer term.

The government will claim that hundreds of children a year can be given a better start in life if they can be moved more quickly from council care into adoptive families.

Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said: "I welcome the bill, but we get adoption legislation only once every quarter century. We have got to get it right. This must not go through on a groundswell of public reaction to a particular case. Children are too important for that."

Social workers are perceived by the public as interfering, ineffective and excessively bureaucratic, according to a survey published yesterday as the Local Government Association launched a campaign to restore public confidence. More than one in six jobs in social care work is now vacant and two-thirds of social services departments have reported difficulties in obtaining staff.

webTitle: No charge for agent in Finucane murder

fields.headline: No charge for agent in Finucane murder
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A spokesman for the Pat Finucane Centre yesterday condemned a decision not to prosecute a former army double agent over the murder of the Belfast solicitor.
fields.body:
A spokesman for the Pat Finucane Centre yesterday condemned a decision not to prosecute a former army double agent over the murder of the Belfast solicitor.

News that Brian Nelson would not face charges came as relatives of Mr Finucane, shot dead by loyalists 12 years ago, arrived in Washington to press for help in getting a judicial inquiry into the killing, in which they believe security forces were also involved.

Nelson worked for the Force Research Unit, at the centre of allegations of collusion between terrorists and security forces being investigated by the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens.

Nelson was both a military intelligence spy and a senior member of the Ulster Defence Association, the Protestant paramilitaries blamed for the murder; Mr Finucane was shot dead in front of his wife and children at their home in 1989.

Nelson was jailed for 10 years for a series of offences, including conspiracy to murder and having information useful to terrorists. Charges of murdering two Catholics were withdrawn. He now lives at a secret address in England.

A spokesman for the Stevens inquiry declined to say if it had interviewed Nelson. But a security source said he had been questioned in London in January, and had been recently informed he would not be charged.

Paul O'Connor, coordinator for the Pat Finucane Centre, said last night: "It beggars belief that a decision like this could be made at this early stage, before the investigation is even complete."

One man has been charged with aiding and abetting in the Finucane murder, and is due to stand trial later this year. He is William Stobie from Belfast, an ex-UDA man and self-confessed former RUC special branch agent.

The Finucane family, who refuse to cooperate with the inquiry since they claim it is a whitewash, do not believe that an inquiry by Northern Ireland's new police ombudsman, Nuala O'Loan, will be able to uncover the entire story.

They want an independent, judicial inquiry on the lines of that in progress in Derry. They will meet US politicians and the issue will be raised at a congressional hearing today.

fields.headline: Killing revives loyalist feud
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Ulster Volunteer Force was blamed yesterday for the murder of a member of the Loyalist Volunteer Force.
fields.body:
The Ulster Volunteer Force was blamed yesterday for the murder of a member of the Loyalist Volunteer Force.

Adrian Porter, 34, was killed by two gunmen at his home in Conlig, Co Down. He was on bail on drugs charges. A 21-year-old friend, the subject of a recent death threat, was also shot but has been discharged from hospital.

A loyalist source said the murder could well have been revenge for a killing by the LVF in January last year: "This could spark more killings."

webTitle: News: Mandela statue proposed for Trafalgar

fields.headline: Plan to place Mandela in Trafalgar Square
fields.standfirst:
Ken Liveingstone supports proposals to erect a statue of Nelson mandela in Trafalgar Square

Special report: Livingstone's London

www.fourthplinth.com Trafalgar Square plinth
fields.trailText: The figure of a second Nelson could rise in Trafalgar Square.
fields.body:
The figure of a second Nelson could rise in Trafalgar Square.

It would be a little larger than life. But - unlike the Nelson already there - the figure of Nelson Mandela would "not be on so high a plinth as to be beyond the reach of people", its sculptor said yesterday.

The 9ft bronze statue of the first black South African president in full speech-making flow would stand close to South Africa House. This was the London storm centre for 40 years of anti-apartheid demonstrations and 28 years of public protests against Mr Mandela's imprisonment by those he gratefully called "the legion of freedom fighters in the darkest moments".

The man who will chiefly adjudicate on the planning permission for the £285,000 tribute is Ken Livingstone, mayor of London and a veteran of those demonstrations.

The project is unveiled today by an eight strong, all party committee of politicians and business leaders. They are Lord Attenborough, creator of the film Cry Freedom; the Conservative peers Lord Howe and Lady Chalker; the Labour peer Lord Haskins and the crossbencher and former SDP leader Lord Owen; the former Liberal leader Lord Steel; the businessman Richard Branson; and the veteran South African former campaigning newspaper editor Donald Woods, on whom a main character in Cry Freedom is based.

They say the statue, by the British sculptor Ian Walters, "will be a salute by the people of Britain to the liberated people of South Africa and will symbolise the special ties between the two countries".

The work will stand on a 6ft plinth. One of the two sites proposed for it would give Trafalgar Square a fifth plinth, in addition to the controversial "fourth plinth", which was left empty for 160 years and is now used for changing exhibitions of contemporary statuary.

A permanent Mandela statue was strongly proposed for this fourth plinth but it is regarded as too remote from South Africa House. So a site on the embassy side of the square is suggested. The alternative is a position on the wide pavement outside South Africa House often trampled by anti-apartheid protesters.

After fighting shy of the idea, Mr Mandela, who is 82, agreed to it during a visit to receive an honour in London last year. Mr Woods said: "He is a very modest fellow but I said to him 'You owe it to our history'."

While Mr Mandela was in prison, Ian Walters sculpted a bust of him from photographs for the Royal Festival Hall, London, to mark the African National Congress's 70th anniversary in 1982.

He re turned this month from his first chance to model the former president in the flesh, at his home at Kunu in the Transkei.

But it was a glimpse of Mr Mandela in action in Bedford that inspired the stance of Mr Walters's statue. Mr Mandela visited the town to speak and unveil an inscription on the sculptor's statue of the anti-apartheid pioneer Archbishop Trevor Huddleston, who was born in the town.

Walters said: "The whole of Bedford turned out for him. It was the most wonderful community occasion of my life.

"He raised his hands to make a point about the unity of peoples that is necessary for South Africa and the world. The expression on that serious, speaking face of his was quite different from the smile which is so much better known. It seemed the right moment to capture him."

fields.headline: £2m fund to sue Omagh bombers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Families of the 29 people killed by the 1998 Omagh car bomb launched an appeal for £2m yesterday to fund a civil suit against either the Real IRA or named individuals.
fields.body:
Families of the 29 people killed by the 1998 Omagh car bomb launched an appeal for £2m yesterday to fund a civil suit against either the Real IRA or named individuals.

At Westminster, former Northern Ireland secretaries Peter Mandelson, Tom King, Peter Brooke, Lord Hurd, Lord Prior and Lord Merlyn-Rees signed in support of the Omagh Victims' Legal Fund.

Police say they know who carried out the atrocity but lack evidence sufficient for a successful criminal prosecution. In a civil court, standards of proof are lower. The families need at least £1m by August to issue writs before the expiry of a three year deadline.

Victor Barker, whose son James, 12, was killed, said the campaign was not revenge but to enable members of the public to stand up against terrorism. A solicitor for the families said it had yet to be decided whether the suit for damages would be against named individuals or the Real IRA as a group.
Press Association

fields.headline: Action on flood defences urged
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Urgent action is needed to minimise the flooding risk to 2m homes as Britain faces the highest levels of rainfall since 1766, the national audit office warns today.
fields.body:
Urgent action is needed to minimise the flooding risk to 2m homes as Britain faces the highest levels of rainfall since 1766, the national audit office warns today.

The report says many flood defences need to be rebuilt and repaired, with those in the midlands, north-east and south-west of England requiring urgent attention.

Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, warned that changes in the climate and rainfall patterns over the next half century meant the flooding risk was expected to increase and the public should know who was responsible for defence measures.

Sir John said: "Changes in climate and rainfall patterns over the next 50 years are expected to lead to an increased risk of flooding. Many houses and businesses have been, and more are likely to be, built in the flood plains.

"It is essential that those people whose properties could be affected by flooding are aware of the dangers, that they know what to do in an emergency, and that they know who is responsible for defence measures."

The worst floods for centuries last autumn hit hundreds of properties in ancient cities such as York and Shrewsbury. In York, river levels rose higher than the previous record level, set in 1625.

The NAO said this demonstrated the serious consequences which flooding could have - 11,000 people were asked to evacuate their homes or businesses and 10,000 properties were flooded.

"When reviewing the lessons to be learned from the floods of late 2000, all agencies responsible for flood defences should consider whether the division of responsibility, and the way permissive powers operate, increase the risks of suffering flood damage for some people.

"They also need to do further work to explore whether the basis of categorisation, of main and non-main rivers, leads to inadequate and inconsistent levels of flood defence service."

The report highlights the complicated bureaucracy involved in handling flood defences. It involves coordinating 235 internal drainage boards, nine regional and 11 local defence committees, the Ministry of Agriculture and the environment agency.

David Davis, Tory chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said: "The environment agency must make it a high priority to determine where remedial work is required and to make sure it is carried out as speedily as possible."

fields.headline: Now, the future is Vodafone
fields.trailText: The vast majority of analysts do not give positive recommendations and outlandish target prices on Vodafone just because it is the world's most powerful mobile phone company.
fields.body:
The vast majority of analysts do not give positive recommendations and outlandish target prices on Vodafone just because it is the world's most powerful mobile phone company.

With telecom stocks around the world being shunned by investors yesterday, Vodafone emerged with a slender gain (up 3.25p to 202.25p) after revealing it is on target to meet the City's earnings forecasts.

The company also admitted that figures showing two-thirds of Britain's owned a handset might have been overstated.

Nevertheless, a jittery market was more interested in Vodafone's expectation of delivering "mobile proportionate [earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation] growth of 25% in this financial year" and "further significant progress" in 2002. Translated, this means Vodafone will meet its forecasts this year and is confident of repeating the trick next.

"Vodafone is confident about the future, something most other highly rated stocks are not," said Andrew Beale, telecoms analyst at Deutsche Bank. "That in itself is a cause for celebration in a very uncertain world."

In the wider market, the FTSE 100 settled 94.8 points lower at 5,625.9 after one of the most volatile sessions in recent history.

Leading shares opened higher on the back of a solid overnight performance from the Nasdaq but were down almost 250 points just before Wall Street reopened, unnerved by speculation that Japanese bank Daiwa had collapsed and a hedge fund had gone to the wall.

Senior traders noted gossip that a bulge bracket investment bank, said to be Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, was liquidating a £2bn equity portfolio for a hedge fund.

But, with the North American markets recovering some of their early losses and the effects of the portfolio sale wearing off, the blue-chip index clawed back some ground.

All of which could not disguise another dismal session for the London market. Over the past four sessions the FTSE 100 has lost 377.3 points and is now at a level last seen two years ago.

The FTSE Techmark eased 41.85 points to 2,136.58.

Vodafone aside, telecom stocks bore the brunt of yesterday's sell-off. The bears were still mauling Cable & Wireless , down 67p to 478p, after Tuesday's warning of falling revenues in its Japanese and North American operations. With C&W's troubles - primarily due to collapsing internet connectivity prices - out in the open, dealers were hunting for the next victim.

Although not directly exposed to North America or Japan, Colt Telecom was down 120p to 938p and Energis was off 48.5p to 325p, even after its chief executive said the company was trading in line with expectations.

The pain was not confined to the telecoms sector. Banking stocks, particularly those with exposure to the far east, were rocked by the Daiwa rumours and news that rating agency Fitch was concerned about the financial health of more than a dozen Japanese banks. HSBC and Standard Chartered , which make half of their profits in the far east, fell 43p to 822p and 27.5p to 833.5p respectively.

Defensive issues such as BAA , which added 3p to 662p, and BG Group , which gained 5.5p to 265.5p, were among the few stocks to register gains.

Investment bank Close Brothers dipped 50p to 887.5 after it emerged that Brian Winterflood, head of its market-making operation, Winterfloods, had exercised options to buy 20,000 shares and immediately sold them for 930p.

Monaco-based entrepreneur Stephen Tucker's Command Fund raised its stake in telematics firm Eagle Eye , perhaps impressed by strong figures from rival Trafficmaster. Command bought 136,800 shares at 66p to take its stake in Eagle Eye to 6.56%. The shares still slipped 1p to 65.5p.

fields.headline: Ericsson effect persists
fields.trailText: The fallout from Ericsson's profits warning on Monday is still being felt in London.
fields.body:
The fallout from Ericsson's profits warning on Monday is still being felt in London.

Filtronic, which makes semiconductors and supplies components for use in mobile phone base stations and handsets, fell 53.5p to 192.5p yesterday after ABN Amro lowered its rating in light of the problems at the Swedish company.

According to ABN analyst Toby Thorington, the evidence suggests that forecasts in Filtronic's three operating divisions are at risk. He says the gloomy news from Ericsson confirms the view that spending on telecoms infrastructure in Europe is slowing and forecasts for mobile phones sales being scaled back.

On the semiconductor business he notes recent profits warnings from other players in the sector.

Although he says Filtronic is trading in line with expectations, he thinks in the next fiscal year it will struggle to hit analysts' forecasts.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: When Labour ministers privatised medical testing for disability and incapacity benefits, they can hardly have imagined disgraced ex-CIA director John Deutsch would end up with responsibility for the UK's ill and injured. But that's what has happened.
fields.body:
 When Labour ministers privatised medical testing for disability and incapacity benefits, they can hardly have imagined disgraced ex-CIA director John Deutsch would end up with responsibility for the UK's ill and injured. But that's what has happened. The government handed the £305m disability contract to French IT firm Sema - which promptly went wobbly - and is set to be taken over by US oil services firm Schlumberger, which employs Deutsch as a board member. Sema is recommending the deal to shareholders because, at £5.60 a share, its money in the bag. But critics believe the present setup treats the disabled shoddily because the contract is "too lean". It seems doubtful that Schlumberger will fatten it up, having just cut 10,000 jobs. One job not under threat is that of Deutsch - best known for taking home his office computer when he retired from the CIA. It was later discovered the PC held a huge amount of secret data that was vulnerable to hackers whenever he used the net. Deutsch was prosecuted for his laxness but pardoned earlier this year, alongside Marc Rich, in Bill Clinton's presidential absolutions.

 There was a similar outbreak of laxness and leaking yesterday morning at the press conference where Tony Blair et al launched their exciting new plans to herd even more of the unemployed off benefits. Before the big announcement, the DfEE proudly handed out a release boasting of the fall in unemployed receiving benefits to 996,200 - below the magic 1m mark. Hats off? Yes, except that the press release was dished out at 9am, a full half hour before the super-secret numbers were officially published along the road by the office for national statistics. Given the ferocious secrecy that usually surrounds market sensitive figures such as these, knuckles should be rapped.

 And now a welcome return for our exciting regular feature, Dog of the Day, showing just how those City analysts earn their keep by providing wise and timely advice for clients. Today's DOTD winners are Stephane Beyazian and Jonathan Shantry, telecoms analysts at Credit Lyonnais Securities in London. On Monday, Steph and Jon put out a "buy" recommendation on Cable & Wireless. In the two days since, C&W's shares have fallen by 30%, or more than £2 a share. Woof, woof!

 It is now the law, thanks to the consumer information obligation regulation, that a retailer selling a product has to provide details on recycling any packaging that comes with it. But this has yet to filter down to retailers, according to a survey by Waste Connect. It rang 100 retailers to ask for simple recycling info. More than nine out of 10 had no clue, and the responses were most entertaining. "Why not go to a normal supermarket?" replied TK Maxx, the discount fashion chain. "Recycling? I don't know what you mean, dear," was Arcadia's honest response. But the best advice came from someone at the Granada Group: "If it was me I would crush it, and give it to the bin men to collect."

 It's well known that internet retailers are really in the shit these days. Just look at bookseller Amazon.com. Now online computer game seller Gameplay is literally in deep doo-doo after a sewerage pipe burst last week, flooding its London offices with effluent. The company says it is doing "e-business as usual", because the nuts and bolts of the operation are sited outside London.

 In a similar vein, hats off to Hong Kong jeweller Lam Sai-wing, who built two solid gold lavatories in the facilities at his jewellery showroom. The ceiling is decorated with jewels, and even the floor has 900-gram gold bars embedded in it. In all it cost £3.5m, for the exclusive use of customers spending £90 or more in the shop.

webTitle: Interbrew wins review of Bass case

fields.headline: Interbrew wins review of Bass case
fields.standfirst: Byers order to sell brewer will undergo court scrutiny
fields.trailText: Interbrew has cleared the first hurdle in its legal challenge to trade secretary Stephen Byers' order that it unwind its £2.3bn purchase of Bass.
fields.body:
Interbrew has cleared the first hurdle in its legal challenge to trade secretary Stephen Byers' order that it unwind its £2.3bn purchase of Bass.

At a high court hearing, the Belgian producer of Stella Artois has been given the green light to seek a judicial review of the controversial ruling, which has triggered a diplomatic row between Britain and Belgium.

News of the decision emerged as Interbrew announced a net loss for the year of €910m (£576m), hit by a €1.23bn write-off on the likely loss in re-selling Bass Brewers.

Interbrew's legal battle with the government will resume with a full hearing in May or June, with an outcome expected in July. The company said yesterday that because events are on hold until the court case it would need at least a year to complete the sale of Bass Brewers.

Chief executive Hugo Powell told reporters that the legal process made it "inconceivable" to sell Bass Brewers any faster: "The good news is, in any case, we have one year to dispose of Bass."

Excluding the effect of Bass, Interbrew's profits surged 43% to €1.08bn with strong growth of brands such as Stella Artois, Leffe and Hoegaarden.

A series of acquisitions has taken the group into new markets, adding to Interbrew's wide portfolio of local brands.

Spokesman Corneel Maes said: "This shows the success story of our strategy of being the world's local brewer. We use local brands as a platform to launch our international beers, like Stella, and specialist products, like Leffe."

The company announced a series of changes on its non-executive board, including the appointment of former Belgian prime minister Jean-Luc Dehaene as a non-executive.

The row over Bass Brewers has reached cabinet level in Belgium - the government has said it plans to take Britain to the European court in an attempt to overturn Mr Byers' ruling. Interbrew admits it has little hope of keeping Bass in its entirety. The business employs 7,000 people in Britain, making beers such as Carling, Tennent's and Worthington.

Interbrew hopes its legal battle will allow it to hold on to certain brands, and to be given greater freedom in selecting a buyer for the business. In Brussels, Interbrew's shares slipped 0.3% to end at €30.40.

 Morgan Grenfell Private Equity has been selected as the "preferred bidder" in the battle to buy Whitbread's 3,000 pubs and bars. The venture capital company has tabled a bid of around £1.6bn, squeezing out competitors such as Hugh Osmond's Punch Taverns. It was unclear last night whether Morgan Grenfell was still in partnership with the PizzaExpress entrepreneur, Luke Johnson.

Chief executive Hugo Powell told reporters that the legal process made it "inconceivable" to sell Bass Brewers any faster: "The good news is, in any case, we have one year to dispose of Bass." Excluding the effect of Bass, Interbrew's profits surged 43% to €1.08bn with strong growth of brands such as Stella Artois, Leffe and Hoegaarden. A series of acquisitions has taken the group into new markets, adding to Interbrew's wide portfolio of local brands. Spokesman Corneel Maes said: "This shows the success story of our strategy of being the world's local brewer. We use local brands as a platform to launch our international beers, like Stella, and specialist products, like Leffe." The company announced a series of changes on its non-executive board, including the appointment of former Belgian prime minister Jean-Luc Dehaene as a non-executive. Interbrew hopes its legal battle will allow it to hold on to certain brands, and to be given greater freedom in selecting a buyer for the business.
