The venture capital company has tabled a bid of around £1.6bn, squeezing out competitors such as Hugh Osmond's Punch Taverns. It was unclear last night whether Morgan Grenfell was still in partnership with the PizzaExpress entrepreneur, Luke Johnson.

fields.headline: Kingfisher loses high street war
fields.trailText: Retail group Kingfisher yesterday revealed a 16% drop in profits, caused mainly by poor performance at Superdrug and Woolworths, the two chains it is trying to offload.
fields.body:
Retail group Kingfisher yesterday revealed a 16% drop in profits, caused mainly by poor performance at Superdrug and Woolworths, the two chains it is trying to offload.

The group, which also includes Comet and B&Q in Britain and a range of electrical and DIY businesses on the continent, put out four profit warnings in the past seven months and its final figures - showing a £605.8m profit, compared with £720.6m a year earlier - were a shade ahead of expectations.

Woolworths' like-for-like sales, which exclude gains from new space, climbed by 1.8%, but the chain's profits slumped 25% from £121.9m to £91m as a result of tough price competition which has eroded margins. Its strongest sellers were mobile phones, toys and videos, where margins are lowest. "We had to take margin reductions to stabilise our market share," chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy said.

Superdrug's profits tumbled from £41.5m to £35m. The chain had a bad first half, as it ran short of key products and the supermarkets made further inroads into its main health and beauty business with tough price competition. But a new management team was installed and Sir Geoff said the chain had now achieved a "strong profits turnaround".

Kingfisher, which is Britain's biggest non-food retailer, is out of favour with investors who want Superdrug and Woolworths offloaded quickly and have grown increasingly suspicious about Kingfisher's lack of openness. The group's shares, which hit 927p two years ago, closed down 6.5p at 457.5p last night.

Kingfisher announced last September that it intended to demerge Superdrug and Woolworths, together with its entertainment businesses EUK, MVC and Streetsonline, as a separately listed "general merchandise" retailer. It has since received four bids for Superdrug, and is expected to announce a deal with the Dutch Kruidvat group shortly. It then became clear that listing Woolworths on its own, regarded as an unfocused ragbag business, could be a problem and the group started to explore a venture capital-backed buyout.

Kingfisher is now exploring both buyout and demerger possibilities, but yesterday Sir Geoff said he favoured a demerger: "It is still my favourite option and it is the one I think we will end up with". He put the odds at "60-40" in favour of demerger.

He also said that Kingfisher had decided to save cash by not taking up its option to buy the remaining 45% of its French offshoot Castorama and addressed shareholders' concerns about transparency.

Kingfisher is to start full quarterly reporting and put together a business model for analysts. The group also provided a target for average annual earnings growth of 10% -although analysts immediately said that looked unambitious. Sir Geoff said: "It is all very well to say it is unambi tious, but I would prefer to have an unambitious target and meet it than end up like Clive Thompson." Sir Clive Thompson, the chairman of Rentokil, set a 20% target and was punished when earnings fell short.

A stronger showing by DIY chain B&Q and electricals units Comet and Darty helped drive group sales 11.5% higher to £12.13bn. B&Q's profits rose 19% to £263m.

fields.headline: City welcomes Smiths demerger
fields.trailText: Smiths Group has abandoned the sale of its automotive arm and is planning a demerger. The engineering firm, which yesterday announced its first results since the takeover of TI Group, had been expected to earn around £900m from the sale of the car parts business.
fields.body:
Smiths Group has abandoned the sale of its automotive arm and is planning a demerger. The engineering firm, which yesterday announced its first results since the takeover of TI Group, had been expected to earn around £900m from the sale of the car parts business.

Instead Smiths will receive about £625m in cash from the demerger and continue to hold just under 20% of the business in preference shares, worth around £315m.

The automotive unit will become a stand-alone operation run by former TI Group chief executive Bill Laule. "We did not think the external bids valued the company so we are going to demerge it. We have a solid option here with what we are going to do," finance director Alan Thomson told Reuters.

"There are buyers - venture capitalists - who are saying what they think the business is worth but we do not think it values the business. They think they have us over a barrel by trying to get a cheap price and we have consistently said we will not do it," he said.

JP Morgan has been working with Smiths on options for the disposal since January.

Smiths reported pre-tax profits of £260m for the six months to January 31 - before merger costs - compared with £242m in 2000.

"We are on track to gain the benefits of lower overheads and improved profitability from the enlarged company," said chief executive Keith Butler-Wheelhouse. He expects savings of £80m by the middle of 2003 as a result of the TI takeover.

Turnover rose to £2.47bn for the six-month period from £2.16bn last time, and Smiths raised its interim dividend to 8.75p from 8.1p. The company's share price rose 30p to 690p on the announcement - the day's biggest gain on the FTSE.

webTitle: Notebook: More pain to come in this return to reality

fields.headline: More pain to come in this return to reality
fields.standfirst: Greenspan can only cut and hope
fields.trailText: The world's financial markets are starting to resemble Britain's stricken countryside. Despite all the words of reassurance, day by day the bad news comes rolling in. The sense of contagion, the feeling that things are starting to spiral out of control are taking hold in the public mind.
fields.body:
The world's financial markets are starting to resemble Britain's stricken countryside. Despite all the words of reassurance, day by day the bad news comes rolling in. The sense of contagion, the feeling that things are starting to spiral out of control are taking hold in the public mind.

Up goes the cry for the authorities to do something, anything, to put an end to the misery.

This is an understandable, if rather naive reaction. Investors and dealers want to believe that there is someone out there who really understands what is going on and can conjure up a magic spell that will stop share prices from falling.

But the idea that Alan Greenspan, let alone a market practitioner such as the now somewhat tarnished Abby Cohen of Goldman Sachs, has all the answers is pure moonshine.

Far from being in total control, Mr Greenspan is now painted into a corner. The markets are crashing but the real economy is not (yet) in recession. If he cuts rates to put a floor under Wall Street he runs the risk of pushing up inflation; if he delays too long in easing monetary policy he runs the risk of turning a severe slowdown into a prolonged recession.

The worst of all scenarios is that he cuts rates and then gets both a recession and higher inflation.

Before next week's meeting the Federal Reserve has to make up its mind whether it is focusing on the markets or the real economy. Recent history, the way in which the markets surged after Mr Greenspan bailed them out in the autumn of 1998, suggests that US rates should be cut only with caution. But this is not 1998. All of the evidence from the corporate sector is that activity and profits are being squeezed by falling demand; investors are belatedly realising that the valuations put on shares a year or two ago were utterly without foundation. Nothing that Mr Greenspan does in the US, or the Bank of England does here, can prevent reality from returning to global equity markets. Share prices were ridiculously overvalued, now they are simply overvalued.

They can seek to mitigate the impact that crashing share prices will have on the real economy by cutting interest rates quickly and aggressively - starting with a full percentage point off US rates next week.

Split opinions

No news is bad news as far as Kingfisher is concerned. Shareholders and analysts want some action on the separation of Superdrug and Woolworths from the rest of the Kingfisher DIY and electrical goods empire, and the shares are unlikely to move much until then.

They should not, however, hold their breath for a jolly outcome on the prices achieved.

The group's talks with Dutch group Kruidvat over the sale of Superdrug do appear to be dragging on - and that never bodes well for the eventual price achieved.

Meanwhile, the struggle goes on to convert the wonder of Woolies into hard cash. Will it demerge or will it be bought by venture capitalists?

Chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy cannot see the problem with a separate listing and insists it is still his favoured option. Last year Woolworths made £91m, he points out, just about the same as John Lewis, and everyone reckons John Lewis could easily float. But it is hard to see Woolworths as a separately quoted company in the current climate.

John Lewis is regarded as a prestige business, while Woolworths is a store that no self-respecting City analyst would be seen dead in and is largely viewed as a ragbag, unfocused chain which does not know its target audience.

But it is still a family favourite, a source of cheap toys on the high street and still the country's biggest seller of CDs and videos. It produces stable cash flow and that will appeal to a financial or trade buyer - but they are the toughest of price negotiators.

Either way, the two chains are unlikely to fetch more than about £900m between them.

The City's finest are split on the outlook for the group, which still commands a premium price-to-earnings ratio. Recommendations range from buy to straight sell.

It is worth remembering that Sir Geoff is not the sort of retailer the City likes these days. He is not a slick serial retailer, he is not a maverick and his idea of a luxury brand is a B&Q warehouse. He is pushing 60 and has been at Kingfisher since Adam was a lad - 20 years, anyway.

But the profits dives at Superdrug and Woolworths reported yesterday show his strategy is right. His decision not to buy the remaining 45% of Castorama in July is also to be applauded.

Even if Superdrug and Woolies do bring in less than £1bn, the sum of the parts equates to a share price up to 100p ahead of current levels, not least because the remaining DIY and electricals business could be a bid target.

fields.headline: Ciro Citterio calls in administrators
fields.trailText: Ciro Citterio, the high street men's fashion chain, last night collapsed into administration with debts of more than £30m.
fields.body:
Ciro Citterio, the high street men's fashion chain, last night collapsed into administration with debts of more than £30m.

The group, which employs 1,750 staff and has 160 stores across Britain and the Irish republic, was put into administration by the high court to be "rationalised and restructured" because of cash flow problems caused by a shareholder dispute.

Administrators Gurpal Johal and Simon Freakley of Kroll Buchler Phillips said 27 unprofitable stores would be closed immediately but trading would continue as usual at the other stores for the time being.

Mr Johal said it was too early to say if jobs would be lost but staff would be given the opportunity to relocate to other shops where possible.

The chain, owned by the Thakrar family, will be ring-fenced from claims by creditors, including £6.9m recently awarded to Kirit Thakrar after a dispute over the valuation of Mr Thakrar's interest in the company.

As a result of the judgment some suppliers have reduced or withdrawn their credit limits for the group.

Ciro Citterio, based in Birmingham, has grown rapidly over the past few years after it acquired Dunn & Co, Horne Brothers, Oakland and the Sweater Shop.

In the past the group has had high-profile sponsorship arrangements with cricket and football clubs, including Aston Villa and Nottingham Forest.

Peter Booth, national official for the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "We are obviously concerned by this turn of events. We will be seeking an urgent meeting to discuss the future of the business and our members."

fields.headline: Fund boasts ring hollow
fields.trailText: It is not just City dealers who are victims of the market sell-off; millions of small investors are suffering falling returns.
fields.body:
It is not just City dealers who are victims of the market sell-off; millions of small investors are suffering falling returns.

Isas

A year ago, investment manager Framlington 's advertisements proclaimed the success of its NetNet technology fund: "Get plugged in. Plus 106% in nine months."

Anyone who plugged a £7,000 Isa allowance into Framlington NetNet last March - and thousands did -will have seen that stake shrivel to under £1,700 after yesterday's downward lurch in tech stocks. The £150m NetNet fund is bottom of the table of Britain's 1,950 unit trusts.

Fund managers traditionally haul billions of pounds into Isas ahead of the April 4 tax year end. A spokeswoman for the Association of Unit Trusts said yesterday that the industry expected Isa sales this year to fall by about a third.

In all, £8.5bn poured into technology funds in February and March last year, much of it into Isas offered by Aberdeen, Henderson, SocGen and Jupiter. Since then the value of each of their tech funds has dropped by more than 50%.

Unit trusts

More than £260bn is held in unit trusts through 17m accounts in Britain, and the funds are suffering across-the-board declines. About £34bn is invested in European unit trusts, which are on average 17% down over the year, while the £7bn invested in Japan trusts is down 32%. The average North American fund has fallen by a tenth in the past month, according to Standard & Poor's figures.

Endowments

Already 3m of the 10m endowments in Britain are at risk of failing to pay off home loans and that total will rise as markets fall.

With-profits bonds

These products, sold by big insurers such as Prudential and Norwich Union, promised annual income of up to 8% plus return of capital. More than £25bn was invested over the past two years by just under 1m savers. The schemes contain a "market value adjuster", allowing the insurer to cut returns during exceptional market conditions. It may be invoked if the market continues to slide.

Pensions

Bad luck for anyone retiring this week on a money purchase plan. They are based on stock market values, so this year's pensioners could be 10% worse off than last year's. One solace: higher gilt and bond prices should boost annuity rates.

fields.headline: Festival gets the green light
fields.standfirst: Cheltenham faces Craven competition but avoids Irish clash
fields.trailText: Cheltenham faces Craven competition but avoids Irish clash.
fields.body:
Cheltenham remained positive that a rescheduled Festival would go ahead when the new dates - April 17-19 - were announced yesterday.

The meeting is due to start the day after Easter Monday, the same as the Newmarket Craven fixture, but the alternative was a clash with the Punchestown Festival in Ireland the following week.

There has been no racing in Ireland since February 25 due to the outbreak of foot and mouth in Britain, but yesterday the Irish Horseracing Authority indicated there could be a resumption at Easter.

The Cheltenham Festival was postponed last Wednesday when it was discovered the course could not meet British Horseracing Board guidelines governing racing during the foot and mouth crisis.

"We are convinced that we can safely conduct a successful race meeting. So long as racing continues and the racecourse remains outside an infected area, we should make every effort to proceed," said Cheltenham managing director Edward Gillespie.

On a day when 17 new cases of foot and mouth were confirmed, Gillespie added: "At the moment there are no new cases in Gloucester, but we are very aware of the significant chance of a local outbreak."

In the event of the Festival being abandoned, alternative openings will try to be found for the 10 championship races. "We are looking at possible locations, but opportunities are few," said Gillespie.

A deadline for the reopened races at the Festival has yet to be set. But tickets will be valid for the same days of the week and ticket holders will get a full refund if unable to attend.

To accomodate Channel 4 coverage of both meetings, Newmarket have brought their start times forward to 1.15 from 2.05 on all three days. Channel 4 will screen live races at 1.15 and 1.45 from Newmarket each day, with the third race incorporated into the four live events from Cheltenham.

There was some concern from Aintree that the timing of the rescheduled Festival was not ideal. "From our point of view it is not handy that Cheltenham will start just 10 days after the Grand National," said Aintree managing director Charles Barnett.

The new dates were welcomed by leading trainers at Huntingdon yesterday. Henriitta Knight, successful with Celtic Season, said: "I am delighted it is going to take place - touch wood. Former champion jump jockey Terry Biddlecombe, Knight's husband and assistant, said: "The new fixture is a very good move, taking all things into consideration. They have had to fight to keep the meeting, and rightly so, because it is part of racing's heritage."

Venetia Williams was another trainer to greet news of the reallocation with enthusiasm and after her Montalcino made an eight-length winning debut in the first division of the maiden hurdle, he could well end up going to the Festival.

Williams said: "Now every one is in the same boat and everyone has to overcome the same problems. The scientists and vets have gone into it in great detail and I will go along with what they say."

They are: Lingfield, all-weather, on Monday, an all-chase card at Warwick the following day and Huntingdon and Southwell (all-weather) on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Wool pulls one over the hi-tech boomers
fields.standfirst: Huntingdon Life Sciences hold title of Britain's best performing stock
fields.trailText: They are the stock tips of the year. Sell tech. Buy animal labs, woollen mills, diamonds and sewing machine parts.
fields.body:
They are the stock tips of the year. Sell tech. Buy animal labs, woollen mills, diamonds and sewing machine parts.

That appears to be the lessons for investors as technology and dot.com stocks crash.

As the markets opened for trading yesterday Huntingdon Life Sciences, the animal testing firm, was the unlikely holder of the title of Britain's best performing stock. Its shares have climbed 211% since January 1.

The ranking will cause dismay among animal rights activists. However, they will be able to take solace in the fact that Huntingdon's finances remain troubled and the price rise began from a very low base.

Of more interest to investors will be the performance of companies like woollen fabric maker Drummond Group, Conroy Diamonds and Gold, and sewing machine parts maker Bogod Group.

Shares in all three "old economy" firms have more than doubled since the start of the year and dominate a list of best performers which 12 months ago was the exclusive domain of technology related firms.

Drummond Group, which has been weaving wool from the same mill at Lumb Lane in Bradford since 1856, has seen its shares climb by 111%.

At the other end of the table Claims Direct is the leading laggard. It has fallen 90% since the start of this year following a series of heavily publicised disputes with customers over personal injury claims.

Other well known members of the 10 worst performing shares group include former technology favourites InterX, Future Internet, SCI Entertainment and Brainspark.

The figures give added credence to the words of legendary American investor Warren Buffett who said at the weekend: "I will tell you now that we have embraced the 21st century by entering such cutting edge industries as brick, carpet, insulation and paint."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Coke modifies schools role
fields.body:
Coke modifies schools role

Coca-Cola, under fire for its aggressive marketing of soft drinks to children, said yesterday it would begin selling juices, water and other healthy drinks to students.

The world's biggest soft drink maker also said it would try to reduce its commercial presence in schools by covering up company logos and ending exclusivity contracts.

Challenge to Nationwide

Nationwide building society came under renewed pressure yesterday to convert to a bank and pay windfalls to its 10m savers and borrowers. Rebel member Andrew Muir has tabled a resolution which, if it wins sufficient support by April 3, will force the society to hold a ballot on whether to convert and pay windfalls that Mr Muir claims could average £700-£1,000.

Anglo reports record profits

Mining group Anglo American reported record annual profits yesterday and put a brave face on the US slowdown, but its shares fell as the entire market took a turn for the worse.

Anglo which is leading a bid for diamond producer De Beers, showed a 53% surge in net profits to $2bn (£1.4bn) for the calendar year 2000.

The result was in the middle of a range of analysts' forecasts, but Anglo American's shares were caught up in the wider market malaise, and fell 4.1% to £43.95 by the close in London.

Core profits up 44% at Thales

French defence and industrial electronics group Thales said yesterday that 2000 core profit had risen a better than expected 44% to €561m (£354.7m) and set new targets for integrating the Racal business it bought last year.

Net profit declined by a smaller than anticipated 27% to €201m. That drop was mainly due to significant exceptional gains in 1999 which boosted the bottom line by €162m.

Celltech raises US presence

Celltech plans to increase its US sales force from 180 to 400, in order to sell a once-a-day version of its attention deficit disorder drug, methylphenidate.

The biotechnology firm announced the move following a 25% increase in full-year profits to £25.1m, excluding restructuring costs of £19.2m.

fields.headline: Markets gyrate in panic
fields.standfirst: Japanese bank fears, a McDonald's profits warning - even Cheney admits concern
fields.trailText: Fevered speculation relating to bank collapses in panic stricken global markets and troubled times at leading companies in Europe and the United States sent share prices tumbling around the world's financial centres yesterday.
fields.body:
Fevered speculation relating to bank collapses in panic stricken global markets and troubled times at leading companies in Europe and the United States sent share prices tumbling around the world's financial centres yesterday.

As the recent slide in stock markets threatened to turn into a rout, banking stocks led Europe's bourses lower amid rumours that Daiwa, one of Japan's leading banks, was about to go bankrupt.

The universally gloomy mood was compounded by news that international rating agency Fitch has placed 19 Japanese banks under review because of their exposure to falling shares prices on the Tokyo stock market.

Amid a profits warnings from the fast food group, McDonald's, the Dow Jones industrial average opened the day sharply lower, breaking below the 10,000-point level for the first time since last October. It closed down 317.34 points at 9,973.46.

Prices then gyrated - but attempts by bargain hunters to move the market higher ran into renewed selling pressure on fears that the American economy faces a serious downturn even if the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, cuts interest rates as expected next week.

The Dow Jones bore the brunt of the selling pressure with the Nasdaq composite index having fallen just under 50 points to close below the 2,000-point level at 1,972.07.

In London, the FTSE 100 index fell 94.8 points to 5,625.9.

At one point during the early afternoon the blue-chip index, depressed by falling telecommunications and banking stocks, was down almost 250 points, its lowest level for more than 27 months.

London's main index has fallen almost 380 points during the past four trading sessions.

The partial recovery in London was based around a brief rally in New York which was later reversed on rumours that PC manufacturer Compaq would become the latest high profile new economy company to issue a profits warning.

Chip manufacturer Intel added to the gloom when it revealed that it had scaled down a huge extension programme at its plant in Dublin.

French and German bourses were also caught up in the turmoil, with Germany's Dax index falling 3% and France's CAC 40 drifting 1.4% lower.

Telecommunications stocks were again among the biggest losers in Europe, as the sector continued to reel from Tuesday's earnings warning from Cable & Wireless.

The decline forced rival business telecommunications operator Energis to say the 17% plunge in its share price yesterday was unwarranted, and that it continued to trade in line with expectations.

Banking stocks were also under fire amid concern that they would be exposed to the problems facing the Japanese banking industry, which is highly vulnerable to the relentless decline by the Nikkei 225 index, which has fallen now below the 12,000 level. Most Japanese banks include hefty share portfolios as part of their capital base.

HSBC and Standard Chartered, both of which make a substantial amount of their profits in the far east, were among the worst affected shares in London because of these fears - falling 5% and 3% respectively.

Yesterday's falls prompted US vice-president Dick Cheney to say he was watching American financial markets with "some concern".

Speaking to CBS Radio News, Mr Cheney rejected the notion that President George Bush's administration has talked down the economy but said that "we had cautioned that _ the possibility existed that we could be on the front edge of a slowdown that's now occurred".

With few traders willing to speculate on when share prices would stabilise, attention has now started to focus on Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Reserve's open market committee, which sets interest rates in the US. A 50 basis-points reduction in rates is widely anticipated.

"Volatility is the name of the game at the moment. We are not out of the woods yet; hopefully we are somewhere near the bottom," one senior trader in London commented.

fields.headline: Hard landing
fields.trailText: As head of training at a flying school in Bedfordshire, Mike Dyson is used to soaring, nose-diving and hard landings. Unfortunately his investment club's performance has gone the same way.
fields.body:
As head of training at a flying school in Bedfordshire, Mike Dyson is used to soaring, nose-diving and hard landings. Unfortunately his investment club's performance has gone the same way.

Mr Dyson is chairman of the "Flyboys" club - 16 instructors at the Cabair Flying School in Cranfield - which meets every month to decide what stocks to invest in. Started three years ago, they have invested £15,000, but yesterday it was worth £7,250.

"We bought lots of speculative telecom stocks and made some pretty enormous losses. The falls have been so steep that they're just not worth selling," he said.

Current markets are the first true test for most of Britain's 9,000 investment clubs, which have grown from just 300 clubs four years ago.

Mr Dyson is sanguine about the stock falls, and said yesterday that the club will in future focus on "undervalued blue chips".

webTitle: Pass notes No 1839: Hans Werner Henze

fields.headline: Pass notes No 1839
fields.standfirst: Hans Werner Henze
fields.trailText: Hans Werner Henze
fields.body:
Age: 75 in July.

Happy birthday, Hans: Indeed. The Royal Opera House is marking the occasion by putting on one of his early operas, starting next Tuesday.

Marvellous. What's it called? Boulevard Solitude.

Oh yes, the one he wrote with Andrew Lloyd Webber. Er, no, you're thinking of Sunset Boulevard.

Well, I'd like to see it anyway. Any problem getting tickets? How many thousand do you want?

It's not proving popular? Covent Garden has only sold 30% of the tickets for the six scheduled performances, and is now giving them away to opera-loving celebs such as Esther Rantzen and Joanna Lumley.

Why not Anthea Turner? Her taste is for Gregorian chant, apparently.

What's the problem with Henze? Modern, German, fondness for atonal music. Is that enough?

I think I'll stay in and wash my hair. Then you'll miss the free oysters and champagne Covent Garden is offering punters brave enough to book.

What's the opera about? Sex, drugs, death - the usual stuff. It's a reworking of Manon Lescaut.

Sounds great. Unfortunately for Henze, Puccini and Massenet got in first with tune-filled versions..

Poor Hans. He must be terribly depressed. Unlikely. As a left-wing gay man who has spent a lifetime of self-imposed exile in Italy trying to come to terms with his father's role in the Nazi party, he has had more pressing concerns than the Covent Garden audience's inability to stomach anything more challenging than Tosca.

Not to be confused with: Karlheinz Stockhausen.

Do say: "It's only 75 minutes long. What a shame they didn't do König Hirsch. In the original five-hour version, of course."

Don't say: "Couldn't we go to Pavarotti in the Park instead?"

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Prepare to leave the planet | How to badger your beer gut
fields.body:
Prepare to leave the planet
National Science Week - that frenzy of 6,600 events which last year drew 1.5m visitors - begins tomorrow. Mo Afzal, who directs science at Kings School, Canterbury, has students who for two years running have taken first prize at the Science Youth Fair. For two consecutive years he has a pupil doing a month at the Weizmann Institute in Israel. So he had to think of something big for next week as well. On March 23, Kings and other schools at Canterbury are staging a major conference on the challenges for science, addressed by stars such as physicist Sir Roger Penrose of Oxford and astrophysicist Sir Martin Rees of Cambridge. "We are going to vacate our planet ultimately and the biggest discoveries are in astrophysics and astrobiology," he says. "Martin Rees is the world authority. Roger Penrose is one of the biggest authorities on general relativity and quantum physics and one of the things we are working on is quantum teleportation."

How to badger your beer gut
Other potential entertainments include badger watching in Devon, following an ale trail in Bury St Edmunds, pursuing the physics of ice cream in Gloucester or recycling chip fat in Glasgow. People with digestive disorders in Scotland can ring the Gut Line, while people in Yorkshire can spend Mother's Day - March 25 - testing Egyptian cosmetics during a Mummy's Day. Liverpudlians will be able to "see" the sound of Scouse at the Liverpool Museum. Men and maids of Kent will be able to reconstruct the faces of ancestors at the Royal Museum. Most of the details are available at www.nationalscienceweek.org.uk.

Oxford is kind to eccentrics...
Says Susan Greenfield interviewed by the Reader's Digest this month. Author of seven books on the brain, she does not even have a science O level. She took up science as a postgraduate. And, she says, it is important for girls to know that scientists are not necessarily men in grey suits.

fields.headline: Thanks for the memory
fields.standfirst: Experiments have backed what was once a scientific 'heresy', says  Lionel Milgrom
fields.trailText: Experiments have backed what was once a scientific 'heresy', says Lionel Milgrom
fields.body:
A bout homeopathy, Professor Madeleine Ennis of Queen's University Belfast is, like most scientists, deeply sceptical. That a medicinal compound diluted out of existence should still exert a therapeutic effect is an affront to conventional biochemistry and pharmacology, based as they are on direct and palpable molecular events. The same goes for a possible explanation of how homoeopathy works: that water somehow retains a "memory" of things once dissolved in it.

This last notion, famously promoted by French biologist Dr Jacques Benveniste, cost him his laboratories, his funding, and ultimately his international scientific credibility. However, it did not deter Professor Ennis who, being a scientist, was not afraid to try to prove Benveniste wrong. So, more than a decade after Benveniste's excommunication from the scientific mainstream, she jumped at the chance to join a large pan-European research team, hoping finally to lay the Benveniste "heresy" to rest. But she was in for a shock: for the team's latest results controversially now suggest that Benveniste might have been right all along.

Back in 1985, Benveniste began experimenting with human white blood cells involved in allergic reactions, called basophils. These possess tiny granules containing substances such as histamine, partly responsible for the allergic response. The granules can be stained with a special dye, but they can be decolourised (degranulated) by a substance called anti-immunoglobulin E or aIgE. That much is standard science. What Benveniste claimed so controversially was that he continued to observe basophil degranulation even when the aIgE had been diluted out of existence, but only as long as each dilution step, as with the preparation of homoeopathic remedies, was accompanied by strong agitation.

After many experiments, in 1988 Benveniste managed to get an account of his work published in Nature, speculating that the water used in the experiments must have retained a "memory" of the original dissolved aIgE. Homoeopaths rejoiced, convinced that here at last was the hard evidence they needed to make homoeopathy scientifically respectable. Celebration was short-lived. Spearheaded by a Nature team that famously included a magician (who could find no fault with Benveniste's methods - only his results), Benveniste was pilloried by the scientific establishment.

A British attempt (by scientists at London's University College, published in Nature in 1993) to reproduce Benveniste's findings failed. Benveniste has been striving ever since to get other independent laboratories to repeat his work, claiming that negative findings like those of the British team were the result of misunderstandings of his experimental protocols. Enter Professor Ennis and the pan-European research effort.

A consortium of four independent research laboratories in France, Italy, Belgium, and Holland, led by Professor M Roberfroid at Belgium's Catholic University of Louvain in Brussels, used a refinement of Benveniste's original experiment that examined another aspect of basophil activation. The team knew that activation of basophil degranulation by aIgE leads to powerful mediators being released, including large amounts of histamine, which sets up a negative feedback cycle that curbs its own release. So the experiment the pan-European team planned involved comparing inhibition of basophil aIgE-induced degranulation with "ghost" dilutions of histamine against control solutions of pure water.

In order to make sure no bias was introduced into the experiment by the scientists from the four laboratories involved, they were all "blinded" to the contents of their test solutions. In other words, they did not know whether the solutions they were adding to the basophil-aIgE reaction contained ghost amounts of histamine or just pure water. But that's not all. webTitle: Light at the end of the barrel

fields.headline: Light at the end of the barrel
fields.standfirst: David Hambling  reports on why the military is planning a bright new career for the laser death ray
fields.trailText: David Hambling reports on why the military is planning a bright new career : At the end of the barrel
fields.body:
George Bush's National Missile Defence system loses credibility every time the interceptor missiles fail during tests. But away from the publicity lasers have been making steady progress. Lasers have been destroying test targets for 30 years, but an operational system has always been elusive. Recent advances mean they will soon be fielded, bringing Star Wars right down to earth.

The military already use lasers for guidance, such as the laser rangefinder in the Challenger tank and the designators used to mark targets for laser-guided bombs. Even sniper rifles can have laser sights. They are useful because it is easy to put a dot of light on a target - whether the following shell, bomb or bullet hits the same point is another matter. If the laser itself was the weapon a hit would be guaranteed. The challenge is to build a laser powerful enough to do the job.

You cannot simply scale up small lasers. Diode lasers such as those used in CD players and barcode scanners only work at low power levels. Gas lasers used in medicine and scientific research are inefficient, converting a small percentage of the power input to laser light and dissipating the rest as waste heat. This is fine if the power level is only a few watts, but impractical for a high-powered weapon. The power consumption would be prohibitive and the laser platform would have to absorb far more heat than the target.

Military research has concentrated instead on chemical lasers. The largest system in prospect is the Airborne Laser, a modified Boeing 747 with six chemical oxygen iodine lasers (Coil). The Coil reacts hydrogen peroxide and potassium hydroxide - better known as hair bleach and drain cleaner - with chlorine to produce oxygen molecules in a high energy state. Iodine is added to take up this energy and emit it as laser light. The output from the six lasers is combined into a single beam powerful enough to destroy a ballistic missile hundreds of kilometres away - in theory.

The Airborne Laser will not undergo live firing until 2003, but a fleet of eight are already scheduled to be built starting in 2004.

There is also the tactical high-energy laser (THEL), a joint US-Israeli development to defend against much smaller missiles. The Lebanese border is often used for rocket attacks on Israel. The rockets are Russian-made Katyushas, originally designed to be fired in salvoes from a launcher mounted on a truck. They are small enough to be man-handled by a single guerrilla and fired from a launch rail improvised from a plank. The Katyusha is barely accurate enough to hit a target the size of a village, but it makes an effective terror weapon, dropping high-explosive warhead up to 20km away. When several are fired together victims have no chance to take cover from the bombardment.

The heart of the THEL is a deuterium fluoride laser, reacting heavy hydrogen (deuterium) and fluorine gas together. Hydrogen is notoriously explosive and fluorine is poisonous, and the product, hydrogen fluoride, is highly corrosive. The reaction is energetic enough to produce a laser of useful power. Last June the THEL detected, engaged and destroyed a Katyusha rocket in a test firing. In September the feat was repeated, this time with a salvo of two Katyushas. The THEL currently occupies several trail ers, and the next stage will be a single mobile unit, capable of defending a wide area.

Each type of chemical laser emits light of a characteristic wavelength. The Coil's beam is transmitted more effectively in the upper atmosphere, while the THEL works better at sea level. The wavelength also affects how much laser energy is absorbed by the target. A missile painted white may absorb 90% of laser using visible wavelengths, but a shiny aluminium finish is more reflective and will only absorb 2%. An infrared laser has more effect against aluminium (about 35% absorption), but can be reflected by other surfaces. Potential enemies could give their ballistic missiles a coating to reflect the Coil's 1.3 micron laser, and protect Katyushas against the THEL's 3.8 micron beam.

The ideal military laser could be tuned to different frequencies according to the target and atmospheric conditions. It would also dispense with the hair bleach, drain cleaner and other inconvenient and expensive chemicals. The free electron laser (FEL) has this capability. In the FEL, electrons are fired into a vacuum, much like a the tube of a television. Unlike a television, the electrons pass through a magnetic array called a wiggler. This causes the electrons to wiggle and emit laser light. Changing the energy of the input and the frequency of the wiggler alters the wavelength of the laser as desired.

So far, all the FELs built have been huge, immobile installations. However, the electron source has now been shrunk from the size of a caravan to a microwave oven. The wiggler's giant electromagnets are being replaced with small superconducting magnets. This should eventually result in a laser small enough for Luke Skywalker to carry - but he would still need a thermos of liquid nitrogen to cool the superconductors, and of course an extension lead for the power supply.

Some platforms have a power supply built into them. Advocates of the next-generation Joint Strike Fighter, in which British Aerospace is a partner, have pointed out that it would be possible to draw several hundred kilowatts of power direct from the jet engine.

By replacing some of the bomb load with a laser, the JSF could become what has been called a "fotofighter". The laser would be comparatively low powered, but still capable of burning out any surface-to-air missiles before they got close. This would make the fotofighter virtually immune to ground fire. Air-to-air missiles would be equally useless, and any attempt to get close enough to engage it with cannon or machine guns would be suicidal. The only way of stopping it would be another laser.

There is no real need for a fotofighter to be small and agile like the JSF. A laser weapon can easily provide 360 coverage, so a fotofighter would never have to engage in dogfights. And it might not be limited to aerial targets.

This brings us to the US Advanced Concept Technology Demonstration programme, which includes a laser mounted on a helicopter or aircraft. The project will focus on "the feasibility of using laser weapons for military or law enforcement operations in an urban environment". Laser weapons can be used with literally surgical precision, but it is still a strange choice for a police operation. Armoured vehicles and buildings are not practical targets for laser weapons. However, exposed human skin is much more vulnerable. A high-energy laser would frazzle humans the way a magnifying glass can kill ants. Instantaneous heating could cause flesh to explode with steam.

Unlike Star Trek phasers, these lasers cannot be set on stun. As Dr McCoy might have said to Captain Kirk, "It's law enforcement Jim, but not as we know it."

fields.headline: Let me entertain you...
fields.standfirst: Next week is Science Week. Every week should be a science week, says  Susan Greenfield
fields.trailText: Next week is Science Week. Every week should be a science week, says Susan Greenfield
fields.body:
The idea of public understanding of science is not new. As far back as the founding of the Royal Institution, its basic principles were to "diffuse science for the common purposes of life".

Throughout the 19th century, lecture demonstrations were held at the Royal Institution. They proved so popular that Albemarle Street, where the institute is situated, became the first one-way street in London due to congestion of the carriages.

Starting with schoolboys at the Festival of Britain, the second half of the 20th century saw science reach a far wider generation of young people, who visited not just science museums, but also science centres. We now have a chattering class avidly lapping up broadsheet science, tuning in to Tomorrow's World, Horizon and, on the radio, the weekly science slot.

Books proliferate to meet the hunger for science. Indeed, the thrill of reading a science book in the 20th century is analogous to that of reading travel books in the 19th century: the author takes you where, as an "ordinary" person, you cannot go yourself. Science sessions have started to appear at book festivals and usually end up with standing room only.

The picture, as I paint it here, seems rosy: there is a need for the public to understand science, and books and the media are rising to meet this need.

But, of course, it is not quite a simple as that. First, we, in the science community, should actually have it clear what we are trying to do. The phrase "public understanding" is itself both patronising and misleading. It is not as if there are clear cut scientific facts that are just handed down to a somehow less intellectually able public. One of our most important jobs is to show what science can and cannot deliver - to explain why scientists disagree, how findings become established through the process of peer-reviewed journals, to rephrase the importance of controls and reproducibility and, above all, the uncertainty from single one-off findings.

We could convey the scientific way of thinking, perhaps through science-in-fiction, plays and stories, as well as through straightforward discussions. We will not solve the concern and anxiety of the new science and technology advances, but rather create an environment where breakthroughs, and problems, can be best understood.

This was highlighted in a recent Mori poll on public attitudes to animal experimentation. There was a huge difference, swinging in favour of animal experiments, once the pros and cons had been fully explained. Similarly, the current controversy concerning GM foods hinges on a logic which works the oppo site way to that of mobile phones. GM foods are subjected to the precautionary principle, whereby they should not be consumed until it has been proven that they do you no harm. By contrast, mobile phones still have high sales, based on the idea that no one has actually proved them to be dangerous.

We should be creating, then, a landscape of scientific literacy, where the full spectrum of often conflicting scientific views can be represented, digested, and debated. But more than that we need, now that people are empowered with information, to give them the chance to participate in the debate. We need far more fora and media by which the public and scientists can interact.

Of course, this is top of my own agenda at the Royal Institution, but not everyone can make their way to London easily and, although we have plans for a "virtual" Royal Institution once we have funds, clearly we cannot, even in our wildest dreams, think that we alone can satisfy the need. That is why we need local institutions such as universities to open their doors to the public, funded possibly by the Department of Culture, Media and Sport.

W e also need to coordinate far more than we have. There is now a far broader church of science centres, as well as science museums, special interest groups, and learned institutions - all of which are increasingly meshing science with society, and Copus (Committee on Public Understanding of Science) is now being reinvented to just this end.

All of us need to retain our autonomy, but must ensure that we are not duplicating effort and leaving other areas of debate unidentified. Above all, we need to identify what we mean by "the public".

In my experience, now two years into my directorship at the Royal Institution, the public does not exist as a monolithic entity. We need to devise ways of meeting different people's needs, interests, and agendas, with different levels of information required. We also need to cater for different moods of individuals, as well as their different ages.

My ultimate dream is that by the end of the century, this kind of article will not be needed. When our grandchildren and great-grandchildren decide where to go for an evening out, are just as likely to visit a scientific discussion as they are a concert or the cinema. Science should not only be interesting and fulfilling for the individual, but should also for make society a truly worthwhile place to live.

 Professor Susan Greenfield is director of the Royal Institution. Her book The Private Life Of The Brain is published next week by Penguin (£5.99)

webTitle: Business: bank ready to counter market turmoil

fields.headline: Bank ready to cut base rates as counter to turmoil on markets
fields.standfirst: <A HREF="http://www.guardian.co.uk/theissues/article/0,6512,135353,00.html">The issue explained: setting Britain's interest rates
fields.trailText: The Bank of England is standing ready to combat the effect of tumbling global share prices on the UK economy by cutting interest rates, the bank's director responsible for monitoring financial markets said yesterday.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott, Jill Treanor and Neil Hume
fields.body:
The Bank of England is standing ready to combat the effect of tumbling global share prices on the UK economy by cutting interest rates, the bank's director responsible for monitoring financial markets said yesterday.

As stock markets in London, New York, Paris and Frankfurt resumed their downward slide, Ian Plenderleith, a member of the bank's nine-strong monetary policy committee (MPC) said there was a significant risk that the end of the long boom in the United States could have a "material dampening effect on UK activity. That would, of course, be grounds for us to contemplate further easing in our monetary stance."

Mr Plenderleith's remarks came as George Bush and his vice-president, Dick Cheney, expressed concern about the effect on the US economy of the relentless slide in US share prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average had lost more than 300 points by lunchtime in New York yesterday to stand below 10,000 points, while the continued woes of the high technology sector pushed the Nasdaq index below 2000, 60% down on its peak of a year ago.

Members of the MPC are closely monitoring events in the financial markets, which were awash yesterday with rumours of Japanese banks going bankrupt, hedge funds being liquidated and more profit warnings from big companies, including Nokia, the Finnish mobile phone giant.

Although the bank voted last week to keep rates on hold, Mr Plenderleith's speech to the National Association of Pension Funds investment conference reflects a vigorous debate within the MPC over the future course of UK rates. The governor, Sir Eddie George, said in Basle this week that there were hopeful signs that the US slowdown would not be as bad as originally feared. But other committee members believe that a painful recession in the world's biggest economy will have knock-on effects in the UK and warrants a cut in base rates of 0.5%.

At one point yesterday, the FTSE 100 index had lost 250 points, although it later recovered some of the ground to close 94.8 points lower at 5625.9. In a sustained fall, the FTSE has dropped almost 400 points in the last four trading sessions to its lowest level since the aftermath of the Asian financial crisis in late 1998.

Ministers believe that so far there has been little impact on the UK economy from falling share prices, which began in the spring of last year. However, one reason for the government's desire to hold the general election in May is concern that the economic outlook will have darkened by the autumn.

Mr Plenderleith said yesterday that there was a possibility that the bank could stoke up inflationary pressures by cutting interest rates too aggressively, but made it clear that the bigger risk was of a sharper slowdown than the bank was predicting.

"The downturn here [in the US] feeds the pessimism in Japan," one official said, "because of the negative effect on Japanese exports. And the faster Japan drops, the more it undermines confidence here."

With Japan already afflicted by both political and economic worries, there were reports yesterday that Daiwa, the country's seventh largest bank, was in serious financial trouble, raising concern that the entire Japanese banking sector was on the edge of a precipice. The rating agency Fitch warned that it might cut its already weak credit ratings for 19 Japanese banks.

A senior City source in London explained that a root of the problem for the Japanese banks was the level of the Nikkei, the Japanese equivalent of the FTSE 100. As the Nikkei tumbled, the level of the assets held by Japanese banks to protect them against insolvency also lost their value. Japanese banks are able to hold 45% of these assets as shares, many of which were valued when the Nikkei stood at 40,000. Yesterday it stood at 11,843.

fields.headline: Two surgeons under scrutiny
fields.trailText: Two gynaecologists at the same hospital are under investigation following complaints from up to 60 women alleging botched operations or insensitive and arrogant treatment.
fields.body:
Two gynaecologists at the same hospital are under investigation following complaints from up to 60 women alleging botched operations or insensitive and arrogant treatment.

One, Lennox Kane, is on sick leave with Parkinson's disease and the other, David Rosenberg, was suspended last Friday after months on special leave from Hemel Hempstead hospital, Hertfordshire.

The private Bupa hospital at Harpenden, where Mr Kane had treated patients since 1986, is also checking its records.

Allegations have been made about the treatment women received from the surgeons following local media coverage of complaints against Mr Kane, some dating back to long before he alerted hospital managers to his developing illness in late 1999. He was still carrying out major surgery last year.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is taking a keen interest and local Tories are demanding an independent inquiry into management at the hospitals.

The NHS has been sensitive about the behaviour of gynaecologists since the case of Rodney Ledward, struck off the medical register in 1998.

The West Herts NHS trust yesterday insisted the investigations into the records of the two doctors were separate issues. Complaints against Mr Kane, which go back eight years, include allegations of problem hysterectomy operations, scarring and rudeness.

One patient, Anastasia Insley, from St Albans, who had a private hysterectomy in September 1997, is taking legal action against Mr Kane and said she was about to have her third repair operation. "My life has been totally ruined."

The Medical Protection Society, which is representing Mr Kane, last night insisted he was "a caring and conscientious obstetrician and gynaecologist" who, on discovering he was suffering from Parkinson's, had informed the authorities and submitted himself to independent assessment. When his condition worsened "he voluntarily ceased all NHS work and has cooperated fully in inquiries".

The trust said that Mr Kane was on light duties by October. "At the beginning of this year, it was decided his condition had deteriorated so much, that he should go on sick leave."

A patient who wished to remain anonymous said she had been treated arrogantly and insensitively by Mr Rosenberg over the termination of her pregnancy three years ago. She alleged "a deap-seated old boys' club and complacent attitude" at Hemel Hempstead hospital.

fields.headline: Social workers deserve better
fields.trailText: It's official: the public does not like social workers, according to a new poll out today. Tell us something we don't already know.
fields.body:
It's official: the public does not like social workers, according to a new poll out today. Tell us something we don't already know.

Social workers have always been in a tricky situation. They are either seen as useless incompetents who can't stop abuse even when it is going on right in front of them, or they are no better than the Stasi, the old east German secret police. They may be wearing leather sandals instead of jackboots but they still storm around people's houses, take their kids away and generally wreck people's lives on the flimsiest of evidence.

Social workers have a huge public image problem. The government acknowledges this. It has now promised to launch a campaign to raise the profile of social care and social work. Locally-based initiatives have been promised that will work alongside a wider national campaign run by the Department of Health (DoH). The government is being tight-lipped about the finer details of the campaign, but at least it is a start.

Journalists are not interested in people doing their job well, especially if they are public servants. News, by its very nature, exaggerates the extraordinary and ignores the ordinary. When it comes to social workers, the only stories journalists are interested in involve tragedy, failure, conflict and incompetence.

Most people have never met a social worker, let alone experienced their work and professionalism first hand - though with their changing role in the care for the elderly this is changing.

According to the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) the public's attitude towards social workers rapidly improves if it has first-hand contact with them. Approval rating for social workers among this group has been recorded as high as 75%.

Social workers and the social care industry need to get out and about, visiting the shopping centres and high centres to explain directly to people what they do. Ian Johnston, director at the British Association of Social Workers, said: "Social workers do need to speak out more."

National Institute for Social Work director Daphne Statham agreed: "We need to improve our skills in communicating with the public. We need to be more transparent and explicit with the public. This means that we will have to become more accountable and open with the press and public. They need to understand why we make decisions."

A spokesman for the ADSS said the government campaign should try to break down stereotypes held by the public: "Social workers are not bearded, muesli eating, trendy twenty-year-olds. Indeed the opposite is the case. It's an ageing profession. Most are in their 40s."

Chris Genasi, chief executive of PR firm Weber Shandwick believes the social care industry needs to think about the type of people who represent them to the public and media. "You do not want someone who looks like a character out of the Young Ones. Image is important. They need to look like people who are in touch with the popular values in society."

He also says the profession should learn from charities such as Barnardo's, which is good at positioning itself as the champion of the people it seeks to protect.

This is no easy task. Social workers are waiting to see this new government campaign in action. But whatever shape it takes, all agree that the DoH should prevent government ministers attacking social workers.

Knee-jerk reactions dished out to the media by the government may be vote-catching but they only contribute to the problem. Mr Johnston summed up the feeling of most professional bodies in the social care industry: "Social workers are entitled to expect a better response from the government. It needs to acknowledge the dilemmas and difficulties of frontline workers and not give simplistic reactions of blame."

fields.headline: Evelyn Glennie
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
In her introductory note to Hit List, her series of three Evelyn Glennie-and-friends concerts, the percussionist emphasises that they are not intended for critics. No one seems to have told the press desk, and a few of us slipped in anyway. She also says that she doesn't like leaving concerts feeling that every piece on the programme was "nice". In that case, I hope she won't be too offended by this review.

Not that the musicians' technical ability was in question. But at times the nature of the concert seemed an excuse for ill-considered programming and self-indulgence. There had been little time for rehearsal - trombonist Christian Lindberg had just flown in that afternoon - and Glennie insisted that we should feel we were eavesdropping on an evening's jam session rather than sitting in judgment on a polished concert. But is the Wigmore Hall, memorably described by Vikram Seth as "the sacred shoe-box of chamber music", the right venue for this?

The most gratifying items proved to be those that were through-composed rather than improvised. The evening started off promisingly enough, Glennie being joined by trumpeter Hakan Hardenberger for Born to Beat Wild, a new piece by the Serbian composer Nebojsa Jovan Zivkovic. The items that followed, however, seemed conceived only to make the audience laugh. Tuba player Oren Marshall shuffled on as though attempting a Tommy Cooper impression; his solo on an instrument customised to produce rasps, squeaks and whistles rather than notes did nothing to convince us that the tuba isn't the joke instrument of the orchestra. Nor did Christian Lindberg's own rather underwhelming pieces leave much room for him to display his considerable musicianship.

Things looked up eventually, though, with Glennie joined by pianist Philip Smith for Dave Heath's 1997 work Darkness to Light, and Zivkovic's marimba solo Ilijas, a flowing yet distorted reflection of a folk dance.

Marshall's second improvisation, duetting with his own sampled and electronically manipulated phrases, was more rewarding. The combination of piano and cymbals in Roberto Sierra's piece Los Destellos de la Resonancia was especially felicitous. And Kit Bones and Hawk Hardon, by the Swedish composer Fredrik Hogberg, had Lindberg's and Hardenberger's alter egos slugging it out as if in a saloon shoot-out, duelling together, breaking off only to grunt in mock pain, growl choice Clint Eastwood one-liners or courteously turn the page.

There's a lot of good music around now involving percussion (Glennie should know - she commissioned much of it) but by being so staunchly eclectic, and relying on the goodwill of her audience, she risks losing her powers of discrimination.

webTitle: Theatre Review: The Comedy of Errors

fields.headline: The Comedy of Errors
fields.standfirst:
West Yorkshire Playhouse
Leeds
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
West Yorkshire Playhouse
Leeds
Rating: **
fields.body:
Most directors treat Shakespeare's story of twins and mistaken identity as if it were double trouble. They approach it as a mad romp, a 16th-century farce that must be jollied along with lots of extra funny business. Ian Brown takes a more sombre tack. It is a full half-hour before the first laughs really ring out. But while this measured approach is less irritating than full-frontal assaults on the funny bone such as the Royal Shakespeare Company's recent effort, Brown's production lacks a distinctive edge or a sense of balance between the comic and the nearly tragic.

Shakespeare's achievement was to write a serious comedy in which loss of identity, loss of kin, loss of heart and very nearly loss of life are suddenly, happily and credibly resolved. Madness is averted and order restored, but nobody will quite be the same again. The sense of something lost or missing remains in the final resolution.

Brown's production captures some of these easy transformations well, with Mic Pool's exquisite lighting creating a watery horizon that turns from rosy hues to midnight blue and that constantly reflects the emotional timbre of the play.

There are other good moments, too: Luciana suddenly realising that the man she believes to be her brother-in-law holds a strong attraction for her, and Adriana's final refusal to be placated by her erring husband, suggesting that the partnership has undergone a permanent sea change.

But in Brown's hands there is never quite enough at stake, never quite enough pain. You long for him to be more daring and create a much darker undercurrent that would bring out the shadows that may be lurking on the dazzling white, stylish 1950s Mediterranean set, where a small yacht bobs lazily by on the blue horizon. The failure to do so results in a production that troubles neither the funny bone nor the heart too much.

Some of the performances also lack inspiration, but there is a really winning one from Howard Saddler, whose Antipholus of Syracuse not only speaks the verse well but also conveys both confusion and wry amusement at his situation. When Adriana, mistaking him for her husband, insists that he come in for dinner he looks like a man who cannot believe his luck. A scene later, when her real husband fruitlessly attempts to gain access to the house, he looks like the cat that has got the cream.

But if West Yorkshire Playhouse is going to do Shakespeare, it has got to do it with more belief, confidence and passion than this. Brown's production isn't a disaster, it just has the dull gleam of cultural duty and it won't win either regional theatre or Shakespeare any fans.

 Until April 7. Box office: 0113-213 7700.

fields.headline: Majestic decline of Joseph Fiennes
fields.standfirst:
Edward II
Crucible Theatre
Sheffield
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Edward II
Crucible Theatre
Sheffield
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Marlowe's hectic chronicle has always been overshadowed by Richard II: although both plays deal with flawed, deposed kings, Shakespeare's shows vastly greater political insight. But the fascinating thing about Joseph Fiennes's performance in Michael Grandage's production is that it shows us a man, like Richard, educated through suffering. The lower Fiennes falls, the higher he rises spiritually.

At first, Fiennes's Edward is recklessly frivolous. He snogs his minion, Piers Gaveston, in front of his blustering barons and treats his wife, Isabella, with casual contempt, airily crying: "Let her droop and pine." His lack of political nous is also shown by the way he allows an aged Bishop to be ducked in the public drains, thereby stirring the church's vengeful wrath. But I've seen other actors, including Derek Jacobi and Ian McKellen, bring out Edward's myopic hedonism more effectively. And, at first, there is something a bit subfusc about Grandage's production: far from being adorned in "proud fantastic liveries", James D'Arcy's open-shirted Gaveston would raise few eyebrows at a gay disco, while the hectoring nobles look like motorway-maintenance men.

But both Fiennes and the production rise superbly to the spectacle of Edward's decline. Having capered dutifully, Fiennes acquires a specific gravity as his kingdom disintegrates after Gaveston's death. The key moment comes when, having donned a monkish habit, he cries, "Father, this life contemplative is heaven." It's as if he has suddenly awoken to the bliss of introspection. Fiennes's voice also takes on a dry, sardonic quality as, in anticipation of Richard, he mockingly hands over the crown. And, at the last, he becomes a muddied martyr as his imprisoned head, in a vicious echo of the earlier scene, is plunged into the castle sewage. Fiennes's true gift is for inwardness; and, through his graceful stealth, he elevates Marlowe's rhetorical homily into true tragedy.

Grandage's production, however, is much more than a one-man show. Fiennes's quality is matched by that of Lloyd Owen, a fast-rising classical actor, as a haughty, excellently spoken Mortimer. So avid is he for power and sex he becomes extremely testy when the cunnilingus he is about to perform on Jo McInnes's enthroned Isabella is needlessly interrupted. Jamie Sives as Lightborne, who kills the king with some peculiarly nasty pokerwork, is also a figure of sinister eroticism; as he straddles the prone king he becomes a strange echo of the more beneficently probing Gaveston.

Marlowe's play lacks tonal variety and political subtlety. But Grandage's production avoids boom and bust, is emblematically designed by Christopher Oram so that suspended blue banners tell us when we are in France, and is brilliantly lit by Tim Mitchell, with both diagonal illumination and vertical walls of light. The real triumph, however, lies in the production's discovery in Edward of a tragic hero who acquires majesty only by losing kingship.

 Until March 31. Box office: 0114-249 6000.

The key moment comes when, having donned a monkish habit, he cries, "Father, this life contemplative is heaven." It's as if he has suddenly awoken to the bliss of introspection. Fiennes's voice also takes on a dry, sardonic quality as, in anticipation of Richard, he mockingly hands over the crown. And, at the last, he becomes a muddied martyr as his imprisoned head, in a vicious echo of the earlier scene, is plunged into the castle sewage. Fiennes's true gift is for inwardness; and, through his graceful stealth, he elevates Marlowe's rhetorical homily into true tragedy. Grandage's production, however, is much more than a one-man show. Fiennes's quality is matched by that of Lloyd Owen, a fast-rising classical actor, as a haughty, excellently spoken Mortimer. So avid is he for power and sex he becomes extremely testy when the cunnilingus he is about to perform on Jo McInnes's enthroned Isabella is needlessly interrupted. Jamie Sives as Lightborne, who kills the king with some peculiarly nasty pokerwork, is also a figure of sinister eroticism; as he straddles the prone king he becomes a strange echo of the more beneficently probing Gaveston. Marlowe's play lacks tonal variety and political subtlety. But Grandage's production avoids boom and bust, is emblematically designed by Christopher Oram so that suspended blue banners tell us when we are in France, and is brilliantly lit by Tim Mitchell, with both diagonal illumination and vertical walls of light. The real triumph, however, lies in the production's discovery in Edward of a tragic hero who acquires majesty only by losing kingship.  Until March 31. Box office: 0114-249 6000.

webTitle: Theatre Review: Crazy Gary's Mobile Disco

fields.headline: Welsh theatre's blazing new talent
fields.standfirst:
Crazy Gary's Mobile Disco
Lyric Studio
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Crazy Gary's Mobile Disco
Lyric Studio
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The latest production from the consistently exciting Paines Plough does two things. It introduces a blazing new talent in Welsh writer Gary Owen, and it points up the limitations of the storytelling theatre that has become all the rage since the success of Conor McPherson's The Weir.

It sometimes seems that we are breeding a generation of playwrights who might once have tried their hand at the short story or novel, but who now think that end-to-end monologues constitute theatre. They can and do, but it is a partial theatre, even when they are as sparkily written and performed as they are here.

There is also a world of difference between the theatrical dynamic of the intercut monologue style of, for instance, John Corwin's Navy Pier or Richard Cameron's Can't Stand Up For Falling Down, and this trio of monologues. Despite the clever connections that emerge as the evening progresses, Owen's monologues have their theatrical interest limited by the fact that there is only ever one person on stage.

And this kind of storytelling can only sustain your interest for so long - two and a half hours makes you feel that you have been cornered by the pub bore. Someone needs to take a blue pencil to the script.

For all these cavils, it is bliss to come across a writer such as Owen, who is prepared to sink up to his neck in the cesspool of language. Owen writes like an angel with a foul mouth, capturing in his tale of lust, violence and revenge the hellhole that is a small Welsh town on a Saturday night.

In the final monologue from Russell, desperate to escape the town, it becomes clear how intimately connected these stories are; how bully boy Gary, who uses violence to get what he wants, and the mentally fragile Matthew Melody are linked to Russell in a damaging web of relationships. But it all falls brilliantly into place, and there is both fear and fun to be had from Gary's pursuit of "the perfect girl" or Matthew's problems with the DSS and a dead cat. David Rees Talbot as Gary, Steven Meo as Mathew and Richard Mylan as Russell tell you what it is like for them, and you believe every word.

 Until April 7. Box office: 020-8741 2311. Then tours to Hemel Hempstead, Leicester, Stamford, Brighton, Eastleigh and Scarborough.

webTitle: Gloom deepens as Yahoo! loses ad chief

fields.headline: Gloom deepens as Yahoo! loses ad chief
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Yahoo! yesterday fuelled speculation of a deepening boardroom split over its future direction when it lost another high-profile member of its management team.
fields.body:
Yahoo! yesterday fuelled speculation of a deepening boardroom split over its future direction when it lost another high-profile member of its management team.

The Silicon Valley-based company said that vice-president of business operations Anil Singh, the man widely credited with building its crucial advertising and marketing platform, was retiring "to spend more time with his family".

Mr Singh's departure is likely to increase the sense of crisis at the internet portal which last week surprised investors by announcing a profits warning and the resignation of its chief executive, Tim Koogle.

Advertising and marketing accounts for about 90% of revenues at Yahoo! and Mr Singh's departure is likely to be as keenly felt as the recent resignations of the heads at its European, Asian, South Korean and Canadian operations.

"Under [Mr Singh's] leadership the company built a top sales organisation from the ground up and pioneered the concept of online advertising," chief operating officer Jeff Mallett said.

Yahoo!, which was once valued at more than $100bn (£69bn), is now worth less than $10bn and has come to symbolise the boom and bust of the dot.com cycle.

Advertising revenues are now on the wane as advertisers, cautious of a slowing economy, rein in spending. Yahoo! has been unable to find other ways of making money out of its 185m users and for the first time since the fourth quarter of 1996 it is unlikely to turn a profit.

Merrill Lynch said it expected the online advertising market to decline 25% this year and for Yahoo's market share to drop from about 16% to 11% in 2001.

Analysts believe that it could now be forced to sell up to an older, established media company, in a move that would raise questions about the long-term survival of even the strongest of internet brands.

Viacom, Vivendi-Universal and Disney have all been mooted as possible buyers of Yahoo! but several of the portal's senior board members are thought to be against any takeover. Reports suggest they would prefer to introduce some form of subscription fee that would charge users for accessing content that is currently free.

AOL, Yahoo's biggest rival, last year stunned the financial markets by agreeing a "merger of equals" with Time Warner. That deal has given AOL access to a wide range of revenue streams that Yahoo! has little chance of emulating as a stand-alone business.

Mr Singh was Yahoo's 21st employee, joining in 1995 what was then a fledgling firm. He was the first sales executive but rose through the ranks and eventually became chief sales and marketing officer with responsibility for worldwide ad sales, corporate marketing, promotions, direct marketing and distribution.

Three months ago the company indicated that he would move from his day-to-day sales role to focus on strategy but in May he will leave the company altogether.

fields.headline: Mr Wonderful
fields.standfirst:
Coliseum Theatre
Oldham
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Coliseum Theatre
Oldham
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The mobile phone is becoming the curse of modern theatre. There is always someone in the audience who can't face being incommunicable for a couple of hours - and the situation gets worse when they start going off on stage as well. While it would be cruel to give anything away about James Robson's carefully planned denouement, there's something depressingly convenient about the fact that he's able to phone it in. The consequences for modern dramaturgy will be disastrous if we resort to the easy convention of the deus ex Nokia .

Ironically, this technological twist caps the most traditional of plays. Robson is one of the theatre's honest craftsmen, turning out solid, slightly irregular comedies like uncompromising but dependable pieces of furniture. What distinguishes them is the fact that human sweat, even pain, has gone into their making.

Mr Wonderful presents a laugh-a-minute demeanour that only fleetingly reveals glimpses of the shy play about quiet desperation behind it. It dissects the relationship between a single woman and her mother upstairs. Norma is beyond what one normally considers marriageable age, while Phoebe is simply beyond redemption. Ever the dutiful daughter, Norma endures regular dates which her mother picks out for her from the local paper's personal column - anything, it would seem, to keep the old bat happy.

Judith Barker presides over the evening in incorrigible fashion as Phoebe, a woman who lapses under the periodic belief that she is the Queen Mother, regally directing operations from the pink nylon swathes of her bed while delivering a masterclass in the art of emotional blackmail.

Judy Holt is impressive as Norma, a woman neurotically aware that she might be growing old without ever growing up; while Paul Gabriel, as her date Geoff, is N/S WGSOH - to reveal any more would spoil it. An honourable mention must also go to the protean talent of Rob Parry in portraying an assortment of booby prizes from the dating game. As an eloquently composed, touchingly performed comedy, Mr Wonderful is certainly recommendable.

If only playwrights would switch off their mobile phones before entering the auditorium.

 Until March 31. Box office: 0161-624 2829.
